HEADLINE: Now Arriving: Costliest Plans For Commuter Lines Since 1970

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER

 BODY:
ANYONE who sits idling in traffic on Interstate 95 has dreamed of a less painful way of getting to work.
Highways choked with traffic and a shortage of parking are pushing people to search for a better way to get from one place to another. Now, two railroad construction projects underway in the state are expected to keep commuter trains closer to their schedules as well as reducing travel time between Boston and New York. The improvements are meant to get people out of their cars, off the plane and onto the train. 
 The State Department of Transportation, which is undertaking the first project, plans to embark this year on the costliest rail construction on the New Haven Line since 1970, with $218 million in Federal and state funds budgeted for new or expanded railroad stations and maintenance shops, a new bridge, replacement of overhead wiring and track repair, said the department's director of rail operations, Richard P. Rathbun.
The department anticipates spending a $1 billion of Federal and state money over the next 10 years on rail improvements and equipment.
Passengers on the New Haven Line will welcome these changes in spite of the billion-dollar price tag, said Harry Harris, chairman of the Connecticut Metro-North New Haven Rail Commuter Council, made up of riders who volunteered to serve as commuter advocates. "I think commuters, by and large, would say, 'Bravo,' he said. "They like the service they are getting and don't want to see it deteriorate."
Mr. Rathbun said riders worried that the construction would cause a nightmare of delays and schedule changes should take heart. The railroad has undergone more construction in the last eight years than in the previous half century, he noted, and trains ran on schedule 96 to 97 percent of the time every year.
But Mr. Harris said that the department must do more to insure that commuters receive notice of delays and schedule changes. "We've been screaming for years about the fact that the transportation notification system is not really adequate," he said.
Mr. Harris said he anticipated that an increase in taxes would be needed to cover the cost of the state's 10-year rail capital program. "But it has to be done," he said. "There's no alternative."
Each day 90,000 trips are made on the New Haven Line over 260 miles of track between the New York-Connecticut border and New Haven, and over the Waterbury, Danbury and New Canaan branches.
 
Intrastate Lines Added
 The Merritt Parkway and Interstate 95 are choked with traffic, and the number of cars continues to grow, according to traffic surveys. Meanwhile, fares return about 65 percent of the cost of running the New Haven Line and over the last 10 years, with more businesses moving out of New York City and into the suburbs, the Department of Transportation has adjusted the train schedule to accommodate more people traveling to work within Connecticut, Mr. Rathbun said. In another effort to gain riders, the department started bus service from the Greenwich, Stamford and New Haven stations to major businesses in each area.
"We're trying to capture more people out of their cars and say, 'Transit is easy,' " Mr. Rathbun said. "Are we going to be able to put 8 to 10 more lanes on the Merritt Parkway and I-95? The answer is no. Is there excess capacity on the New Haven Line? Yes."
Meanwhile, Amtrak, the nation's intercity rail passenger carrier, is more than a year into its Northeast corridor improvement project; $900 million is to be spent on infrastructure and $450 million on new cars and locomotives. The entire project is designed to reduce travel time between New York and Boston to less than 3 hours for express trains and less than 3 hours and 40 minutes for conventional trains, according to a spokesman for Amtrak, David Carol. Currently express trains take about four hours, and conventional trains about 40 minutes longer.
People living near the railroad tracks who are concerned about the environmental effects of the construction oppose the plan. On the other hand, Mr. Carol said, the advantages extend beyond faster service to the prospects of additional jobs in the area and less congestion on highways and at regional airports.
The improvements will make Amtrak more competitive with air-shuttle service, Mr. Carol added. A round-trip rail ticket between New York and Boston costs as low as $79 and as high as $178 for first-class during a peak period, while the round-trip shuttle fare, according to airline representatives, costs anywhere from $138 to $238, depending on the time of travel.
Over the past year, Amtrak has added conference cars, furnished with fax machines and video equipment, where as many as eight people can meet. "It differentiates us from the airlines," Mr. Carol said. "This is not down time."
The new Amtrak service is not expected to compare with the out-of-pocket costs of traveling in a car, Mr. Carol said. "The way we get the motorist on the train is by saying they can relax, sleep, eat -- and there's no parking. And with so many people on I-95 in summer, our business picks up."
Amtrak will provide electrical power to the Northeast corridor's main line between New Haven and Boston -- the only stretch in the corridor without overhead electrical power. This will allow the use of high-speed electric locomotives that accelerate quickly around curves and end the need to change locomotives in New Haven, according to a report Mr. Carol wrote on the project. The rail line itself will be improved to permit higher speeds and a smoother ride.
"The challenge for our engineers will be to upgrade what is the curviest rail line in the Amtrak system (a train makes the equivalent of 12 full circles between New York and Boston) to permit train speeds of up to 150 miles an hour," the report says.
Congestion will be lessened at points in New Rochelle, Stamford and New Haven, which will make traveling faster for both Amtrak and Metro-North riders.
The issues raised by people along the shore in southeastern Connecticut involve the environment. More than 100 homes are within 50 feet of the tracks and these residents want to know more about the risks caused by emissions from power lines and substations providing electricity for the Northeast corridor. They also express fear that historical buildings, wetlands and wildlife near the railroad will be endangered, Mr. Carol said, adding that there is almost no opposition in communities served by commuter trains.
 
Grade Crossings an Issue
 The 15 grade crossings between New Haven and Boston pose a serious safety problem to drivers and pedestrains, according to Amtrak. Twelve are in Connecticut, many in environmentally sensitive areas, the project report says. Under the recently passed Amtrak Authorization and Development Act, the Federal Government must prepare a plan for elimination of these crossings. "This is a highly charged issue at the local level," Mr. Carol wrote in the report, "with most communities staunchly opposing any alternative" to what exists at grade crossings now.
Public hearings will be held after a draft of a Federal environmental impact report is released in late May. If the environmental study is approved, Amtrak will seek the permits needed from the State Department of Environmental Protection, Mr. Carol said. Construction of overhead electrical power lines is expected to begin next fall. Elimination of the grade crossings will depend on agreements between Amtrak and individual communities.
"Amtrak will be required to eliminate any significant impact, or construction will not be permitted to go forward," he added.
A market study done by the Coalition of Northeastern Governors in 1990 for Amtrak showed that three-hour service would attract up to 3 million more passengers a year, most of whom would otherwise have traveled by plane or car, Mr. Carol said. The time savings will also reduce congestion at regional airports, especially Logan International Airport in Boston.
Once completed, the improved transportation could inject $440 million and nearly 5,000 jobs annually into the New England economy, according to the study.
The Amtrak work may take as much as a year longer than the originally scheduled five years in order to keep current service running on time. The main problem will occur in commuter areas, Mr. Carol said.
The Northeast corridor project includes the following:
* Constructing the electrical power system, including electrical substations and overhead wiring.
* Raising about 35 of the nearly 300 bridges crossing the Northeast corridor between New Haven and Boston to accommodate the overhead wiring.
* Installing an underground signal system, allowing Amtrak to eliminate above-ground signal and communications wires.
* Eliminating old freight tracks and switches and installing continuous welded rail and concrete ties.
* Converting 65 bridges from open deck, where tracks are attached to steel beams, to ballasted deck, where tracks rest on a gravel-covered, solid deck.
* Constructing center-island platforms at the Stamford station to allow intercity and express commuter trains to stop along the center tracks rather than local tracks. This will reduce congestion and save time.
* Reorganizing the tracks through New Haven to allow faster speeds and save time.
Amtrak intends to purchase 26 sets of locomotives and cars for operation beginning in 1997. The cars will be built in the United States.
 
The Challenge of Updating Riders
 At this point, the most immediate problem with both plans seems to be communication. Mr. Rathbun said commuters learned of delays and schedule changes through notices placed on the trains, in newsletters and public meetings. Although Mr. Harris agreed that Metro-North communication had improved over the years, he said it still fell short. "One person makes all the announcements now for delays up and down Metro-North. On a really bad morning with problems on many lines, you have one guy running around like crazy."
At the same time, people in some shoreline communities said their questions about the Northeast corridor project remained unanswered.
"We want some form of face-to-face communication with the people running the N.E.C.I.P. We want to have some effect, even if it's only advisory, on what's being done to us," Theodore C. Rice, of West Mystic, wrote in a letter about the project.
Mr. Rice, who said he lived between 70 and 80 feet from the railroad, belongs to a group of homeowners and business owners along the shore in Connecticut and Rhode Island, who question Amtrak's claims concerning the number of additional riders the project will attract, the cost of the work and its economic benefits.
John McGee, president of the Mystic Chamber of Commerce, said he worried that Amtrak would make fewer stops at the Mystic station where tourists and merchants going to Boston used the station. But Mr. Carol said all stops in Connecticut would receive more service.
Putting the occasional inconvenience aside, Metro-North commuters said they were willing to pay to keep the relatively smooth service they now enjoy. "It's an unusual thing for the train to be delayed," said Leonard Schreiber, who has been riding from his home in Westport to his office in New York City for 30 years. "Thirty years ago, I used to drive in. But the traffic has become unbearable."

HEADLINE: Keeping Pressure On Unicef To Move

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

 BODY:
UNDAUNTED by reports that Unicef plans to remain in Manhattan, city officials in New Rochelle last week said they would continue their effort to convince the international agency to move to their city on Long Island Sound.
"We are in a very good position," Mayor Timothy C. Idoni insisted, adding, "We are continuing to lobby the ambassadors" who serve on the international organization's 41-member executive board. That board will make its final decision when it meets in New York in late April. 
 Ten days ago, James P. Grant, the Executive Director and Under Secretary General of Unicef, announced that he would recommend that the executive board accept a joint offer from the New York City Economic Development Corporation and the United Nations Development Corporation to extend Unicef's current lease at 3 United Nations Plaza in Manhattan until the year 2017.
"The children of the world will benefit from New Rochelle's action," Mr. Grant said, adding that the competitive proposal from New Rochelle had forced New York City to make an attractive counteroffer.
 
Eventual Purchase Planned
 That offer calls for a further extension of the Unicef lease to 2026, at which time the city and the United Nations Development Corporation would transfer ownership of the present headquarters building, known as Unicef House, to its current tenants if Unicef agrees to stay in Manhattan.
The offer includes a proposal to provide additional office space at an undisclosed nearby location. Monthly rents would be replaced by lease payments on both properties, money that would defray the cost of buying both buildings.
The recent growth of the United Nations Children's Fund and its inability to find additional office space at a reasonable rent in New York City for its 950 employees prompted 76 cities around the world to urge Unicef to move.
The bid from New Rochelle, which would reduce Unicef's yearly rent to $531,156 from $10 million and provide a 575,000-square-foot, designed-to-order, 20-story building, made it into the top four proposals under consideration, it was reported last fall.
 
Revitalization Hopes Raised
 The plan was the centerpiece of a proposal to revitalize the city's deteriorating downtown. A so-called United Nations Community District covering much of the central business area would include four additional office buildings, 360 units of market-rate housing, a 1,000-space parking garage and an extensive landscaping and beautification program.
The initial success of the New Rochelle plan generated tremendous excitement and spurred hope for revitalization in a city buffeted by a series of economic misfortunes.
Downtown areas have deteriorated following the departure of several major retailers, including Bloomingdale's and Macy's.
Last year, the New Rochelle City Council rejected a plan for a $1 billion residential development on Davids Island in Long Island Sound, a plan that was rejected following a decade of arguments over environmental considerations.
 
'No Proposal Can Touch Ours'
 Last week, Mayor Idoni said he was confident that New Rochelle's proposal will receive strong consideration from Unicef's executive board. "It would have been much better if our proposal had been recommended," the Mayor said, but he added:
"There's no proposal that can touch ours. No one can offer a site so close to the United Nations which saves the amount of money we are proposing."
If the New Rochelle proposal is eventually defeated, Mayor Idoni said, the city's efforts will not have been wasted. "There are lots of American and international corporations looking to consolidate their operations in a single location," the Mayor said.
"Thanks to Unicef's interest in us, our community and Westchester County have come together, and we have set up a network of cooperation that didn't exist before. Now, we are ready to do business."

HEADLINE: Scarsdale Agent Finds Publisher and $2 Million for a 1st Novel

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

 BODY:
THE scene is a luxurious hotel room overlooking the Caribbean Sea. A man in a dripping wet bathing suit is talking on the phone while the rug he is standing on gets soaked. He has been on the phone with clients for most of the day, but this is the conversation that counts: He has just clinched a deal that makes book-publishing history.
If a film were to be made about a literary agent, this would be a climactic moment. And although Aaron M. Priest, a self-effacing man, would probably not play himself in the film, he tells the story with a cinematic flourish: 
 How he submitted the 937-page manuscript of a writer's first novel to seven publishing houses and then went on vacation; how within two days of receiving the manuscript, three different publishers were on the phone with him in Barbados, bidding for rights to the book; how two days later, over that hot Barbados telephone line, the book was sold for $2 million.
Well, not quite. Mr. Priest and his wife, Arleen, residents of Scarsdale, had left the hotel room for a short time when executives of Little, Brown & Company and Warner Books called back to confirm their earlier combined $2 million offer for the American hardcover and paperback rights, respectively, to "The Day After Tomorrow," a first book by Allan Folsom. The 51-year-old author, who lives in Los Angeles, had previously written only for film and television.
 
Flying High Since Sale
 Because Mr. Priest was out, the callers phoned Molly Friedrich, the other book agent at the Aaron M. Priest Literary Agency in Manhattan, who was working at her home in Mount Kisco that day. Knowing that Mr. Priest had approved the figure in an earlier phone conversation, Ms. Friedrich accepted the offer, and that was how the story came to be published that Mr. Priest's highly regarded agency had made a record-breaking deal while he was off somewhere on a beach.
Despite that bit of rankling, Mr. Priest has been flying high since the sale three weeks ago, fielding telephone calls from foreign literary agents and discussing film deals with Mr. Folsom's movie agent.
Just back from his less than restful vacation, Mr. Priest played host recently to his newly famous author, whose book -- an international thriller with an intricate plot -- will not be published until April 1994. That morning, the two men had visited Warner Books and Little, Brown, and the tall, blond author had taped an interview for the "Today" show. Despite this television appearance, which would be viewed by millions, Mr. Folsom declined to have his picture taken in Mr. Priest's office.
 
'Not Always Like This'
 The sums of money involved were so large, and the struggling unpublished writers out there might be so furious, that it was safer for him not to be photographed, the author said. Mr. Priest described Mr. Folsom as a struggling writer himself before the sale.
During the author's visit, the Priest Agency's phone rang often, and the office staff darted to and fro. It is a small and friendly group, consisting of the two agents, an assistant for each of them and a part-time editor. In addition, Mrs. Priest works as the office bookkeeper.
Amid the happy chaos, Mr. Priest seemed almost apologetic. "Believe me, it is not always like this," said the agent, a bearded, trim-looking man with perpetual worry lines in his brow. He is a former book salesman who began his own agency 19 years ago in a tiny Manhattan office annex. His first clients were two Texans writing under pseudonyms, he said, followed shortly by the not-yet-famous Erma Bombeck.
Mr. Priest helped the humorist climb to the top of the best-seller list with books like "The Grass Is Always Greener Over the Septic Tank" and the current "When You Look Like Your Passport Photo, It's Time to Go Home," and she helped him build a reputation and a life style. The two are close, and she has visited his home in Scarsdale many times.
The agency now represents many best-selling authors, including Robert James Waller, whose novel "The Bridges of Madison County," has been on The New York Times hardcover fiction best-seller list for six months and was recently No. 1; Jane Smiley, who won the 1992 National Book Critics Circle Award and the Pulitzer Prize for "A Thousand Acres"; Terry McMillan, author of "Waiting to Exhale," and Sue Grafton, author of the alphabet mystery series.
Mr. Priest also handles movie rights and confided in a later telephone conversation that besides the Folsom sale, which had generated volcanic excitement for the agency, "something even hotter" was going on -- a movie auction for the rights to "Slow Waltz in Cedar Bend," a new Waller novel. Hence, all the telephone calls, the agent said, adding, "I have not seen a feeding frenzy like this in 19 years."
Mr. Folsom met Mr. Priest through the legendary literary agent Irving (Swifty) Lazar, who recommended the Manhattan agent some years ago for a short story Mr. Folsom wrote. Mr. Priest, the author recalled, encouraged him to keep writing. "He said, 'I can get you a career as a paperback writer,' " Mr. Folsom recalled. After another try at a novel, the author began work on "The Day After Tomorrow," which is a working title. "I wanted it to take eight or nine months," he said. "Instead, it took two years."
 
Contradicts Current Trends
 The agent accepted the book at once and told Mr. Folsom he could sell it for $50,000 to $250,000. Mr. Priest said that the $2 million figure for the work of an unknown author, especially in today's economy, was "very unusual."
"Publishing has been around for a few hundred years," he said, "and as best as we can tell, this is the highest sale of a first novel since Bantam Books paid more than a million for Sally Beauman's 'Destiny' in 1985." Warner Books and Little, Brown are subsidiaries of Time, which itself is a subsidiary of Time Warner.
The sale contradicts current book trends, Mr. Priest said, since today's market is usually "name-brand driven." The reason, he said, is that Mr. Folsom's novel has the one ingredient essential to a best seller: it is a book that people can't stop reading.
 
A Changing Market
 "It's as simple as that," the agent said. "It takes twists and turns, and they can't put it down. Whether it's a complicated love story, a thriller or a courtroom drama, a book has to be a page turner." He said Mr. Folsom's book, which involves an American doctor and a neo-Nazi conspiracy, was extremely well written and "superbly crafted."
He realized that the sale could go high when a very conservative company first called to offer $350,000, he said, and a second company called an hour later to offer $500,000. "A part of me finds the whole thing obscene," Mr. Priest said of the inflated prices. "Especially when I have a good writer that I can't get $25,000 for. But I don't make the rules."
The downside of his business, he said, is that while some authors are finding wild success, others represented by the agency are having painful slumps. "It's the nature of the market," Mr. Priest said. "The cold war ends. Spy thrillers are not what they used to be, and people don't want Western Americana anymore. It's hard to get decent advances for some authors I've represented for a long time."
Both he and Ms. Friedrich, who personally represents Terry McMillan, Jane Smiley and other authors, including her father, the writer and editor Otto Friedrich, say agents should not outshine their authors. "The stars of the agencies are always the writers," said Ms. Friedrich, a vivacious woman who has been with the agency since 1978. "It's an extremely dangerous and dishonest trend" to think otherwise, she said.
Mr. Priest shuns the limelight, preferring to spend time with his family, which includes two grown sons, and friends outside the business. He spends summers in a quiet part of Rhode Island, where, he said, he can talk tomatoes instead of books. He is a religious Jew who attends services regularly at Temple Israel Center in White Plains and takes weekly Talmud classes on Wednesday nights.
Other weeknights lately have found him in his office, he said, talking movie rights with such famous producers as Richard Zanuck of Zanuck Brown Productions in Beverly Hills, Calif.
Superstars, however, don't impress him, the agent said. "I don't care what their name is," said Mr. Priest. "That way, I don't get nervous making these deals."

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Will Clinton's Gamble Pay Off?

BYLINE: By Kenneth N. Gilpin

 BODY:
"If there's anything that this program is directed at, it's interest rates."
 Robert E. Rubin,
 chairman of President Clinton's
 National Economic Council.
 WALL STREET's bond traders can be forgiven for feeling more than a little bit used upon hearing Robert E. Rubin's comment about the importance of the credit markets to the Clinton Administration's economic plan. 
 After all, the program proposes to slap a huge income tax increase on the many well-to-do participants in the fixed-income markets, as well as the companies for which they work. Yet at the same time, the Administration is gambling that bond traders will ease some of the economic pain that higher taxes will doubtless cause by keeping interest rates low.
Nevertheless, many credit-market participants said the Administration's gamble on low rates is one that could well pay off.
"The thing that has struck me are the consistently low economic growth projections of 3 percent or less that are coming out of the White House and the Congressional Budget Office," said Stephen Slifer, an executive vice president at Lehman Brothers. "That says to me inflation going forward is not going to accelerate. That still leaves the potential for significant further declines in interest rates."
If inflation remains tame and the Clinton Administration is successful in cutting the Federal budget deficit, Mr. Slifer said, there is no reason why the inflation-adjusted rate of return on long-term bonds should not fall back to the 3 percent range it held for much of this century. Over the past decade, inflation-wary investors have demanded an average premium of 4 percent.
A number of factors are working in the Administration's favor, said William H. Gross, a managing director at the Pacific Investment Management Company, an investment firm in Newport Beach, Calif., with $42 billion under management. All will help to keep both short- and long-term interest rates low for the next 12 to 18 months, he said.
The Administration needs to keep short-term rates as low as possible for as long as possible, Mr. Gross said, and to do that it needs a friend at the Federal Reserve. Fortunately, Mr. Clinton's program to systematically attack the Federal deficit seems to have won over the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan.
"Even if inflation picks up a little bit, I don't sense Greenspan will move quickly" to counter it, Mr. Gross said, "because he is a gradualist" who realizes dealing with the deficit will take time.
Mr. Gross also expects the Treasury Department will try to coax down long-term rates by cutting the supply of 30-year bonds it auctions each quarter by 50 percent.
Interest rates are also falling in most countries in Europe, and probably will be soon in Germany, Europe's most important financial market. Falling European rates tend to enhance the attractiveness of rates on this side of the Atlantic.
All of these factors are enough to get Mr. Clinton's program in place, Mr. Gross said, but they are not necessarily enough to get it to work.
"For that he needs several years of low rates to get investment going," Mr. Gross said. "He needs to keep Alan Greenspan on board and he needs to have a little luck with inflation."
Despite the optimism, the bond market's reaction to the new Administration's promise has already been so extravagant that many in the financial community are questioning whether yields can fall further.
Since the election, yields on 30-year Treasury bonds have declined by some 65 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7 percent, the lowest level since the Government began regularly issuing the bellwether security in the late 1970's.
True, the Administration's proposals, if enacted, may stunt growth in 1994 and beyond. But some analysts said the bond market is overlooking the fact that the economy is humming along at about a 4 percent clip right now.
And Mr. Clinton has promised additional momentum in the form of $30 billion worth of short-term stimulus from spending on infrastructure and jobs programs.
"There is almost no negative sentiment in the bond market, and I find that disturbing because in my view the economy is very strong and getting stronger," said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear Stearns & Company. "I think the market is highly vulnerable."
Indeed, some analysts say that rates are so low now that other forms of assets are beginning to look attractive.
"As the price of financial assets goes higher and higher, real assets start looking better and better," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities Inc. "Rather than buy a bond, people may start looking at condominiums."
Congress is another stumbling block for both the Administration and the bond market.
Based on the recent past, it seems unlikely that all of the spending cuts asked by Mr. Clinton's Office of Management and Budget will pass muster on Capitol Hill, or that Congress will refrain from adding to his stimulus package, said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. And experience has shown that revenues from tax increases are never as large as projected.
"I would bet a lot of money right now we will not get the deficit cuts over the next four years the Administration is projecting," Mr. Resler said.
"If Congress adds to the stimulus, or chips away at spending cuts, then the market's elation will be short-lived."

HEADLINE: A Baby Bell Primed for the Big Fight

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: STERLING, Va.

 BODY:
IT looks like any other brick colonial home in this Washington suburb. But for Raymond W. Smith, chairman and chief executive of the Bell Atlantic Corporation, it is both a dream house and a castle to be defended.
Linked to the outside world by optical fibers, the unoccupied house was built recently by Bell Atlantic to show how a telephone company can deliver far more than talk. 
 In the kitchen, a person can point a clicker at a television screen to browse the specials at a local grocery store, order the week's food and specify a delivery time. In the family room, the television is wired to instantly retrieve movies from a remote electronic library. Upstairs, children can order video games or study topics like the Civil War by calling up documentaries.
Stripped to its essence, however, Mr. Smith's dream house is nothing less than a staging area in a multibillion-dollar battle to determine which companies will provide the next generation of communications for the American home. At stake is what Bell Atlantic and the nation's other local telephone companies see as their Holy Grail: an all-purpose network that will deliver a flood of new services and produce a flood of new revenues.
But for the first time in their history, the phone companies face tough competition and big risks, and their identities will be shaped by how they respond. Even though no one knows how badly customers will want this communications cornucopia, a convergence of technologies is driving cable television companies and other rivals to provide the same kind of highway to the home. The danger for the phone companies is that they will be left behind.
"They don't want to let the next stage of business growth pass them by," said Peter D. Shapiro, a senior consultant in telecommunications at Arthur D. Little Inc. in Cambridge, Mass. "It is more an aggressive move than a defensive move, but if they don't do it, they fear that the major cable suppliers will get in there and lock them out."
But if any company can hold its own in this high-tech, high-stakes free-for-all it is Bell Atlantic, one of the seven regional "Baby Bells" that emerged from the 1984 breakup of the American Telephone & Telegraph Company.
 
Going Head to Head
 Perhaps more than any of its siblings, Bell Atlantic under Mr. Smith has moved to meet competitors head on. Based in Philadelphia and operating from New Jersey through Virginia, it has upgraded its networks at a furious pace, rolled out dozens of new services -- like Caller ID and improved data communications to the home -- and begun a headlong plunge into the video marketplace. That includes big plans to make available to every home in New Jersey the same kinds of services available in its showcase house here.
"We will be a full-service company," Mr. Smith said in a recent interview. "We have three information instruments in the home -- the telephone, the television and the computer -- and they are all coming together to communicate on a full-service network. The time is not far off when you will be answering your television set and watching your telephone."
Just who will be transmitting the answers and images is far from clear, however. Indeed, the battle is part of a larger debate over efforts by the Clinton Administration to develop a nationwide "information superhighway." The Government is already financing a high-speed network that would link supercomputers, but it is also trying to make the highway accessible to the public. Vice President Gore has long argued that the phone companies should play a big role and he supports removing a key obstacle in their way: a Federal law that bars them from owning cable television systems in their areas.
The cable companies already operate networks that deliver dozens of television channels into more than 60 percent of the country's homes. Now they are boosting that capacity more than 10-fold, and are introducing so-called switching technology to offer two-way communications.
The cable companies are also making a big push into wireless "personal communication services" -- low-powered, inexpensive pocket phones and hand-held computers that communicate over the air. These services are expected to be authorized by the Government within two years.
Still other rivals are on the horizon. Long-distance companies are edging back into the local market by teaming up with cellular phone companies, as in the pending alliance between A.T.& T. and McCaw Cellular Communications, and many experts predict similar alliances with cable companies. And the cable companies have acquired many of the growing number of new fiber-optic carriers, which provide high-speed local communications services for big corporate customers.
Finally, local phone companies are beginning to turn on each other. Just two weeks ago, the Southwestern Bell Corporation said it would pay $650 million for two cable franchises outside Washington, in Bell Atlantic's backyard. Because Southwestern already owns a cellular telephone franchise in the Washington area, the deal immediately raised the specter that Southwestern would raid Bell Atlantic's territory by setting up a hybrid cable-telephone operation.
Bell Atlantic is hardly running scared. Under the 54-year-old Mr. Smith, who has been head of the company for four years, Bell Atlantic has been spending about $1.5 billion a year on high-capacity fiber optics and advanced switching technology. It is also investing heavily to link wireless communications to its regular phone network.
Alone among the Bells, it has committed itself to deploying a new digital compression technology that allows customers to receive television pictures over ordinary phone lines. Over the next two years, long before most neighborhoods have been re-wired with optical fiber, the company hopes to offer what amounts to an electronic video store.
 
Teams and Lawsuits
 And, by both confrontation and collaboration, it has begun a broad effort to compete directly with the cable industry. It recently announced that it will spend an extra $1.5 billion to run fiber optic lines to every neighborhood in New Jersey by 2010. In the last few months, it has teamed up with other companies in New Jersey to deliver cable TV programming over modernized phone lines in Morris County and Dover Township.
And in Virginia, Bell Atlantic recently filed a lawsuit seeking to overturn the Federal prohibition against cable ownership. In that suit, the company said it wants to build a fiber optic system in Alexandria that will offer hundreds of channels and two-way communications for every home.
Many industry analysts applaud Bell Atlantic, saying it exemplifies the kind of aggressive thinking phone companies need to adopt.
"They are attempting to seize their own destiny, at a time when they're under siege just the way A.T.& T. was under siege before the breakup," said Janice Obuchowski, who was head of the National Telecommunications and Information Administration under President Bush.
But others are skeptical. Some say cable companies have fundamental long-term advantages in the video marketplace, and that telephone technology is not yet up to par. Others think Bell Atlantic and some of its siblings are being fuzzy and too grandiose in their attempt to be all things to all people.
"My basic criticism of all seven regional Bell companies is none of them have really prioritized a long-term future," said Victor Schnee, president of Probe Research, a telecommunications consulting firm in Cedar Knolls, N.J. "They've got all their tentacles out, but they're so big and so sprawling that it's hard for them to come up with a succinct game plan."
 
Sizing Them Up
 Nonetheless, the Baby Bells are looking at the future in different ways. The Nynex Corporation, parent of New York Telephone, has been very reluctant to push into television services because its executives say they face too many regulatory burdens. Pacific Telesis, parent of Pacific Bell, is spinning off its high-growth, unregulated wireless business. And Southwestern Bell appears to be hedging its bets by modernizing its own network more slowly than some of its siblings while also buying outside companies.
Notwithstanding their strategic differences, the phone companies as a group offer some stark strengths and weaknesses when compared with the cable companies.
With combined annual revenues of $100 billion and enviably steady profits, the phone companies dwarf the $20 billion cable industry. And because cable companies have borrowed to the hilt to finance their growth, they have far less financial leverage than the phone industry.
Bell Atlantic, which serves one of the most densely populated and affluent regions of the country, is particularly well poised. Despite the slow economy, its earnings jumped 7.6 percent in 1992 to $1.3 billion, on revenues of $12.1 billion.
The phone companies also bring to the table powerful switching networks that can route millions of calls at a time and instantly link customers over a patchwork of independent long-distance carriers and wireless services if necessary. But the phone industry's Achilles' heel is the last mile of copper wire that reaches to individual homes and businesses and was installed for the simple purpose of handling ordinary phone calls.
 
One-Way Line
 By contrast, the cable industry has been more aggressive about employing new technology, wiring initially with coaxial cable rather than thin copper wires. By adding fiber optics to their main arteries, or "trunk lines," and by using new digital compression technologies, the cable companies are now gearing up to offer hundreds of channels. Cable systems have their own weakness: they were originally built only for one-way service to the home. But by adding switching technology, many systems hope to offer a free-wheeling mix of video entertainment, phone service and two-way data communications.
Tele-Communications Inc. of Denver, the nation's biggest cable company, recently announced plans to introduce technology that would give systems as many as 500 channels. Last month, Time Warner Inc. announced it was building a system in Orlando, Fla., to provide video on demand as well as two-way communications.
Indeed, some experts argue that the cable industry may have a big short-term cost advantage.
Bruce L. Egan, a research fellow at Columbia University's Institute for Tele-Information, recently estimated the amount of money needed by the cable and the telephone industries to upgrade their services.
To reach the modest goal of supplying both conventional cable television and ordinary phone service over the same line, telephone companies would have to spend about $1,500 per customer while cable firms could spend just $300, Mr. Egan said.
Building the most advanced system -- high-speed, two-way communications for both video and data -- could cost the same amount for each side, $1,500 or so per line.
Cable's "advantage is in the short run," said Mr. Egan. "But the short run may be what really matters."
 
A New Weapon
 Bell Atlantic executives question comparisons like this one, saying that the costs of new technology will almost certainly come down as modernization accelerates. Meanwhile, hoping to short-circuit the cable industry, the company is now rolling out an innovative interim technology called Asymmetrical Digital Subscriber Line, or A.D.S.L. Developed by Bellcore, a research consortium owned by the seven Bell companies, A.D.S.L. makes it possible for the first time to send TV images as good as those from a videocassette recorder over an ordinary copper wire.
The new technology can only send a single channel of television at one time. But the allure is that customers could eventually have a virtually limitless number of choices, because the telephone switching network would allow people to order up the programs from a huge computerized jukebox. As envisioned, customers could dial up not only the phone company's jukebox but those of other information providers.
"This battle will be fought in two dimensions," said Stuart C. Johnson, president of Bell Atlantic regional services. "One is convenience and the other is variety. Five hundred channels is still a broadcast technology. Our concept is to provide switched architecture, which will give our customers infinite variety."
But experts emphasize that the technology still has big limitations. Couch potatoes won't be able to flip through different channels, for example, because the system takes as long as five minutes to cue up a program.
An even bigger drawback is that the system can't transmit live programs, which rules out offering news or sport events. The problem is that the system must compress the video into a comparatively small stream of digital data, a process that takes time and must be done in advance.
Bell Atlantic executives say this is only a temporary hitch and that equipment available within two years will quadruple the amount of data that can be sent and enable them to handle live programming.
But others are skeptical about both the technology and the economics. "The basic business case isn't there," said Jerome Lucas, president of Tele-Strategies Inc., a consulting firm in McLean, Va. "The technology is too expensive to get costs down to the level of video rental stores," he argued, adding that cable companies can pull off similar feats at lower costs.
Meanwhile, Bell Atlantic has been pressing toward the ultimate solution: running optical fibers, which can carry almost unlimited amounts of information, into every neighborhood, as it hopes to do in New Jersey.
Bell Atlantic executives and many analysts say the most logical path is to team up with cable companies. But that may prove difficult. Mr. Shapiro, of Arthur D. Little, noted that cable companies now collaborate with each other on many fronts, especially in producing popular programs, and many may be reluctant to raid each other's markets with help from a telephone company. And many cable companies seem bent on upgrading their own networks rather than leasing lines from the phone industry.
Others contend that the public would be better off with fewer mergers of telephone and cable systems.
"There are a lot of people in both the telephone and the cable industries who think that one wire to the home is enough," said Philip J. Sirlin, vice president of Strategic Systems Group in Woodbury, Conn. "I'm not convinced of that."
For his part, Bell Atlantic's Mr. Smith remains exuberantly optimistic. Competition is inevitable, he said, but cable companies underestimate the challenge of providing failsafe two-way communications.
"They're going to find out it's very difficult to move into our territory, if we have anything to say about it," he said.
 
 
A BELL ATLANTIC SITCOM
 FOR most of this century, telephone companies did not have to sell anything. They were monopoly utilities, supplying a necessity of modern life.
But now the phone companies are trying to sell a growing list of frills, from Caller ID to a feature that blocks calls from particular numbers, and even the most hokey sales gimmicks are getting a try.
In the past year, the Bell Atlantic Corporation has used door-to-door salespeople from Amway; set up shop in Kmart stores; was part of a direct-mail effort with Domino's Pizza and touted its services as a long-term "headache remedy" in envelopes containing Tylenol tablets.
But all that is timid compared with "The Ringers," the world's first 30-minute television "infomercial" written as a situation comedy. The show chronicles the misadventures of what Bell Atlantic calls America's "funniest, phoniest" family.
Something of a blend between "Father Knows Best" and "Roseanne," the show features Ralph Ringer, a plumber, and his wife, Rhonda, and their two children, whose names also begin with an "R." Hilarity ensues when teen-age daughter Rachel gets tangled in boy problems, only to be rescued by new phone features like call-waiting. A toll-free number flashes at the end, so viewers can order services on the spot.
The infomercial was broadcast in November in Baltimore and company officials say the results were encouraging. More episodes will be produced this year for broadcast elsewhere in the company's service area.
 
A SHORT-TERM SOLUTION
 WHILE it will take decades and billions of dollars to build a high-speed fiber optic highway that links every home and business, Bell Atlantic has been the most aggressive of the seven Bell companies in offering a low-cost interim technology that dramatically boosts the power of ordinary phone lines.
Called the Integrated Services Digital Network, or I.S.D.N., the technology makes it possible to simultaneously send voice, video images and computer data over a conventional phone line. I.S.D.N. transforms all information into the ones and zeroes of computer code and speeds up data transmission by nearly 15-fold over today's fastest modems.
Using I.S.D.N., people in different locations can collaborate on a writing project, with each watching the work progress on a separate computer screen. And doctors can exchange high-resolution color images of a patient's body in less than a minute.
The appeal of I.S.D.N. is that it can be within the price-range of individuals and small businesses, but the phone companies vary widely in how fast they are making it available and how much they charge.
Bell Atlantic plans to offer I.S.D.N. on 87 percent of its lines by the end of 1994, the fastest deployment of any regional phone company. Convinced that widespread adoption will jumpstart the market for lucrative information services over phone lines, the company is charging a flat rate of $28 a month for each line -- a modest premium over regular phone service.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Can America Endure Kicking A Deficit Habit?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
ECONOMISTS tend to assume that every economic cycle will be like the previous ones. That is why nearly all were stunned by how long it took the economy to begin a significant recovery after the 1990-91 recession. And it is why President Clinton's economic plan is provoking talk of a new recession.
Underlying such talk is the fear that this economy is like a heroin addict, able to function only with a massive injection of fiscal stimulus. Addicts know that the drugs are likely to lead to death, but they crave the immediate high and fear the pain that would come from withdrawal symptoms. 
 That view of the economy gained strength after Washington's last effort to reduce its dependence on deficit spending. The 1990 budget deal was ill timed, coming just as the economy was weakening anyway, and it helped to produce the last recession. And the recession, in turn, caused tax receipts to plunge, making the deficit even worse.
"The thing that is wrong with the economic program is that is would scuttle the recovery," said Byron Wien, Morgan Stanley's chief U.S. strategist. He still thinks stocks will move higher, but that is based in part on the assumption that the Clinton program will not win approval. It would, he said, lower consumer spending and raise business costs "when the recovery is just getting off the ground."
There is, however, reason to hope that Mr. Wien may be wrong. Mr. Clinton's fiscal brew is of an unusual type. It takes money from the well off and distributes it, through higher spending on such things as Head Start and highway building, to groups lower on the economic scale.
Because the rich are more likely to invest a marginal dollar of income, while the poor are more likely to spend it, that can provide a short-term economic stimulus only partly offset by the broad-based, and regressive, energy tax. Add in the fact that the Clinton plan's deficit impact is quite mild in the first couple of years, and the fiscal pain begins to appear bearable.
Another positive is that markets are narrowing the spread between long-term and short-term interest rates. That cuts the profit banks can get from buying Government securities, and may encourage them to step up lending, thus providing some stimulus.
It is in later years that the economic impact grows more dubious. A strategy of bringing down the deficit is supposed to free up investment for private use, but tax-the-rich schemes reduce money available for investment. If those taxes really bite, the bond market's current euphoria might prove to be excessive.
Last week began with a stock market plunge, partly reflecting concern over the anti-business rhetoric that dominated the President's Monday night talk.
But prices then stabilized, in part because individual investors see declines as buying opportunities. It may be that traders assume Washington won't risk the pain, but it is also possible that they believe the economy can survive kicking the deficit habit.

HEADLINE: Japanese Computer Giants See the Danger of Following I.B.M.

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
JAPAN'S industrial policy for building a computer industry has been shaped for 30 years by the goal of catching up to the International Business Machines Corporation. Now, Japan's computer giants are in danger of following I.B.M. right over the cliff.
Fujitsu Ltd. and Hitachi Ltd. -- together with the Amdahl Corporation, a Fujitsu affiliate based in Sunnyvale, Calif. -- have emerged as the world's major competitors to I.B.M. in mainframe computers. Their machines are considered superior to those of Big Blue in some cases and they have been gaining market share, contributing to I.B.M.'s problems. 
 But like I.B.M., Fujitsu and Hitachi now find themselves overly dependent on the big expensive machines and proprietary operating systems software at a time when the industry is undergoing a massive shift toward smaller machines and industry standard software. The two trends, known in industry parlance as downsizing and open systems, have punctured the profitability of the computer industry.
The implications might seem obvious. Fujitsu in particular "is going to go through a gut-wrenching three to five years where its experience will mirror that of I.B.M.," predicted Steven W. Myers, electronics analyst at Jardine Fleming Securities in Tokyo.
But the Japanese companies have one thing that I.B.M. did not -- advance warning. The movement toward smaller machines and standard software that hit I.B.M. so heavily is only now getting started in the Japanese market, two or three years behind the American market. That gives them time to react.
The will to move was reinforced, of course, by I.B.M.'s recent announcement of a $5 billion loss for 1992 and the impending departure of John F. Akers, its chief executive.
"NATURALLY, I was very surprised because I thought Mr. Akers was taking a lot of measures to restructure I.B.M.," said Tadashi Sekizawa, Fujitsu's president. But then he added, "It reconfirmed to me that Fujitsu has to take quicker steps to cope with the changing markets."
Both Fujitsu and Hitachi are shifting toward smaller computers and toward machines that use Unix as the basic operating software. They are emphasizing their software and service businesses instead of hardware. And they are trimming costs here and there.
But they have not resorted to the restructurings and employee reductions of I.B.M. and say they don't think they will need to, prompting some analysts to question whether they are too complacent.
The situation is most dire for Fujitsu, the world's No. 2 computer company after I.B.M. That's because it derives more than 70 percent of its $26 billion in annual revenues from computers. (Most of the rest is split between telecommunications and semiconductors.)
Company officials say only about 40 percent of the computer revenues, or less than a third of overall corporate revenues, come from mainframes, but that covers only the machines themselves and the operating systems software. If disk drives and mainframe applications software and services are included, mainframes probably account for 55 percent of the company's total business, said Mr. Myers of Jardine Fleming.
By contrast, mainframes account for about 20 percent of I.B.M.'s revenues and less than 50 percent when mainframe-related businesses like large disk drives and maintenance are included, according to estimates by Annex Research in Phoenix.
Until the last year or so, Fujitsu seemed immune to the problems at I.B.M. While I.B.M.'s revenues have been stagnant, Fujitsu's sales, helped by the acquisition of Britain's ICL, have grown about 60 percent in five years.
But now the pain has started, added to by Japan's recession. In the six months ended last Sept. 30, Fujitsu reported a net loss of 19.2 billion yen ($161 million), its first net loss ever. A loss is also expected for the full year.
For Hitachi, which is still profitable, about 65 percent of computer revenues, and a higher percentage of profits, come from mainframes, including disk drives, software and service, said Shigemichi Matsuka, board director and general manager of Hitachi's computer division.
But computers account for only about $11 billion of Hitachi's roughly $60 billion in revenues and the company has many other businesses, like electric power-generating equipment.
The new trends are not all bad for the Japanese. The move toward industry standard operating systems like Unix, developed by A.T.&T. and now being purchased by Novell Inc., will liberate Fujitsu and Hitachi from having to try to clone I.B.M. systems. Now, it will be Unix into which everyone will have to hook.
If all computers can use the same basic software, customers will choose machines based on just the hardware quality and price, which could play into the hands of the Japanese manufacturers, which have been better in hardware than in software.
The problem is that hardware profits are collapsing. Mainframes are made using exotic chip technology at which Fujitsu and Hitachi excel. But now machines of equivalent power can be made at a fraction of the cost from collections of inexpensive microprocessors.
I.B.M., for all its woes, is the world's leading manufacturer of personal computers and does respectably well in work stations. But that still hasn't allowed it to develop enough business to carry the huge number of employees it needed for the mainframe business. Both Fujitsu and Hitachi are far less successful in personal computers and work stations than I.B.M.
ANOTHER big difference between I.B.M. and the Japanese is in employment practices. I.B.M. has drastically cut its workforce, mainly through voluntary retirements, from 400,000 in 1986 to 300,000 now and more to come.
The Japanese companies say they cannot lay off people or even do massive voluntary retirement programs. Nor, they say, do they need to. Mr. Matsuka of Hitachi said the computer division is overstaffed by only 10 percent, which can be reduced gradually. The company employs a total of 324,000 people, 53,000 in computers. And Fujitsu has not set any target for staff reductions, although it recently said it would cut 20 percent of its 2,000 administrative jobs in finance, accounting and personnel. It employs a 156,000 people, but will not disclose how many work in computers.
Avoiding large-scale voluntary resignations could allow Fujitsu and Hitachi to sidestep the huge losses being reported by I.B.M., which come more from special restructuring charges than from operating results. On the other hand, the inability to shed workers rapidly could depress profits of Fujitsu and Hitachi for years, although low profits are more acceptable in Japan, where a company's shares are owned mainly by friendly banks and affiliates.
In Japan, both stocks have languished of late. Fujitsu was selling last week for around 525 yen, down from 850 yen at the beginning of 1992. Hitachi was selling for about 680 yen, down from 946 at the beginning of 1992.
Hitachi, but not Fujitsu, also trades on the New York Stock Exchange in the form of American depository receipts. Last week, these shares were trading at under $57, , near their 52-week low of $55.50 and well below the 52-week high of $68.50.
MR. SEKIZAWA, who is 61, has been trying to light a fire at Fujitsu. The company formed a special open systems unit and another semi-independent personal business systems unit to spur development of small machines.
Fujitsu is also stressing software and service, which accounts for more than 30 percent of computer revenues. Japanese computer companies often write the accounting and inventory management and other programs used by their customers. In the past, however, this software was often practically given away, or included in the price of the machine. Now, the computer companies, in part pushed by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, are trying to charge separately.
Mr. Sekizawa is also pinning his hopes on multimedia, the combination of data, video and sound that could spur new uses of computers.
He envisions Fujitsu as a provider of all parts of the multimedia chain, from the handheld video-computers to the networks needed to transmit such information. Fujitsu, for instance, just won a contract from the Nynex Corporation for a new type of telephone switch that can handle video signals as well as voices.
In consumer multimedia equipment, Fujitsu was a pioneer with its FM Towns computer, which can display images and play music from CD-ROM compact disks. Having had moderate success with FM Towns, the company last week introduced a portable CD-ROM player that attaches to a television set. In the next few months, Fujitsu is expected to introduce an electronic book -- a tiny device consisting mostly of a liquid crystal display screen that will show pages of books stored on memory chip cards. To enhance its move into multimedia, Fujitsu has finally entered the business of making sophisticated liquid crystal display screens.
Fujitsu also is finding support from various acquisitions and alliances. Because it became a manufacturer of Sun Microsystems Inc.'s Sparc microprocessor, Fujitsu found itself in the fortunate position of being able to resell Sun work stations in Japan.
Indeed, Fujitsu's partners, Amdahl and ICL of Britain, are also working on products based on the Sparc microprocessor and are trying to share more efforts to cut costs.
Another important piece of that strategy is the 44 percent stake Fujitsu owns in a Silicon Valley startup named Hal Computer Systems, for which it paid $40 million in 1991. As with Amdahl, Hal is headed by a former star designer at I.B.M., in this case R. Andrew Heller, who led the development of I.B.M. work stations. His new company is developing super-powerful Sparc microprocesors and a whole family of computers that will use those chips.
Mr. Heller dismisses criticisms that Fujitsu executives are too complacent. But the changes in the business are so great it might be impossible to adjust without great pain.
"They know it's going to happen," he said. "I don't think they know how to react to it."
 
 
IN THE BEGINNING . . .
 The seeds of the current situation in the Japanese computer industry date back to the late 1950's, when Japan's Government began an effort to build the industry. As I.B.M. came to dominate the world market, the powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry decided that compatibility with the giant was the best policy. In the early 70's, it divided Japan's six largest industrial electronics companies into three teams to design different-sized computers. Fujitsu and Hitachi were teamed to develop the largest ones.
In the ensuing decades, Fujitsu and Hitachi have waged a sometimes brutal war against Big Blue. Hitachi in 1982 was caught in a Federal Bureau of Investigation sting operation trying to buy I.B.M. trade secrets. In a separate case, Fujitsu, after a lengthy arbitration, was told to pay more than $800 million for the right to examine I.B.M. mainframe software for a period of 10 years.
In the 1970's, Fujitsu bankrolled Gene Amdahl, a former star mainframe designer at I.B.M., as he started the Amdahl Corporation, which achieved the first success with I.B.M.-compatible mainframes. In 1990, Fujitsu paid $1.3 billion for majority ownership of ICL, Britain's leading computer company, in an effort to expand its operations globally.
I.B.M., in turn, began to regard the Japanese as its biggest threats. But it turned out that machines based on cheap microprocessors were the biggest enemies of all. While MITI's strategy might have been right at first, the attention to fighting I.B.M. no doubt prevented Fujitsu and Hitachi from reacting sooner to the emergence of smaller machines.

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Bristol, Pa.;
Redeveloping The Old Mill

BYLINE: By David J. Wallace

 BODY:
THE redevelopment of a four-building mill complex has given its main tenant a new lease on life and provided a new source of office, warehouse and distribution space for this former industrial town.
Over the last 10 years, Fred Baumgarten has renovated portions of the Grundy Industrial Complex, a 335,000-square-foot former woolen mill. He bought the four buildings for $295,000 in 1982 rather than relocate his Majestic Mills, which has rented 120,000 square feet since the 1960's. The company processes fabrics, packaging them for clothing manufacturers. 
 Work is under way to prepare 8,500 square feet for a furniture warehouse, said Joseph Scott, the property's manager. When it is occupied, there will be about 60,000 square feet of space that could be made quickly available, he said. The rest of the space, he said, is being used for storage by Majestic Mills.
Although renovations of the remaining space are done on an as-needed basis, Mr. Baumgarten said he had spent "in the significant six figures" renovating the complex, whose first structure was built in 1876 to produce woolen fabrics.
The building is on the National Register of Historic Places, but Mr. Baumgarten said he had not sought Federal tax credits for the 12-acre project, at the corner of Canal and Jefferson Streets.
After its career as a textile mill, part of the complex was used to warehouse tea in a storehouse built in 1910. These days the complex, about a half-hour drive northeast of Philadelphia, has such tenants as a parts supplier for Army jeeps, a computer-assisted design firm that produces robots and several storage users.
"These buildings are structurally obsolete," Mr. Baumgarten said. "My hope is to make them relevant to the 21st century.
The interconnected buildings surround a courtyard. Atop the storehouse is the complex's trademark -- a four-sided lighted clocktower topped by a flagpole.
Demand for space has been slow because of competition, Mr. Baumgarten said. The recession has forced down rents for comparable space to $4 or $5 a square foot, even at several industrial parks closer to the Pennsylvania Turnpike and Interstate 95. Grundy is several miles from the highways within the narrow streets of Bristol Borough.
"It's a chameleon, it's whatever you want it to be," said Steve Cooper, a broker with Cushman & Wakefield, which represents a nearby property. "Tenants are still making good deals so there's downward pressure on rents."
Founded in 1681, Bristol became an early industrial center because of its canal link in 1800 to Trenton and northeastern Pennsylvania and a railroad connection by the 1830's. The borough's Victorian-era homes draw tourists to scenic spots along the Delaware River.

HEADLINE: Measuring Schools And Dollars

 BODY:
"Comparing School Spending and Taxes" [Jan. 31] makes the unfortunate and all-too-common error of confusing property-tax rates with property taxes paid. High property taxes are generated by a low tax rate on highly assessed property as surely as by a high tax rate on more reasonably assessed property. The heterogeneity that marks other aspects of Long Island school districts is also manifested in real-property assessment.
Another misleading assumption of the article is that dollars-spent-per-child is an automatic indicator of educational quality. Based on New York State Education Department statistics measuring student performance by such instruments as standardized test scores and numbers of Regents-accredited high school diplomas earned by local graduates, denoting successful completion of an academically rigorous curriculum, the high price paid by the taxpayers of the Oyster Bay school district does not translate into superior education for its students. Instead, it supports a highly paid, excessively numerous administrative and teaching staff most notable for its insistence that mediocre student achievement is really "excellence." 
 I find it most interesting that those who are reported to find school consolidation "unworkable" are the very people in whose economic or other personal interest it is to maintain an archaic, expensive, wasteful, unconscionable multiplicity of local school districts, which number 56 in Nassau County alone.
 
DORIS MEYER
The writer is on the executive board of the Oyster Bay-East Norwich Com mitte for Accountability and Responsibility in Education.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Bold Plan Sets Social Policy His Way

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR all its sweep and potential economic impact, the budget proposal that President Clinton delivered last week is far more than an ambitious plan to recharge the economy and reduce the deficit. It is a blueprint for one of the most profound changes in social policy in this century.
The budget is the policy, as the architects of Ronald Reagan's military buildup in the 1980's well knew. Mr. Clinton's budget would, in effect, transfer a great share of power from that bureaucracy, the followers of former Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, to the disciples of Marian Wright Edelman, the crusader for children, who has long been a source of inspiration for Hillary and Bill Clinton. 
 This is no hidden agenda. The new President titled his budget "A Vision of Change for America." What that means, in short, is an end to 12 years of laissez-faire social policy.
One must scrutinize Mr. Clinton's tax and spending proposals to see how pervasive the social changes might be. National income, and political control over it, would be redistributed. Many of the proposals would aid members of minority groups and the poor, even though Mr. Clinton, for political reasons, chose to emphasize potential benefits for the middle class.
In the budget, Mr. Clinton portrays Government as a powerful engine of social change, a catalyst for economic growth, an incubator for new technology, a partner of private industry.
And more is on the way. Much more. In 10 weeks, Mr. Clinton will publish his plan to overhaul one-seventh of the nation's economy: the vast health-care industry, now growing by $100 billion a year.
The evidence of change was on every page of Mr. Clinton's budget and his economic program. He said his proposals were intended to combat an "alarming rise in inequality" -- a trend repeatedly denied or minimized by Reagan and Bush Administration officials.
After a decade in which Republican Presidents proclaimed their desire to get Government off the backs of the people, Mr. Clinton said it was time for the Government to get up off its back and put people to work. Thus, he would increase the number enrolled in the Job Corps to 104,000, from the current 70,000.
"In America," Mr. Clinton said, "no one who works should have to raise a family in poverty." So he proposed a huge expansion of the Federal tax credit for low-income working families with children, at a cost to the Treasury of $27 billion over five years. In the same period, he asks an extra $13.8 billion for Head Start and $3.6 billion on the Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children.
Mr. Clinton's budget puts into practice the philosophy of Mrs. Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund. In lectures at Harvard in 1986, referring to "the greedy military weasel," she said the money spent on Star Wars research in one year could lift 2.5 million children out of poverty. Seven years later, Mr. Clinton proposes slashing Star Wars funds.
Mr. Clinton also used Mrs. Edelman's strategy to build a multiracial coalition. He did not talk much about minority groups or civil rights last week. But blacks would probably benefit from many of his proposals because their poverty rate is three times that of whites.
Ronald Reagan often seemed to suspect that many dollars spent by Government agencies other than the Pentagon were wasted. But Mr. Clinton declared that "every dollar of Federal spending, worthy or unworthy, is someone's income." Accordingly, he says the Federal budget deficit must be reduced -- but not too quickly, lest recipients of Federal largess cut their spending.
There is little danger of that, however.
On Wednesday, the White House said the President's plan would reduce the deficit by $493 billion over four years. Detailed budget documents issued a day later showed the savings would be $325 billion. This was no bookkeeping error. Nor was it a deliberate attempt at misrepresentation by Mr. Clinton or his budget director, Leon E. Panetta.
Rather, the discrepancy shows their fragmented view of the budget, their failure to integrate their attack on the deficit with their proposals to increase spending on children, highways, the environment and job training.
The gap between the two numbers is the difference between gross savings and net savings. One-third of the savings initially claimed by Mr. Clinton would be given away in new tax breaks or spent in programs to stimulate the economy or "invest" in America's future. He simply omitted those costs from his initial calculations. The brutal discipline of the Federal budget recognizes no distinctions between worthy and unworthy spending. If the Government spends $10 on vaccine, the outlay increases the deficit now, and the budget takes no account of what might be saved later.
Mr. Clinton's belief in Government's helping hand can be seen in his proposals to aid workers and industries hurt by cuts in Pentagon spending. He wants the Economic Development Administration at the Commerce Department to help "communities hurt by defense reductions." By contrast, Mr. Reagan had proposed to abolish the economic development agency.
Mr. Reagan and Mr. Bush scorned proposals for Government to help high-tech industries, as governments do in other countries. But Mr. Clinton would invest Federal money in nationwide data networks, high-performance computers, fiber-optic communications and magnetic levitation trains.
John F. Cogan, deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget under Mr. Reagan, said: "The spending side of Clinton's budget has a strong political component. It is weighted toward big-city programs like mass transit, summer youth jobs and community development grants." The United States Conference of Mayors, which rarely had a good word to say about Mr. Reagan or Mr. Bush, hailed the Clinton budget, saying it would provide billions of dollars for public works.
Within hours after the President delivered his plan to Congress, he and his Cabinet fanned out across the country like traveling salesmen to promote it. His efforts to cut the Federal budget deficit won praise from Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
As a recipe for revolution, Mr. Clinton's budget suffers by comparison with Mr. Reagan's "Program for Economic Recovery," issued Feb. 18, 1981. Mr. Reagan's proposals were far more numerous and specific, and they generated the political momentum that enabled him to drive his program through a skeptical Congress.
Mr. Clinton has strong allies on Capitol Hill. But with moderate and conservative Democrats skittish about many of his proposals, it is not clear whether his revolution will come off entirely as planned.
