HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
For U.S., Aid To Terrorists Is Hard To Define

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE very idea that terrorist operations could be orchestrated from within the United States is alien to an American sensibility that regards terrorism as a thankfully foreign phenomenon.
Yet that is the image some Israeli officials are now seeking to imprint in the American consciousness. Sharing findings gained from the interrogation of an Arab-American prisoner, they asserted last week that command and control over Hamas, the Palestinian terrorist group, is exercised not from the West Bank or Teheran but from a headquarters in suburban Virginia. 
 And Israel is far from the only foreign government pointing a finger at operations on American soil. Egypt has accused Islamic fundamentalists in New Jersey of encouraging terrorist attacks by others along the Nile. Britain protests the United States' willingness to tolerate Boston barroom collections for the "charitable causes" of the Irish Republican Army.
Indeed, experts say terrorists have deeper American roots than is commonly recognized; residents of this country have long given at least aid and comfort to terrorist causes. But the indirectness of such efforts has made it difficult for authorities to intervene. For those who have studied the phenomenon, the latest assertions only add to years of frustration about the difficulty of distinguishing ferment from violence.
If this latest round of blamesmanship causes one person to look askance at another, however, that would be overreaction. Only a very small number of dissidents here lend any kind of a hand to foreign causes, according to law-enforcement officials who worry that Arab-Americans and members of other ethnic groups might become targets of unfounded fears.
Of course, the United States has had its own vivid encounters with terrorism, even at home. In 1954, Puerto Rican nationalists shot and wounded five members of Congress on the floor of the House of Representatives. Croatian terrorists carried out attacks during the 1960's and 1970's on Yugoslav immigrants; so too did Armenians against Turks residing in America. A 1988 bombing plot by a member of the Japanese Red Army was interrupted only when the man was found to be carrying the explosives along the New Jersey Turnpike.
But the latest suspicions have to do with a different kind of conduct. Rather than aiming attacks at American soil, those now under scrutiny are alleged to be using the United States as refuge to plot operations abroad. Just as Cubans in Miami once helped to mastermind terrorist campaigns in their homeland, some Arab-Americans are giving support and direction to attacks by Hamas's military wing against Israeli civilians, the Israeli Government says. But experts like Bruce Hoffman of the Rand Corporation say that it is rare that American-based sympathizers of such groups have crossed the line from aid to control.
"Any number of terrorist groups over the years have had extensive fund-raising and some recruitment in the United States," Mr. Hoffman said in an interview last week. "But if it were true that these supporters were providing direct leadership, that would really be a departure from the norm."
United States officials have expressed a similar skepticism. Although the Federal Bureau of Investigation is looking into the allegations about Hamas's network of American support, the officials say the structure appears responsible principally for raising money, mostly for the organization's political and social welfare activities. They say that the military wing of Hamas is almost certainly still controlled from within the occupied West Bank. That contrasts with the Israelis' contention that Palestinian-Americans living in the United States actually play crucial roles in coordinating the organization's political and military operations.
A similar dispute exists between the United States and Egypt over the roles played by Islamic fundamentalists who meet periodically in New Jersey motels with Omar Abdel-Rahman, a militant leader. Egyptian officials have complained that tape recordings of the sessions are shared with similar groups in Cairo. But American authorities say the recordings offer encouragement, not direction, for the violent challenges to Egyptian authority.
Yet no one pretends that such technicalities disprove the link between these groups and terrorism. As Britain has long protested, even contributions to the "charitable activities" of the Irish Northern Aid Committee frees up other funds used by the I.R.A. for more violent endeavors. To terrorism experts like Brian Jenkins of Kroll and Associates, a security consulting firm, such distinctions are little more than gradations.
"The supporters may say that donations are going to support widows and orphans," Mr. Jenkins said. "Money is fungible, though, and it's pretty plain that this is financial support for terrorism."
But United States law embraces such fine distinctions, and American authorities say that is what limits their ability to satisfy the foreign complaints. It is not enough to show that an individual supports or is affiliated with the group; the Constitution protects First Amendment rights to free speech and association. To win prosecution, authorities must prove a link between a suspect and an act of terrorist crime.
Depending on the outcome of a trial now under way in Los Angeles, the Government may gain further latitude. Federal prosecutors are seeking to deport two Palestinians accused of raising money and otherwise giving assistance to the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a militant wing of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The case will test a 1990 immigration law authorizing the expulsion of non-citizens who have given "material support" for a terrorist organization.
Civil rights advocates protest that the widened authority would deprive immigrants of their First Amendment rights. But law enforcement officials frustrated by current constraints say a favorable ruling would give them an important new tool. "We're the only nation in the world that can't uninvite people to our shores even when we find that they're engaged in supporting terrorist groups involved in attacks on Americans or American allies," said Oliver Revell, who until recently led the F.B.I.'s investigations division.
But some experts most concerned about the sustenance given to terrorism say the answer may require a shift not in power but perspective. "What I see out of it all is a negligent United States," said Robert Kupperman, a adviser to the Center for Strategic and International Studies. "We get fixated on every incident that takes place abroad. But I don't think we're doing what we need in monitoring terrorist activities in the United States."

HEADLINE: Wanted: Those High-Tech Jobs for Retrained Workers

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN

DATELINE: BAL HARBOUR, Fla.

 BODY:
WHAT American workers need are a lot more high-wage, high-skilled "quality" jobs, as President Clinton called them last week. Find those jobs and train people to do them, and the Government, the schools, industry and the labor unions will build a prosperous middle class and the mighty American economy of the 21st century.
"We need an aggressive attempt to create the high-tech jobs of the future," the President said. That was just a thematic salvo to the jobs plan the Administration will eventually put together. But the planners might have to do some heavy thinking about one dimension: just what are those high-tech jobs? 
 "We're raising the same question," says Morton Bahr, president of the communications workers union that represents most A.T.& T. employees. "What jobs are you going to train people for? We don't know what the answer is." Does Ron Carey, president of the teamsters union know? "No," he says. "I would not know how that comes about."
This could be an urgent question for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. leaders who held their winter meeting in Bal Harbour last week and for the politicians who came to pay their respects, including the new Labor Secretary, Robert B. Reich. Giant companies like General Motors, I.B.M., United Technologies, Boeing, Eastman Kodak and Sears, Roebuck are still shedding workers, many of them high-wage, highly skilled machinists, tool makers, sheet metal workers, accountants, supervisors and systems engineers.
With G.M. and I.B.M. boarding up factories, many of those jobs will never return. And in this economic recovery, unlike those of the past, many other businesses' skilled jobs that succumbed in the recession are only trickling back. So where will the cast-offs go? Where will their sons and daughters go in the 21st century when they set about looking for the kinds of jobs their parents had?
A good job pays at least "$40,000 a year with decent benefits," says Richard L. Trumka, president of the United Mine Workers. But what many skilled workers are getting now are low-wage, low-skilled, lousy jobs. In the view of people at the unions' executive council meeting here, the middle class that emerged in the bustling economy of the 1950's and 1960's is sliding into the ranks of the working poor. The skilled, two-worker, two-job family with generous health and pension benefits is becoming the unskilled, two-worker, two, three and four part-time job family without benefits.
If things keep going as they are now, Secretary Reich has been saying for some time, the work force will keep dividing into an educated elite, with brainy and computer-connected lawyers, investment bankers and consultants on one side; and vastly more people, without college degrees, toiling at the only other jobs -- ringing up groceries, cleaning office buildings and making deliveries.
Unlike many of the union presidents, Mr. Reich also believes he knows where the high-wage, high-skilled jobs will be, provided business and labor join the Clinton Administration in creating them. "What we lack," he said in an interview here, "is a layer of technicians -- technical workers who are earning good wages and who could comprise the new middle class.
"Example," Mr. Reich said: "In this country we have a dwindling number of computer-aided machine operators. Why? Because robots are gradually taking over. But in Europe, there's a growing number of computer-aided machine programmers. People who know how to program the machines and make them work ever more flexibly in the production systems there."
Another example, he said, is engineering. An American engineer is one of the elite who usually needs a graduate degree to go to work. But he said many engineering tasks require less preparation, just two or three years after high school. Europeans can get that training, he said, and Americans cannot.
"The global economy is producing the capacity for a vast number of technician jobs that are semi-skilled, both in the manufacturing sector and the service sector," he said. "But the technician class earning middle-class wages is not developing here." In the Reich view, build an American labor force on workers like this, and employers, including foreign companies, will set up American factories and offices to hire them.
Mr. Reich's prescription jibes with what a few unions are already doing. They are collaborating with companies like A.T.&T., Xerox and several steel companies to create what they call factories of the future. Workers help design their own jobs. They learn a variety of skills, they supervise themselves and they join with management in devising ways to make what they make better and faster and cheaper.
A problem arises, however. As worker-technicians work more efficiently, they raise their productivity. That means a business produces more and more semiconductors, loaves of bread, refrigerators or banking transactions with the same crew of workers -- or the same number of goods and services with fewer workers.
For these industries to employ tens of millions of workers, someone has to buy their goods. The hope is that consumers all over the globe will buy them, making America the world's department store. This is not a uniquely American insight, however. Other countries, notably Germany and Japan, have similar schemes.
So far at least, the hyperproductive American businesses that are conquering world markets are far too few to stop the decline of the old high-wage, high-skilled jobs. Sometimes, too, a factory of the future can get in just as much trouble as a factory of the past when no one wants its goods.
 
Workers Learn Computer Design
 Peter S. diCicco, a top official of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and previously the New England director for the electronic and electrical workers union, collaborated with General Electric in creating such a factory in Lynn, Mass.
Highly productive, highly skilled workers there build the rotating parts for jet engines. "The workers learn computer design," he said, "production routing, the capacity of various machines -- a whole variety of different skills."
Alas, the loss-ridden airlines have stopped ordering airplanes, putting jobs at the Lynn plant, as at Boeing's plants in Seattle and Wichita, in jeopardy. And where will those workers go for other high-wage, high-skilled jobs? Mr. diCicco said he did not know.
Maybe this assumption that so many people have about an emerging abundance of high-wage, high-skilled jobs itself needs retooling. Rudolph Oswald, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s chief economist, knows of another way to at least deal with the wage part. "Better income distribution," he said. In the 1980's executive salaries soared, while workers' wages actually declined a bit.
Owen F. Bieber, president of the United Automobile Workers, says part of the strategy should entail saving old high-wage, high-skilled jobs with tougher trade relations with foreigners, like the Japanese car makers. "Our good-paying industrial jobs have been leaving faster than you can bring on board new, good, high-paying jobs."
 
A Shorter German Workday
 Lynn Williams, president of the United Steelworkers of America, sees some good jobs emerging in the factories of the future but probably not enough if everyone works 40 hours a week. "One piece of this has to be shorter hours," Mr. Williams said. He said German industry produces half as much steel as American industry but with the same number of workers. "We've been going the other way."
Mr. Reich winces at the thought of shorter hours. He says there should be a full day's work for everyone. New industries like desktop computers and Federal Express keep coming and old ones, like adding machines and the Pony Express, keep going. The new ones often take on more workers than the old.
Maybe so, but the labor leaders wonder if that's still true.
Mr. Bahr and A.T.&T. have been working together training high-wage, highly skilled workers for their factories of the future. But he has not seen any additional jobs. "I hope we live long enough to see the job creation that's supposed to come with it," he said. "I haven't seen it yet."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1949 words

HEADLINE: Research, Promotion and Profits: Spotlight Is on the Drug Industry

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
While drug companies say they need high prices to support innovative research, health economists say that more and more of the companies' revenues are going to increasingly elaborate promotions. They include gifts for patients who take their drugs, payments to doctors as consultants and large donations to nonprofit hospitals.
And much of the research by drug companies is aimed not at innovation but at developing medicines that have the same function as similar drugs made by rivals, academics who study the drug industry have said in interviews and in testimony before Congress. Officials at the Food and Drug Administration say that of the 90 new drugs approved last year, only about 40 percent were a significant advance over medicines already available.
 
Debating Obscured Figures
 Drug costs have soared in recent years, and President Clinton lambasted the drug industry this month for its hefty prices and profits, contending that it spends $1 billion more on promotion than it spends on research and development. 
 The drug companies say that assertion is unfounded and unfair. They argue that drug development is extraordinarily expensive and risky and that marketing advanced drugs often requires sophisticated, one-on-one sales presentations.
But the industry has presented little hard data about its costs and pricing strategies. As a result, many health economists who admire the industry's record of innovation say they have recently grown skeptical of its claims that research would decline were it not for high prices.
 
'I Don't Believe Them'
 "The industry spends more on promotion than on research and development, so when they say they don't have enough money to develop new drugs, I don't believe them," said Dr. Barry Bleidt, a professor of pharmacy administration at Xavier University of Louisiana. "I consider myself pro-industry, but I'm also pro-consumer."
Dr. Bleidt and others say they are concerned that drug companies are now using their promotional budgets to circumvent restrictions on marketing by Federal regulators and hospitals. For example, companies are not permitted to promote a drug under development, but in some cases doctors who were paid consultants of a company have presented the merits of such drugs at medical meetings.
Although the industry willingly reveals its research and development costs -- projected at $10.3 billion in the United States for 1993 -- drug companies often obscure what is included in the category. And like many publicly traded companies, they consider their marketing and promotional outlays to be privileged information.
In documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, drug companies include promotional costs in categories like "selling, administration, general" or "cost of sales" or just "other."
"They try to keep their operating budgets as veiled as possible," Dr. Stephen Schondelmeyer, professor of pharmaceutical economics at the University of Minnesota, "which implies that there's something they do not want to reveal. When you look at the rosy picture painted in annual reports and then hear them tell Congress they can't afford to do research, there are a lot of discrepancies."
 
Promotion-Research Gap
 He and other health economists say that while many companies have survived on promotion, others, like Merck & Company, have an extraordinary record of innovative basic research.
The Pink Sheet, a newsletter for executives in the pharmaceutical industry published by FDC Reports of Chevy Chase, Md., estimated that in 1991, drug companies spent $10 billion on promotion, exceeding by $1 billion the amount spent on research.
Dr. Schondelmeyer's best guess is that the gap is even greater. Based on a review of annual reports and documents filed with the S.E.C., he estimates that a typical drug company spends about 16 percent of its budget on research and development and as much as 20 percent on promotion.
Most consumer-based industries spend about 2 percent of their budgets on marketing, although some beer and cosmetics companies spend 10 percent or more.
Dr. David A. Kessler, commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, said he worried that much of the money spent on promotion not only was wasteful but imperiled patient care. "Our concerns about promotion go well beyond the costs it adds to drug prices," he said. "Promotion is designed to create a market for a product, and the market that's created is not necessarily the market that will benefit from the drug. So it's going to result in inappropriate prescribing, and people will be hurt."
Pharmaceutical companies say patients get value for their money. Jeff Warren, a spokesman for the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, said, "We think we are unparalleled in terms of research intensity, and that bucks a trend that says that research and development are generally declining in this country." The association estimates that 16.7 percent of revenues are used for research and development. It does not keep records on marketing or promotion.
The industry defends large marketing budgets on the grounds that at least some of the promotion educates doctors and patients. Rick Honey, a spokesman for Pfizer Inc., noted that patent protection generally lapses in 10 to 15 years, "so from a business standpoint we have to market our product aggressively."
 
'Not Like Marketing Soda Pop'
 "More important, this is not like marketing soda pop," he said. "Many of our employees in marketing have advanced degrees and get extensive training in how to use our products."
Drug manufacturers also stress that millions of dollars go into research on drugs that never make it to market.
While pharmacologists acknowledge the enormous expense and great risk in pharmaceutical research, many say the companies owe the public a better accounting of their costs.
Dr. Marcus Reidenberg, editor of Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics, said: "There's so little hard data that there's no way for an outside observer like me to be able to come to a conclusion about whether high prices are fair high prices or unconscionable high prices. I've tried to get people from drug companies to write commentaries on their costs and how they set drug prices but haven't received any manuscripts."
 
Accounting Criticized
 The accounting standards used by pharmaceutical companies are "incredibly lax," said Dr. Peter Arno, professor of health economics at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx. "Their corporate reports are very vague, and they seem to fold advertising into research and development and confuse production costs with research and development."
And not all the research benefits patients. While Bristol-Myers Squibb is supporting some important basic research it has also spent research dollars to prove that its antibiotic Duricef is effective against strep throat, a condition that is readily treated by a host of far cheaper antibiotics.
Calls to Bristol-Myers Squibb for this article were not returned.
Based on a 1990 study at Tufts University, drug companies claim that it costs an average of $231 million to bring a drug to market. But only half of that is budgeted for development; the other half is what economists call opportunity cost -- the return that could have been expected if the company had invested the money instead of tying it up in developing the drug.
In recent years, the F.D.A. and various medical societies have imposed restrictions on how drug companies may promote their products to doctors, strictly limiting the types of gifts. And an increasing number of hospitals are placing restrictions on visits by sales representatives. In response, the industry has developed more subtle promotional techniques directed at patients and hospitals.
"The pharmaceutical industry is incredibly clever, and I say that from a position of both respect and disgust," said Dr. Bleidt, the Xavier University pharmacologist. "There are fewer outright bribes to doctors these days, but they didn't decrease their promotional outlays, of course. They became smarter in how to use them."
Dr. Kessler said that many pharmaceutical companies had tried to get around the restrictions on promotion and advertising by going undercover. Instead of making the rounds to promote their products themselves, they hire prominent doctors as "consultants" who preach the virtues of the medicines at medical conventions, on hospital rounds and in journals.
 
New Rules, New Tactics
 New guidelines drafted by the F.D.A. do not prohibit drug companies from paying lecturers or from sponsoring conferences but require that the ties be revealed and the terms of the contract be publicly available.
The drug companies are also increasingly sponsoring newsletters or supplements to respected journals that appear to be part of the journals. In 1991, the Food and Drug Administration took action against Bristol-Myers for printing a newsletter called Oncology Commentary that was designed to look like a medical journal but only discussed the company's drugs; the name of the company was nowhere on the publication.
Many companies are starting to give incentives to potential patients as well. To promote its new arthritis drug, Relafen, SmithKline Beecham offered patients who visited a doctor free memberships worth about $20 in the Arthritis Foundation, a support and information group for people with the disease.
Although drug company executives acknowledge that some abuses have occurred, they say that pharmaceutical marketing often provides doctors with up-to-date information. For example, when Wyeth-Ayerst began to market the Norplant contraceptive two years ago, its marketing budget covered the cost of teaching doctors to insert the now-popular device.
Perhaps most worrisome to critics of the industry is the way drug company money now permeates hospitals and doctors' offices, where skepticism has long been relied upon to keep overzealous sales pitches in check. Scientists and hospitals say that as research costs have risen and public funds have declined, they have come to rely more heavily on industry grants.
Certain drug companies have become major charitable donors to hospitals, contributing $25,000 here and $100,000 there. Marion Merrell Dow revealed in its annual report that in the name of "strategic philanthropy," it had given an undisclosed amount of money to help establish a cardiovascular research center at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.
"I'm not against public philanthropy," Dr. Schondelmeyer said. "But I disagree when industry seems to raise capital far beyond what they need to produce their product. As a consumer, I begin to wonder whether the hospital is acting in my best interest when they tell me I need this expensive drug."
 
15-Year Monopoly
 Sam Peltzman, a business professor at the University of Chicago, said lower drug prices were not likely to lead to less promotion -- or to less research either, at least in the short term. He said the drug industry acts as if high prices "are a fountain for research and development, which is just nonsense."
"We give companies the freedom to set price and a monopoly to sell their product for 10 to 15 years, so they are going to try to maximize their profits," he said. "That's in large part why prices have risen."
He said that lowering drug prices would only threaten development of drugs that showed little promise.
"Drug companies undertake these massive searches knowing there will be a big payoff if they hit a winner," he said. "We can have lower drug prices if we accept less of that searching. That's the choice we face."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN;
DEMOCRATS' UNEASE MAY SLOW CLINTON ON ECONOMIC PLAN

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Signs of dissatisfaction have begun to appear in Democratic ranks on Capitol Hill that could complicate and perhaps delay the passage of President Clinton's ambitious economic program, on which he has staked his political future.
There are important dissidents, especially in the Senate, on both procedural and substantive grounds. A few have publicly expressed their doubts and reservations, but many more have spoken critically at closed meetings on the plan this week. Most of the criticism has come from conservative and moderate lawmakers from the South and the Midwest. 
 Some of the critics think the whole package is out of balance, with too many tax increases, most beginning in 1994, and too few tax cuts. Some fear that it penalizes their states too severely. And some, while applauding Mr. Clinton's approach, think the White House is exposing them unnecessarily to reprisal from disillusioned voters.
 
First, the Palatable
 But White House aides expressed what one called "tenuous confidence" that the plan can be pushed through by late summer, and they have devised a fairly detailed multivote strategy for doing so. Although Congressional leaders have not accepted it yet, they are leaning toward the idea of taking up the program in several stages, passing the more politically palatable spending programs before the hard votes on cutting and taxing.
Today, Mr. Clinton himself continued to try to generate public support and pressure on Congress for his program. Having campaigned in three states on Thursday and Friday, he was in an avuncular mood as he answered children's questions at the White House for a carefully staged national television broadcast.
Initial polling results, and the turnouts for Mr. Clinton's appearances in Missouri, Ohio and New York this week, suggest that he has a reservoir of good will to draw on. But later polls and the skeptical questions asked of him indicate that the support is fragile.
 
A $30 Billion Stimulus
 The Administration is pushing for a vote on unemployment payments before March 6, when the present authorization runs out. That seems fairly uncontroversial. But an extension of the debt ceiling, due in March, could cause serious complications.
Before the Easter recess in early April, the White House would like to gain approval for $30 billion in short-term stimulus to the economy -- new spending on highways, waterways and the like -- so the money will be available for summer, when the weather is right and youth employment can be undertaken on a large scale.
All the rest of the complex plan would be left for a single climactic vote on the budget-reconciliation bill, either in August or after Labor Day. That combined approach is crucial to White House strategists and their supporters on the Hill.
"I think the prospects of getting it enacted are pretty good," Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said in a telephone interview. "If every member wants the package tailored to his or her requirements, there won't be any package, and in the end my guess is that the country's insistence on change will prevail."
But for Democrats like Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma the idea of voting to spend more money months before casting a more popular vote to cut the deficit is impolitic and unwise.
"That could be a crucial mistake," he said. "It would send the wrong message to the country. If the first thing they see us do is pass a stimulus package, it's going to destroy our credibility. A lot of us will be extremely uncomfortable with voting more money for anything before we lock in deficit reduction. I would move the reconciliation vote up to May and vote on everything at once."
 
Spinach or Dessert?
 Senator Boren said he worries that some liberals would never vote for cuts if they were separated from the $30 billion stimulus package. "If you let your 5-year-old eat dessert before he eats his spinach, he'll never eat his spinach, and history indicates that we're dealing with a lot of 5-year-olds here," he said.
As many as half a dozen other Democratic senators voiced similar views at a policy committee meeting on Thursday, participants said, and some have told Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the White House chief of staff, about their concerns. Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and Herb Kohl of Wisconsin are reportedly among those with apprehensions.
In the House, the major committee chairmen wrote to Mr. Clinton shortly after his election to say that if he would provide a strong lead, they would follow. But an aide to one Democratic leader said that among the 100-odd freshman members there were "a lot of sweaty palms about the prospect of voting for more money for anything quite this soon."
Some more experienced members are unhappy as well. Representative Pete Geren, Democrat of Texas, said he and a group of like-minded conservatives were trying to put together a package of further cuts, though he conceded that prospects were slim.
 
Soothing Nervous Lawmakers
 To try to give nervous lawmakers a bit of political cover, the Administration has proposed a vote on a budget resolution offering a general pledge of deficit reduction, before the vote on the stimulus plan. But that would be much less persuasive than a vote on actual reductions.
Some further compromise by the White House may be necessary. Few Republicans are likely to support the President, so with only a 14-vote Senate majority the Democrats can afford to lose only a handful of votes.
Some of the Democratic senators who object to Mr. Clinton's plan want to accommodate Republican critics who argue for many more spending cuts.
Senator Jim Exon, a conservative Nebraska Democrat, told the budget director, Leon E. Panetta, during a hearing on Friday that the proposal has "no chance" of passage without major changes. He added, "Unless we can reach some kind of compromise, we're going to see gridlock on this, and that is the worst of all possible worlds."
 
Farm-State Grumbling
 Other Democrats object to particular aspects of the plan. Farm-state senators are grumbling about deep cuts in agricultural subsidies, and Senator J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, chairman of the Energy and Natural Resources Committee, said this week that he intends to explore the possibility of substituting a value-added tax, a kind of national sales tax, for the energy tax that is one of the main features of the President's plan.
That effort will begin Wednesday morning, when the committee holds hearings at which a number of economists have been invited to testify in behalf of a value-added tax.
Mr. Johnston met with Mr. Clinton late this week, and White House aides say they are sure the two will eventually work out an agreement. The outlook regarding Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, the powerful chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, is less certain, and he could present a major problem, because the deep defense cuts proposed by the President are a key to the program.
On Thursday, Mr. Nunn said his mind was open, but he said the $76 billion reduction in military spending over four years urged by Mr. Clinton "is certainly more than I recommend."
 
'No Quick Fixes'
 In a detailed report issued last September, Senator Nunn and Senator Pete Domenici, a Republican from New Mexico, warned that "there are no quick fixes" and urged that the budget deficit and the country's other ills be attacked in a 10-year program.
"Sam doesn't want to be seen as an impediment to the President's plan," said an official who is close to the Georgian. "Their relations are better than many people think. But there will have to be some accommodation from the White House, because he isn't going to sign off on something he thinks will hurt military morale."
Mr. Clinton has said he is willing to listen to suggestions for changes in his plan, but the White House wants to hold them to an absolute minimum, lest the whole program be picked to pieces.
"There's a big difference, in our minds, between rounding off some rough edges and making basic changes," a Presidential adviser said.
The White House is prepared to fight a suggestion that an overhaul of the health-care system, which will require further tax increases, probably on tobacco and alcohol, be lumped together with the economic package. That is another idea floated by those afraid of voting to raise taxes, who would prefer to do it just once if they must do it at all. The Administration thinks it would delay the showdown so long that all of the current momentum would be lost.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Cut To the Cuts

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
Bill Clinton's speeches have often sounded like the kind of careful, correct, rather stiff compositions an A student produces when he wants to protect his grade point average. But his speech to Congress on the economy was about as good a speech as I have ever heard him deliver.
It was also dangerous. 
 It was dangerous for the Republicans, who responded to Mr. Clinton's rhetorical magnanimity with the same old same old. "There is plenty of blame to go around," the President said, "in both branches of the Government and both parties. The time has come for the blame to end." And he invited Republicans who didn't like his specifics to come up with specifics of their own, as though they were all in this together.
But as soon as he was finished speaking, the House minority leader, Robert H. Michel, launched into a Republican response that owed more to cliched partisan buckshot than to deficit reduction, incorporating, among other things, the deftly wrought phrases "failed big government schemes of a generation ago" and "biggest propaganda campaign in recent political history."
Mr. Clinton came to the Congress having learned the deficit-reduction lesson of Ross Perot. But the Republicans seem in danger of forgetting the other part of the Perot phenomenon: that people are sick and tired of the constant bickering that passes for government in Washington. Listening to Bob Dole carp about the Democrats is deja vu all over again, neither illuminating nor pretty.
But Mr. Clinton's speech was dangerous for him, too, because it did that most dangerous of things -- it raised expectations, not only for new programs but for hard choices. To meet them, he must make far greater cuts in spending than the ones we have heard about so far.
The superconducting supercollider and the space station should be shelved to save billions. These two high-tech projects are the equivalent of luxury cars; we just can't afford them right now. And the fact that both benefit the Treasury Secretary's home state of Texas makes their survival in lean times look too much like pork.
The military budget must finally address the ridiculous redundancies in the way the four branches operate. The Air Force has fighter wings. The Navy has fighter wings. The Marines have fighter wings. And so on, through overlapping light divisions, legal and medical corps, and other missions, programs and services. The taxpayers should not have to finance interservice rivalries as though the military were the Big Ten Conference.
But the most important thing the President needs to do is to make government make sense. When the issue of the elevator operators who run the automatic elevators for members of Congress comes up, as it has before, it should finally be settled in the only way that makes sense. And that is to assume that members of Congress are competent to push elevator buttons themselves.
Not because this is a big boondoggle -- it's not -- or because it will save lots of money. It won't. But because it is emblematic of how fat and disdainful government has become. Each time a taxpayer is handed from person to person to person in a bloated and befuddled bureaucracy, she apprehends anew a system that treats her money as though it were nothing. Deputy directors. Assistant deputy directors. Assistants to the deputy directors. Public relations officers, the rabbits of government, multiplying uncontrollably. Cut 'em all back. Make the managers manage.
Mr. Clinton asked for sacrifice, and the most remarkable part of these budget discussions is how reasonable the American people have been about chipping in. A scant two years ago, deficit reduction was largely the purview of the econowonk, Paul Tsongas's little hobby. Today most Americans assume it is the key to economic survival.
When Mr. Clinton talked about sharing the sacrifice, he had to know that shoving the six-figure folks into a higher bracket would not be enough. There are small fish, and there are big fish. And then there is the whale, and the whale is government. For support to continue for the President, and for Congress too, the bickering must stop and the blubber must go. Remembering, of course, that the taxpayers know fat when they see it because they've been living lean.

TYPE: Op-Ed

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 1348 words

HEADLINE: U.S. CONSIDERS AID ON LONG-TERM CARE

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is considering a new Government-subsidized program to provide long-term care to people with chronic illnesses or disabilities.
Elderly people have long sought Federal help with the cost of long-term care, one of their biggest health expenses. 
 Confidential work papers from the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform show that a major goal of the "new long-term care program" is to shift spending from nursing homes to "community-based services" that provide medical care and other types of assistance to people living in their own homes.
 
Broad Need Seen
 The planning is still in the early stage. No decisions have been made, and the cost of the new program has not been calculated. The elderly are the biggest users of long-term care, but the work papers show that the Administration sees a need for such services among people of all ages.
"Whom do we plan to cover in this initiative?" asks the working group on long-term care, one of two dozen such groups operating under the supervision of Hillary Rodham Clinton. "Disabled elderly. Physically disabled nonelderly. Mentally retarded, developmentally disabled." The "target population" also includes people with AIDS, the working group says.
The memorandum does not mention the four million people with Alzheimer's disease. But the working group is well aware of their needs because a vice president of the Alzheimer's Association, Steven R. McConnell, briefly served on the staff of the task force.
Mrs. Clinton's task force is considering potentially costly new benefits at the same time President Clinton is asking Congress to trim $62 billion from the projected growth of Medicare and Medicaid over the next five years. The working group on long-term care evidently wants to encourage people to buy private insurance to cover the costs of such care, but it also assumes that there will be new Federal costs.
Though the work papers make no estimate of those costs, they show that the task force is considering new taxes to finance the new program, including estate taxes and payroll taxes. Other options include general revenues, private insurance and personal savings, perhaps with new tax breaks for people who establish accounts earmarked for long-term care. The taxes would be above and beyond those proposed by Mr. Clinton this week: $251 billion over five years from higher individual and corporate taxes.
On Friday the Federal budget director, Leon E. Panetta, said the Administration would probably seek higher taxes on cigarettes and alcoholic beverages to help pay for the President's health plan.
Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri, a moderate Republican, said it would be "extremely difficult" for Congress to pass new taxes for health care on top of those sought for deficit reduction.
 
Reining in the Industry
 "How many big tax bills is Congress going to pass in a year?" Mr. Danforth asked. "How much is the country going to swallow in a year?"
Mr. Clinton has said he will submit his health plan to Congress by May 1. Lawmakers from both parties say the nation must control health costs before it can guarantee access to care for 35 million people without insurance, as Mr. Clinton has promised to do.
The work papers of the task force confirm that the Administration is considering imposing "interim cost controls" on the health-care industry, which accounts for one-seventh of the nation's economy, during the transition to a new health system.
The documents show that the task force is considering these options: a "freeze on health-care prices," controls on drug prices and Federal limits on doctors' fees, hospital charges and private health insurance premiums. Again, no decisions have been made.
In the Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton said, "No Americans should have to impoverish themselves to qualify for long-term health care," and he promised to expand long-term care.
 
Becoming Poor to Get Help
 As a model for the nation, Mr. Clinton cited an Arkansas program known as Elder Choices. This program, he said, "gives the elderly the right to take money previously available only for nursing home care and spend it instead on home health care, personal care, transportation to senior centers, nurses' services or attendance at an adult day care center."
The cost of nursing home care is the biggest out-of-pocket health expense for the elderly. Groups like the American Association of Retired Persons have been lobbying for years to get more Government aid for such care.
Medicaid, the Federal-state program for low-income people, covers 65 percent of the nation's 1.5 million nursing home residents. Many of these people were once in middle-income families, but to qualify for Medicaid they impoverished themselves, either by spending all their money for a nursing home or by giving away their assets.
More than 2.4 million people have bought insurance against the high cost of nursing home care, which averages more than $30,000 a year per person.
A study this month by Families U.S.A., a research and advocacy group, said private long-term care insurance was unaffordable for most middle-aged and elderly people. Ronald F. Pollack, executive director of the group, said, "The only way to make long-term care affordable is a public system where everybody pays and everybody is protected."
The Health Insurance Association of America asserts that long-term care policies are affordable. In 1991, it says, annual premiums on a basic policy averaged $1,100 for a person 65 years old. Premiums were $2,500 a year for a person of that age seeking extra protection to preserve the benefits of the policy against inflation.
The Clinton panel studying long-term care is headed by Robyn I. Stone, a senior policy analyst at Project Hope, an international health foundation. The panel includes Joshua M. Wiener, an economist at the Brookings Institution. In a 1988 book, Mr. Wiener and Alice M. Rivlin, now deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget, recommended expanding Medicare to cover much more of the cost of long-term care.
But in his budget this week, Mr. Clinton proposed eliminating a part of the Medicaid law that guarantees payment for "personal care services" to certain disabled people living at home. He said the change would save $5.8 billion over five years.
Elma L. Holder, director of the National Citizens' Coalition for Nursing Home Reform, a consumer group, said this proposal was "quite inconsistent with Clinton's campaign statements emphasizing his support for home and community-based care."
 
The Old Question: Who Pays?
 While Medicaid is widely seen as a welfare program, Medicare is considered a form of social insurance because it is financed mainly through premiums and payroll taxes and is available to elderly and disabled people regardless of their income.
The Administration has not decided who should pay for the new program. The working group on long-term care has framed the question this way: "Should the increase in taxes be borne by the biggest users of the services (i.e., the elderly), or should they be borne by the general population?"
Congress expanded Medicare to cover the cost of catastrophic illness in 1988. But after elderly people realized they would pay the bill, through higher taxes and premiums, they forced Congress to repeal the catastrophic insurance program a year later.
The working group is considering four ways to cover long-term care. Building on Medicare, the Federal Government could establish a full-scale social insurance program for people of all ages. Alternatively, it could make a flat payment to a "case manager" who agrees to provide a wide range of social and health services intended to keep people out of hospitals and nursing homes.
The Government could expand Medicaid to cover more people. Or it could negotiate a deal with the states, requiring them to cover the full cost of long-term care for low-income people, in exchange for a Federal commitment to pick of the cost of hospital care and doctors' services.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Medicaid and Nursing Care" shows breakdown of Medicaid expenses and percentage used to pay for nursing home patients. (Source: Department of Health and Human Services) (pg. 25)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%);

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN;
Economic Plan Grew Slowly Out of Marathon of Debate

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
At the first meeting of Bill Clinton's economic team, on Dec. 30, the members already knew what the public suspected: the new President would abandon one of his earliest campaign pledges. There would be no tax cut for the middle class. In fact, taxes would probably rise on the very people Mr. Clinton had vowed to protect.
The discussions went on for weeks before Mr. Clinton put his ideas to Congress last Wednesday. But at that first meeting, in the Washington offices of Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, Mr. Clinton's advisers were already aware of statistics that the outgoing Bush White House was about to make public, showing that the Federal deficit was going to rise $50 billion a year more than they had expected. The information crystallized Mr. Clinton's budget predicament. 
 The new figures handed a powerful weapon to a group of advisers who came to be known as "the deficit hawks" and, behind their backs, as the "pain-is-good" crowd because of their belief that spending cuts or higher taxes were needed to bring the Federal deficit under control. The promised middle-class tax cut, one adviser said, would just be allowed to "float away" and higher energy taxes would be substituted for it.
It also immediately became conceivable that higher taxes on more affluent Social Security recipients would be part of the the President's program. Neither idea would be popular or easily sold.
 
Straight Out of Vaudeville
 The dynamics of these decisions, rooted in politics, personality and economics, would color the entire process as Mr. Clinton desperately searched for a balance that would work.
To meet his goal of a reduction in the Federal deficit and a spur to the economy in the face of the larger deficit projection, Mr. Clinton needed big new taxes and deep cuts in spending. His advisers were telling him he needed to be bold. And to make his plan workable politically, he would have to mete out the taxes and spending reductions with a diamond cutter's precision.
George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said this week that the two-month enterprise was a balancing act that reminded him of the juggler who could keep china plates spinning on 10-foot poles.
"In the end, he had to have the right balance on job creation, economic stimulus, deficit reduction, balance on regions, population groups and balance between credibility and the chances for passage," Mr. Stephanopoulos said.
Which plates crashed to the ground?
"They're still spinning," he replied.
 
Managing the Minute
 In the early stages, Mr. Clinton realized that the budget plan he intended to define his young Presidency would do two things that any politician abhors: break promises and raise taxes.
In interviews, several of the President's senior aides, who spent dozens of hours in meetings that began at the Governor's Mansion in Little Rock, Ark., and continued at the White House, gave accounts of a process run by a President whose mastery of the wide range of topics under discussion was greater than that of anyone else at the table. Mr. Clinton took a micromanager's pride in hammering out the most minute details.
"There's no question that the President knew this stuff better across the board than anyone else at the table," said Roger C. Altman, the Deputy Treasury Secretary. "Others may have known more about particular aspects, but no one else understood so much about so many things."
 
Sides of Battle
 The result of the weeks of deliberations, grandiosely titled "A Vision of Change for America," included more tax increases than spending reductions, a far cry from Mr. Clinton's initial target of making $2 in spending cuts for every $1 raised in higher taxes.
The deficit hawks of Mr. Clinton's economic policy group were Leon E. Panetta, the budget director; his deputy, Alice M. Rivlin, and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen.
On the side of greater attention to stimulating the economy and creating jobs were Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers; Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich; Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and the bulk of Mr. Clinton's politically attuned communications staff.
The hard-liners won their biggest victory on the day that the Clinton camp received the official deficit news.
Mr. Bentsen, who sat at Mr. Clinton's right hand in the meetings, agreed that strong action was required. Although the former Texas Senator had not been one of his more enthusiastic supporters in the Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton held Mr. Bentsen in high regard. Typically, when the discussion of a complicated issue reached the decision point, Mr. Clinton would turn to him and say, "Lloyd, what would you do?"
 
Challenging a Deduction
 This is what happened, for instance, on the question of whether tax deductions should be eliminated for mortgage interest payments that total more than a certain amount, perhaps $20,000 a year.
Mr. Bentsen, who was seen as a patron of the real estate industry, said it would be unfair to limit the deductions on existing mortgages, since the loans had been taken out with the understanding that the interest payments would be deductible.
Limiting the deduction on new mortgages, Mr. Bentsen argued, would be fair but would not raise much new revenue in the next few years. In sum, it was not worth the political price of taking on the real estate industry, which would certainly oppose it.
Mr. Clinton agreed, and the proposal was dropped.
 
Academics to Reality
 Until this point, it had still been an economic exercise for Mr. Clinton. And it remained so until Jan. 20, when he took the oath of office and the hard part started behind closed doors at the White House.
Trade-offs became a regular feature of these meetings, at which participants snacked on cookies, fruit and diet sodas.
Mr. Bentsen decided to support an energy tax based on the amount of heat that various fuels generate rather than one he personally favored based on the price of fuels. He knew from his experience in the Senate that this "B.T.U. tax" would be easier to pass.
Some special pains were also taken on behalf of particularly valuable members of Congress.
For example, the policy makers had Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, in mind when they decided to include a measure that would allow donors to museums and other charitable organizations to take a tax deduction for the full market value of their gifts. Under current law, donors of, say, a painting, can deduct only what they paid for the art.
Changing the law to please Mr. Moynihan, who would see the many museums in New York City benefit, seemed worth the effort, as the Senator is chairman of the Finance Committee. Almost the entire economic package must pass through Mr. Moynihan's committee, and since the tax break for charitable contributions would cost only about $70 million a year in lost revenue, it seemed a small price to pay.
Similarly, the economic team quickly discarded a proposal for an energy tax based on the carbon content of various forms of fuel. That would have placed coal producers at a serious disadvantage, and the coal industry is of vital importance to Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who heads the Appropriations Committee.
 
Single-Minded Panetta
 Mr. Clinton consistently asked his advisers to prove their assumptions by producing charts that demonstrated how people at different income levels would be affected by each proposal. Because of that, Mr. Clinton decided relatively late in the process to increase the tax break for families whose earnings fall below the Federal poverty line.
One of the most zealous budget-cutters in the room was Mr. Panetta, a gentle, affable man who proved so single-minded about reducing the deficit that he was occasionally unaware that the others around the table were having a laugh at his expense.
At one point, Mr. Panetta suggested having the Coast Guard charge for rescuing boaters in distress. Someone made a crack about asking a drowning man whether he wanted to charge his rescue to Visa or MasterCard. Mr. Clinton and the others roared. Mr. Panetta kept talking, oblivious to the laughter.
The process was usually not so lighthearted. A week to the day after the inauguration, Mr. Clinton had Democratic Senate leaders to the White House. At the meeting, Mr. Panetta declared that he favored a one-year freeze in cost-of-living adjustments in Social Security benefits. Word leaked out.
Mr. Clinton apparently never liked the idea. But his advisers were worried about saying that the President had ruled anything out, fearful that it would show what had been ruled in. Furthermore, leaving the freeze on the table gave political cover to the proposal that was eventually adopted, increasing the amount of Social Security benefits on which the more affluent retirees must pay income tax.
But Mr. Clinton's habit of building escape hatches into his public comments and his policy quickly became a liability. By refusing to disavow any intention to freeze cost-of-living adjustments to Social Security, the President left the impression that cutting benefits for the elderly was at the top of his priority list.
 
The 'Grand Plan'
 In the last weeks before the big economic speech on Wednesday, the White House political machine moved into high gear. "You can have a grand plan," one White House official said, "but if it doesn't fly, it's not a grand plan. You have to find common ground."
The political staff, led by Paul Begala, outlined the route of attack. Play down taxes, play up spending cuts and define all new spending as "investment" in the future.
Mr. Clinton insisted to reporters that he was spending "95 percent" of his time working on the economy. But in doing this, he ignored other warning signs that led to some serious political snags. Two candidates for Attorney General fell by the wayside, and the President became ensnared in what he saw as a premature flap over whether to allow homosexuals in the military.
But the economic plan moved apace. Treasury and budget officials often went home at 5 A.M. after running numbers through the computers all night. The brainstorming sessions -- to which the President was habitually late -- became a daily marathon.
On the night before the President addressed a joint session of Congress, he summoned Cabinet members, their deputies and top aides to the White House for a series of political and budget briefings.
Mr. Bentsen later commented that the Clinton people were "the meeting est group I've ever seen."
On the night of the speech, Mr. Clinton was still working on his text less than an hour before he was to give it. He had rejected drafts that sounded too traditional, too much like old-fashioned Democratic politics. He specifically directed the writers who were helping him with the speech to omit any bashing of big business and to emphasize self-reliance and training programs.
Cabinet members who watched the speech from a row in the House chamber looked exhausted. Afterward, Labor Secretary Reich, who has known and advised Mr. Clinton for years, acknowledged the intensity of the budget-making experience.
"During the past couple of months," he said "I have seen more of my friend Bill Clinton than I have ever before in my entire life."

GRAPHIC: Chronology: "FROM A PROMISE TO A PLAN"
 
DEC. 10, 1992: President-elect Bill Clinton, elected on a promise of fundamental economic change, announces the appointment of his economic team.
DEC. 14-15: In Little Rock, Ark., Mr. Clinton holds an economic conference of economists, business executives and labor leaders. The conference ends with a consensus on the need to spur growth in the short term and reduce the deficit over the long haul, but with contradictory advice on how to achieve these goals.
DEC. 30: Mr. Clinton's economic planners in Washington tell his transition staff in Little Rock of the new, higher deficit estimates that the Bush Administration is expected to release the next week.
JAN. 7, 1993: Mr. Clinton spends six hours with his senior economic advisers going over the new deficit estimates, concluding that they may require him to back off campaign pledges to cut the Federal budget deficit in half in four years and avoid raising taxes on the middle class.
JAN. 20: Mr. Clinton becomes the 42d President of the United States. In the afternoon, the economic team meets in the office of Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen.
JAN. 28: Mr. Clinton meets with Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Hours after the meeting, Mr. Greenspan tells the Senate Budget Committee that the Administration's goals for deficit reduction are about right. The day before, Mr. Greenspan told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress he agreed with the "general thrust" of Mr. Clinton's policies to speed growth with a modest short-term stimulus.
JAN. 30-31: Mr. Clinton and his advisers work on the economic plan at Camp David.
FEB. 1: Mr. Clinton discusses his proposals with the National Governors' Association and Democratic Congressional leaders.
FEB. 4: Mr. Clinton meets with the three dozen Democrats who round up votes in the House and urges support of his stimulus package.
FEB. 13: Mr. Clinton fine-tunes the economic plan with his economic team and Democratic House members. In a radio address he seeks to assure middle-class Americans that they will be treated fairly in the plan.
FEB. 15: In his first televised address from the Oval Office, Mr. Clinton appeals to the American people to support the tax increases and spending cuts he says are needed to cut the deficit and put the nation on the path to greater prosperity.
FEB. 17: In an address to a joint session of Congress, Mr. Clinton unveils his economic plan. It includes a short-term stimulus plan, new spending in areas like education and public works and a four-year blueprint for reducing the deficit through a mixture of tax increases and spending cuts.

HEADLINE: Clinton Talks to Children, But Addresses Everybody

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Pursuing his public relations campaign to pressure Congress to support his economic agenda, President Clinton appeared on television today to answer questions from 40 polite and admiring children.
The two-hour ABC News special, "President Clinton Answering Children's Questions," was another small triumph in the White House's continuing effort to advertise the President and his plans. 
 Stylistically a cross between "Donahue" and "Mr. Rogers's Neighborhood," the program gave the President a chance to sell his plans and policies directly to children and parents and without challenge.
The children's questions, which were rehearsed in the White House by ABC News Friday night, included the cute ("Is Chelsea single?"), the soft ("Why did you want to become President?") and the politically pointed ("As a country we are very biased towards homosexuals; what are you going to do to help America accept them?").
 
Warm and Fuzzy
 With the ABC News anchor Peter Jennings guiding him through the live broadcast from the East Room, Mr. Clinton was shown to great advantage, engaging each child in brief conversations that were masterworks of Mr. Clinton's talent for political dialogue of the warm and fuzzy genre.
Several especially effective exchanges were preceded by biographical films of the children involved. Many of the children asking the questions had been affected by the issues they raised. A child with AIDS asked Mr. Clinton what he would do to restore money for AIDS research, money that the child said was cut by President George Bush (Mr. Bush actually increased the financing). A boy from Louisiana whose brother had died of a rare cancer asked what Mr. Clinton would do to end pollution and thus reduce the risk of environmentally caused cancers. A girl from Washington who had lived in a shelter for the homeless asked Mr. Clinton to help find houses for people without them.
The President addressed each question by presenting his policies and plans on the issues as the appropriate response to the suffering displayed before him.
"We'll do it for your brother," Mr. Clinton said, in assuring the boy from Louisiana that he would work to increase antipollution efforts. He urged the child with AIDS to "hang in there" until increased financing for AIDS research led to a cure. To the girl from Washington, he said, "I don't think Americans want children like you living in a homeless shelter."
 
'A Good Forum'
 ABC News, which conceived and produced the program as part of its series of Saturday morning specials for children, tried to sell the idea for it to both the Bush and Clinton organizations during the 1992 Presidential campaign, Mr. Jennings said in a telephone interview after the program.
"They both saw that this was a good forum for them in political terms," Mr. Jennings said. ABC renewed the idea after the election and found Mr. Clinton's advisers receptive. "Having seen the President with the kids today," he said, he thought they were "pretty satisfied."
ABC News chose the children to "show a cross section of America" and to illustrate such specific issues as the environment and homelessness, said an ABC News spokesman, Arnot Walker.
Mr. Walker said the network knew in advance the general nature of the questions that would be asked of Mr. Clinton but did not rehearse the questioners. He said the children used during a technical rehearsal at the White House on Friday night were different from those shown on the program.
 
One Child Invited Back
 But a ABC News employee, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the child who got the program's biggest laugh by asking Mr. Clinton if his daughter, Chelsea, were single, had first asked that question as a member of the rehearsal audience and had been invited to return and ask it on the air. (Chelsea herself had joined her father before the camera when the question was asked.)
Jeff Eller, a deputy in the White House communications office, said ABC News had provided the President's staff with biographical sketches of the children chosen. He added that George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, and Frank Greer, a Washington political consultant, had both been involved in the program. White House officials, Mr. Eller said, were aware of the general nature of the questions the children intended to ask. But he said neither Mr. Clinton nor White House officials knew precisely what the questions would be.
The program made the President exclusively available to a commercial television network for a program paid for by the Nynex Corporation, for which tax-deductible public service announcements were shown during commercial breaks.
Both Mr. Jennings and Mr. Eller defended the program. Mr. Eller said: "I think that this gave the American people a longer, in-depth view of Bill Clinton, and how he thinks, and we're able to see him with children addressing the specific concerns that they have. The concerns of children are no less important than anyone else's."
Mr. Eller's defense suggested an important way in which the program served Mr. Clinton. By putting goals of the Clinton Administration in the mouths of children, it was suggested that what Mr. Clinton wants to do is what America's children want, too. That could arguably equate a stand against the President with stand against the nation's sons and daughters.
 
Little Hint of Dispute
 While no one at either the White House or ABC suggested that this was the intent of the program, that seemed to be one effect. All the children who questioned the President on policy were supportive and approving. Only once was there even a hint that the views of children might not be any more monolithic than those of adults. That moment came when Mr. Jennings gave Mr. Clinton a joking warning as one boy readied himself to speak. "You'll have to work a little bit on Omar here, because he tells me he is a Republican," the newscaster said. But Omar's question turned out to be a politically safe one.
Mr. Clinton seemed to enjoy himself most answering questions about how he and his family found the experience of living in the White House. With Chelsea and the family cat, Socks, briefly joining him in rare public appearances, he fielded questions about domestic life of interest to children.
The President said he did indeed help his daughter with her homework, particularly with algebra. And he doubtless won the hearts of his audience when he told them that he did not punish his daughter often.
"Chelsea is a pretty good girl," he said. "The No. 1 thing we have to do is make her go to bed early. She has a fault that her father has: she likes to say up late at night."

He told the child it was sometimes because he was tired and sometimes because of allergies. At right was Peter Jennings of ABC. (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Most Cambodians See Nothing of Aid

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHNAP, Cambodia, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Tith Poth and her neighbors line up each morning with their dented aluminum pails and white plastic jugs in hopes of coaxing a little water from the single functioning well in Chnap.
"Nothing has changed," said Mrs. Tith Poth, a 65-year-old widow, grinning at the thought that life had somehow grown easier in Chnap since the arrival in Cambodia of thousands of United Nations peacekeepers. "Sometimes the white United Nations cars drive by, but the people inside never get out." 
 More than 50 families in this small, bleak village in central Cambodia depend on the well for their water for drinking and bathing. There is a village dispensary, but it lacks the most basic medicines and equipment. The flimsy, wood-frame houses in Chnap are roofed with palm leaves left cracked and torn by the sun. "When the rainy season comes, we just get wet," Mrs. Tith Poth said.
The deprivation here is not unusual. The United Nations-sponsored peace settlement in Cambodia was meant both to end a long civil war and to begin the reconstruction of one of the world's poorest nations. But more than a year after the United Nations sent a 22,000-member peacekeeping force to Cambodia -- and eight months after the architects of the peace plan pledged $800 million in reconstruction aid -- the lives of millions of Cambodians are no better.
 
Fighting Continues
 For many of the seven million people of Cambodia, the war is not over, with Government soldiers and rebels in large stretches of the countryside violating the cease-fire as if it never existed.
Equally worrisome to some United Nations officials is that with only months to go before the scheduled departure of most of the peacekeeping force, the reconstruction of Cambodia has barely begun.
Most of the peacekeepers are expected to leave Cambodia within weeks of national elections, now scheduled for late May.
Roger Lawrence, rehabilitation director for the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia, said he was concerned that donor nations had held back hundreds of millions of dollars in promised reconstruction aid out of a fear that the peace process will collapse.
"We are in a vicious circle here in which the peace process founders in part because the economic component isn't working -- and the economic part is not working because the peace process is perceived as foundering," he said. "It's disturbing. Whole regions of Cambodia haven't seen any tangible evidence of reconstruction."
 
Pledges Mostly Undisbursed
 The rehabilitation aid was meant to support everything from road and bridge repair to well-digging and the purchase of school books and essential medicines. But of the $800 million pledged by donor nations at a conference in Tokyo in June, only about $95 million has been disbursed.
According to figures compiled by the United Nations, the United States, the largest donor at the Tokyo conference, has come up with only $14 million of the $145 million it pledged. Japan, the second-largest donor, has turned over only about $9 million of the $135 million it promised.
Lee Twentyman, the Cambodia representative of the United States Agency for International Development, questioned the significance of the United Nations figures. He said that while much of the promised American aid money has not yet been spent, Washington had legally committed tens of millions of dollars that now can be drawn on by contractors working in Cambodia for the United States.
"I'm disbursing money at a rate faster than I've ever done before anywhere," Mr. Twentyman said. "I do agree that more should be done, but I think there were false expectations on what physically could be done here in a postwar environment in a short period of time."
A Japanese Embassy spokesman in Phnom Penh said that his Government was moving as quickly as it could in disbursing aid money in Cambodia, but that there was no way around the time-consuming scrutiny required by the Japanese Foreign Ministry for all foreign aid projects. "We have very complicated procedures," he said.
 
Rural Areas Neglected
 The nine Japanese rehabilitation projects in Cambodia demonstrate what many relief officials believe is another failing in the United Nations-sponsored reconstruction plan for the country. Five of the projects are intended to benefit the residents of Phnom Penh, Cambodia's booming capital, even though nearly 90 percent of Cambodia's population lives in rural areas.
Even as Phnom Penh prospers from foreign investment and aid, rural villages like Chnap, which is only about 35 miles southwest of the capital, are going without.
"It's shortsighted to throw billions of dollars into a peacekeeping operation and then not spend even a little money in a place like this," said a Western relief worker in Kompong Speu province, where Chnap is situated. "Maybe 5 percent of the people in the province have safe water. It would take so little money to dig some wells and solve that problem."
A few steps from the United Nations compound in Kompong Speu province is a stagnant pond that serves as a community bathtub for Cambodians -- and their farm animals -- living nearby.
 
Cursed by Poor Soil
 Chnap, like much of the province, is cursed by poor soil. Only a few sickly trees are left standing in the parched rust-red earth. The rest were hacked down long ago by rice farmers who, desperate during bad harvests, sold the trees as firewood.
The only food that villagers say they can depend on is rice, and it is almost all they eat. "It's only rice for us, every meal, every day," Rek Som said as she stirred the rice that bubbled in a charred aluminum pot. Since her husband died of malaria three years, Mrs. Rek Som, 33, said, rice "is the only food we can afford."
Her 5-year-old son, who was so small and frail that in any developed country he would pass for barely 3, sat patiently on the dirt floor, waiting for his noon meal.
"When we heard the United Nations would come to Cambodia, we were all happy in the village because we hoped it would mean peace for the country and our families," Mrs. Rek Som said. "But the peace will not matter to me if there is not enough food for my son."

Aid for reconstruction is almost nonexistent in rural areas, and despite a peace agreement after years of civil war, the resolution of the country's political future has been delayed repeatedly. (Philip Shenon/The New York Times) (pg. 10)
