HEADLINE: Soft Hands, a Big Smile and a Piercing Gaze;
A President's Personal Touches Become the Stuff of Memories in Hyde Park

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HYDE PARK, N.Y., Feb. 20

 BODY:
For Donna Stein, it all came down to the touch of Bill Clinton's hands.
"His hands were so soft," she recalled Friday evening, a few hours after she and her husband, Sheldon, elbowed their way to the front of the room to congratulate the President after his economic address at the Haviland Middle School here. 
 "As we were shaking hands, I put my left hand on top of his right hand," said Mrs. Stein, 33, a nurse and graduate student in psychology. "Then he put his other hand under mine."
 
Life Returns to Normal
 After a week in which this town of 21,230 was overrun by dozens of law enforcement officials and members of the Presidential advance team, life in Hyde Park seemed to approach its normal cadence today. For the first time since Tuesday, there were rooms available at the Super 8 Motel, the White House having vacated the 20 or so rooms that it had fashioned into a command post.
Hyde Park's main street, Route 9, was also clear today, the unusual gridlock of the day before just an unpleasant memory. While New York Telephone technicians pulled out the 200 extra phone lines that had been connected at the Middle School at the behest of White House officials and reporters, maintenance workers began to reattach the 100 chairs that had been torn from the auditorium floor so that the President could have room to maneuver.
President Clinton spent only a couple of hours in Hyde Park on Friday afternoon, but it was clear -- based on the animated conversations at the Town n' Country Diner this morning -- that he shook an inordinate number of hands while he was here.
 
Working the House
 He worked the auditorium, where about 500 invited guests heard his speech. Then he wended his way across the hall, to the school's gymnasium, where another 400 people had watched the address on a single television, the other monitors having broken down.
Mike Moshier, a commercial representative for Central Hudson Gas and Electric, had a front-row seat for the President's address, thanks to his brother, who has a friend in the Secret Service. Mr. Moshier watched as Mr. Clinton spent about 20 minutes shaking hands, beginning with the teachers and students assembled behind the lectern and then stepping down to meet -- and chat with -- the crowd of business leaders, elected officials, children and other townspeople.
"He shook my hand, along with my brother Pat, his wife, Sue, and my three nieces, Jennifer, Katie and Genna," said Mr. Moshier, who voted for President Bush last November but has decided, for the time being, to support President Clinton's efforts.
 
From a Distance
 "I got my vice-president from my company a seat down in the front row," added Mr. Moshier, 44, a life-long resident of this Hudson River town. "The President shook his hand too."
Others glimpsed the President from a distance.
Jerry Govoni, 43, and his wife, Linda, 41, described over coffee and juice how they had driven to Hyde Park from Marlborough, Conn., yesterday, unaware that the President would be in town. They had come here with their daughter, Heather, 7, and son, Lyle, 4, to tour the Franklin D. Roosevelt Library. Then traffic inexplicably came to a standstill on Route 9, and before they knew it the President was whisking by in his motorcade.
"He was smiling," Mrs. Govoni said. "A big smile."
President Clinton came to the town where Franklin Roosevelt was born and is buried to invoke the Roosevelt legacy and to pay his respects. Aleta Knight, 37, the supervisory park ranger at the Roosevelt home, was assigned to stand at President Roosevelt's grave Friday as Mr. Clinton and Mr. Roosevelt's grandson, James, each laid down a red rose.
 
Playing With the Elevator
 "He had a very piercing gaze," said Ms. Knight, who works for the National Park Service. "When he looked at you, you turned beet red."
Later, she accompanied the President inside the Roosevelt home, where, she said, he playfully took hold of the ropes that control the hand-operated elevator that they were riding in.
"He was having a blast," she recalled. "He said, 'Oh, this is fun!' "
There was also a memorable moment in the Roosevelt Library, which is overseen by the National Archives and which houses President Roosevelt's papers and mementos.
 
Special Register
 After welcoming the President into his office, Verne Newton, the library director, asked him to sign the 52-year-old register of guests who had visited Mr. Roosevelt's study here. Mr. Clinton dutifully complied, turning, as directed, to a special page where the names Winston Churchill, Lyndon Johnson and Nelson Rockefeller are scrawled.
But after everyone else left, the woman who had applied the President's make-up for a television interview quietly signed her name too -- on the same, historic page.
"A hundred years from now," Mr. Newton said, "historians will be trying to figure out, 'Who was Simone Levy?' "

HEADLINE: Perot Is Back Running Hard; The Question Is, 'For What?'

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 20

 BODY:
Ross Perot is back on the hustings, trying to hold President Clinton's feet to the fires of fiscal responsibility but mainly stoking a few political fires of his own.
He will not say whether he plans another Presidential run in 1996, after his strong showing last year, when he captured 19 percent of the vote. 
 But he is spending this weekend hop-scotching the length of Florida, from cheer-filled rally to cheer-filled rally, and the impression left by the billionaire businessman is that he is running hard after something.
It is not clear whether that something is the Presidency or more national influence or some greater measure of ego satisfaction. But the man is on the move, urging his supporters to organize, strutting the stage before them, hand on hip, jug-eared head cocked, homespun aphorisms pouring forth in that twangy Texas accent.
 
Instant Understanding
 "Are we gonna talk about it or are we gonna do it?" he asked an overflow audience of 3,000 that jammed into a Shriners' auditorium here this morning, amid red, white and blue balloons and to the sound of patriotic music.
At that early point in his speech, he had never defined "it." But his audience, mainly Perot partisans, understood instantly and answered with a standing cheer.
"You own this country." Mr. Perot went on, reaching back, as he does throughout all his post-election speeches, for the lines and subject matter that played so well before the election. "You own this country and those people up there in Washington work for you and don't you ever let 'em forget it."
More cheers.
"He's right on the mark," said Betty Nordman, a retired Jacksonville teacher who voted for President George Bush last fall and is now looking for a political alternative for 1996.
"Bill Clinton has already broken his promise on taxes," she said. "From here on out, I'm keeping my eye on Ross Perot."
 
Dispensing Perot Medicine
 A couple of weeks ago, Mr. Perot made a similar speech swing through Maine, with similar results. Next he plans to tour his home state of Texas. And late in March he plans to take to national television again, much as he did during the fall campaign, with a Perot-financed special on what ails America and what medicine is needed.
And he continues to call on voters who supported him last fall to close ranks anew to build a nationwide grass-roots organization, "United We Stand, America." Its goal, he says, will be to reform government "from the White House to the tiniest local school board."
He has sent out more than two million registration forms and has hired half a dozen or more professional organizers to oversee the project. His aides refuse to disclose how many people have signed up thus far, at a cost of $15 for an annual membership.
"But if this thing doesn't work," Mr. Perot promises, "I'll send your money back."
Now and again on his stops he taunts Mr. Clinton a bit, urging him to provide more details about his economic plan and warning him about the dangers of the national deficit.
"I don't really know what to say about the new Clinton economic plan," he told 2,500 people who packed the Pensacola fairground auditorium to overflowing Thursday night. "The President only laid out the outlines. He needs to give up the details now. And then begins the hard part."
Mostly, however, Mr. Perot talks up his new organization and taunts Congress.
"Our legislators are arrogant," he says. "We've got to organize and reach out and tap them on the shoulder and let them know we're watching. Our numbers are our strength. Together we can slam-dunk it."
Then, much as he did in the fall campaign, he calls for a reduction in the national deficit, a balanced budget, a line-item veto and strict controls on lobbyists.
 
Hammering the Lobbyists
 The loudest cheers usually come when he hammers the lobbyists, calling them "a real cancer on society."
"I can tell you folks this much about Bill Clinton's economic plan," he said in Pensacola. "Over the next few months as the lobbyists try to work it to suit them, they're going to make more money that ever in the history of this country. In 1960, there were 365 of them in Washington. Today there are more than 40,000. That's what we're up against."
While Mr. Perot's appearances have most of the hallmarks of campaign rallies, there are several important elements missing. He seldom moves out into the crowds to shake hands, seldom takes any questions from the press and, except for the membership dues for his new organization, totally skirts the pandering of fund-raising, as only a man of his wealth could afford to do.
"He's just feeling his way along on all of this," said Ed Campbell, one of Mr. Perot's professional organizers. "He wants to stay out in the open, get United We Stand, America up and running and then see what happens."

HEADLINE: Project to Use Reefs to Halt Beach Erosion

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
The State of New Jersey hopes it has found a novel way of taming the coastal storms that have inflicted hundreds of millions of dollars in property damage along its coastline. It is working with a private company to submerge a series of artificial reefs to soften the ocean's assault on Jersey shores.
A reef that cushioned the blow of waves on vulnerable beaches and kept sand from washing away would be a bonanza, not only for its developer but also for taxpayers, who pick up the growing costs of replenishing vulnerable beaches with sand that can vanish with the next major storm. 
 "This new technology is largely untested but if it proves itself it could provide an answer to our erosion problems," said Anthony Mangeri, the hazard mitigation officer for New Jersey, which is on the verge of approving a trial of submerged reefs this summer at three shore towns: Avalon, Belmar and Cape May Point. Official approval of the reef projects from the state is not expected for a week or two.
 
Some Predict Failure
 Anyone who has ever walked into the surf knows why anchoring an underwater reef at the turbulent edge of an ocean is a complicated challenge, and why some people predict that submerged reefs will surely fail, as other solutions have failed in past efforts to protect the beaches.
With each incoming and outgoing wave, swirling water undermines the ground underfoot until the bather settles ankle deep in the shifting sand. Roiling surf works the same way on artificial structures. In a major storm, even a massive reef could be lifted and moved like a toy in a child's wading pool.
A reef that remained stable while absorbing the energy of waves -- much like a speed bump slows down a car -- would be a valuable advance in the search for answers to a coastline under siege from storms like the December northeaster that swept away beaches and sand dunes in New York and New Jersey.
A report released last week by the Federal Emergency Management Agency said it was time to rethink the economics of restoring beaches. The Federal Government alone has poured more than $8 billion into sand replenishment projects conducted by the Army Corps of Engineers in the last two decades, and the states, local communities and the emergency management agency have contributed billions more.
The FEMA report, assembled by investigators drawn from Federal, state, local and private interests, recommended for the first time that New Jersey consider buying some storm-damaged beach properties and taking them out of development.
The recommendation chilled both private and commercial beachfront property owners, who have successfully resisted relinquishing their grip on the shoreline. They want money to go to replenish sand, not to buy their property; they say a state acquisition fund would unfairly deprive them of their property at prices far below market values.
That is where companies like Breakwaters International Inc. come in, touting the economic benefits of submerged reefs. The company, based in Flemington, N.J., is awaiting final approval from New Jersey officials to proceed with the installation this summer of three 1,000-foot-long underwater reefs made of new water-insoluble concrete materials, said Richard Creter, president of Breakwaters. The project would cost $2.1 million to be paid by the state and by the towns of Avalon, Belmar and Cape May Point.
 
The Argument Against
 But many experts share the opinion of Dr. Orrin Pilkey, an authority on shoreline preservation, who argues that no artificial structures have a place on sensitive beaches.
"It looks like more public money down the drain," said D. W. Bennett, director of the American Littoral Society, a New Jersey-based group concerned with the nation's coasts.
"Underwater reefs may work in the short term for a specific beach, but the dynamics of these things is that they eventually steal sand from other beaches somewhere down the line," Mr. Bennett said, arguing that it would be better to buy up beach land to keep it out of development.
At Breakwaters, Mr. Creter shows off a scale model of the reef that he says has been perfected by 10 years of research and trials. An earlier design was used to install a 200-foot-long reef off Oakwood on the north shore of Long Island and another at Sea Isle City near Cape May, N.J.
These earlier generations of reefs, he said, were similar to traditional breakwaters in that their tops broke the surface of the water.
The latest models are designed to be constantly submerged, with the top of the six-foot-high reef at a depth of five feet below the ocean surface at low tide.
A 1,000-foot-long reef would consist of about 100 interlocked units made of microsilica concrete, each weighing 20 tons. Each 12-foot-wide unit, with concrete teeth projecting from a 15-foot base, is intended to be anchored on a thickly woven plastic mat positioned on the sea floor about 250 feet from the shoreline and parallel to it.
"The reef bites into the mat and seats itself into an uneven sand bottom," Mr. Creter said.
The units have a terraced seaward slope designed to absorb a wave's energy as it crosses over it, forcing the wave to curl and break well short of the beach.
The snubbed beachward slope has a fluted surface that funnels a wave's backwash up to a flat peak, where it is jetted toward flumes that propel the sand-filled water toward the surface, to be carried shoreward by the next onrushing wave. The returning sand is deposited at the toe of the reef, preventing it from being underminded, Mr. Creter said.
 
Won't Restore Sand
 He concedes that his reef, by itself, will not restore sand-starved beaches. "But it will protect beaches from normal erosion and at times of severe storms it will keep sand from being washed out into the ocean and lost, thereby reducing expensive replenishment costs in the future," he said.
The beaches for the test projects were selected, he said, because each has natural features that represent different challenges of beach erosion.
Belmar, in Monmouth County, has a headland beach with existing jetties perpendicular to the shore. The beach and boardwalk suffered heavy damage in the December storm.
Avalon, near Atlantic City, hasa barrier-island beach without breakwaters or jetties that has conducted its own beach replenishment projects in the past.
Cape May Point, at the southern end of the 127-mile long coastline, is badly eroded by cross-currents where the ocean and Delaware Bay meet.
 
Florida Experience
 One coastal community that already has extensive experience with underwater reefs is Palm Beach, Fla.
 
Private Money for a Reef
 A 552-foot offshore reef designed by Atlantic Coastal Engineering Inc. of West Palm Beach was installed in front of an eroded private beach in 1988 and the $200,000 cost was paid by the property owner, Willis du Pont.
The beach subsequently grew by 60 feet, according to Nancy S. Douthit, a Town Council member, "and Mr. du Pont believes his personal financing was well spent."
The town eventually received permits by the Florida Department of Natural Resources to install a 4,000-foot reef in front of its public beach. Atlantic Engineering used cranes to put 57 concrete units into the ocean last summer and locked them together before weather forced a postponement of work on the remaining 185 units until this spring.
The 650-foot reef has already paid off over the winter, Ms. Douthit said.
"Out of no beach -- there were waves lapping at the base of a seawall at low tide -- has emerged a good 60 feet of beach at mean high water," she said. "We also have sand at the base of the seawall six feet higher than what it was before."
 
Reservations Expressed
 The state has provided $500,000 to monitor the reef's effectiveness, although reservations have been expressed by officials of the Natural Resources Department.
"All the present structures have problems with inadequate foundations," said Paden Woodruff, a senior engineer in the department's Bureau of Coastal Engineering and Regulation. "But we've gone along with it because if we didn't we would be called closed-minded bureaucrats."
As it will be in the New Jersey tests, the stability of the reef is at issue.
Mr. Woodruff says it took only one storm for the reef to shift.
"It sits on a thin layer of sand and all the natural material under the reef washed away beneath it," he said. "Two months after it was installed our tests found it had settled two to three feet below its functional level."
Ms. Douthit acknowledges that the reef has settled but says it has still been effective.
"Where there had been no beach before there is beach now," she said. "And even after six northeaster storms this winter it keeps growing. That's a pretty bizarre result for a technology that doesn't work."

HEADLINE: ON PRO HOCKEY;
N.H.L.'s Northern Lights Starting to Dim

BYLINE: By Joe Lapointe

 BODY:
While the expanding National Hockey League harvests a $100 million cash crop from the sunny, southern climes of Anaheim, Calif., and Miami, financial fault lines are widening in two places on its northern frontier.
Tremors are being felt in Edmonton, where the model franchise of the 1980's is becoming an embarrassment of the 90's, and in Minnesota, where the revival of two years ago might not be enough to keep the North Stars in one of the most sophisticated hockey markets in the United States. 
 First, Edmonton. Remember how baseball's Kansas City Athletics served as a de facto farm club for the Yankees in the 50's and 60's before they moved to Oakland?
This seems to be the model for the Oilers. They now supply other teams by trading and selling expensive players while their owner threatens to transfer the franchise.
With the season nearing the three-quarter mark, the Oilers, despite a 5-4 victory Thursday night over the champion Penguins in Pittsburgh, were 4 points out of the fourth and final playoff berth in the Smythe Division before Winnipeg's game last night at Vancouver.
If they fail to qualify for the post-season, it will be a first; the Oilers have played in 37 tournament rounds since joining the N.H.L. in 1979-80, when the World Hockey Association went out of business. Without the roughly $250,000 profit from each home playoff game, the owner, Peter Pocklington, speculates, the team will lose $2 million.
He has threatened to move to an undisclosed location unless he gets a better lease deal from Northlands Coliseum or a new building with more luxury suites. Fans who remember teams like the Baltimore Colts and the Brooklyn Dodgers know that such threats aren't always hollow. Pocklington traded Wayne Gretzky. Never say "never."
"It always comes as a great shock to people, but I don't know why," said Bill Tuele, the public relations director for the Oilers, referring to teams that move. "What's surprising about that? You either make it in business or you move."
The business community in Edmonton is taking Pocklington seriously. Gerry Yuen, president of the Northlands Coliseum board, is negotiating with Pocklington to buy the team.
"If we lose the Oilers, Edmonton will suffer from an economic and status point of view," Yuen said in a telephone interview. "Peter knows what we want and we continue to talk. We have the means to put it together. We have the financial backing."
As for their roster, the Oilers show evidence of the tough-mindedness of Glen Sather, their president and general manager. Right wing Joe Murphy tried to win himself a higher salary this season by sitting out. He hasn't played a game and hasn't earned a dollar. Sather didn't return calls seeking comment on the situation, but Tuele explained the Sather philosophy.
"Joe Murphy has one decent season," Tuele said. "Not great, not good, just decent, and he demands a million bucks. See you later, Joe. Have a nice life."
Gary Bettman, the new N.H.L. commissioner, said he talked with Pocklington about his alternatives to relocating.
"There are certain aspects of the Oilers' situation that are difficult for them to operate under," Bettman said, "and Peter Pocklington is working very hard on trying to remedy those situations so that it wouldn't be necessary."
Meanwhile, the Minnesota owner, Norman Green, spent part of last week in Dallas, investigating a possible move to Reunion Arena. After Green purchased the North Stars from the brothers Gordon and George Gund for the 1990-91 season and averted a move to San Jose, Calif., the team reached the Stanley Cup finals.
Despite increased attendance since then, Green insists he lost $10 million last season and will lose $5 million this season. Although the Twin Cities have three hockey arenas of major league quality, Green said none offers "appropriate assurances for the long-term viability of the franchise."
In a high-profile visit, Green toured Dallas with Roger Staubach, the former Cowboys quarterback. (Idle thought: If the North Stars move to Dallas and become the South Stars or the Lone Stars, wouldn't a natural rivalry be with Houston? But if the hockey Oilers move there, they couldn't keep their name because the National Football League franchise already uses it.)
More ominously, Bettman said this week that the league's board of governors has given Green permission to move his team. In seeking a "geographic footprint" for television, the N.H.L. has said it needs Texas to become more attractive to advertisers and networks.
Losing Edmonton would be embarrassing for Canada, but would bring hardly a shrug on Madison Avenue. A Dallas-Houston tandem would be a logical fit, and established organizations could field competitive teams there quickly. What about Minnesota and Edmonton? They could line up for expansion franchises. The N.H.L. has two more to award. All you need is money.

HEADLINE: Real Political Reform Can't Wait

 BODY:
"We must begin again to make Government work for ordinary taxpayers, not simply for organized interest groups and that beginning must start with real political reform," President Clinton said midway through his economic address on Wednesday. "Believe me," he improvised after the applause died down, "they were cheering that last section at home."
The television offered a richly symbolic image at that moment. Visible over the President's left shoulder was the genial face of House Speaker Thomas Foley. It was not possible to tell from his expression what Mr. Foley thought of this remark, but Mr. Foley did seem to be clapping his hands. Now he needs to use them to open up the legislative throttle if the country is to get the campaign finance and lobbying laws that are needed to clean up Congress. 
 So far, Mr. Foley has given theoretical assent to campaign reform, but has made the House calendar a hostage to recalcitrant Democrats who hope that Mr. Clinton's idealism will burn itself out and that public demand for reform will wilt in the summer doldrums.
Mr. Clinton called in his speech for action on campaign finance reform "this year." That may have sounded good to most viewers at home. But it's a clear retreat from his commitment to put the issue at the top of his legislative agenda. In the Congressional lexicon, "this year" could just as well be never, and it is a troubling signal that Mr. Clinton may be swayed by Mr. Foley's private warning that pushing campaign reform will endanger his economic legislation.
It is easy to understand why fund-raising-obsessed House incumbents would want to delay any action to make them less beholden to the special interests that finance their campaigns (see chart). Yet, why Mr. Clinton would go along is baffling, especially given the strong conflicting advice from the Senate majority leader, George Mitchell. Mr. Mitchell has put campaign finance legislation on a fast track in his chamber, with the hope of moving it to the floor for a vote as early as next month.
Just as baffling is Mr. Clinton's warm endorsement of the lame lobbying disclosure bill proposed by Senator Carl Levin of Michigan. In his speech, he called on Congress to pass it "quickly" as a step "to deal with the undue influence of special interests." What Mr. Clinton didn't say, but what every senator and House member well knows, is that the bill doesn't require disclosure of the sort of embarrassing details that might actually shame the typical member to quit mooching off lobbyists for expensive meals and exotic vacations.
Mr. Clinton may be hoping that speedy approval of a flawed lobbying bill would detract attention from the laggard path of campaign finance reform. If the President wants to play this shell game, he should be prepared to be exposed as phony and fainthearted on this issue.
But if Mr. Clinton would level with Americans on political reform, as he has on the economy, he would gain in popularity and respect. The next step is for Mr. Clinton to say how he would toughen the campaign finance bill passed last year by Congress and vetoed by President Bush, and to demand from Congress a firm timetable for getting the legislation to his desk. And the next time he is standing at the lectern in the House, it would not hurt to turn around and tell Mr. Foley to quit clapping and get on with the people's business.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Bill Did Good

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
This column is to praise President Clinton for his stunningly honest and realistic economic speech last week and to point out that leaders abroad are hailing it left and right.
I am very annoyed at myself for attacking the speech for scanting foreign policy issues without first making clear the pride I felt in a President talking to the American people as adults. Who knows if his plan for revitalizing the economy will work, but it was pure pleasure to hear a Presidential address on the economy that seemed to make sense and wasn't riddled with baloney. 
 My colleagues and I, like journalistic Dr. Strangeloves, are ready to nuke Mr. Clinton at the slightest provocation. We ought to let up a little on the 1-month-old President -- or show at least as much patience with him as foreigners do.
Something interesting and important was largely ignored last week as we did our journalistic thing. Foreign leaders and most Americans discovered a supranational common bond: They agree that the American people should suffer, struggle and endure privations for the next four years to atone for the high living of the 80's.
This astounding bond results not from a devious Republican plot to insure President Clinton's defeat after four short years. It is, rather, the product of Mr. Clinton's well-argued call for higher taxes and spending cuts to lower the Federal deficit.
Such harsh medicine is what Americans have been dodging and foreign leaders demanding for years. Americans are now willing to take it because they are frightened and don't see any real alternative. Foreign leaders have long been convinced that there is no alternative, that Americans have to tighten their belts to restore a healthy economy and that a strong American economy is essential to grow the world economy.
All the talk of the 1980's about Germany and Japan emerging as the new engines of world economic growth turned out to be just talk. In their heart of hearts, foreign leaders knew that all along. But they had just about given up hope of any U.S. President having the courage to raise taxes, cut spending and take the lead again.
For years, European and Asian leaders had been saying that the American economy was deathly ill. To get well, they had been telling Presidents Reagan and Bush, the U.S. had to reduce its ballooning deficit. They had just about given up hope that any American President would have the courage to ask his citizens to take such harsh medicine -- until Bill Clinton.
A typical reaction came from Yuji Tanahashi, a senior Japanese trade official. "We think the President's proposal is realistic and aggressive. It showed his firm determination to ease the country's budget deficit and increase industrial competitiveness," he said. "If the U.S. economy recovers through these policies, it will also be good for the world economy."
The French newspaper Le Monde, in spite of itself, was even more effusive. "At the risk of his own popularity," said its editorial, "he attacked the roots of the 'American evil.' "
Financing the U.S. debt has soaked up one trillion dollars in foreign loans in the last 10 years alone. The huge yearly U.S. deficit, more than anything else, increased competition for loans and kept the costs high for borrowing money worldwide. The Clinton plan gives foreigners new hope of borrowing more easily at lower rates -- and thus of stimulating their own economies.
At the same time, foreigners have found something new to worry about. They see that Mr. Clinton is asking American businesses to absorb a variety of new costs and tax burdens, and they fear the companies will come back to the White House and demand trade protection in return -- and that the President, in need of their political support, will heed their cries. In general, foreigners remain very nervous about Mr. Clinton's possible protectionist proclivities.
But most of all, they see in Mr. Clinton's plan a coming to grips with America's underlying economic problems. And they know that the U.S. must get its own economic house in order before it can regain the confidence to lead a new march for freer trade -- the only certain way to create more and better jobs and a renewed sense of hope for a pessimistic world that is turning inward and becoming nasty.

HEADLINE: End Baseball's Privileged Status

 BODY:
To the Sports Editor:
I was distressed to read Clark Griffith's extensive apologia for Major League Baseball's antitrust exemption ("Good Reason for Baseball's Antitrust Exemption," The Times, Jan. 17). In my opinion, it is filled with inaccuracies and faulty judgments that can only mislead fans and public policymakers anxious to rectify the woefully errant course of our national pastime. 
 First, Griffith says baseball does not act like a monopoly, and cites as evidence the fact that "teams in the nonexempt sports leagues charge higher prices for game tickets than does baseball." True enough, basketball and football charge higher prices, but basketball plays half the number of games in arenas with one-fifth the seating capacity as baseball, and football plays one-tenth the number of games. The different ticket prices have to do with the law of supply and demand, not the existence of the exemption.
Second, Griffith suggests that the reason Congress and the Supreme Court have not lifted the exemption is because the exemption is reasonable. In fact, both Congress and the Court have concluded exactly the opposite on several occasions. Their inaction has to do with politics, not with reason.
Third, Griffith says there is nothing unusual about Major League Baseball's legal status, noting that "exemptions from antitrust laws are quite common." He then cites the cases of power, water and gas companies. What Griffith leaves out is the fact that these natural monopolies are then made subject to public rate regulation. The technology of utilities' production (falling average costs) provides justification for this treatment; not so with baseball.
Fourth, Griffith cites the case of the N.F.L.'s Raiders and notes that if the N.F.L. had baseball's exemption, the Raiders would still be in Oakland. Here he is probably right, but it should be noted that the decision of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in this case had to do with the interpretation that football's rule 4.3 was attempting to protect the Rams' monopoly in the Los Angeles area. Thus, the judicial precedent is ambiguous in its applicability to other situations.
Lifting baseball's exemption would not guarantee that the shortage of teams would be rectified, but it would create conditions making it more possible for a competitive league to emerge. Baseball is the only team sport that has not been challenged by a rival league over the last 40 years, and baseball has expanded more slowly than the other sports' leagues. Congress should not only lift the exemption and put an end to "the baseball anomaly," it should pass legislation granting cities the right of first refusal (enabling them to buy a team before it is allowed to move) and establishing an expansion timetable.
If the political winds in Washington judge this to be excessively interventionist, then Congress can break baseball's four divisions into separate business entities, allowing the entities to collaborate on playing rules and post-season play but not on setting territorial monpolies, television contracts or collective bargaining.
The gains from such a public policy shift would be obvious and far-reaching: cities would receive a fairer treatment; fans would have more access to viewing games at the ballpark and on television; more opportunities for playing professional baseball would emerge; the quality of play would not perceptibly diminish but games would be more exciting as star players once again would begin to challenge longstanding single season performance records; and, competitive pressure would force owners to be more responsive and efficient in the management of their teams.
ANDREW ZIMBALIST
Northampton, Mass.
 
The writer is a professor of economics at Smith College in Northampton, Mass., and the author of "Baseball and Billions" (Basic Books, 1992).

HEADLINE: In Defense of Mr. Gaidar

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Vladimir Kvint ("A Healthy Realism for the Russians," Viewpoints, Jan. 24) is both rude and wrong in his evaluation of Yegor T. Gaidar, the economic reformer and former Prime Minister of Russia. 
True, Mr. Gaidar had no experience in the bankrupt Communist world of Soviet industry. But since that system of centralized planning led to the corruption of many otherwise honest people who worked in it, and to the economy's collapse, it is to Mr. Gaidar's credit that he avoided it.
But, more important, Mr. Kvint is 100 percent off the mark to argue that Mr. Gaidar knew no economics until he became Prime Minister. Mr. Gaidar spent many years studying both economic theory and the practice of stabilization and monetary policy around the world. His understanding of the economics necessary to turn his country around was subtle, sophisticated and for the most part correct. The failures of Russian economic reform lie at the feet of those, like Mr. Kvint, who would argue for unlimited inflationary subsidies to the dinosaurs of Soviet socialist state industry.
 
THOMAS J. RICHARDSON
New Haven, Jan. 26
 
The author is an assistant professor in the department of economics at Yale University.

HEADLINE: The Far Side of the Gas Tax

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Mr. Schipper wants the American public to accept a gasoline price of $3.15 a gallon, a price boosted that high by a vastly increased Federal motor fuel tax. 
 It will be a tough sell. And the real costs of such a move would be retarded economic activity, a rise in unemployment and aggravated inflation.
The fact that Europeans are more heavily taxed at the pump should have little bearing on United States tax policy. Europe is an irrelevant model. High gasoline taxes were imposed there when cars were considered luxuries, and even today the per-capita car ownership rate is far lower than in the United States. No one argues that Americans should pay higher income taxes because Europeans do. Why should gasoline be the exception?
Our economy and way of life benefit from our mobility. It should not be cavalierly constrained without a clear understanding of the consequences.
 
ANDY YOOD
Washington, Feb.3
 
The author is taxation director of the American Petroleum Institute.

HEADLINE: A COLD WAR ICON COMES UNDER SIEGE

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, two icons of the cold war, are to be shut down under President Clinton's deficit-reduction plan, according to Administration officials and officials with the two broadcasting operations.
Among the cuts outlined in the President's economic plan are a $60 million savings in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1 and $644 million savings over five years for the Board for International Broadcasting, which oversees the foreign-language broadcasts. 
 Officials with the Office of Management and the Budget and the chairman of the Board for International Broadcasting say these cuts would be accomplished by merging Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty into the United States Information Agency. The officials said such a consolidation would mean shutting down the two services in 1995 and letting more than 1,600 employees go. Most are based in Munich.
 
Lobbying Is Planned
 Officials of the Board for International Broadcasting say they intend to lobby Congress to have their funds restored, arguing that despite the end of the cold war, the two operations have not lost their relevence.
"What you have is a budget document that is calling for these savings," said Malcolm S. Forbes Jr., board chairman. "But I think these proposals have not been thought through or carefully weighed by the President's foreign policy team, and certainly not by the Congress."
Mr. Forbes is hoping that support in Congress, particularly from Senator Joseph R. Biden, Democrat of Delaware, who has been a staunch advocate for the radio operations, will lead to the restoration of the cuts. Foreign-language broadcasting, Mr. Forbes said, "is the cheapest, most effective way of influencing events in other countries on a daily basis."
But a Congressional aide involved in overseeing the budget said that given the questions about the broadasts' relevence after the demise of Communism, and the pressure to approve spending cuts and painful tax increases as part of the President's package, he doubted there was sufficient political support on Capital Hill.
 
Begun During Cold War
 "If the only spending-cut vote that members would have to take was Radio Free Europe-Radio Liberty, they would feel they got off very lightly," said the Congressional aide, who asked not to be identified.
Begun during the cold war, using funds from the Central Intelligence Agency, the two stations broadcast local news in 24 languages to the Eastern bloc and the former Soviet Union. Radio Free Europe, which began in 1951, broadcasts to Eastern Europe, with the exception of the former Yugoslavia. Radio Liberty, started in 1953, broadcasts to the former Soviet republics and to Afghanistan.
Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty are separate from the Voice of America, a worldwide service that broadcasts general news, music, features and commentary.
The Clinton economic plan does not envision any special trims in the current operations at Voice of America, but it does eliminate plans for a $1 billion relay station planned for the Negev, in Israel. The Negev station, which would cover 2,000 acres, has been vigorously opposed by environmentalists, who say that the installation would disturb a delicate desert ecology and that radio waves would disorient migrating birds.
The plan does allocate $125 million for a relay station in Kuwait to carry V.O.A. broadcasts in Arabic.
There are no specific spending cuts planned for Radio Marti or TV Marti, two Spanish-language outlets broadcasting to Cuba.
The proposal to eliminate Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty is the latest thrust in the back-and-forth debate over maintaining the services in a new technological and political era.
 
Hard Look by Congress
 In December 1991, a Presidential panel recommended that Radio Free Euorpe and Radio Liberty have their roles redefined, rather than curtailed. But last August a different Presidential commission recommended phasing out the services. Congressional aides say that even if Mr. Clinton had not put forward a plan to eliminate the stations, Congress would have taken a hard look at the need for continuing them.
Advocates of curtailing the services say that they are less needed now, with Communism on the wane, and that commercial operations like Cable News Network are making inroads into the former Soviet bloc, ending the need for government-backed broadcasting.
But supporters counter that while Communism is receding, democracy has yet to take root. They note that in some countries, like Slovakia, the state maintains tight control over the news. They also say the economies of many countries are not developed enough to make private broadcasting commercially viable.
"Communism may have lost, but democracy has not yet won," Mr. Forbes said.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 24, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about plans to eliminate Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty misstated the cost of constructing a radio transmitter in Israel. The amount appropriated by Congress is $255.4 million, not $1 billion.

HEADLINE: Can Tourists Learn to Tread Lightly?

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN; TIMOTHY EGAN is chief of the Seattle bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
EVERY year, thousands of people pay up to $5,000 a week for the right to snap pictures of Kodiak brown bears on their home turf, savagely beautiful Kodiak Island in the Gulf of Alaska. The problem, from the bears' point of view, is that there are not a lot of places left in the world where they can gulp huge quantities of king salmon without human interference. If too many spectators line the swollen rivers of the island, the bears will start to change their behavior, maybe even directing their appetite toward tourists.
That is the conundrum facing modern tourism in distant and unscarred lands. More and more, people who travel are clamoring for places where the culture is untouched by MTV, and the land is yet to be burdened with warehouse shopping centers. But visitors can change the character of a place. 
 To cope with what many see as a major threat to the future of tourism -- the loving-a-place-to-death syndrome -- the industry has begun to form some guiding principles for the broad area of travel known as ecotourism. While the term may smack of trendy environmental correctness, it has found its way into the mainstream. The World Wildife Fund defines ecotourism as "any kind of tourism that involves nature." The travel industry has used the term to encompass everything from cruise ships in the Caribbean to East African photography expeditions. According to one industry estimate, the market for ecotourism is more than 43 million Americans.
At the same time, there is an emerging consensus that the travel trade should practice "sustainable tourism" -- basically, that visits to a given area should be limited to a number of people that will not have a detrimental effect on it. The idea is that a tropical island beach hike, or a visit to a Mayan temple in Mexico, should be around for future generations in much the same form as it is today. Like other types of conservation, this model draws a line at growth, a painful thought to many operators in an expanding business.
Yet to do nothing but allow more feet to stomp over the thinning dust of the world's unique places is to invite economic and environmental trouble, tourism experts say.
"We know we can't sell a place if it doesn't look good," said Shawn Flaherty, a spokeswoman for the Travel Industry Association of America, the nation's largest tourism trade group. The organization last year released a report on ecotourism, based in part on a survey showing an overwhelming number of those polled are concerned about humanity's threat to its best-loved places. It was this report that estimated the market for ecotourism at 43 million Americans.
"The report's message is clear: the travel industry must become more green because the environment is our chief product, our livelihood," said Edward R. Book, the association's president.
The central irony that more travel reduces the allure of a place predates late-20th century concerns about habitat loss and cultural interference, of course. Amid all the imperial superlatives in 19th-century British travel journals was a smattering of discussion about what the tea-drinking citizens of the Empire were doing to East African wildlife and Egyptian monuments. Late in life, Paul Gauguin lamented that the Tahiti he had helped idealize in his paintings was starting to fade in the light of an oncoming 20th century. So many souvenir-seekers chiseled away at the unique rock formations of Yellowstone that early laws had to be passed protecting the park from its fans.
With the growth of air travel, the world became smaller, virtually overnight. The National Geographic would no sooner discover a "lost tribe" in some remote corner of the globe than enterprising travel companies would begin offering package tours to visit the unspoiled inhabitants. And when indigenous people change their economy from, say, fishing to selling trinkets, both sides may be worse off, ecotourism proponents say.
In the modern era, Americans conquered Mount Everest in 1962, and were followed within 15 years by expeditions to the highest spot on the planet for the purpose of picking up garbage left behind by mountain climbers. Everest, like other points that pierce the ceiling of the atmosphere, is no longer lonely. Witness the trekking phenomenon to the Himalayas, which has led to a stripping of high-alpine forests and shrubs for fuel, and drastically changed village life.
But no amount of handwringing about uncaring crowds and foothills of litter has really lessened the urge of people to travel, and especially to untrammeled places. Many economists believe that tourism will be the number one industry, worldwide, by the year 2000. In the United States, it is the second largest single source of jobs -- about 6.4 million -- generating $344 billion in revenue last year, according to the travel association's figures.
Given the seeming inevitability of growth, what some people in the industry are trying to do is change the way tourists venture out. To a considerable degree, that has already happened with the astonishing growth of what is known as adventure travel.
In general, the major tourism interests have shied away from such measures as outright restrictions on visitors or placing vulnerable areas off-limits. They call on tour groups to educate clients about abuse of the land and culture they visit, to promote environmental awareness and to contribute financially to causes that will keep the scenery intact. But there seems to be a general awareness in the industry that if the travel industry does not take steps to curb its potential for abuse, outsiders in government or elsewhere will do it for them.
To cope with waves of visitors, the government of Ecuador imposed a limit of 10,000 visitors a year to the Galapagos Islands, a national park known for its odd creatures stuck in an evolutionary time warp. Adventure travel magazines are full of ads for visits "with a biologist" to the islands. But enforcement of the crowd limit has been weak, and more than 45,000 visitors a year have been allowed on the island, according to some Ecuadorean estimates.
"Ecuador is faced with these two realities: so much to offer and so much to defend and protect," said Oswaldo Munoz, of the Ecuadorean Ecotourism Association, in a recent address in Canada.
To many environmentalists, the steps the industry has considered taking are timid.
"I don't think the mainstream travel industry people understand it yet," said Jerry Mallett, president of the Adventure Travel Society, which represents nature-based tourism operators. "Things may have to be regulated, worldwide, or we face a crisis. The national parks understand this. The guide operators understand this. But it may not be clear to everyone else yet."
Mr. Mallet said the market for travel based on natural or cultural resources has increased dramatically in the last 10 years. There are nearly 9,000 adventure-travel outfitters in the country, according to the society, specializing in everything from wilderness horseback trips to bungee-jumping from dramatic cliffs. Whale-watching, swimming with dolphins, catch-and-release fishing, llama trekking, rain forest canoe trips -- all these activities are showing up in brochures, along with such mainstays as beach and skiing vacations.
One of the biggest growth areas -- and a major challenge to operators who want to steer clear of cultural interference -- is travel to visit aboriginal people, said Mr. Mallett. "If you can go to these places with a local guide, a storyteller, somebody who crosses the two worlds, you can avoid a lot of the problems," he said.
In the United States, many Indian reservations have long agonized over how much they should play up native rituals and dances for tourists. In parts of Montana and the Southwest, Indian powwows and craft festivals are major money-makers during the vital summer season. The struggle, say native leaders, is to maintain authenticity and integrity in the face of demand for what tourists want. Some tribes, such as the Blackfoot Indians of Montana, have decided to use their promixity to a national park -- in this case Glacier -- and fully market the crafts and customs unique to their tribe. The same thing is true among Hopi and Navajo entrepreneurs in the Southwest. It may look crass to some purists, but the alternative is poverty, the Indians argue.
A cursory tour of some of the world's more fragile places shows that the tensions brought on by travel have become a primary concern around the globe.
In Costa Rica, as in Ecuador, nature-based travel is the fast-growing segment of the tourism industry. The small Central American nation has an excellent national park system, and has won high marks for how it manages its rain forests. But it may be reaching its tourism saturation point, according to some operators -- the nation of 3 million people had 500,000 visitors last year. Officials in Costa Rica are taking steps to limit visits to some rain forest reserves.
British Columbia, home of a fast-disappearing temperate rain forest, turquoise glacial lakes and fjords crowded with killer whales, has been trying to market itself as an ecotourist's paradise, under the slogan: Super, Natural British Columbia. But the new image is in conflict with some of the old industries of the province, particularly logging, which has stripped most of the ancient trees from Vancouver Island, and mining, which has spoiled a number of waterways. In addition, quaint old Victoria, the capital of British Columbia, does not use secondary treatment for its sewage -- as virtually all major American cities are required to do -- flushing several thousand tons of waste water into the Strait of Juan de Fuca every day.
"We have a real conflict," said Darlene Marzari, the Minister of Tourism for British Columbia. "Ecotourism is probably the most important growth industry in B.C. Our niche in the world market is to be known as fresh, clean and green." She said the new National Democratic Party government of the province was planning to double the number of parks, to cut back on excessive logging and to push for secondary treatment of the sewage in Victoria.
The United States gave the world its first national park more than a century ago with the creation of Yellowstone. But today, environmentalists say one of the biggest threats to the park system is overcrowding, particularly in automobiles. In 1991, 267 million people stopped in the parks, a record. There is a reservation system for camping in Yosemite, Grand Canyon, Yellowstone and other popular parks. Yosemite limits the number of cars to the valley to 5,000 a day. Now, there is a call for restricting the number of visitors -- not just vehicles -- to certain parks.
The national parks have been models of sorts in confronting the problem of overuse. The bears of Yellowstone used to be garbage-eating scavengers, hooked on discarded Twinkies and wiener wrappers. More than a decade ago, park biologists, worried that Yellowstone was becoming a kind of Rocky Mountain theme park, made the bears go cold turkey, separating them from campers. It has been a rousing success, the officials say. Now Yellowstone has a thriving bear population that feeds on what it has always fed on -- berries, insects and occasional small animals.
ECOTOURISM advocates would like to see much of the world adopt the attitude of New Zealand, which has for more than a decade practiced the concept of sustainable tourism. The number of visitors to some areas is restricted. Strict environmental standards are applied to new developments. Tour operators must agree to abide by certain stewardship principles. Visitors are encouraged to stay longer and spread their money around to more places, rather than clustering in a few large resort areas. The Mexican beach community of Cancun, the overcrowded Greek islands and high-rise resorts in Hawaii are held up as something to avoid -- the old model. The effort has met with some resistance among private tour operators, but New Zealand officials say they are trying to insure the country's natural wonders will be around for future generations.
In essence, preservation for tomorrow is what drives most of the discussion about a kinder and gentler tourism. The initial reaction of many visitors to, say, the chasm of Grand Canyon is awe. After that, there is a sense of protection. The canyon, like most natural attractions, belongs to all the world. What the disciples of ecotourism hope to do is build on the more altruistic attitudes of travelers, arguing that it is in the best interest of the soon-to-be dominant global industry to tread lightly.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Economic Opus: A Thousand Lines of Type

 BODY:
The Highlights
President Clinton proposed an ambitious plan to remake the American economy, raising taxes on energy, business and the rich, making deep cuts in the military, the Federal bureaucracy and health care payments, and trimming the budget deficit. As Republicans dug in their heels, Mr. Clinton and his aides began a cross-country campaign to sell the program to the American people.
DEFICIT REDUCTION
Over the next four years, the plan would have the Government take in $246 billion in new taxes and spend $247 billion less than planned in present budgets. It would increase other spending on "stimulus and investment" by $169 billion. The net reduction in the deficit over those four years would be $325 billion. But deficit reduction would not begin until next year, because an extra $30 billion would be spent this year to stimulate the economy. (1) (see The Fine Print at right) 
TAX INCREASES
Personal
Rates: The top marginal income tax rate, now 31 percent, would be raised to 36 percent for couples with a taxable income of $140,000, single heads of household with a taxable income of $127,000 and individuals with a taxable income of $115,000. A taxable income of $140,000 is the equivalent of adjusted gross income of about $180,000. (2)
 
Surtax: A 10 percent surtax would be placed on taxable incomes above $250,000. (3)
 
Captial gains: The top tax rate would remain at 28 percent.
 
Medicare tax: Wealthy individuals would have to pay Medicare tax on all their earned income, not just the first $135,000.
 
Social Security:Retired couples with incomes above $32,000 and individuals with incomes above $25,000 would pay income taxes on 85 percent of their Social Security benefits, up from 50 percent.
 
Energy tax: A tax on most forms of energy would eventually raise families' annual combined bills for gasoline, home heat and electricity by between $100 and $150. (4)
 
Business
Rates: The top corporate tax rate, now 34 percent, would be raised to 36 percent on companies with taxable incomes of more than $10 million - about one-tenth of 1 percent of American companies.
 
Deductions limited: Only 50 percent of the cost of business meals and entertainment could be deducted, down from 80 percent.
 
Deductions lost: Lobbying expenses and club dues would no longer be deductible. Businesses would be denied deductions for executives' pay above $1 million a year. (5)
 
Credits Lost: The 100 percent credit for wages paid to workers in Puerto Rico would be reduced to 65 percent.
 
Portfolios: Securities dealers would be required to price their holdings at market value.
 
Multinationals: Taxes would be raised for some multinational and foreign companies doing business in the United States.
 
Users fees: Fees would rise or be imposed for many Government services, including grazing or mining on Federal lands, recreation in national parks and forests, use of inland waterways and registration of airplanes.
 
TAX CUTS
Personal
Virtually all families with incomes below $30,000 would get earned-income tax credits.
 
Business
Capital gains: A special capital gains break would be given for investments in small businesses held at least five years.
 
Investment credits: Small businesses would get a generous investment tax credit for the purchase of new equipment.
 
Real estate: Write-offs of losses from real estate investments would be made more generous for taxpayers in the real estate business.
 
Charity: Taxpayers who make gifts to charitable organizations like museums would be permitted to take deductions for market value, not purchase price.
 
IMMEDIATE ECONOMIC STIMULUS
More would be spent this year on construction projects, summer jobs, wastewater clean-up, childhood immunization and other programs.
 
FUTURE SPENDING INCREASES
More would be spent on research into nuclear fusion and renewable energy and on making buildings more energy efficient.
 
A program to let students pay off colege loans through national service would be created.
 
More money would go to worker training and Head Start.
 
More community-development grants and tax incentives for businesses and housing in poor areas would be offered.
 
The Government would help pay for a fiber-optic data network.
More would be spent on mass transit, high-speed rail, airports and highways.
 
SPENDING CUTS
Military spending would be reduced over the next four years by $76 billion more than President Bush planned, mostly by paring 200,000 more troops and most Star Wars spending.
 
New limits would be placed on some payments to doctors, hospital and laboratories under Medicare and Medicaid.
 
Federal workers would have their pay frozen for one year. About 100,000 Federal jobs would be eliminated through attrition.
 
Spending for the space station and the superconducting super collider would be reduced.
 
Loans for veterans housing would cost more, and veterans would pay part of G.I. Bill benefits.
 
To cut interest costs, the maturity of some Treasury securities would be shortened.
 
Scores of other Government programs would be eliminated or timmed back.
 
(The Fine Print)
 
(1) Shifting the Blame
In its first two years, Mr. Clinton's plan to reduce the deficit relies mostly on tax increases, not on spending cuts, which are probably even more difficult to get through Congress. In 1994, spending cuts would amount to only $5 billion, while additional taxes would bring in $33 billion. Then the cuts accelerate. By 1997, after another round of Congressional elections, they would climb to $73 billion, while taxes would bring in $68 billion.
 
(2) Who's Middle Class?
The Administration says 70 percent of the tax increases would be paid by those with pre-tax incomes over $100,000. It calculates that taxpayers with incomes over $200,000 would see their taxes rise by about 3 percent. Those with incomes between $30,000 and $200,000 would see increase of up to 1 percent. Those below $30,000 would get no increase.
 
(3) Politically Graceful
With the surfax, the top marginal tax rate for Americans earning at least $250,000 in taxable income would amount to 39.6 percent. The White House chose to phrase it as a "10 percent millionaire's surfax " - more politically palatable than asking for a rate of nearly 40 percent.
 
(4)So What's a B.T.U.
The energy tax is based on the B.T.U. content of different fuels. (It's British Thermal Units, not Buy Thermal Underwear). As a common denominator, it's easier to use than calculating barrels vs. tons vs. cubic feet vs. kilowatts. It also makes more sense than taxing fuels simply on what they cost: $100 worth of coal, for example, contains far more unreleased heat (measured in B.T.U.'s) than $100 worth of natural gas or $100 worth of gasoline. And a B.T.U. tax also would not penalize states that use one fuel instead of another.
 
To discourage dependence on imported oil, oil would be taxed at 60 cents per million B.T.U.'s, whether it's refined into gasoline or jet fuel or burned to make electricity. Coal, natural gas and nuclear power would be taxed at 26 cents per million B.T.U.'s.
 
Solar, geothermal, wind and other renewable sources would not be taxed. Oil used to make things like plastics, chemicals and tires would not be taxed.
 
The tax climbs very rapidly. It is expected to take in only $1.5 billion next year, but $25 billion by 1997. Within 4 years, it is expected to add 7.5 cents to the cost of a gallon of gas and $2.25 to the average electric bill.
 
(5) The Executive Loophole
Exceptions could be made for salaries tied to the company's performance; the Treasury has not defined them yet. Many executive pay packages are now tied to some measure of performance.

HEADLINE: Helping the Retarded Help Themselves

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
SUPPORT, not supervision, is the watchword of the Community Living Corporation in Mount Kisco, an agency that maintains 3 group homes and 20 apartments for 100 people with developmental disabilities.
The concept that mentally retarded people can successfully live in the community if they receive some support was radical in 1966 when the first community-residence program was started, said John J. Signorelli, the executive director of the nonprofit agency. 
 "In those days, families had no choice, no alternative," Mr. Signorelli said. "Either mentally retarded family members were kept at home or they were put into a state institution. It had been the practice for 50 years until Judith and Maurice Mezoff, a social worker and a psychologist, decided there was a better way."
And so did many middle-class parents with mentally retarded children who joined forces with the Mezoffs, under the title Mezoff Associates, to establish the first supportive group home.
A supportive environment is one in which people with developmental disabilities are given help only when needed and are not under constant supervision.
 
Expansion Started in 1990
 "There is a world of difference between support and supervision," Mr. Signorelli said. "In the days when the accepted professional wisdom was that the mentally retarded would always need supervision and would never be able or allowed to live on their own without it, the Mezoffs believed that people with developmental difficulties would be better off if they were allowed to do as much as they were capable of doing for themselves."
In New York State, 150,000 people are classified as having developmental disabilities: cerebral palsy, autism and mental retardation, Mr. Signorelli said. "In terms of improving the quality of life for them, the Mezoff concept has proved so successful that today it has been replicated by many other agencies," he said.
 
Day-to-Day Assistance
 In 1990 when illness forced the Mezoffs to retire, Mr. Signorelli, a clinical social worker and the former director of an agency for handicapped children and adults, was recruited to convert Mezoff Associates to the Community Living Corporation.
"We also started an expansion program at that time," he said. "From one group home and a few apartments, we've grown to 3 group homes and 20 live-in apartments, with 1 to 4 people living in each apartment unit."
The residents of the group homes and apartments are given the support they need in day-to-day living, Mr. Signorelli said, including such things as shopping for food, making out menus and opening bank accounts. "All of them are employed," he said.
"Some work in sheltered workshops, others in supportive employment positions and a variety of outside jobs in nursing homes, in the food industry or in retail stores as stock clerks," he added. "In doing so, they are no longer economically dependent but have joined the mainstream, buying goods and services and paying taxes just like everybody else."
About a year ago, the agency came up with the concept of starting a for-profit business with a threefold purpose, Mr. Signorelli said. To provide transportation for its clients, it would give some of them the opportunity to work and it would raise money for the benefit of the clients.
Enter Jeffrey L. Biever, a banker with 17 years' experience who felt it was time for him to leave his career in banking for "something entrepreneurial with social values."
"I had met John Signorelli through business and we exchanged ideas," Mr. Biever said, "and I thought that the concept he had for a specialized transportation company for Community Living was something I'd like to develop."
In January 1992, C.L.C. Transportation, a wholly owned for-profit subsidiary of the Community Living Corporation, was started, with Mr. Biever as president.
"We began with one van, bought partially with my personal loan and partially through dealer financing," Mr. Biever said. "It took the place of taxis in taking our C.L.C. clients to doctors' appointments and work programs."
 
'The Van Is Such a Boon'
 Ann A. McDonald, the mother of two children with mental retardation, is the executive director of the nonprofit C.L.C. Foundation, the fund-raising, development and management arm of the Community Living Corporation.
"The van is such a boon," Mrs. McDonald said. "No one knows better than I do the need for courteous, dependable and safe transportation for people with developmental difficulties. I've done my time with cabs that never arrive and with drivers who are indifferent to the needs of their passengers."
Community Living, she continued, has experienced all the same problems and frustrations transporting its Medicaid clients to day-treatment and medical appointments.
"So the transportation company grew out of a real need and also a conviction that who would be better equipped to handle special passengers than we were?" Mrs. McDonald said. Mr. Biever thinks of it as a transportation company with a third dimension.
"And that is sensitivity, which is extremely important when you are dealing with passengers who have special problems," he said. "We stress it in every aspect, especially in hiring drivers. All are experienced drivers. Some have worked with disabled people before, but still we require them to take a two-day course in sensitivity training and emergency medical procedures."
The company has grown in a year to the break-even point, Mr. Biever said, and is now operating six vans, all of them equipped with mobile phones and first-aid kits, and driven by drivers holding commercial licenses.
"It is great to have a business that gives us an opportunity to offer employment to some of our own," Mr. Signorelli said. "Jobs are so important. Some of our clients prep the vans; others work as aides on them, assisting physically handicapped passengers and scheduling pickups and being useful to the driver."
Aides earn a beginning wage of $4.25 an hour, which can increase, based on merit, to $7.
 
An Outside Contract Added
 Thomas Murphy, one of the aides, is 32 and lives in a supportive apartment in Mount Kisco. "I love my job," Mr. Murphy said. "I make sure that all the clients are wearing their seat belts. I double-check to see they all take their lunches when they leave the van. I also help physically handicapped people get on and off. I like earning money because now I'm able to pay toward my rent. I also have a bank account, and every other week I put money into it. I love working. I'd like to do more of it."
Mr. Murphy and the other aides may get their wish. The transportation company recently obtained its first outside contract: transporting outpatients to Phelps Memorial Hospital Center in North Tarrytown. This Wednesday, the service will begin in the Croton area, said Nancy McPartlin, a Phelps spokeswoman.
"We're very excited about it," she said. "We're starting with seniors who need outpatient transportation to the hospital, who previously had to use taxis and buses, which are catch-as-catch-can and a cause for anxiety."
 
An Eye on More Hospitals
 The service is a boon for hospitals, Ms. McPartlin said. "Having reliable and caring people transporting outpatients is so important to us that we thought of doing it on our own," she said. "But it was too expensive a proposition."
Eventually, Mr. Biever said, he expects to have a fairly large transportation company serving several hospitals and agencies.
Those interested in learning more about C.L.C. Transportation can call Mr. Biever at 241-0112.
