HEADLINE: The Battle to Keep Retail Dollars at Home

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
THEY are a loyal group of cus tomers followers of the latest fashion trends with dollars to spend. Typical is Julia Yodice of Ardsley, a former account executive for a cosmetics company and now a homemaker. "In my heart of hearts," she said while shopping the Presidents' Day sales last weekend, "I'm a true-blue Bloomie's customer who just loves this place; they have everything I need."
For Mrs. Yodice and other customers who regularly scan the aisles of Bloomingdale's here, the chain is about to build a larger playground. 
 "Bigger can only be better," said Carl Kaffeman, an investment broker from Ossining who was also shopping in the White Plains Bloomingdale's last weekend.
 
Responding to Competition
 The chain, overstocked and underfinanced several years ago, emerged from Chapter 11 protection of the bankruptcy law last year and is planning to expand the 262,000-square-foot mirrored-glass building that was built 18 years ago on the grounds of New York Hospital.
Bloomingdale's also wants to develop a mall at the site and bring in smaller stops and another major retailer, said Carol A. Sanger, a vice president of corporate affairs for Federated Department Stores of Cincinnati, Bloomingdale's parent company.
Spokesmen said the store was responding to competition -- an all-out battle for middle- and upper-income retail dollars -- along a tree-lined stretch of Bloomingdale Road, which until recently had resisted further growth.
Dotted with several upscale department stores, hotels and office buildings, Bloomingdale Road has attracted loyal suburban shoppers over the years to the lunchrooms, cosmetic counters and designer boutiques of Saks Fifth Avenue and Neiman Marcus as well as Bloomingdale's.
But what had been seen by many residents as a charming, low-key area in which to shop has recently been viewed by developers as a golden opportunity.
Early this year, the Manhattan-based O'Connor Group, a real estate investment firm, broke ground at the corner of Maple Avenue and Bloomingdale Road for a million-square-foot mall. The Westchester, as it will be called, is to include Neiman Marcus, 150 smaller stores and the first Nordstrom store in the state.
The goal, said William J. McCollum, senior vice president for the O'Connor Group, is to build a mall that will compete with malls in Connecticut and New Jersey. He said that shoppers looking for a higher concentration of upscale stores than is now available in the county often travel to New York City or to Bergen County in New Jersey or Danbury Fair and Stamford Town Center.
Another builder, the Conroy Development Company of Greenwich, has also announced plans to develop retail property here. The company plans to renovate Saks Fifth Avenue, across the street from Neiman Marcus, and add more shops.
Janet Wilcox, manager of the Bloomingdale's store in White Plains, said: "We are certainly aware of what's going on down the street. Clearly, we have to meet the competition."
The fight for retail dollars is also heating up in other parts of this city, although different markets are being targeted. The Galleria, in downtown White Plains, last year announced that it would spend $8 million to renovate the 880,000-square-foot enclosed mall, which offers moderately priced merchandise.
Another mall, the Westchester Pavilion, at South Broadway and Maple Avenue, plans to open discount stores like Toys 'R' Us this fall.
While developers along Bloomingdale Road said they are confident that their plans to bring upscale stores like Talbots, Abercrombie & Fitch, Gucci and others to White Plains would be a retailing success, some analysts are skeptical.
 
Two Ends of the Spectrum
 The question, the analysts said, is whether opening expensive stores makes sense at a time when the county is struggling to emerge from a recession and when job layoffs continue in many large corporations.
They said expansion plans along Bloomingdale Road follow last year's closings of two department stores in other parts of the county -- Macy's in New Rochelle and Alexander's in Yonkers -- along with the demise of B. Altman & Company in White Plains several years ago.
Another troubling aspect, analysts said, are figures showing that the number of retail jobs in the county at the end of last year -- 57,700 -- was the lowest for a December since 1976. "It's not to say these more upscale projects can't succeed, but they will have to stay on their toes," said Frank M. Surdey, a regional economist for the State Department of Labor. "This economy is still not healthy."
Analysts also point to trends that suggest that deep discounting -- rather than high-end marketing -- is the wave of the future in the county.
"It's two ends of the spectrum," said Noreen L. Preston, an economist with the county's Office of Economic Development. "Here we have all this activity at the upper end and also we have very strong indications that the warehouse stores -- the no-frills, buy-in-bulk outfits -- are the way to go."
Many of the discount stores, like Filene's Basement and the Burlington Coat Factory Warehouse, are in strip malls along Central Avenue, which runs south from White Plains through the middle of the county to Yonkers.
But Keith J. Foxe, an industry spokesman for the Manhattan-based International Council of Shopping Centers, said it is not an either-or situation. Consumers, he said, are cross-shopping these days.
"Conventional wisdom would indicate that the deep discounter is the way to go in this economy," Mr. Foxe said. "But that's not necessarily the case. Shoppers will buy discount for one item and then pay full price for another kind of purchase."
 
Household Incomes Studied
 He said that Westchester "was like no other county in the nation in terms of population density, per capita income and general demographics that included strong upper- and lower-income shopping activity" and that there was room for both types of retail development.
Federated Department Stores, the O'Connor Group and the Conroy Development Company are basing their high-end marketing plans on statistics that show, for example, a median household income of $120,000 in Scarsdale and $104,822 in North Castle in 1989, the last year for which figures are available, said Vincent J. Pasquale, director of research for the County Department of Planning.
The median household income countywide was $48,405, which took into account cities like Port Chester, where it was $35,216, and Mount Vernon, $34,850.
Westchester -- where 25 percent of the population has household incomes of more than $75,000 and 15 percent has more than $100,000 -- is an "under-stored market that has room for everybody," said Thomas J. Spitznas, a Mount Vernon economist who specializes in regional forecasting.
"The retail sector is finally catching up in Westchester," he said. "There is purchasing power out there to support this development, and if we don't grab it, it is going to continue to fly right out of the county."
 
Countering the Sales-Tax Crunch
 County officials, who have watched sales-tax receipts flatten during the recession, said they welcomed the upturn in retail development.
"The recession and recent department store closings have created a sales-tax crunch," said Stephen V. Reitano, the county's Commissioner of Finance. Westchester's 1.5 percent sales-tax rate is expected to generate 15 percent of the county's $170 million budget this year.
"We need this retail activity to keep the sales tax modest," Mr. Reitano said.
The O'Connor Group said it plans to open The Westchester mall next year. It has signed up Talbots, Talbots Kids, Williams-Sonoma, Pea in the Pod and the Museum Company, among others, said John E. Phelan, executive director of the company. The firm is also negotiating with Polo/Ralph Lauren, Ann Taylor and Liz Claiborne, he said.
Plans for Westchester Place, which include modernizing the Saks Fifth Avenue store here, are being completed, said Alexius C. Conroy, president of the Conroy Development Company. The proposal includes 100 higher-end stores, he said.
 
A Good Christmas Reported
 For Bloomingdale's, the expansion plans come at a good time, said Ms. Sanger of Federated Department Stores. Earnings were up last year for Federated's 222 stores, which include Abraham & Straus, Bon Marche, Burdines, Jordan Marsh, Stern's and Bloomingdale's, among others.
No earnings figures were released for the White Plains store, although Miss Wilcox, the manager, said: "This has been a very good store for Bloomingdale's. Even with the tough economic times, we had an excellent Christmas."
The chain, in addition to building its two-story, 40,000-square-foot addition to the store here, is negotiating with New York Hospital, from which it leases the land, to develop 100,000 square feet for small retail shops and another 120,000 square feet for a co-anchor store. No timetable has been announced for the development.
At least one shopper at Bloomingdale's last week said she wondered whether matters were getting out of hand.
"More is not necessarily better," said Margaret DiPace, a banker from Mamaroneck. "Bloomingdale's shoppers are going to shop Bloomingdale's, no matter what. The store shouldn't be put off by the competition."
"Maybe," she said, "this is all going to be too much."

HEADLINE: Right Again, but Somewhat Left

BYLINE: By Alan Ehrenhalt; Alan Ehrenhalt is the executive editor of Governing magazine and the author of "The United States of Ambition: Politicians, Power and the Pursuit of Office."

 BODY:

BOILING POINT
Republicans, Democrats, and the Decline
of Middle-Class Prosperity.
By Kevin Phillips.
307 pp. New York:
Random House. $23. 
 THROUGH more than 25 years of analysis and prediction, nobody has been as transcendently right about the outlines of American political change -- or as tantalizingly wrong about crucial details -- as Kevin Phillips. In "The Emerging Republican Majority," written in 1967, the year before Richard Nixon took the White House out of Democratic hands, Mr. Phillips predicted not only Mr. Nixon's victory but also the full quarter-century of Republican Presidential dominance that was to follow. The social and racial upheaval of the 1960's, Mr. Phillips wrote, would be to Democrats what the Depression was to Republicans: it would probably be a full generation before the average middle-class white voter trusted any Democrat to run the country again.
That truth, grasped so early and argued so cleanly, stands as perhaps the single most brilliant political insight of recent times. The only complication was that Mr. Phillips went beyond it to infer something more sweeping: Republican control of Congress, the states and all levels of the political system. The failure of that prediction provided ammunition to critics; it also confounded Mr. Phillips himself. At one point in the 1970's he argued that the top-to-bottom Republican majority was snatched away at the last moment by Watergate. Later he said it had been blocked by the power of the news media to control election results. Neither of those explanations was very convincing.
By the early Reagan years, however, Mr. Phillips had moved on to other grand forecasts. In "Post-Conservative America" (1982), he traced the economic frustrations of the American voter and prophesied that years of political instability would follow. Once again, Mr. Phillips demonstrated a genuine sensitivity for the middle-class American mind and political temperament. But his analysis suffered, if nothing else, from unfortunate timing. He saw chronic inflation as a scourge of modern government and the source of electoral disruption. Just as his book was appearing, inflation began a steady decline that essentially removed it as a political problem for a decade to come.
But in 1990, Mr. Phillips renewed his reputation as an astute political thinker. In "The Politics of Rich and Poor," he penetrated the veil of Reagan-Bush prosperity and showed how the previous decade had redistributed income and wealth away from middle-class and working-class families and into the bank accounts of the rich. In the years since, as recession and stagnation have settled in everywhere, much of what Mr. Phillips wrote in 1990 has become both conventional wisdom and underlying text for political debate.
Now, in "Boiling Point," Mr. Phillips has expanded on his rich-and-poor-in-the-80's thesis to explore the phenomenon of middle-class decline from the widest possible perspective, tracing not only the fat and lean decades of postwar American life but the lessons of other times and places as well: Victorian Britain, the 17th-century Netherlands, even the Spain of Philip II.
In the last 20 years, Mr. Phillips says, the American middle class has been losing cash and a great deal more. Not only has real income been falling since 1973, a point most economists are now willing to concede, but also the typical $40,000-a-year family has been the victim of a galaxy of economic changes few have bothered to add up.
What this family gained in the 1980's in lower income taxes, it lost in higher payroll taxes for Social Security and higher sales and property taxes at the state and local level. It has paid further as the real cost of services and leisure has soared: tuition, legal fees, even the price of baseball tickets and cable television. Most important, this family and others like it have been the primary victims of massive deindustrialization. The middle-class family that thrived in the 1950's and 1960's on one breadwinner's income from a high-wage manufacturing job is now forced perilously close to financial collapse as a working husband and working wife find themselves mired in dead-end service jobs or nonunion factory work that pays little more than the minimum wage.
Each of these things has been said elsewhere, but Mr. Phillips puts them together with a thoroughness that no one before him has achieved, and he delivers them in an acerbically provocative prose style. "Huge chunks of industrial America . . . had become graveyards of vocational mobility," he tells us. "In less than a generation, the average American went from being a political icon to being a fiscal milch cow."
Some of the arguments are less than precise. For example, we never learn precisely just what Mr. Phillips means by "middle class." At times, he stretches the term to include families that earn as much as $100,000 a year. At other times, he seems to include these families as part of the elite that middle-class Americans ought rightfully to resent.
But the major themes are carefully presented and convincing, and they will ring true to anyone who has troubled to read the newspaper of any major American city in the last few years. The economy of the 1990's is middle-aged fathers in Ohio and Indiana, men who used to earn good incomes at Ford or Caterpillar, saddled with low-wage jobs at Kmart or Wal-Mart that offer little comfort, satisfaction or hope of advancement. It is young mothers who commute 30 miles from one suburb to another for a pink-collar job whose wages are half eaten by child care and travel costs. It is families that scarcely see one another for days on end.
Meanwhile, Mr. Phillips tells us, the share of pretax income going to the richest 1 percent of American families rose from 8 percent to 13 percent in the dozen years from 1977 to 1989, while the effective tax rate on those same families was declining from 35.5 percent to 26.7 percent. Taken together, these facts are a powerful economic indictment, and they generate legitimate questions about when and if the nation is going to face a middle-class populist rebellion against the wealthy.
But Mr. Phillips is not content to justify such a rebellion or even to predict one. He is determined to show that it is already taking place. And here his book simply fails.
Mr. Phillips tells us, for example, that Gov. Pete Wilson of California accepted a modest 1991 increase in taxes on the highest incomes because of overwhelming popular support for a so-called soak-the-rich ballot initiative scheduled for a vote the following year. He does not tell us that a soak-the-rich measure, albeit a stronger one, did come to a statewide vote in November 1992 and was decisively defeated.
MR. PHILLIPS cites the Presidential campaign successes of both Jerry Brown and Ross Perot as signs of national populist enthusiasm, but this argument requires feats of selective memory. Mr. Brown, like the radio talk-show populists he came to resemble, aimed his attack at political elites, not economic elites. It was not Sam Walton or John Kluge that Mr. Brown ridiculed in his campaign. It was the leadership of Congress and the complacency of its incumbents. This is populism of a sort, but not the sort that Mr. Phillips claims to have discovered.
Ross Perot, with his East Texas twang and his gibes against Washington, can be said to have learned some of the lyrics of populism. One must ask, however, what sort of soak-the-rich movement would serve up as its voice of rebellion an unrepentant Texas computer billionaire preoccupied with budget deficits. In a genuine populist revolt, Mr. Perot would not be the hero. He would be one of the villains.
Then there is the question of Bill Clinton and his promise to raise the taxes of those who earn more than $200,000 a year. If it takes that much income to be rich, the fact is that there are very few rich people in the United States, and confiscating their money would do little to redistribute overall wealth. Far more telling than Mr. Clinton's willingness to tax the super-rich was his mortal fear of raising revenue from the upper middle class, the people between $100,000 and $200,000, who in any legitimate populist rebellion would be among the targets. If one has to use the Clinton campaign as evidence that 1992 was a populist political year, as Mr. Phillips does, one is on very shaky ground.
But it is not necessary to accept Mr. Phillips's strained account of the 1992 election to appreciate his book for what it is: an impressive piece of economic analysis and a troubling moral argument. The past decade has done more than enough societal damage to make populists out of those on the losing side of economic change; it simply has not made populists out of very many of them up to now. "Boiling Point" may create a few more.

LENGTH: 935 words

HEADLINE: Start Worrying, Feel Better

BYLINE: By Garry Wills; Garry Wills, adjunct professor of history at Northwestern University and author of "Lincoln at Gettysburg," is writing a book on leadership.

DATELINE: EVANSTON, Ill.

 BODY:
Two things about the President's economic program are clear. One, it cannot be done. Two, but it better be.
It cannot be done because it is both too much and too little, too much to pass and too little to solve our multiple problems. It tries to address everything, which is a prescription for addressing nothing. It equals in urgency some war measures, yet there is no war. All that, on one side of the ledger, says "impossible." But there is even more to be said on the "absolutely necessary" side of the books. 
 Enemies of democracy, from the time of Plato, have said that it must ultimately fail because it reduces its politicians to servicers of constituents' appetites, so that candidate and electorate are caught in a cycle of mutual bribery. The items on the "impossible" side of the ledger seem to confirm that indictment of popular government. Plato argued that the politician is to the statesman as a chef is to a doctor. The doctor says: "Take this medicine. It will be immediately nauseating but ultimately healing." The chef says: "Taste this. Isn't it delicious? No? Then taste this. Or this."
In our situation, there is general agreement that the deficit must be reduced by steps that will crimp our living for a while but in the long run help us all. Yet every member of the House of Representatives runs for re-election, not in the long run, but next year. These candidates shudder at the thought of facing an electorate denied what it wants at that very moment.
So we combine agreement on what needs doing, and doubt that it can ever be done. That is the real gridlock in our system. Everyone knows that steps must be taken, and soon, and drastically, on problems like these:
* The deficit is draining our economic strength, wasting our resources in interest payments, blocking more productive investment and preventing our reaction to other challenges (since we lack mobilizable cash to meet danger or seize opportunity).
* Our education system is not equipping us to stay competitive with other commercial nations; it is disabling our work force, sending money to find jobs elsewhere, making ours a service economy when the high stakes of the future are in high technology.
* Our energy consumption is inequitable in world terms, unbalancing in our own economy, hurtful to the environment, and it makes us vulnerable to the fate of our suppliers.
* The basic undergirdings of our national stock are eroding -- roads, bridges, transit systems, inner cities -- in ways that inhibit business efficiency and communal satisfaction.
* The perceived inequities of the economic structure have strained our internal accord, lessened civility and provoked despair in those left out.
* Health care costs too much and does too little, and its growing expense places cruel burdens on families, the Government and the elderly.
* America, though not in decline, has been slowed in areas where competitors most challenge our eminence.
These are not difficulties that call for a chef. Ronald Reagan and George Bush said, in an inversion of the F.D.R. maxim, "The only thing we have to worry about is worry itself." Forget the doom-sayers, the misery merchants, the root-canal doctors. Have another pastry. The American people are basically good and if left alone by government they will automatically create good schools, new roads, clean air, revived cities, less intensive oil use.
Even acknowledging the existence of problems was greeted as a return to McGovern or Carter pessimism. Politicians could not raise the T-word to constituents, or the E-word (for Entitlements), at election time (which is all the time).
If the problems cannot be addressed singly, then must they be cumulatively insurmountable? Maybe not. At a certain point, more challenging becomes less. Ours is a case where nothing can be done until it seems undoable. Only the sense of large-scale crisis can provoke people past grudging refusal to make small-scale efforts. We respond that way in war, when Bill Clinton's derided terms -- sacrifice, contribution, investment in your country, discipline -- seem natural.
We responded that way in the Depression, when Roosevelt used warlike terms, and people flew the National Recovery Administration blue eagle as a battle flag. Even the so-called public-relations aspects of the Clinton plan are important: morale is always important in a crisis.
What chance President Clinton's program has is based precisely on the fact that it attacks all the aspects of our economic trouble. Even the elements that do not go far enough in themselves lend support to other parts of the plan. The freeze on Government wages makes it easier to ask for taxes on Social Security for the well-to-do. The investments are to be judged not only as job programs but as directing money again toward infrastructure, education and technological development -- goals to be pursued in any event.
Roosevelt did not have to create a sense of crisis. Everyone knew there was a Depression. President Clinton must dramatize problems that do not go away with every slight ratcheting up of the economic indicators. He must keep reminding people how bad things are if he is to make them even a little better.
The most effective part of his speech to Congress was the closing vision of the bleak future we will have if we keep eating the pastries of politician-chefs. And, like Roosevelt, he must keep experimenting, adding new efforts, stressing the process of undoing an entire train of bad policy decisions. It is a long haul, and breakdown can occur anywhere along the way. But it better not.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CLINTON SAYS U.S. IS PLANNING AIRLIFT TO EASTERN BOSNIA

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that the United States was drawing up plans with its allies to conduct an emergency airlift of food and medicine to remote areas of eastern Bosnia and that they expect to disclose the initiative in the next few days.
"We'll probably have an announcement today for you or tomorrow," Mr. Clinton told reporters at the White House as he left for a two-day visit to California. "We're working on it. I have authorized our people to talk to the U.N. Security Council about the possibility of extra help with food and medicine for Bosnia." 
 An estimated 200,000 people, most of them Bosnian Muslims, are suffering critical shortages of supplies in towns and villages of eastern Bosnia that are besieged by Serbian forces.
 
For Remote Areas
 American officials said that the plan they are hammering out through diplomatic channels with allies, the United Nations Security Council and the parties on the ground would use transport aircraft of the United States and other nations to drop relief supplies into remote, mountainous areas of Bosnia that have not been reached by overland United Nations convoys.
The operation being planned is an "emergency effort that would supplement the overland convoys, not replace them," an Administration official said. The official made clear that the convoys are continuing. One arrived today at the eastern town of Zepa after a week of delays. [Page A8.]
The official added that while the planned air operation would not be just a one-time-only undertaking, it was not meant to be a permanent complement to the convoys. Besides providing relief aid, he said, the effort would also ideally highlight for the world the insufficient amount of aid that the Serbs are allowing into Bosnia overland and increase pressure on them to stop pilfering so much of it.
 
Symbolic Objectives
 Although the President said he would probably announce the operation by Monday, aides said later that the announcement would probably not come before Tuesday because of the sensitive technical, military and diplomatic steps that need to be coordinated first. The operation is expected to start immediately after the announcement.
The airlift would appear to have symbolic, as well as humanitarian, objectives. In the Presidential campaign last year, Mr. Clinton was critical of what he said was President Bush's passive attitude toward the fate of the beleaguered Bosnians and promised a more aggressive American role if he became President.
Since taking office, though, Mr. Clinton, heeding military advisers skeptical about getting involved in any armed operation to relieve Bosnia and a public wary of a Balkan quagmire, has opted for a very cautious diplomatic approach.
A high-profile airlift, even if limited in scope and duration, would be a way for Mr. Clinton to demonstrate an activist approach more consistent with his campaign promises. A more aggressive American relief operation might also enhance Washington's credibility at the negotiating table, where it has promised -- but has yet to demonstrate -- a more energetic effort to use diplomatic and economic sanctions to pressure the warring parties into a mutually acceptable peace settlement.
The way airdrops normally work is that food and other supplies are packed in boxes and then bundled together on huge wooden pallets, which are then dropped by parachute out the back of a transport aircraft.
The planes have to fly low enough to be sure to drop the pallets in open areas, so they do not land on people or houses. Flying that low, though, can be dangerous in a war zone, although the Serbian gunners besieging the Muslim areas do not have particularly sophisticated antiaircraft weaponry. Nevertheless, this risk was one reason that the Pentagon was initially reluctant about the operation, which was being pushed by the State Department.
But a senior Administration official said that the President is now satisfied that the operation can be conducted without much risk to American personnel or aircraft. The Administration is apparently considering some sort of airlift operation with planes other than the normally slow-flying C-130's, to limit the exposure.
The United Nations High Commissioner for refugees, Sadako Ogata, announced last week that she was suspending aid deliveries to most of Bosnia because of interference by the warring parties.
On Friday, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali rebuked Mrs. Ogata and reversed her order. Mrs. Ogata said today in Geneva that she had received assurances from the factions that they would not harass shipments, and that full aid operations could be resumed this week.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 1072 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN;
Voters Viewing Tax Bill, And Saying They'll Pay

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Nobody is cheering the arrival of new taxes, but many voters here say they accept what seemed so hard for voters to accept during the glory days of the 1980's: that new taxes are simply necessary.
President Clinton's appeal to patriotism and a sense of national need is not taken lightly by people like Jim Seros, a restaurateur visiting from Detroit who declares, "I know it's going to cost me a little bit, but that's O.K.," or Steve Nudelberg, a 32-year old telecommunications executive in Miami, who says, "I'm in an income bracket where it actually affects me dramatically, but I'm a firm believer that at some point somebody's going to have to sacrifice." 
 They cited the deficit, the state of the economy in general, the sense that the nation needs a basic shift in direction and that Mr. Clinton deserved a chance to lead it.
The leap of faith by the voters is even more striking because their attitudes toward Washington remain so dark, judging from interviews with more than 40 voters around South Florida. Again and again, people noted ruefully, or angrily, or suspiciously, that this was still Washington they would be sending their money off to, still the big, unpopular Federal bureaucracy. They worried that the idea of "shared sacrifice" would never quite extend to Congress, that they would get sucked in yet again to a program of tax increases and spending cuts that would never get around to the spending cuts.
This, to put it mildly, roused strong feelings. "Giving extra money to Congress is like giving extra money to someone who's already maxed out on their $3,000 credit card limit," said Michael Tabor, a 40-year-old respiratory therapist from Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
Frank Skotny, a 59-year-old machine shop owner from Boston, hailed Mr. Clinton's program in one breath and fretted about Congress's sabotaging the proposed spending cuts in the next. "If it's only one-sided, then God help him and all Democrats," Mr. Skotny said. "For the next hundred years, they will never get in."
Such doubts were being stoked this weekend by that maestro of voter discontent, Ross Perot, who was in Miami (and in the local newspapers and television news) asserting that Washington should reform itself before getting additional money from the taxpayers. "I suggest that as a price for getting all these things done and all these taxes they want, we put up a 'not for sale' sign in Washington," he declared Saturday night in a speech that avoided direct attacks on Mr. Clinton but was riddled with implicit digs.
Still, in the first few days after Mr. Clinton's address to Congress, voters seemed inclined to give the man and the economic program a chance. In the inner-city neighborhood of Liberty City, William Cooper, a 23-year-old reserve police officer and security guard on duty at a government building, said with a shrug, "I voted for him because obviously I trust him."
 
Polls Find Support
 Down in the affluent shopping district of Coconut Grove, Joey Worman, 35, who owns a T-shirt business, said, "I'm going to pay more taxes, I know that; but I'm willing to pay to get out from under the deficit."
This attitude was also reflected in two national polls released this weekend, for Time/CNN and Newsweek, both of which found solid majorities supporting the Clinton plan. Representative Carrie Meek, a freshman Democrat who described her Miami-area district as primarily moderate to lower income, said of her constituents' reaction, "The consensus seemed to be we know we've got to take some heat, we've got to take some punishment, but we want to make sure we get something out of it."
Many people were reluctant to discuss in much detail how the Clinton program would affect their personal financial situation, or were still uncertain. They watched the speech on television -- some taped it, they said, to watch it later -- or they caught snippets of it on the television news. The energy tax seemed to penetrate people's consciousness the most, prompting a lot of worried talk about the price of gasoline and utility bills in general.
Jacqueline Thompson, a caseworker for the state welfare department and the mother of two, said her income was low enough that she should qualify for a new tax break but added, "It's not going to pay day care for the full year, and it's not going to pay the rent and utilities." Ms. Thompson, meanwhile, was worried about the impact of the energy tax on her commute to work.
 
Tax Increase Was Expected
 There were, not surprisingly, other reservations and fears. Carl Liggett, who retired to South Florida from New York, said he expected his taxes to go up and voiced the reflexive fear of people living on fixed incomes.
Mr. Tabor, the respiratory therapist, said somewhat philosophically: "I make over $50,000 a year, and I expect to get hit. But as soon as Clinton was elected I expected to get hit, and he's not disappointed me."
There were also voters who took up the Republican line of attack, noting that Mr. Clinton's proposed income levels for higher taxes kept getting lower and lower. Still, for many, the more relevant voice in the coming debate was Mr. Perot's. At a rally in Miami on Saturday night, Mr. Perot said he was still awaiting the details of Mr. Clinton's economic plan but proceeded to list a host of conditions that Washington should meet before getting new tax dollars, from keeping better books to slashing Congressional salaries and perks.
He also suggested that the Clinton Administration was trying to move too fast on health care. "These are folks who have never flown who are trying to fly the F-16," he said. And he told his happy audience that he was taking his message to national television again next month, with a block of time on NBC.
Mr. Perot, and the doubts he appeals to, suggest the fragility of the consensus around Mr. Clinton's plan. The grass roots may be accommodating at the moment, but it is also watchful and wired.
Ava Overstreet, who works in the telecommunications industry, was in the audience at Mr. Perot's rally the other night, and said afterward: "Since Clinton's gotten in, and I wish him all the best, I have at this point contacted my Congressman, Senator and Mr. Clinton about 10 times -- by voice, speech, telegram and letter. I think the only way these guys are going to wake up and smell the coffee is because people like me are going to sit there and hound them."

GRAPHIC: Photos: "I'm a firm believer that at some point somebody's going to have to sacrifice," said Steve Nudelberg, left, who sat with Joey Worman in the shopping district in Coconut Grove, Fla. "I'm going to pay more taxes, I know that; but I'm willing to pay to get out from under the deficit," Mr. Worman said. "I voted for him because obviously I trust him," said William Cooper, a security guard in Miami. Ava Overstreet, after a Perot rally in Miami, said, "I think the only way these guys are going to wake up and smell the coffee is because people like me are going to sit there and hound them." (Photographs by Susan Greenwood for The New York Times)(pg. A14)

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN;
Lobbyists Hearing 'Taxes' But Don't Cry 'War' (Yet)

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Understand, please, that Tom Donohue, the president and pre-eminent lobbyist for the American Trucking Associations and its 4,000 members, does not actually oppose President Clinton's package of tax increases and deficit reductions. Not even its tax on energy sources, including the diesel fuel that is the truckers' lifeblood.
"People want Bill Clinton to succeed," he said. "We're not going to fight it. We're just going to work with Congress to assure that it is fair." 
 Washington's lobbyists, who easily number in the thousands, are starting to talk, and suddenly the town has a serious echo problem.
Mr. Clinton wants to cut low-interest Federal loans to rural electric utilities. "Our guys will take their fair share, with the emphasis on the word 'fair,' says a spokeswoman for the National Rural Electric Cooperatives Association representing 1,000 utilities and 25 million customers. "We want them to look at the subsidies the rest of the utility industry gets."
Mr. Clinton wants to pare back subsidies and crop insurance for farmers. "We feel a freeze in all Government spending is the best way to be fair," says a lobbyist at the American Farm Bureau Federation with four million members. "Everyone should share equally in the burden."
Mr. Clinton wants to stimulate the economy, which could increase mortgage rates, and he wants to scale back guaranteed benefits like the low-interest home loans for veterans. "Deficit reduction is something we feel strongly about," says the chief lobbyist for the National Association of Realtors with its 800,000 members. "The question is not having it apply disproportionately to real estate."
"Not that we don't expect to pay our fair share," he adds.
For now, this is Washington lobbying on the Clinton economic package: scores of biplanes swarming about King Kong, too far away to fire effectively and too wary of joining the battle lest they be swatted down in flames. The lobbyists themselves say that is a measure of uncertainty, both about the actual merit of the President's proposals and about the extent of public support for them.
"It's early," said one, Nicholas E. Calio, who was a important lobbyist in supporting the last tax-law overhaul in 1986. "There is a calculation right now that it's better to be muted, even supportive, in the hope that you can maximize your bargaining position later."
The truth, as spoken by a score or more of industry executives and lobbyists in interviews, is that almost no one much likes what Mr. Clinton has proposed. But few have concluded that their unhappiness rises to a level that demands all-out opposition.
 
Courting by White House
 None have decided yet to mount a full-scale campaign to influence Congress, or a public-relations offensive that might sway the opinion of White House officials like the budget director, Leon E. Panetta, or Congress. Rather, they say, they will probably chip at the margins, trying to alter provisions that hurt them most without damaging the package's one indisputable good: a smaller deficit.
To some extent, the White House is even encouraging that approach. It called in large schools of lobbyists for briefings, telling them that the crucial fine print of the economic proposals remains to be written and that their suggestions are still welcome.
"Clinton had our legislative group in for an hour two weeks ago, and we saw Panetta today," said John Rother, director of legislation for the American Association of Retired Persons, at 34 million members strong, one of the nation's most muscular interest groups.
"They've gone out of their way to make sure we're feeling included. We may not like it, but at least they've heard our concerns."
Lobbyists' concerns are as varied as their clients. But clearly, business interests most detest Mr. Clinton's energy tax, which would raise the cost of manufacturing and distributing products; his proposed two percentage point increase in corporate tax rates, to 36 percent, and what they say are his comparatively small cuts in Federal programs.
Farmers and rural groups like the electric utilities, and energy-intensive businesses like trucking and heavy manufacturing, are most adamant about changing the energy tax. The Amoco Corporation, the Chicago-based oil company, said it hoped to persuade the industry's Washington trade group, the America Petroleum Institute, to lead a crusade against the energy tax, said Ted Eck, the company's chief economist. Mr. Eck said companies whose energy costs exceeded 5 percent of their total expenses "could be mortally wounded" by the tax, and he noted that such energy costs for some industries, like aluminum and cement making, already accounted for about a fifth of their outlays.
By comparison, some less energy-intensive industries and trade groups, like wholesalers, appear more concerned about the cumulative impact on their profits of the entire Clinton program, from the corporate tax increase to potential new taxes for health care to the limited sweep of the President proposed investment tax credit.
Of major lobbying groups interviewed, three of the largest -- the retired persons' association, the real estate agents and the National Auto Dealers Association -- expressed the fewest reservations about Mr. Clinton's proposals. Officials for the real estate agents and the retired persons groups suggested that they might be persuaded to lobby in behalf of the plan if some of their biggest concerns, like health care changes and the inflationary effects of the program, are mollified.
Only one group of any size appears so far to have taken dead aim at the heart of Mr. Clinton's plan, but that group is a potentially powerful one. Called the Tax Reform Action Coalition, it is an amalgam of hundreds of big companies and trade groups and is led by some of the nation's most influential business voices. The group helped push the 1986 overhaul of tax laws through Congress.
That change successfully traded away tax shelters, loopholes and generous deductions in exchange for lower, flatter and more equitable tax rates that applied to almost everyone. And now that Mr. Clinton proposes raising rates again its members are fighting mad.
"TRAC wants meaningful deficit reduction, too," said Alan Kranowitz, the group's executive secretary. "But I suspect there will be a solid voice around the table that the White House ought to cut out the economic stimulus part of the package and leave corporate rates where they are, and find some other spending cuts to offset the 36 percent rate for individuals."
At the same time, both Mr. Kranowitz and many others expressed what seemed a sincere willingness to accept limited tax increases and larger cuts in benefits for a better-balanced Federal budget. This stems partly from the conviction that the Democratic Congress will inevitably send tax legislation and budget cuts to Mr. Clinton's desk.
But the relative modesty of Mr. Clinton's proposed spending cuts is tempering the enthusiasm of business for the program.
"Given the fact that this plan is less than one-for-one in spending versus tax increases and Congress's history of accepting the sugar but not the vinegar, the question is, 'Can this stick? What does this really mean for long-term America?' " said Michael C. Maibach, director of government affairs at the Intel Corporation, the computer chip maker.
He added: "You can be a first-class passenger on an airplane. But if the pilot doesn't know what he's doing, the whole plane goes down."

HEADLINE: Japan's 'Recycling' of Its Trade Surplus Declines

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Even as Japan racks up the largest trade surpluses in history, the flood of international investments that the surpluses were supposed to finance have declined sharply in recent years, undercutting one of the Government's justifications for the imbalances.
The Japanese Government has taken a variety of steps to blunt criticism over the overwhelming size of its surpluses. One of the more important of these, during the 1980's, was the development of multibillion-dollar programs to "recycle" some of the money to needy areas of the global economy. The Government sent funds to areas of the developing world that were starved for capital and encouraged Japanese corporations to make productive investments in the United States and Europe. 
 This money paid for everything from foreign aid projects in Thailand to Honda auto plants in Ohio and securities purchases on Wall Street, prompting the Government to argue that they were a beneficial side effect of the country's trade surpluses.
But that has changed, with surprising speed. The waves of capital that Japan sent washing over the world have contracted to a trickle, leaving a residue of mistrust among some foreign officials and analysts. There has been some flow out of Japan of what is called short-term capital, but economists say that is merely a consequence of Japanese banks' paying down their short-term borrowings in New York and other wholesale banking markets, not the kind of productive investments the Japanese had promised.
The more important long-term capital investments are staying in Japan's recession-battered economy, where they are being used to shore up the nation's troubled banking industry, hold together a severely depressed real estate market and repay some of the reckless borrowing that took place during Japan's boom of the 1980's. Several trillion dollars of Japan's wealth has also been wiped out by the three-year-old depression in the Tokyo stock market.
Long-term Japanese investments overseas peaked at $136.5 billion in 1987, then turned into a trickle of less than $30 billion last year. They are expected to remain depressed this year. In comparison, Japan's trade surplus hit a record $132.6 billion in 1992, more than double the level of two years earlier. The surplus with the United States came to nearly $45 billion, and economists are projecting further growth this year.
The Government's official recycling program, first announced with great fanfare in 1987, sent $65 billion abroad in the five years that ended last June. But there is no longer any official program in place.
 
From Corporate Japan
 In those years, the bulk of the money sent overseas, by far, came from corporate Japan. But with a deep recession forcing manufacturers, insurance companies and banks to tighten their belts, these companies are marshaling their capital at home. Banks, for instance, have had to take large write-offs for bad loans, and are having to raise billions of dollars of fresh funds to meet rules specifying the minimum levels of capital they must keep on hand.
Manufacturers are suffering slowdowns of sales both at home and abroad, so they are building fewer plants and reducing spending on research and development. In many instances they are reporting losses, so some of their capital is being eaten up by sustaining their bloated production bases. Even if they are helping to generate the country's huge surpluses, the manufacturers overbuilt during the 1980's. The excess factory capacity is now an expensive liability.
Government pressure on Japanese companies and financial institutions to send capital abroad has also stopped. The Finance Ministry has halted a campaign that had encouraged some of the foreign investment.
Nonetheless, Japan appears ready to resort to recycling again to deflect political pressure from the United States and other countries. Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa has indicated in recent days that he will announce a new program at the summit meeting of the leaders of the Group of Seven industrialized nations, to be held here in July.
But most economists believe that even with a new Government program, which some officials have said will involve $130 billion within five years, the flow of investments abroad will not match that of the 1980's.
"Recycling is really a smokescreen," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, which has ties to some officials in the Clinton Administration. "They look too much like an excuse not to make the adjustments in the trade surplus that are necessary. The real point is that we have to get the surpluses down, not recycle them."
The concept of recycling surpluses is extremely complex. In a world where borders are open to flows of capital, the surpluses that accumulate in one country automatically find their way into the global financial system through a variety of means -- as long-term investments, short-term bank deposits, grants and loans, and purchases of securities, commodities and the like. Thus some economists say an active recycling program is superfluous.
But many Japanese and some foreign economists argue that certain kinds of investments are more productive than others, and that these should be encouraged. They regard long-term investments as a more stable and productive source of capital than short-term flows. They also say that the free markets do not always direct the capital to areas of the world that need it, like underdeveloped nations.
"Short-term capital outflows and long-term outflows are not the same," argued Makoto Utsumi, a former senior Finance Ministry official who was instrumental in designing the programs. "Our duty is to encourage long-term flows, which have certain advantages, and to direct those funds to the areas that really need them."
For Japan's trading partners, the question remains whether the country should be doling out money through recycling programs, or whether a more important priority would be to bring the country's trade into balance by opening its markets and reinvigorating its economy. It is a question the Clinton Administration will have to ponder.
Unlike the recycling of OPEC's "petrodollars" in the 1970's, which aimed to send capital from oil-exporting states to the parts of the third world that were hurt the most by sharp increases in crude oil prices, Japan's recycling programs had no such urgency. They were intended to demonstrate, in part, that Japan's surpluses were ultimately beneficial. Several billion dollars, for instance, were used to support the Brady Plan, a program for helping resolve the third world debt crisis.
Tetsuo Kondo, a member of Parliament and former Minister for Economic Planning, gave speeches during the late 1980's describing Japan's surpluses as "appropriate" and "necessary."
Mitsuhide Yamaguchi, governor of the Export-Import Bank of Japan, a Government institution involved in the recycling program, said that at least some of the Group of Seven nations had to generate trade surpluses so that the group could provide aid to less-developed countries. Only Japan is now running a trade surplus among the group, he said, which also includes the United States, Canada, Germany, France, Britain and Italy.
Japan's recycling policy sent so much government and private capital abroad that the outflow of long-term investments exceeded Japan's accumulated trade surpluses. The outflow of long-term investments totaled $552.6 billion from the beginning of 1985 through the end of 1989. During those same five years, Japan had total trade surpluses of $417 billion.
 
Outflows Have Fallen
 Yet now the flows of capital from Japan have been drying up. Japanese corporations made $15 billion in corporate acquisitions abroad in 1989, buying everything from Columbia Pictures to a controlling interest in Rockefeller Center. Last year, the figure plummeted to $2.4 billion, according to Ulmer Brothers, a New York investment bank that tracks this data.
Some financial experts say one problem is that the Government's recycling efforts are too conservative to have a big impact on the world economy.
"The real way to recycle would be to deregulate their markets at home to make for stronger domestic demand and get the surpluses down," said David C. Mulford, the vice chairman of CS First Boston in New York, who until recently was a senior Treasury Department official.
Even in Japan there is some skepticism about the effectiveness of the recycling programs.
"It is generally desirable for Japan to encourage a large outflow of long-term capital," said Kazuo Ogura, the Deputy Foreign Minister for Economic Affairs. "But frankly speaking, there were some positive aspects and there were some areas that were short of our expectations. We had wanted the Government money to prime the pump in the developing countries, to attract more private capital. But it did not generate as much private investment as we had expected."
Many experts are also reconsidering Japan's financial recycling as they learn more about what it entailed. A total of $12.5 billion of the Government's $65 billion program consisted of routine foreign aid. That money, presumably, would have been provided regardless of whether Japan had big surpluses. (The United States spent tens of billions of dollars on foreign aid in the 1980's in spite of its trade deficits.)
Several billion dollars of the Japanese money consisted of commercial bank loans at commercial rates. And $13 billion was private capital that multinational bodies like the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank raised by selling bonds to private investors in Japan.
Government policies have also inhibited the flow of money to several troubled regions of the world. Japan is still refusing to provide substantial financial assistance to Russia, for instance, because of a territorial dispute lingering from World War II.

HEADLINE: Canada Is Found to Lead U.S. In Holding Drug Prices Down

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Canada has been successful in the last five years in getting drug companies to hold back rising drug prices while also getting them to increase their spending on research, a Congressional report finds.
The report, by the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, suggests that the United States consider establishing a board to review drug prices similar to the one in Canada. 
 "Canadian experience shows that a drug-price review board can restrain prescription drug prices," the accounting office report said. "Relative to U.S. drug prices, the Canadian prices of some drugs, subject to board review, were on average one-third lower than had there been no board."
The report is to be released Monday at a hearing of the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health and the Environment. It is to be the opening salvo an effort by both the White House and the Democratic Congress to rein in rapidly rising drug prices in the United States.
On Wednesday, the Senate Special Committee on Aging will hold its own hearing on the issue. And other committees will be holding hearings over the next few months as part of an overall campaign for changes in the health-care system. The idea, Congressional aides say, is to keep the public spotlight, and pressure, on drug companies, doctors and insurance companies.
 
Finding 'Excessive Prices'
 Canada established its Patented Medicine Prices Review Board in 1987, with the power to investigate drug prices, get confidential price information from drug companies, and pull their patent rights if they fail to accede to the board's requests to reduce what it calls "excessive prices."
The Canadian board is one part of that nation's attempt to control drug prices, an effort that also includes requiring drug companies to negotiate with provincial officials on drug prices and federal rules that promote the sales of generic equivalents of brand name drugs. The board, which has 35 employees, did not try to control nonprescription drug prices, or the price of drugs when they were first introduced.
The board determined that a drug price was "excessive" if its cost per day or per treatment was above the maximum for comparable drugs or treatments. And price increases were found unacceptable by the board when they increased faster than the consumer price index in Canada.
The accounting office is expected to testify about a report, released last fall, in which it found that drug prices in Canada were more than 40 percent lower than in the United States.
In the United States, drug prices have been rising at a rate several times higher that of the consumer price index. But last year the price increases were not as high, said Gerald Mossinghoff, president of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association. While inflation was running about 3 percent, drug prices rose 9.5 percent in 1989, he said. But by 1991, price increases were 7.8 percent, and he said that in the past 12 months the increases have been less than double the rate of inflation in the rest of society -- or about 5.1 percent.
Jeff Warren, a spokesman for the association, acknowledged that drug prices were higher in the United States. But he said profits in the drug industry could not be compared to other industries that "just stamp out their products over and over."
"Pharmaceuticals are a high risk, research-intensive industry," he said. Profits are about five times higher in the drug industry than in others, but Mr. Warren said they were only two percent higher than comparable "high risk" industries like high-technology.
He said the General Accounting Office made a false comparison when it looked at the United States and Canada because the American industry had succeeded in bringing many innovative products to market, but the Canadian drug industry "has produced virtually no important new drugs."
Also at the hearing on Monday, Ronald Pollack, director of Families USA, a Washington health-care reform advocacy group, will testify that "while the Consumer Price Index increased only 21 percent from 1985 to 1991, prescription drug prices rose 66 percent," according to his prepared statement. "The average price of the 20 most frequently prescribed drugs increased 79 percent over the same period."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN;
Seeing Figures, 2 Sides Calculate Clinton's Math

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Much of the Congressional battle about President Clinton's economic package could come down to a duel over algebra: the ratio of proposed tax increases to proposed spending cuts.
Republican mathematicians attack the President's plan as a tax-and-spend scheme, asserting that it includes $1.75 to $18 in tax increases for every dollar in spending cuts. Mr. Clinton's number crunchers respond that it is a prudent, balanced plan, with one dollar in revenue tax increases for each dollar in spending cuts. 
 Which side is right in this battle of the calculators?
The answer, in the never-never land of American politics, is that both sides are, depending on how one cuts the deck, what time period is used and how one defines what is a spending cut and what is a tax increase.
 
Fuzziness on Both Sides
 Although both sides' arguments include some haze and fudging, a few things are clear. In proposing to cut the 1997 budget deficit by $140 billion, the Clinton Administration has fallen short of its goal if cutting two dollars in spending for every dollar in tax increases. As for the Republicans, while they insist that more spending cuts are in order, they have yet to supply the details.
Leon E. Panetta, the White House budget director, says the Administration has proposed $246 billion in revenue increases and $247 billion in spending cuts from the fiscal years 1994 to 1997. That, of course, produces a 1-to-1 ratio.
Not so fast, the Republicans say. Those are gross numbers, calculated before the Administration includes its $169 billion "investment" plan, which aims to improve education and job training as well as highways and other public works. Administration officials say this $169 billion should not be looked at as just another type of spending that will be frittered away; they say it is investment in building a more productive economy.
The plan includes $109 billion in increased spending from 1994 to 1997, and $60 billion in tax incentives -- reduced taxes for corporations to encourage them to expand and invest. Once those numbers are factored in, there are $138 billion in net spending cuts and $186 billion in net tax increases. That produces a ratio of one dollar in spending cuts for each $1.35 in tax increases.
"That is 76 cents in cuts for every $1 in taxes, and I don't know how that's going to help the American economy," said Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico.
 
Benefits or Tax?
 But some Republicans say the picture is far worse than that. The Republicans assert that the Administration is pulling another fast one by counting its proposal to tax 85 percent of Social Security benefits, up from 50 percent current, as a spending cut rather than a tax increase.
The Administration counters that the Social Security change, which would save $21 billion over four years, should be counted as a benefit or spending cut because the Government is merely taking away with one hand some of what it gave with the other. A decade ago President Ronald Reagan called his decision to tax Social Security benefits a benefit cutback, the Democrats note, and the Republicans did not quarrel with that classification.
Regardless of who is right on that point, if this $21 billion is counted as a tax increase, as the Republicans contend, then the Administration is proposing $207 in net revenue increases and $117 billion in net spending cuts. That produces a ratio of one dollar in spending cuts for each $1.77 in revenue increases.
Representative John R. Kasich, a Ohio Republican who is the ranking minority member of the House Budget Committee, cuts the deck another way and finds even more to complain about.
Using Mr. Kasich's computations, for the fiscal year 1994, the plan calls for $2 billion in spending cuts, after factoring in $15 billion in spending on investment and short-term stimulus. That same year, the plan provides for a net revenue increase of $36 billion. Thus, Mr. Kasich sometimes talks of a ratio of $18 in revenue increases for each dollar in spending cuts.
 
Looking at 1998
 In the Republican view, over 1994 and 1995, the program calls for $20 billion in spending cuts and $76 billion in revenue increases. That means that for each one dollar in spending cuts, there is almost $4 in tax increases.
Defending the Administration, Mr. Panetta argues that it is fairer either to look at the whole package over four years or to look at it when all the spending cuts and tax increases are phased in. That means 1997. Counting Social Security changes as a spending cut, he notes that for fiscal year 1997 the plan calls for $112 billion in spending cuts and $83 billion in revenue increases. That translates into 74 cents in tax increases for every dollar in spending cuts.
Appearing today on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," Mr. Panetta said, "What you have is a situation when you get to '97, where you do have almost 60 percent spending cuts versus 40 percent tax increases, and as you continue beyond, because the spending cuts are permanent, you're going to see even greater spending cuts versus revenue."
In an appearance today on the ABC News program "This Week," Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said it would be difficult for Congress to finish action on the package before July. As a result, he said, the proposed tax increases might take effect July 1 and not be retroactive to Jan. 1, as the President has proposed.

SECTION: Section A; Page 15; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 2062 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN;
Clinton's Point Men Face Doubts About Their Edge

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
After the fall of Speaker Jim Wright, an arm-twister who alienated many lawmakers, House Democrats looked for integrity, calm and conciliation. They turned to Thomas S. Foley and Richard A. Gephardt.
The two leaders buried the poisons of the Wright era, but now they face a very different and bigger challenge: how to steer the biggest legislative package to come through the House since Lyndon B. Johnson's Great Society program in the 1960's. 
 In an interview on Friday, Mr. Foley predicted that the House Democrats were ready "to pass a strong, bold program" without heavy-handed politicking from him or Mr. Gephardt. While conceding that lawmakers would make some changes in President Clinton's budget package, he said, "The goals of creating jobs, health-care reform and deficit reduction I think will be accomplished."
But some House Democrats express doubts, noting that the very attributes for which Mr. Foley and Mr. Gephardt were chosen three years ago now look more like liabilities. Many Democrats wonder whether their leadership has the muscle and calluses to drive the deals and resist the armies of lobbyists. With near unanimous opposition developing among House Republicans, the leaders will need to persuade the vast majority of House Democrats to cast tough votes for tax increases and cuts in programs that benefit their districts.
 
2 Temperate Men
 In Mr. Foley, the genteel son of a judge, Democrats selected a seasoned lawmaker with a taste for classical music, gold stick collar pins and folded white handkerchiefs peeking from his jacket pocket. As Speaker of the House, he supplied a nonpartisan patina to his management of an institution whose reputation needed a shine.
And in choosing Mr. Gephardt as majority leader, the Democrats found another temperate politician known more for patience than vision. An avid baseball fan -- his team is the St. Louis Cardinals -- Mr. Gephardt appealed to younger suburban voters and blue-collar workers that the Democratic Party needed to woo back into the fold when he ran his credible campaign early in the 1988 Presidential primaries.
 
Letting Things Get Messy
 The doubts swirling around Mr. Foley, and to a lesser extent Mr. Gephardt, began to emerge during last year's long-running House bank scandal, when they were repeatedly outmaneuvered by the gunslinging Republicans. Suddenly, many Democrats waxed nostalgic for Mr. Wright.
"I'm constantly charged by more partisan Democrats of not being sufficiently tough, of not bashing either President Bush or the Republican leadership," the 62-year-old Mr. Foley acknowledged. But he suggested that with the election of a Democratic President gridlock would end and the leaders would become agents of unity rather than opposition.
Mr. Gephardt, 52, predicted in a separate interview that "the test for the two of us is probably going to be unseen," mediating the give-and-take between the White House and House members. "We lived through the Carter period, and we remember the failures we suffered because there was a lack of attention to negotiation" before legislation was introduced, he said.
Making a similar point, Mr. Foley said he and the majority leader were "going into a new gear."
But the new gear looked like the old the other night when the leaders tried to solve one problem, only to let another get out of control.
Mr. Foley had summoned Mr. Gephardt and other leaders to his office to plot a last-ditch effort to stop junior Democrats from teaming up with the Republicans to abolish four House select committees. The insurgent Democrats called on Mr. Foley to join the cost-cutting effort, but the Speaker decided to risk an embarrassing defeat rather than abandon four chairmen who supported him last year when others in the caucus were plotting to replace him.
While reviewing their options, the leaders noticed on Mr. Foley's television that down on the floor a vote was spiraling out of control in favor of a Republican amendment to the family leave bill. The amendment was trivial, but the leaders wanted to avoid defeats, no matter how small.
"It was grab-your-coat-and-run time," said Representative Patricia Schroeder of Colorado, who watched the leaders scurry for the door. But Mr. Foley reached the chamber too late. The Republican measure squeaked by 223 to 209 with the votes of several conservative Democrats.
 
'No Sense of Fear'
 The amendment was eventually killed in the Senate, but the defeat belied the conventional wisdom that the House, with its nearly 3-to-2 Democratic majority, will be Mr. Clinton's dependable rear guard. The next day, middle-ranking Democrats grumbled to Mr. Gephardt that the floor defeat, along with a series of recent leadership retreats on rule changes, left an impression of disarray that invited more challenges.
"Can Foley and Gephardt deliver?" asked Representative Timothy J. Penny, a conservative Democrat from Minnesota who frequently deserts the leadership. "I don't know, because it means confronting the power centers in the caucus."
Mr. Penny complained that Democratic committee leaders were already angling to gain more money for housing, education, transportation and public works, at a more vigorous pace than they did when a Republican White House promised to veto such spending. While Mr. Foley and Mr. Gephardt are calling on them to heed Mr. Clinton's call for austerity, Mr. Penny said, "There is no sense of fear of retaliation or of any price to pay for bucking the leadership."
Representative Jose E. Serrano, a liberal Democrat from the South Bronx, said he wished the leaders would demand more fealty for the good of the party. "Here, nobody tells you to do anything," he said. "Every once in a while you'd like them to call and say, 'Guys, here's the agenda.' "
 
Dependence on Clinton
 Mr. Foley responded to the criticism by saying: "You don't get support for these programs by routine arm-twisting. It's mythical to think members can be forced to do something they don't want to do."
Senior members are grumbling about proposed restrictions on campaign financing, which they say could threaten Democratic control of the House. Liberals and conservatives are badly split over what kind of health-care insurance plan should be passed. And influential conservatives are complaining that Mr. Clinton's budget package is too heavy on taxes and too light on budget cuts.
The matter of Mr. Foley's and Mr. Gephardt's effectiveness may be resolved more by Mr. Clinton's performance than anything the House leaders do. Should the President rally the country behind him, the two House leaders may be able to unite the fractious Democratic caucus after all.
Mr. Gephardt is widely respected for his astonishing patience. He is a schmoozer who believes that the House Democratic caucus can coalesce if members feel consulted and part of a larger cause. Mr. Foley can be just as persuasive in one-on-one meetings, but he is much criticized for his inclination to insularity, a trait that got him into trouble last year, when he let public disgust over representatives' overdrafts ripen into outrage before he ordered the House bank closed.
 
Rifts in the Partnership
 Representatives and senior aides said the Foley-Gephardt relationship came under serious strain during the bank affair, which revealed Mr. Foley's weaknesses: his failure to anticipate political problems, his aloofness and perhaps most important, his aversion to conflict. Mr. Gephardt did not take up the leadership slack, the officials said, because he resented the Speaker's neglect to consult with him until the grenades had already exploded.
Communications between the two leaders broke down again early this year when Mr. Foley gave his private consent to President George Bush's Iran-contra pardon of former Defense Secretary Casper W. Weinberger without speaking first to Mr. Gephardt, who publicly criticized the pardon.
But colleagues say the two House leaders have patched things up, andMr. Foley now says he regrets he did not close the bank and consult with Mr. Gephardt sooner. "I wasn't as assiduous in drawing everybody immediately to the controversy as I should have been," he said. "I didn't happen to foresee the political use of it that would be made by the Republicans and the reaction of the press."
A photograph that hangs in the majority leader's office displays a mirthful Speaker Foley watching Mr. Gephardt rear back to throw the first ball at a St. Louis Cardinals game. The image of the two hail-fellows straddling the pitching mound is one both Mr. Foley and Mr. Gephardt now carefully cultivate, and it is also a scene that roughly approximates what President Clinton expects of them: the two enjoying a moment of applause from fans who save their heartiest cheers for Ozzie Smith.
 
A Lack of Belligerence
 Defenders of Mr. Foley and Mr. Gephardt note that they are loyal team players with egos firmly in check. They maintain that many Democrats are more likely to talk about hard-nosed leadership than to follow it. And they say the two leaders, like the new President, have demonstrated a willingness to challenge entrenched party interests for the sake of good government.
Mr. Foley built his House career by leading a series of battles against secrecy and seniority in the 1970's, in effect modifying the very powers he would probably find useful today. True to his reformist roots, he is a booster of Mr. Clinton's pledge to rejigger campaign finance laws. At his best, he is capable of demonstrating political courage, as when he stood firm in 1989 against a constitutional amendment against flag burning that he viewed as an infringement on freedom of speech.
But more often, Mr. Foley seems more like a counselor to the king than the king himself. It is rare that he takes a lesson from Machiavelli, as when he removed Representative Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma as chairman of the Intelligence Committee last month for plotting against him. Even then, Mr. Foley described Mr. McCurdy's removal as a routine job rotation.
"I wish he was more belligerent," said Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts, a Foley supporter.
Mr. Gephardt is more of a street fighter. He has a flair for populist oratory, although he has also been at the cutting edge of neoliberal Democratic rethinking since he helped found the Democratic Leadership Council in 1984. His power base centers on 25 young, middle-ranking moderate Democrats who challenge the liberal orthodoxy.
 
Danger of Looking Dumb
 At the 1990 budget talks he was instrumental in cornering Mr. Bush into breaking his "no new taxes" pledge. Later, Mr. Gephardt became one of the party's most effective spokesmen, opposing Mr. Bush when he was viewed as invincible.
But like Mr. Clinton, the majority leader is sometimes criticized for shifting on issues. All last year, he sought to reach a consensus among House Democrats on health care, but he neglected to design a plan for members to rally around. At a caucus meeting in July, Mr. Gephardt vented his frustrations at the split between conservatives who want to tinker with the existing system and liberals who favor a radical move toward a Canadian-style single-payer system.
"I do not want to get out here on the floor discombobulated, disorganized, not knowing what in the world we are doing, and look foolish at the end of the day," he told the caucus, in effect throwing up his hands. "I would rather do nothing than come out here and look dumb, dumber than we will look if we have nothing to say."
 
Thomas S. Foley
