HEADLINE: Trade Pact Job Gains Discounted

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
The two most influential academic experts on the North American Free Trade Agreement, whose forecasts of short-term job gains were heavily cited by the Bush Administration last year, have concluded that any net increase in job gains would evaporate after 15 to 20 years.
The two experts, Gary C. Hufbauer and Jeffrey J. Schott, who are both senior fellows at the Institute for International Economics here, have not included this conclusion in their new book on the pact, although they do mention that the short-term gains may not be permanent. 
 Mr. Schott said the long-term estimate was omitted because it relied on many complicated assumptions and because any economic forecast over such a long period was unreliable. Mr. Hufbauer also said the long-term assessment was omitted because the book was too long and the two men were in a rush to publish it. The book also mentions that the agreement's long-term effect on jobs is insignificant compared with the effect of broader economic trends.
While Bush officials relied extensively on the Hufbauer-Schott data, the Clinton Administration, which has endorsed the pact contingent on completion of three supplemental agreements with Mexico, does not cite them.
 
Forecasts 175,000 Jobs by 1995
 The book, "NAFTA: An Assessment" (Institute for International Economics), was released on Wednesday. It repeated, with little change, the two men's forecast last year that using 1990 job figures as a base the pact would produce a net gain of about 175,000 jobs in the United States by 1995.
The long-term conclusion came to light because Mr. Hufbauer appeared on a panel of trade experts last month at a luncheon organized by the Women's National Democratic Club. He distributed what was then a preliminary table from the book estimating that increased trade from the pact would provide jobs for 318,600 Americans by the year 2010 and that these workers would be producing goods for extra exports to Mexico that would not be possible without the reduction of trade barriers provided by the pact.
But the same table indicated that the agreement would also displace 324,000 jobs in the United States, as imports from Mexico replaced products made less efficiently by American factories, for a net loss of 5,400 jobs.
Mr. Schott said the table was created only to analyze the effects of the pact on income distribution, not on overall employment, and had been used to determine that low-skilled workers and highly skilled workers would be equally affected by the agreement. He said he and Mr. Hufbauer had tried to figure out the effects on employment by industry if exports and imports each increased by $30 billion, roughly doubling their level in 1990.
The use of a $30 billion figure was arbitrary and not based on any computer modeling, Mr. Schott said.
Mr. Hufbauer said the forecast of net job gains over five years assumed there would be a large American trade surplus with Mexico in 1995. The assessment of a tiny net job loss over the next two decades, he said, was based on the assumptions that Mexico's heavy dependence on foreign investment, in the form of American factory equipment and other American exports, would fade as Mexico's economy grew and that imports and exports would be roughly balanced within 20 years.
Most economists strongly support free trade because it encourages countries to specialize in the goods that they make most efficiently, exporting these goods in exchange for imports of other goods that are more efficiently made elsewhere.
But Mr. Hufbauer said that in the case of the United States and Mexico, these efficiencies would actually be very small because the United States already has such low trade barriers to imports from Mexico. The short-term job gain would come from a temporary American trade surplus with Mexico, he said.
 
'Politically Inconvenient'
 Thea M. Lee, an international trade economist at the Economic Policy Institute who appeared on the panel last month with Mr. Hufbauer, said she saved a copy of the preliminary table. "I was astonished that it wasn't in the actual book, and I was disappointed," she said.
"It looked like a decision to excise a politically inconvenient section instead of intellectually facing up to it."
Mr. Hufbauer said that he and Mr. Schott had not intended to present a biased view, but that on reflection he believed they should have included the long-term assessment in their new book. "We should have kept in the long-term scenario," he said, but added that other trade experts had expressed little interest in that when shown draft copies of the book.
"It seemed to be clutter at the time," he said, citing "the rush to print and edit."
The book's publisher, the Institute for International Economics, has been feuding with the Economic Policy Institute about the job impact of the free trade pact. Both institutes receive much of their money from nonprofit organizations like the Ford Foundation, and some money from corporations. The Economic Policy Institute also takes contributions from labor unions.
Jeff Faux, the president of the Economic Policy Institute, forecast last summer that the pact would cause the loss of 500,000 jobs in the United States within 10 years. Mr. Faux said that his estimate of heavy job losses over the next 10 years was based on the assumption that American exports of factory equipment would have a much more immediate effect on Mexican industrial production.
The International Trade Commission, a Federal agency that is independent of Congress and the executive branch, concluded in a report on Feb. 3 that the free trade agreement would produce a very small "long-term" gain in employment in the United States, but did not define how long this would take.
 
Clinton Endorsement of Pact
 While still a candidate last fall, President Clinton endorsed the free trade pact but said that he would not sign legislation putting its provisions into law until three supplemental agreements had been concluded. Negotiations are scheduled to begin during the week of March 15 on these supplemental pacts, which are supposed to cover labor issues, environmental issues and surges in imports that may follow the lowering of trade barriers.
Anne Luzzatto, the press secretary for Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said today that the Administration had not seen the disputed Hufbauer-Schott table, but that "since these numbers can't take into account the effect of the yet-to-be-negotiated supplemental agreements, they are premature."
The Labor Department relied heavily on Mr. Hufbauer's and Mr. Schott's research in developing the Bush Administration's plan last autumn to give financial assistance to workers laid off because of the free trade pact. The Bush Administration never prepared its own estimate of the trade agreement's effects on employment.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN;
Clinton Heads West, Stressing His Plan's Rewards

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Feb. 21

 BODY:
President Clinton traveled to the West Coast today to turn the debate over his economic plan away from the unpleasant topic of what taxpayers will lose to a more politically salable discourse about what he says they will gain.
Appearing before a supportive crowd leavened with politicians and celebrities at Santa Monica College, Mr. Clinton said, "The only reason for reducing the deficit is not just to prove you can bring it down, but because it's better for the people of this country." 
 Conscious of his audience in Southern California, where cuts in the military industry have hit hard, the President announced that he had released $500 million in Federal money set aside for retraining displaced military workers. He said the Bush Administration had refused to release the money, part of $1.7 billion the previous Congress had approved for converting military industries to civilian businesses.
Mr. Clinton said that much of the money would be spent in this state, which could be expected to absorb much of the blow of the $76 billion in additional Pentagon reductions that Mr. Clinton proposed in his budget plan to Congress last week.
 
Heading for Stress Points
 In Seattle on Monday, Mr. Clinton will meet with workers of the Boeing Company, which last week announced it would lay off 28,000 employees. He will be joined there by Vice President Al Gore, and aides said he would announce the Administration's technology policy.
Today in the community college's gymnasium, the President said: "This whole part of the country, which has been the beacon of hope for decades for Americans, is now under great stress. And the economic problems aggravate the underlying social difficulties that you find in every big city in America: more and more poor people, more and more single parent households, more and more children forgotten and left behind."
Mr. Clinton also said he had made tougher decisions than either past Presidents or past Congresses had been willing to make. And he pledged that any package he supported would have to retain the balance he sought.
"I will not support a tax increase, even a tax increase on the wealthiest 1.2 percent of the American people -- who are the only people whose rates are being raised -- I won't support that until I know we have the spending cuts too," he said. "I don't think anybody should pay more until we cut more."
Paul Begala, a political consultant who has been traveling with Mr. Clinton to advise him on how to direct his sales talks, said the intent of today's speech was to place the call for action squarely at Congress's door.
 
Using the Bully Pulpit
 "This is not a game," Mr. Begala said. "He's had four weeks to come up with 150 spending cuts. Some of these folks up there had four years. Some of them had four decades. Surely they can come up with something."
Mr. Begala said the President had taken to the road to demonstrate his commitment to forcing his economic plan through Congress. The President's advisers are also convinced that Mr. Clinton is particularly effective on the campaign stump, where he can be seen talking to citizens outside of the confines of the White House.
"The power of the Presidency to use the bully pulpit is significant," Mr. Begala said. "And with this President, it's more than most."
Mr. Clinton, apparently hewing to a campaign tenet that a central point can never be made too many times, once again challenged Congress to pass his economic package unless they can suggest better and more specific spending cuts.
"Nobody wants to talk about half the things that I tried to deal with in this budget, because they're too painful," Mr. Clinton said. "But if you only worry about what's happening today and tomorrow you never really look beyond that."
Dismissing Republican criticism that his plan uses gimmickry to bring about spending cuts, he said voters should tell their representatives in Congress that "you just can't have the sweet parts if this program; you've got to have the tough parts, too."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN;
Energy Tax's Effect Understated Up to 50%, Industry Officials Say

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
The proposed tax on energy would be much larger than the Clinton Administration asserts, costing a typical family as much as $500 a year rather than $320, industry officials and a former Secretary of Energy contended today.
In budget documents released by the Administration last week, the energy tax was projected to raise $22 billion a year after it was fully phased in on July 1, 1996. But industry critics said today that the tax would actually raise $33 billion or more. 
 "It understates the effect on a family of four by 50 percent," said Charles J. DiBona, president of the American Petroleum Institute, the industry's chief trade association. For gasoline, he suggested that the new tax would raise the retail price by 10 cents a gallon, not the 7 1/2 cents projected by the White House.
The Administration has estimated that an average family of four would pay about $120 a year more in direct taxes and about $200 a year more in indirect costs passed on by businesses if the proposed energy taxes were approved.
James R. Schlesinger, Energy Secretary in the Carter Administration and now a consultant in Washington, said he had reached the same conclusion. "The numbers just didn't stack up," he said after analyzing them over the past few days. "The tax turns out to be understated. The oil industry will by itself pay about $20 billion."
 
Difference of Opinion
 In response, an aide to Lloyd Bentsen, the Treasury Secretary, flatly called the critics wrong. And a career Treasury Department analyst, who spoke on condition of anonymity, cited various factors that he said refuted the criticism, among them the decline in demand that usually results from higher taxes.
"I feel pretty confident that it's all there -- and it's right," said this analyst, a financial economist who is not a political appointee.
Mr. DiBona's argument was fairly straightforward, based on American consumption of 17 million barrels of oil a day, or 6.2 billion barrels a year. Since the tax on oil is to be $3.47 a barrel, this comes to $21.5 billion a year, just below the $22 billion projected to be raised by taxing all energy -- coal, natural gas, nuclear fuel and hydro-power as well as petroleum.
The petroleum institute acknowledged that the Clinton plan did not tax nonfuel uses, like oil that becomes part of a plastic product. These are estimated at 10 percent to 15 percent of fuel use.
And both industry and Administration spokesmen agreed that the White House had properly accounted for three measures aimed at minimizing the tax burden on the poor -- the earned income tax credit, the food stamp program and the low-income energy assistance program.
One source of disagreement was what the Treasury Department analyst called "behavior adjustments." Those adjustments reflect the fact that a price increase for any product tends to reduce demand and may also encourage demand for alternatives. "There is some conservation," the analyst said.
He also pointed to what was probably the biggest factor in the Adminstration's calculation of net tax revenues of $22 billion a year. This reflected assumptions about how the rise in the energy tax would affect such things as jobs, incomes and inflation.
The main point of dispute, then, appeared to be over an Administration assertion that consumption of oil would rise modestly through the year 2000, even with the tax increases, "representing modest conservation and fuel switching without shock to the real economy."
Mr. DiBona contended that demand for oil in the year 2000 would be at least 8 percent higher, nearly as much as without the tax. This meant, he said, that the Administration's argument, rather than undermining his position, supports it.

A NEW HOME (IN NEW YORK) FOR LETTERMAN
CBS has bought the Ed Sullivan Theater on Broadway to serve as the new studio home for David Letterman, making it certain that his late-night show will continue to be produced in New York after he switches to CBS from NBC this summer, CBS officials say. Cuomo. But the method Mr. Weprin proposes would give the selection process at least the appearance of openness. Edward V. HEADLINE: Trade Partners Back Clinton

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Representatives of the leading industrial countries praised President Clinton's deficit-reduction plan over the weekend, but they voiced concern about the troubled international and Russian economies, diplomats said.
The closed meeting in New York of senior officials on Saturday, the first economic gathering of major nations since Mr. Clinton took office last month, reached no decisions. 
 The session was mainly intended to prepare the way for a full-scale ministerial meeting of the so-called Group of Seven next Saturday.
 
U.S. Looking for a Deal
United States officials say they hope that Washington can strike a deal with the other Group of Seven nations in the coming months on a common strategy to spur lagging global growth, and they are optimistic that Mr. Clinton's new economic plan will help them achieve that.
The other nations -- Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy and Japan -- have been pressing the United States for years to put its fiscal house in order.
"If we get this package through . . . that puts us in a much more credible position, a more influential position where this country can restore its rightful leadership and help" the Group of Seven nations, United States Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said Friday.
Diplomats said that the deputy finance ministers who met Saturday seemed impressed by the plan and voiced hopes that it would be passed by Congress. But they added that this preliminary support did not mean the United States would have an easy time convincing its allies to take the action it believes necessary to spur world growth.

HEADLINE: Peru's Leader Clears a Path With Sharp Elbows

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru

 BODY:
One morning in January, Alberto Arciniegas, a retired army general, looked out of his bedroom window here and noticed that his armed guards had disappeared.
A few weeks earlier, General Arciniegas presided over a secret military tribunal that imposed a life sentence on Abimael Guzman Reynoso, founder of the Shining Path guerrilla movement. Suddenly stripped of Government protection, the general started to hear the terrorist clock ticking loudly. 
 Within hours, he and his family were flying to political exile in Argentina. With the general's departure, President Alberto K. Fujimori had knocked another rival off Peru's political chessboard.
At midterm, Peru's President rules isolated from organized political support, relying largely on a power base formed by public opinion polls. With a series of authoritarian moves, starting last April with the suspension of the Constitution and the closing of Congress and the courts, Mr. Fujimori has forced into exile or retirement a long list of allies turned enemies.
"Fujimori is a solitary man in power," said Enrique Bernales Ballesteros, a human rights advocate who was a Senator until Mr. Fujimori closed Congress. "He's insecure and mistrustful."
 
U.S. to Review Aid
 The nature of the Fujimori presidency will become an issue for the Clinton Administration this spring when it reviews a $255 million aid request inherited from the Bush Administration. Largely for economic aid, this request is double last year's level and is one of Latin America's highest.
Mr. Fujimori's defenders say that his authoritarian brand of democracy is an evil far less significant than an army coup or a takeover by the Shining Path revolutionaries, a violent group whose leaders admire Mao and Stalin.
So far, Peruvians seem to accept this argument. In the last 18 months, Mr. Fujimori's public approval ratings have not fallen below 50 percent. His popularity has been sustained by sharply reduced inflation and the dramatic capture of Mr. Guzman.
On a continent where corruption charges provoked the impeachment of Brazil's President last year and two coup attempts against Venezuela's President, Peru's President carefully cultivates an image of the honest, hard-working outsider. Mr. Fujimori's popularity crosses borders, something that is rare for Latin America.
 
Authoritarian Portent?
 In Venezuela, his approval rating is 75 percent -- about 10 times that of Venezuela's President, Carlos Andres Perez. The authoritarian Mr. Fujimori may be a face of Latin American politics to come.
Paradoxically, although Peruvian per capita incomes are now at the same levels they were in the 1960's, Mr. Fujimori's popularity remains strong. Fearful of a fatal dip in the polls, Mr. Fujimori jealously guards his two trophies: the arrest of Mr. Guzman, and Peru's 1992 inflation rate of 57 percent, the lowest in 15 years.
When Peru's television and magazines gave glowing coverage of a police general who directed the manhunt for Mr. Guzman, Mr. Fujimori shunted the general aside to what one journalist here called "a broom-closet office." Tarnishing the glitter, Shining Path attacks increased from an average of four a day before the arrest to an average of six a day until the end of the year.
When an Economy Minister, Carlos Bolona Behr, started to get a large part of the credit for low inflation, Mr. Fujimori abruptly dismissed him, in January. To soothe business people alarmed over the dismissal, Government officials promised continuity, or "bolonismo without Bolona." The free-market policies of Mr. Bolona include the sale of state companies, severe budget austerity and Peru's return to international credit markets.
 
The Common Touch
 Contributing to the steep drop in inflation are a sharp increase in tax collection, which helped close the big budget deficit; a rise in rates for money-losing state utility companies so less money would have to be printed to cover their losses, and reductions in the real salaries of Government employees.
One cost of the attack on inflation has been a surge in the number of poor people during Mr. Fujimori's tenure, from 7 million in 1990 to 12 million today out of a total population of 22 million, according to Government figures. Mr. Fujimori has vowed to restore economic growth this year.
In a modern version of a long tradition of personalist politics in Latin America, Mr. Fujimori stays on top without the aid of an organized political party.
Instead of addressing the people from a palace balcony overlooking Lima's central plaza, the President prefers Sunday evening television talk shows. And instead of the ornate oratory of his Latin predecessors, this 56-year-old son of Japanese immigrants prefers Spanish that is short, direct and unadorned.
In Peru's ethnic mix, the President's Japanese ancestry is now an asset. In this Pacific Coast nation, people routinely tell poll takers that the nation they most admire is Japan. Plastic surgeons here do a booming business changing the features of Peruvians so they can emigrate to Japan with false papers of Japanese ancestry to seek employment.
With Fujimori-style pragmatism now stamping politics here, Lima residents on Jan. 29 overwhelmingly re-elected Mayor Ricardo Belmont, a political independent whose slogan was "Work, Not Talk." Reflecting a general collapse of traditional political parties, the mayoral candidate of the Popular Revolutionary American Alliance, long Peru's most powerful party, received only 3 percent of the vote in Lima. The party scored poorly nationwide, winning only two mayoralities in the north, its traditional stronghold.
 
A Scattershot Approach
 To maintain an independent image, Mr. Fujimori deliberately fires his verbal machine guns in all directions.
In recent weeks, he branded as "traitors" a group of navy officers under investigation for corruption, tried to justify to the people the dismissal of 20 percent of Peru's diplomatic corps by asserting that several were homosexuals, brushed off charges that army officers arrested in connection with plotting a coup had been tortured in custody, charged that some human rights advocates were "apologists for terrorism" and allowed an important minister to say that some reporters were "information terrorists."
"Peru is in very bad shape and these criticisms of soldiers, diplomats and journalists go over well with the man in the street because Fujimori is attacking the establishment," said Alfredo Torres, manager of Apoyo, an independent polling service. "It also knocks the opposition off base because he is always changing targets."
Indeed, Mr. Fujimori's popularity hit its highest recorded level, 81 percent, immediately after he unexpectedly closed Peru's courts and Congress in April.
"Only 2 percent of Peruvians have real access to Government," said Hernando de Soto, a former Government adviser. "For the other 98 percent, the difference is not great between a Peruvian President who is a democrat and one who is a dictator."
 
A History of Coups
 Mr. Fujimori and his press spokesman, Carlos Orellana, have declined all interview requests from The New York Times over the last year. No reason has been given.
While most of the President's oral darts do little more than leave flesh wounds in Peru's elite, many politicians warn that attacking the army is risky in a country that has a long history of coup attempts.
After the coup attempt in November, Mr. Fujimori enraged army commanders by briefly billeting 3 generals and 10 other officers in a maximum-security prison here that holds convicted Shining Path guerrillas. Confronting open rebellion from the military high command in mid-December, Mr. Fujimori canceled a trip abroad and stayed home to retire several popular generals, including General Arciniegas.
But by mid-January, Peru's National Intelligence Service was detecting more army plotting. A loner by nature, Mr. Fujimori once commented, "The intelligence service is the only institution I trust."
But with polls showing that most Peruvians expect a new coup attempt this year, many politicians wonder whether Mr. Fujimori should rely entirely on a service that detected the November attempt only at the eleventh hour.
[On Feb. 18, 28 of the officers accused of plotting to overthrow Mr. Fujimori were given prison sentences ranging from six months to eight years.]
 
Caution Is Advised
 "The Government's main support base is the army, but the armed forces are divided," said Pedro Caceres Velazquez, a nonaligned member of the new Government-controlled Congress that convened here on Jan. 1. "Fujimori should be more cautious and careful with the military."
Nor do Mr. Fujimori's authoritarian innovations win applause overseas.
Since August, 154 Shining Path suspects have gone before secret military tribunals where hooded judges preside. Of the accused, 85 percent have been convicted, and 104 have been sentenced to life imprisonment. New legislation provides life sentences for teachers convicted of proselytizing for Shining Path and for journalists convicted of "apology of terrorism." Mr. Fujimori plans to hold a national referendum this year to win public approval for establishing the death penalty.
Fostering a climate of intimidation, military tribunals in late January convicted of treason the two lawyers who defended Mr. Guzman in his October trial and sentenced them to life in prison.
Prison directors have barred visits by the International Committee of the Red Cross since September. Red Cross prison visits were at the top of a list of human rights conditions stipulated by the Bush Administration for giving aid to Peru. Officials at the United States Embassy here predict that Congress and the Clinton Administration will require tighter compliance with human rights standards in return for the approval and release of the proposed American aid.
 
Press Freedom Erodes
 "Freedom of the press in Peru is steadily eroding in what appears to be a broad campaign by the Fujimori Government to intimidate or silence critics and political opponents," Americas Watch, a division of Human Rights Watch in New York, said in early February.
The group cited the jailings of four reporters last year, the libel conviction of Enrique Zileri, Peru's most influential magazine publisher, and a police investigation of Ricardo Uceda, editor of another news weekly.
Often at odds with Europe and the United States, Mr. Fujimori, however, has his finger firmly on Peru's pulse.
Asked in January to select "Peru's three greatest problems" from a 22-item list, respondents in a recent Apoyo poll here named terrorism, unemployment and poverty.
Human rights violations ranked 10th. "The interruption of the constitutional regime" ranked last.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru, who has been noted for being solitary and insecure, has forced into exile a long list of allies-turned-enemies. Nevertheless, Mr. Fujimori's public approval rating has not fallen below 50 percent, in part because of Peru's reduced inflation. (Bernstein-Spoone/Gamma-Laison)

HEADLINE: States Are Ready to Spend Extra Clinton Transit Aid

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

 BODY:
Officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are anticipating a windfall of more than $435 million in new transportation aid as part of President Clinton's economic stimulus package. They say that if the money is approved by Congress, it could create about 12,000 new jobs this year as local highways, bridges, and subway stations are rebuilt.
While transportation officials are still analyzing details that were released in Washington last week, they have already calculated what share of President Clinton's $4.16 billion in transportation proposals they will get if the $30 billion package, intended to provide an immediate stimulus to the economy, is passed in full. 
 White House officials, who are expected to submit the proposals to Congress this week, have said that they hope the package will be passed before the Easter recess in early April so that the money will be available in time for summer.
Partly because the new money would restore most of what Congress cut from transportation projects last year, after authorizing the spending a year earlier, Representative Jerrold Nadler of Manhattan said yesterday that he thought it "quite likely" that the plan would be enacted with minor adjustments. The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, has voiced similar sentiment, but other senators have expressed reservations about voting to spend before they vote to cut the deficit.
 
'Coming at a Good Time'
 Aware that the political mood in Washington is as unpredictable as in any state capital, local officials are nonetheless optimistic.
"It's money coming at a good time," said Mortimer L. Downey, chief financial officer at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, whose own infrastructure budget is in limbo until the New York State Legislature sorts out a budget, due April 1. "It will be used for stuff that would not get done otherwise."
Officials in Albany, Trenton and Hartford all said that new aid would be spent either to start projects that were ready to go -- planned, designed and postponed because of state budget constraints -- or to accelerate those already underway. In both cases, they said, the spending would be for projects that can start, and put people to work, within 60 days from the time Congress approves it.
"It's use it or lose it," said Thomas M. Downs, Commissioner of Transportation in New Jersey, which expects to receive at least $115 million more. "One of the criticisms of spending money on transportation has been that it takes too long before you see any of it in the economy, but this package is designed to go only to projects that can start right away."
 
To Some, a Modest Snack
 At the same time, some transportation experts likened the new money to a modest snack that will quickly disappear in the jaws of an ever-hungry transportation system, especially in New York City, which is badly underfed in maintenance and repairs. New York State hopes to get $250 million more but it is not clear how much will be spent on New York City projects.
Twelve thousand new jobs are not likely to make a noticeable dent in the region's overall unemployment, since more than 400,000 were out of work in New York State alone last month.
"It's very much needed," said Raymond R. Ruggieri, director of the New York Metropolitan Transportation Council, a planning organization for the State Department of Transportation. "But it's really only a tiny amount of what we need overall."
For example, while the M.T.A. is expecting $80 million of the total tri-state funds, it is still waiting to hear from Albany about its request for $9.6 billion for capital improvements over a five-year period.
 
Wouldn't Avert Fare Increase
 M.T.A. executives have also warned that a 25-cent fare increase may be necessary in April if their $185 million operating deficit is not plugged by lawmakers. But the Federal aid is for infrastructure and will not affect the possible fare increase. Mr. Downey said the new grants would probably be spent to renovate subway stations and replace outdated signal systems.
The Clinton Administration asked every state in late January to submit a lists of projects that were ready to go, to learn how many total jobs could be produced quickly.
New York officials spotted $425 million worth of such projects, New Jersey found $280 million worth, Connecticut listed $250 million worth, and the M.T.A. found $305 million worth.
 
Less Generosity for Transit
 Transportation officials noted that the President's proposal was more generous with financing for highways and bridges than for mass transportation. The package would restore virtually the full amount of Federal aid for highways and bridges that Congress originally authorized under the $151 billion Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991, known by transportation mavens as ISTEA, which they pronounce "ice tea."
Yet for transit, President Clinton's proposal would restore only part of the grant that was cut last year.
"It's unfortunate, because mass transportation needs it most," said James Tripp, counsel for the Environmental Defense Fund. "I think it reflects the overall influence of state departments of transportation and county highway departments. There's a bias toward highways."
More aid may come for aviation and high-speed rail projects, but will be at the discretion of the Federal Department of Transportation. Highway and most transit financing is divided among states on a predetermined formula based on population.
In New York City, the highways that may benefit include the Cross-Bronx Expressway, the Major Deegan Expressway, the Van Wyck Expressway and the Grand Central Parkway. M. Michael Francese, regional director of the New York State Department of Transportation, said that the department had planned to repair sections of connecting bridges on only two of those four roadways, but would now probably go forward with all of them.
 
Faster Work on I-95
 In Connecticut, which is hoping for about $70 million in new aid for highways and transit, repair work on Interstate 95 in Fairfield County will be accelerated, and reconstruction work on seven different bridges will begin ahead of time.
In New Jersey, Mr. Downs said, a chunk of the new money would be spent to resurface 65 miles of highways throughout the state. Another major project to start is the rebuilding of the Berry's Creek Bridge, near the Meadowlands sports complex.
No matter how great the difference between what help from Washington they would like and what they will get, most of the region's transportation officials seemed pleased with the direction of the new Administration.
"After more than a decade in the wilderness, there is an Administration in Washington that recognizes the importance of public transit," said Peter E. Stangl, chairman of the M.T.A. "That is welcome news."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: Peace From Chaos -- A special report.;
Mozambique's Outlook Brightens As Truce Holds and Drought Ends

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TETE, Mozambique

 BODY:
On a continent of withered promise, where country after country has defeated recent dreams of creating civil order out of chronic chaos, Mozambique has unexpectedly emerged as a candidate for an African success story.
When a cease-fire was signed in October few expected it would end this country's savagely indiscriminate 16-year war, but it has held for months. A ruthless drought that had aid donors touting Mozambique as the next Somalia has been broken by quenching rains, and the country is carpeted with corn.
 
Peace Plus Rain
 Here in the fertile northwest, refugees who fled the insurgent Mozambique National Resistance, or Renamo, are streaming home from border camps in Malawi and rebuilding the cane huts burned by the rebels. In other regions, food and medicine are reaching villagers isolated for many years behind guerrilla battle lines. 
 "We've got a combination of peace and rain, which there hasn't been in Mozambique for a quarter of a century," marveled Arthur M. Hussey 3d, coordinator of relief deliveries for CARE.
Mozambicans from President Joaquim Chissano down to the resettled peasants and dormant warriors describe a universal weariness of war. Foreign donors and diplomats speak of Mozambique with an optimism that surprises them, as a place where the West's post-cold-war ambition of playing midwife to new democracies stands a chance of being fulfilled.
 
Other Crises Distract
 The greatest danger now to Mozambique's tranquillity, almost everyone agrees, is Mozambique's tranquillity.
Lacking scenes of carnage and starvation to disturb Western television audiences, Mozambique is having trouble competing for attention with Somalia and the former Yugoslavia.
As a result, the dispatch of United Nations peacekeeping troops, which is a prerequisite for disarming the rivals, merging them into a new national army and moving toward elections, has fallen far behind schedule.
Some fear the cease-fire faces a serious test in March, when the new crop comes in and Renamo, which was drawn to the peace table in part by hunger, is no longer dependent on foreign handouts.
"Delay is a big danger, of course," President Chissano said in an interview at his oceanside residence in Maputo, the capital. "The soldiers and the Renamo fighters are in the countryside with their arms in hand. They are doing almost nothing, they are waiting to be fed. They can get annoyed."
Aldo Ajello, the United Nations special representative in Mozambique, said he hoped the demobilization of the rival forces could begin in April. The country's first elections, once planned for October, are now tentatively scheduled for June or July of 1994.
Mr. Ajello said his superiors in New York, who have more than enough troops volunteered for policing duty in Somalia, have had trouble finding countries interested in dispatching peacekeepers to Mozambique. The reasons, he said, are obvious:
"Nobody is dying. Nobody is starving. We are not on CNN."
 
The War
In Ravaged Nation, Countless Dead
 To Mozambicans, almost continually at war since 1964, it seemed the dying and starving would never end.
It took 10 years of insurrection to dislodge the Portugese colonialists, who abandoned the country in 1975, looting and sabotaging as they fled. The next year, with a Soviet-backed Marxist Government struggling to find its feet, Renamo was born.
The guerrilla group had its origins in a loose militia recruited by Portuguese industrialists to protect their interests during the war of independence.
This motley band was later adopted by the intelligence service of white-ruled Rhodesia as a tool for destabilizing the Mozambican Government, which provided sanctuary for black Rhodesian insurgents. After blacks won control of Rhodesia (renaming it Zimbabwe), South Africa took over as Renamo's sponsor.
The guerrillas, who proclaimed themselves anti-Communists, waged a scorched-earth war aimed at destroying any sign of Government-sponsored progress. They burned clinics by the hundreds, schools by the thousands. They mined and ambushed along Mozambique's transport corridors, blowing food convoys off the roads with bazookas and immobilizing the ports and railroads that were one of Mozambique's few sources of foreign earnings.
Those who lived under Renamo control tell of massacres and mutilations, rapes and forced labor, and everywhere the kidnapping of children for training as soldiers.
By the late 1980's Renamo had lost its foreign patrons, and the Government had abandoned Communism for a version of free-market pragmatism. But the war raged on.
Of Mozambique's 15 million people, it is estimated that up to one million died, that 1.5 million fled to squalid refugee camps in a half-dozen neighboring countries, and that perhaps 3 million more were driven from their villages into overcrowded towns and cities.
Over the last two years, the misery was compounded by southern Africa's worst drought of the century.
When President Chissano and the rebel leader, Afonso Dhlakama, signed their peace accord last October after two years of international pressure, there was little confidence that either man could deliver what he promised.
Renamo was widely regarded as an uncontrollable gang of young thugs, and Government soldiers were badly demoralized, prone to looting sprees and occasional terrorism. Anarchy seemed the more probable fate of this hungry and gun-saturated land.
 
The Peace
Paralyzed Country Is Stirring Again
 The most immediate sign of normalcy is that Mozambique, long paralyzed, is moving.
Relief workers who relied on remote landing strips for their deliveries in Renamo areas now dispatch aid convoys on the highways. Diplomats and journalists who had hunkered down in Maputo now explore the country by road. Sun-worshipers mosey up the coast from Maputo for the more secluded Indian Ocean beaches.
Cities that had swollen with hungry and fearful peasants are now spilling their crowds back into the countryside, and those trapped for years behind Renamo lines have been allowed to leave, emerging with malnutrition, disease and tales of terror.
When they showed up at a relief center here, Chassassa Nvunganene, 30, and her three skinny children had walked three days from a Renamo zone in the central province of Sofala. They trudged barefoot, surviving on grasshoppers and roots.
Listlessly she recounted a common litany of sorrows: Renamo captives since 1989, one daughter dead of malaria in a Renamo camp, husband killed by a land mind while hauling food for the guerrillas. Only three months after the cease-fire, she said, did their captors relent.
"Renamo said, 'If you want to go, you can go, we don't have food for you,' " Mrs. Nvunganene said, as her 6-year old son fished a squirming grasshopper from a plastic bag and handed it to his little sister.
Western relief workers say the tide of victims like Mrs. Nvunganene has now subsided to a comparative trickle.
Three months ago, said Felice Dindo, the chief delegate for the International Committee of the Red Cross in Mozambique, "we were seeing people starving and nothing moving."
We were blocked on the roads," he said. Now, "the emergency, we can say, is over, at least in the places we've been able to reach."
This is an important caveat. Relief workers believe that in some Renamo strongholds, especially the valley along the Zambezi River, there are still substantial pockets of hungry people stricken by cholera and other disease, isolated by demolished roads and the estimated two million land mines seeded across the country.
Crews are removing the mines and slowly opening routes into these areas.
When Red Cross workers first penetrated late last year into Chibabava, in central Mozambique, Mr. Dindo said, they were alarmed to find 20,000 fearful squatters jammed into the town and a raging cholera epidemic. Doctors and nurses were rushed in, work crews began digging latrines. But in December they found another way to clear up the problem.
"We distributed seeds in December, and the population was down to 2,000 in a matter of a month," Mr. Dindo said. Everyone went home to plant corn.
 
The Combatants
The Road Back To Brotherhood
 Perhaps the most striking sight on a 400-mile drive along the once perilous roads of north and central Mozambique was the casual foot traffic of Renamo fighters and Government soldiers, some armed and others not, exchanging polite greetings as they passed one another.
"Come here, my brother," yelled Tembo Beachane, a Government soldier, hailing a Renamo guerrilla to meet visiting reporters in the market town of Guro.
The guerrilla, Josias Mbaula, had trudged for two days in his knee-high rubber boots to mail letters in Guro and was now meandering back to base, an AK-47 assault rifle strung over his shoulder. A guerrilla for 13 of his 33 years, six times wounded, he now chattered amiably about the peace.
"I fought, I finished, and I am happy," he declared, and like every other combatant interviewed along the route he predicted an easy reconciliation. Gesturing at Mr. Beachane, he said, "We will understand each other because we belong to the same family."
Asked when he would surrender his weapon, and what he wanted to do next, the Renamo man answered automatically, as did almost every Renamo fighter to whom the question was put:
"For me, everything depends on what they tell me to do."
Western peacekeepers who have been surveying the military situation in Mozambique in preparation for demobilization said this answer was typical, and reassuring. It suggests that Renamo is under much tigher control than previously supposed, and thus likely to disarm when ordered.
Indeed, United Nations officials and diplomats said, the guerrillas appear far better disciplined than the disgruntled army.
The plan mapped out by the United Nations calls for fighters -- an estimated 20,000 from Renamo, perhaps 70,000 Government forces -- to be mustered at 49 assembly points policed by international troops.
After registering, turning in their weapons, and getting medical checkups, they will be issued civilian clothes and money. Some will be sent for training as soldiers in the new national army, to be composed of 15,000 men from each side, and the rest returned to their homes.
The object is to avoid the mistakes of Angola, where Western peacemakers pushed for elections before the combatants had been disarmed. Angolan rebels refused to accept their electoral defeat in September, and the renewed fighting has pushed that country to the brink of collapse.
In Mozambique, the Security Council has approved a $330 million budget for a peacekeeping force of about 7,500 troops, but Mr. Ajello, the United Nations representative, said that the budget had been stalled in bureaucracy and that member countries had shown little enthusiasm for sending soldiers.
After much lobbying the United Nations has offers of troops from Italy, Uruguay, Bangladesh, Zambia, Botswana and India, but no country has offered the engineering and logistics units needed to rebuild roads and supply the demobilization centers, he said.
Even so, officials here agree the immediate danger is escalating banditry by restive soldiers, not the resumption of war.
"We are prepared to wait for a little while," said Vincente Z. Ululu, the general secretary of Renamo, after complaining of the delays. "We want everything to be fixed properly so we do not have the same mistake like in Angola."
 
The Refugees
Voting for Peace With Their Feet
 Flying low out of Tete, north toward the jutting mountains of Malawi, a pilot points out the fresh-plaited roofs and green cornstalks of new settlements that were not there last October. This is the district called Angonia, and these are the homes of returned refugees, voting with their feet for peace.
In Ulongue, the district capital of Angonia, the district administrator rattled off the estimates of returnees. In October 1,472. In November 9,228. In December 33,184. In January, when the rain slowed them, 31,530.
The administrator, Evaristo Wezulo, said two-thirds of Angonia's prewar population of 159,000 had fled. Most have already come home. Those who remain behind, relief workers say, are wives and children subsisting on refugee-camp ration cards until the first harvest at home, or children finishing the Malawi school year.
Salvatore Ippolito, who oversees United Nations refugee relief efforts from Tete, said the return was spontaneous and unexpected.
"The peace agreement surprised us," he said. "It worked so fast and so well."
Among the refugees themselves, confidence in the peace depends on how recently they have arrived.
Those fresh from the border, like Maria Viriato, were dubious. Juggling her infant son and a bundle of live chickens, Mrs. Viriato made her way along the road from the border toward her village, Tembwe, laid waste by Renamo in 1987. Her husband had come ahead in December to build a hut and plant a crop.
Was the war really over? she was asked.
"I believe, and I don't believe," she replied.
Those who have been back longer were steadier in their optimism.
Wizidolo Kabango, who returned to his burned-out village in November after hearing about the peace on Malawi radio, felt secure enough that he returned to the refugee camp to fetch his furniture.
With a tiny table and two chairs balanced on his head, he was walking the 15 miles home again, "because there is no more war in Mozambique."
Angonia has the advantage of being fertile and accessible. In other, more devastated regions bordering the southern tip of Malawi, few refugees have gone home because there is no relief lifeline yet to supply them with seeds or to feed them while they plant their first crop.
Mr. Ippolito said that as soon as roads were opened into other areas and seed distributed, donors would gradually cut off rations in Malawi to encourage the rest of Mozambique's displaced to go home.
 
The Outlook
With Passion Spent, Time for Politics
 "Last year we were comparing Mozambique to Somalia," said Felice Dindo of the Red Cross. "This year we were comparing it to Angola." As it happens, Mr. Dindo and others agree, Mozambique is neither, and that may be its salvation.
Unlike Somalia, Mozambique has a functioning Government, and is naturally fertile. Unlike Angola, Mozambique seems to have spent its passions, and to be ready to move to the nonlethal combat of politics.
It is too early to say how robust the new democracy will be. Several opposition parties are functioning, but they are penniless and, except for Renamo's political wing, largely unknown. In the countryside, few people have heard about the plans for elections.
Almost everyone assumes the ruling party, Frelimo, will win the first elections by default. Renamo leaders say they would accept that outcome, if the elections are fair, and foreign observers here tend to believe them.
Among the civilians brutalized by the war, there is lack of vengefulness that is astonishing to an outsider. Some educated Mozambicans attribute it to fatalism, others to the ancient southern African tradition that vanquished enemies are incorporated into the tribe, and still others to a talent for postponing vengeance.
Perhaps it is simply fatigue with a war that people say made no sense to them. Time and again, victims almost shrugged off their suffering, blaming not Renamo or the Government but "the war."
Although Mozambique's calamity has eased, it is still a long way from the "prosperidade" promised on the Government's New Year billboards in Maputo.
"We will need aid, in terms of food and other aid, for some years to come," said President Chissano. With regular rains, he estimates, the country can again be self-sufficient in food within three years. "This will consolidate the peace."
Manuel Lopes da Costa, the Portuguese Ambassador in Maputo, said Mozambique could expect a quick infusion of income from the reopening of the railroads and ports, and from the sale of energy from a power plant idled by the war.
"I would not be surprised if in two or three years the need in Mozambique will be reduced to one-third of what it is now," Mr. Lopes da Costa said. "I would not be surprised if in a decade Mozambique would be a perfectly viable nation."
 
 
 
MOZAMBIQUE AT A GLANCE
 HISTORY: Portugese colonized the Indian Ocean coast in the late 15th century, but inland principalities remained autonomous until the early 20th century. In the intervening years the area was an important trading center for gold, ivory and slaves. Mozambique became independent on June 25, 1975, after 10 years war. The ruling party, the Front for the Liberation of Mozambique (Frelimo) espoused Communism and one-party rule, but it shifted toward free markets and legalized rival parties at end of the 1980's.
ECONOMY: Mainly agricultural, producing cashews, cotton and sugar for export. The ports and railroads are vital corridors for landlocked neighbors.
PEOPLE: Of the estimated 15 million. there is no dominant ethnic group, but Makua people are thought to be most numerous. The civil war hads a faint ethnic-regiona l undercurrent, with southern Shangaan disproportionately represented in Government, and Ndau and other groups from the center and north tending to predominate in Renamo.
LAND AREA: 303,769 square miles, about twice the size of California.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: February 22, 1993

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1806 words

HEADLINE: As Plants Close, Injury Claims Rise

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
On June 1, 1991, a jeans manufacturer named Big Yank shut an Oklahoma factory employing 225 workers. As the plant closed, the employees filed nearly 400 workers' compensation claims for injuries on the job, despite having filed only 6 in the previous year.
The company, which had already been battered by foreign competitors with lower labor costs, saw workers' compensation premiums for its nine factories across the country rise to more than $3.6 million a year from $1.8 million. It says the increase forced it to shut three more factories that had employed 800 American workers. 
 "Workers' compensation has been an abomination for us," said Kerry Mortensen, chief financial officer of the Big Yank Corporation, based in Lexington, Ky. "It is a major American tragedy. People don't realize that the abuse of workers' comp is causing the loss of our own jobs."
 
 
Link to Plant Closings
 Big Yank's complaint illustrates a problem widely reported by employers and insurance companies but little studied so far on a national scale: when companies close plants -- as they have during this latest recession -- workers' compensation claims often skyrocket.
Lawyers defending workers argue that a flurry of claims at a plant closing reflects the plight of injured and mistreated employees who chose not to file justifiable claims until they faced unemployment.
"There are many people who are not totally dysfunctional, but they are the working hurt," said Lloyd B. Rowe, the president of the California Applicants Attorney Association, a group for lawyers in workers' compensation practice. "Now their source of income has been removed, their medical insurance has been ended and they may have little or no chance of getting another job."
 
 
System's Intent
 But companies argue that the workers' compensation system of private insurance, devised at the turn of the century to support workers disabled on the job, has evolved into one that helps protect workers from economic blows.
Companies say this evolution has been helped along by insurers that have paid the claims with little question. The insurers counter that in many states such claims are hard to dispute because the laws are so lenient.
Because workers' compensation insurance is required by almost every state, some companies in troubled manufacturing industries say they are often forced to pay stiff increases in premiums on top of annual premium increases of 10 percent in many states.
Although experts say there has been no overall study of the problem, data from various states indicate a widespread increase in the use of workers' compensation as unemployment rises. And in recent interviews, risk-management experts, insurance executives and investigators across the nation said employees frequently file waves of workers' compensation claims when plants close in declining industries, particularly in states with liberal workers' compensation laws.
 
 
State-by-State Reports
 In Michigan, Roger Fries, the executive vice president of the Competitive State Accident Fund, a public agency that sells workers' compensation coverage to corporations, said that in many if not a majority of the closings of heavy industrial plants in the state in recent years, 50 percent or more of the workers filed claims for strains and sprains that are not easily disproved. On investigation, he said, his agency found the majority of those workers were motivated not by injuries but by sudden economic hardship. His agency, he said, has fought those claims.
Edward Palsho, the secretary of the New Jersey Manufacturers Insurance Company, the largest workers' compensation insurer in that state, said that it was "extremely common" to find large numbers of workers filing claims for very general breathing and hearing problems upon the closing of foundries and chemical plants.
Cheryl Budd, a spokeswoman for the National Council on Compensation Insurance, a rate-setting organization for the industry, said companies in Louisiana reported bursts of claims when they shut down plants during the state's economic slowdown in the 1980's.
In California, Steve Dornbach, the manager of a special investigation unit of the Transamerica Insurance Company in Orange and San Bernardino Counties, said 40 percent of the claims investigated by his unit involve plant closings, often with as many as 95 percent of the workers filing claims.
The California Department of Labor found that workers' compensation claims for stress-related disabilities rose to 15,668 in 1991 from 10,444 the previous year. Alan Tebb, vice chairman of the California Workers Compensation Institute, a nonprofit research organization, said the increase was driven in large part by the state's economic downturn and corporate layoffs. Long-term studies in Texas also indicate that as unemployment rose in the 1980's, workers' compensation claims jumped.
"When there is a plant closing, often there is just a ton of claims, particularly stress and cumulative-injury claims," Mr. Tebb said. "Employers call it fraud. But others say fraud is in the eye of the beholder."
 
Dwindling Business
 Perhaps there is no more striking example of the phenomenon than that of the Big Yank plant in Wewoka, Okla.
Big Yank was once one of the nation's largest manufacturers of work clothing, operating 24 plants in the 1940's. Like many clothing makers, it has watched revenues slip over the years as it lost business to factories overseas.
Revenues of the company, which produces pants for retailers and marketers like the Gap and Levi Strauss, fell to $65 million last year from $110 million in 1991. Big Yank now operates six factories in the United States and two in the Caribbean that together employ 3,100. Mr. Mortensen, Big Yank's chief financial officer, said the closely held company lost money last year.
In the spring of 1991, the company told workers that it was closing the plant in Wewoka, the only source of employment for many middle-aged men and women in the economically depressed central part of the state.
Several weeks before the closing, Big Yank said, a representative of a workers' compensation law firm met with employees, distributed forms and told them how to file claims. On May 28, 1991, two days before the plant closing, 247 claims were filed, the company said, and the number of filings rose to nearly 400 in the weeks that followed.
 
 
Cumulative Traumas
 None of the claims were related to injuries from a specific accident on the job, the company said, and almost all involved cumulative traumas that are hard to disprove in court: complaints about joint dysfunctions, breathing, hearing and sleeping problems. The claims involved 114 employees, some with six complaints each.
In some cases, husbands and wives, sisters or entire families filed claims that described similar injuries. The forms show that a father, mother and three children all filed claims, describing injuries to hearing, hands, lungs, necks and other body parts, but no injuries from job accidents.
A spokesman for Big Yank, Kim Lassiter, said the company suspected that many of the claims were fraudulent. Lung injuries, though a problem at textile plants where raw cotton dust sometimes fills the air, are rare at factories where finished fabrics are sewn. Of the approximately 40 workers' compensation claims filed at the plant in the preceding three years, he said, the company received few complaints of the type filed once the closing was announced.
Workers' compensation claims are paid by the company's insurer, and a company's track record is used to calculate its future premiums. In 1992, Big Yank says it was told that its annual premiums would more than triple to $5.8 million, from $1.6 million. After disputing the calculation, Big Yank had its premium set at $3.4 million.
 
 
Passing On Higher Prices
 But even that increase was traumatic to a company operating on thin margins in a highly competitive market. The company said it was forced to raise its jeans' wholesale prices, which were $8.50 and $11.50 pair, by 30 cents a pair. As a result, it lost a number of large customers.
With a sudden drop in orders, the company said it had no choice but to close plants in Tyrone, Pa., and in Middlesboro, Ky. The loss of orders was also a big factor in the decision to close yet another plant, in Hattiesburg, Miss. Altogether, about 800 workers lost their jobs at the three sites.
"The cost of doing business became unprofitable for a number of marginal customers," Mr. Mortensen, the company's financial officer, said. "A 2.5 percent rise in the price of a pair of jeans is significant. When we first heard of the higher figure the insurer was going to charge, we thought we would have to close all of our domestic plants."
Big Yank is now suing its insurance company, Liberty Mutual of Boston, for not properly investigating and fighting the fraudulent claims of workers. In its suit, Big Yank has charged that Liberty Mutual saved its own investigative costs and agreed to make payments to 35 former workers for false claims. In cases where Liberty Mutual did take disputes to court, Big Yank said, the insurance company's lawyers were ill prepared.
 
Insurer Faults Laws
 Liberty Mutual says Big Yank's anger is misdirected.
 The Oklahoma workers' compensation laws, which define how much proof a worker needs to show a disability, have been widely criticized for accepting questionable medical diagnoses, inflating awards and giving little deference to information presented by insurers or employers that claims are exaggerated, said James F. Kelleher, Liberty Mutual's assistant vice president and general counsel. Injuries from years of repetitive work are particularly hard to dispute.
Liberty Mutual did the best it could in investigating Big Yank's claims and disputing those that appeared questionable, Mr. Kelleher said. So far it has paid out nearly $1 million, but is still investigating or disputing claims from 64 of the 114 individuals.
"Employers and insurers ought to focus on fixing the system," Mr. Kelleher said.
To the employees in Oklahoma who suddenly found themselves without work in 1991, who had been living on salaries of $9,000 or $13,000 a year, workers' compensation comes as welcome assistance after years of draining toil. In telephone interviews, several former workers who had filed claims said they had been suffering from medical complaints for years but did not know about workers' compensation until the plant was about to close.
"I'd been working at the plant for 17 years, and I had been hurting for 10 years," said Susie M. Harjo, who lives outside Wewoka and said she remains unemployed. "From doing the same thing every day, bending over the machines, the carts, I just hurt all over."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television;
One Offended Viewer Tries To Hit 'Donahue' in Wallet

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
Dozens of companies that were advertising on the "Donahue" show a year ago have stopped doing so, and Dr. Richard Neill says he is the reason.
Last summer, Dr. Neill, a Fort Worth dentist, sat down and watched one of Phil Donahue's talk shows. He didn't like it. 
 "I think it was about a guy who said his mother was a slut," Dr. Neill said. The program, to him, seemed gratuitous -- much too sexually explicit for daytime hours when children might be watching.
Dr. Neill spent $360 for 120 transcripts of various "Donahue" shows and decided he was disturbed enough about the content of several of them to do something about it.
First he tried to persuade WFAA-TV, the local station in Dallas, to put the show on after 11 P.M., which he still says would satisfy him. Having lost that battle, he began a one-man campaign, urging advertisers to drop their support of Mr. Donahue's syndicated talk show.
The total effect of Dr. Neill's campaign is disputed. A wide range of advertisers, including national giants like Kraft/General Foods, General Mills, Seven-Up/Dr Pepper and the Keebler Company, have withdrawn their ads in the last six months.
Dr. O'Neill asserts that more than 130 advertisers have dropped the show because of his campaign, which includes a videotape compilation of "Donahue" moments he found especially offensive, and a long list of references to other excerpts.
He provided copies of dozens of replies from company executives expressing various degrees of support for him. Some said Dr. Neill's letter had led them to drop their sponsorship at once.
Several other companies, however, told a reporter that these pleas were only one factor, or no factor at all, in their decision to stop sponsoring "Donahue." And executives from the show say they have had no trouble finding other sponsors and have not lost a dime.
Lately, Dr. Neill's campaign has included attempts to publicize the success he claims. He has called news conferences in Dallas, and he telephoned The New York Times seeking attention for his cause.
"Donahue" executives say Dr. Neill's list of offenses takes subjects out of context. Among the list of sexually oriented material he cites from shows taped from late 1991 to mid-1992, are four teen-age topless dancers, mother-daughter stripper teams, married couples describing their mate swapping and a sadomasochistic mistress talking about her cages for sex slaves.
"Donahue" is hardly the only daytime talk show that deals with sexual topics, and Dr. Neill, who acknowledges that he does not know much about television, said he took aim at "Donahue" only because that was the show he happened to see.
His effort is the latest example of viewers' taking action to oppose what they consider offensive material on television. Four years ago a Michigan housewife, Terry Rakolta, took on the Fox show "Married . . . With Children" by talking to advertisers, and she received some support from them.
Other campaigns, usually by religious groups, have been more organized.But Dr. Neill said in a phone interview that his was not a religious cause, "though I do go to church regularly." He also said his motivation was not political, "though Phil is at the opposite end of the political spectrum from me; I'm a Rush Limbaugh man."
Many advertising industry executives express concern that if viewers who do not like what they see continue to take aim at advertisers, there might be a chilling effect on the introduction of any sort of controversial subject matter.
But Allen Banks, executive vice president of media for Saatchi & Saatchi, said Dr. Neill's campaign could be described as a form of democracy in action. "I kind of like the idea that one person who doesn't like what he sees can take a stand on principle and have this kind of impact," he said.
Besides, Mr. Banks, said, Mr. Donahue and other daytime hosts may have been risking just such a reaction. "It is because Donahue has stooped to stuff like this, because television in general has stooped to this point, that a campaign like this can have an effect," he said.
So far, "Donahue" has suffered no economic fallout from the advertiser defections, said Robert Turner, president of Multimedia Entertainment, the program's syndicator. He said advertising revenue had increased this season.
"Some advertisers have dropped out," Mr. Turner said. "But a new sponsor, Procter & Gamble, has come in in a big way." And he said Mr. Donahue had no intention of changing the content of his show.
Kraft/General Foods dropped "Donahue" last summer, said Michael Mudd, the vice president for corporate communications, mainly because "it seemed that the majority of the shows were going in the direction of sexually gratuitous material."
Dr. Neill has sent letters to current advertisers, naming those who have dropped out. But some of the former advertisers listed object to this.
"I'm really angry about his using our company that way," said Carol Kirby, vice president of marketing for Baskin-Robbins. "I don't endorse Dr. Neill's campaign. I certainly don't endorse that kind of blackmail."
Mr. Mudd said Kraft "did have some discussions with Dr. Neill, but we had already been looking at 'Donahue' as a show with problems."
"We objected to his using our name to imply that he was involved in our decision," Mr. Mudd added.
But other advertisers said Dr. Neill had shown them the way, and some said it was all right for Dr. Neill to invoke them.
Stuart Greenblatt, director of corporate communications for Keebler, said: "I don't think that we're averse to his using our name. I don't know that if you polled many media people, they wouldn't have this reaction. This is pretty sick stuff."
Mr. Banks of Saatchi & Saatchi said the issue was broader than whether the "Donahue" show might be affected economically by Dr. Neill. "We grapple with this problem all the time," he said. "There's a difference between rocking the boat with some thoughtful subject that's being discussed in a serious way, and any subject being discussed. If an advertiser sees something inappropriate for them to be associated with, they should be able to make the decision to drop out without feeling they're deserting the greater good of television. If Phil got out of these subjects, he'd have a better show anyway."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Fixated on Texas and No Apologies

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 21

 BODY:
Ross Perot showed up on the cover of Texas Monthly last year caricatured as Alfred E. Neuman, along with the headline, "What, Me President?" Gov. Ann W. Richards came along the next month in a much-doctored photograph, leather-jacketed and straddling a Harley-Davidson. "White Hot Mama," the magazine called her.
When the state's economy took a dive in the 1980's, Texas Monthly was right there with a helpful feature, "Life Styles of the Rich and Bankrupt (How Texans Go Bust Without Going Broke)." And it's not as if the magazine only cares about politics and finance. "Hats Off to Big Hair! A Tribute to a Texas Classic" was a recent cover story. 
 But if one cover symbolizes why Texas Monthly has survived as so many other regional magazines collapsed in recent years, it might be this month's, on an issue that celebrates the magazine's 20th anniversary. A globe swirls through the universe with a single, large land mass on it -- the state of Texas.
The magazine has endured in part because its founder and publisher, Michael R. Levy, insisted on a single focus -- a consuming, if not exactly reverent, interest in all things Texan. And many of its employees and readers cite a broader reason behind its commercial success -- the way Texans view themselves.
"There is a difference between a Texan and a New Englander," said Joseph Nocera, who has written for both Texas Monthly and New England Monthly, which is now defunct. "A person in Massachusetts does not define himself first and foremost as a New Englander, whereas a person who lives in Dallas or San Antonio or Amarillo is very likely to define himself pre-eminently as a Texan. That is something very important."
 
Refusal to Be a Casualty
 The regional-magazine market has claimed victims across the country in recent years, from California magazine to New England Monthly, with Rocky Mountain, Southern and others in between. But Texas Monthly, with a circulation of 309,000 and advertising revenue that approached $18 million last year (up 6.5 percent from 1991), is very much alive.
State and regional magazines "are usually a disaster," said Martin S. Walker, chairman of a Manhattan-based magazine consulting firm, Walker Communications. "Advertisers generally don't target states. They target major metropolitan market areas."
Many city-based magazines, including the ones named after New York and Los Angeles, have prospered, Mr. Walker added, because of their natural advertising base and because it is easier to find a common base of reader interest.
"But can you imagine trying to do a magazine in New York State that would appeal to people in New York City and Buffalo and Schenectady all at the same time?" he said.
Texas Monthly, though, which began its third decade with a black-tie-and-boots bash here Saturday night, does the equivalent. Lawrence Wright, a longtime writer for the magazine, said it had managed both to tap into and to feed Texas's perception of itself as "a place apart, kind of like the Quebec of America."
"Texas is like a sub-nation," said Mr. Wright, who recently left to become a staff writer at The New Yorker. "It's really wired itself that way, and Texas Monthly is part of the matrix that draws it together."
And Daniel Okrent, who left as president of Texas Monthly Press to found New England Monthly in 1984, said one problem he faced was the lack of "common institutions" in New Englanders' lives.
"There are certain Texas institutions that everybody has reason to be concerned with -- the governor, the university, the oil industry," said Mr. Okrent, now the editor of Life magazine, going on to add less seriously, "cowboy hats and big boots."
"That's less true in New England," he said, adding that the problem extended to the critical task of luring regionwide advertisers as well. "Once you get past Jordan Marsh and Filene's, those things don't exist," he said. New England Monthly went out of business in 1990.
If anybody ought to know the perils of trying to reproduce the Texas Monthly success elsewhere, it is Mr. Levy, the magazine's brazen, balding publisher. He bought New West magazine in 1980, changed the name to California, and promptly lost, by all accounts, a lot of money.
"It was a major debacle," Mr. Levy said cheerfully in his Austin office, though he refused to disclose either the exact losses or the terms of his sale of a minority share of Texas Monthly in 1987 to Dow Jones & Company to pay them off.
"We were dumb," he said. "The state is different than Texas. We really thought California was a cohesive community of interests -- you know, Southern California, Northern California, it's all California. It's not. It's more like Bosnia and Herzegovina."
What Mr. Levy says he learned is this: "If you can do one thing, do it well." Altogether, Texas Monthly has won seven National Magazine Awards, the industry equivalent of a Pulitzer Prize.
Both the layout and the writing are lively. Nicholas Lemann, a former executive editor, describes it as having "very high editorial quality with very low snob appeal -- it's a magazine written for a world of smart people who don't worry about whether they're ordering the right wine." (Perhaps. But the coming issue does have a feature on the right clothes to wear for an "encounter with the Texas wilderness.")
 
Tacky? No, Truly Absurd
 If there are few sacred steers in Texas Monthly, there are plenty of Bum Steers -- which is the name of an annual feature that celebrates "the best of the worst" in the state.
Some winners in recent years have included the East Texas entrepreneur who announced plans for a drive-though funeral parlor where motorists could view the deceased without leaving their cars; an Exxon subsidiary that described the odor of a newly developed diesel fuel as "a strong, fruity fragrance accentuated with floral top notes," and the Texas mother accused of hiring someone to assassinate her daughter's chief rival for a cheerleading spot.
That the focus of the magazine is so purely Texan has long been a source of staff dissension. Some writers argue that it should expand into a sort of Texas-based national magazine that addressed non-Lone Star topics.
But Mr. Levy, 46, and Gregory Curtis, who followed William Broyles Jr. as only the second top editor in the magazine's history, have staunchly resisted. "Everything in the magazine," Mr. Curtis said, "is about Texas, one way or another. Period."
Even many of those who argued with Mr. Curtis about the magazine's focus are now willing to admit that his instincts were probably wise. "But you have to understand, Texas felt a million percent different in 1981," said Mr. Lemann, who as the 26-year-old executive editor at the time was one of those firmly pushing for expansion. "It was incredibly ambitious. There was a sense that Texas was the rising region of the country."
Of course, the oil bust changed all that, and the magazine's horizons receded along with the state's. Today Mr. Lemann, an author and correspondent for The Atlantic who is still a contributing editor to Texas Monthly, acknowledges: "Perhaps my idea of Texas as the centerpiece of America was a little unrealistic. I can still make the case, though. All three Presidential candidates this last year were Texan. Or bordering Texan."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "If you can do one thing, do it well," said Michael R. Levy, right, founder and publisher of Texas Monthly. At left is Gregory Curtis, editor of the magazine, which celebrates its 20th anniversary this year. (Zigy Kaluzny for The New York Times)
