HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Coffee Romance Leads to a Hit Book

BYLINE: By SUZANNE CASSIDY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
In the United States, the serial television commercials for Taster's Choice coffee have attracted a fair amount of interest. But in Britain, where the soap opera-like commercials originated more than five years ago, they have become something of a national obsession. 
 The ads, now approaching their 12th episode (there have been five in the United States), are for Gold Blend, as the coffee is known here. And they have come in for the sort of attention ordinarily reserved for royal romances.
In December, when The Sun, Britain's biggest-selling daily tabloid, discovered that the yuppie male character in the commercial was finally going to tell the female yuppie character that he loved her, it splashed the news across its front page.
And when, earlier this month, "Love Over Gold," a paperback novel inspired by the commercials, was published, even the country's quality press had a caffeine fit.
 
When Yucky Is Forgivable
 The Independent, a newspaper that normally displays the calmness of a decaf drinker, decided that the occasion merited an editorial. It said that while the commercials might have a "heavy yuck factor," the publication of "Love Over Gold" was a triumph for Nestle U.K., the makers of Gold Blend, and for its advertising agency, McCann-Erickson.
It was, acknowledged Michael Freter, executive director of McCann-Erickson, more of a marketing triumph than a literary one. "Love Over Gold," he said, "is not going to have Charles Dickens turning over in his grave."
But literary quality, or the lack of it, has hardly stopped it from selling. After less than two weeks on bookstore shelves, "Love Over Gold" appeared on The Sunday Times's paperback fiction best-seller list today at No. 10.
Nicholas Clee, book-news editor of The Bookseller, a trade weekly, said he finds the commercials "very, very banal" and their characters "insufferably smug." Nevertheless, he said he could understand why Corgi Books, which published "Love Over Gold," proposed the book to Nestle.
The publishing industry, plagued by the recession, likes a few "sure-fire hits," Mr. Clee said, adding that "a book that spins off an advertisement which is seen by millions of people is very attractive."
 
Fish and Fish Again
 John Saddler, the senior editor at Corgi who dreamed up "Love Over Gold," said he had been inspired by a book titled "Fly Fishing" by J. R. Hartley, which was prompted by a television commercial for Britain's Yellow Pages. So successful was that book that its publisher, Stanley Paul, a subsidiary of Random House Ltd., recently issued a sequel, "J. R. Hartley Casts Again."
"Love Over Gold" was written by an established mystery writer, Susan Moody, under the pseudonym Susannah James. Using the British commercials as the framework for her story, Ms. James does write a happy ending for the Gold Blend couple. But it is by no means a certain one, so a sequel would not be impossible.
Neither Nestle nor Corgi would say if Nestle had shared the costs of producing "Love Over Gold" or would get a portion of any profits. Nestle's involvement, however, is evident in the design of the book: the Nescafe Gold Blend logo appears on the front and back covers, and the typeface of the title, rendered in red and gold, matches the logo on the Gold Blend jar. There is also an order form at the back of the book for compilation videotapes of the commercials.
 
Publicity Beyond Purchase Price
 And what the book has yielded in media coverage has made the exercise more than worthwhile for Nestle.
The campaign has been a "stunning success," said Dominic Mills, editor of Campaign, a weekly advertising journal. The company, he said, "could not have paid" for the coverage generated first by the on-screen romance and now by the book. It was probably worth "three or four times" what Nestle spent, he said .
What Nestle did spend was an average of $9.4 million a year on the British television campaign, a company spokesman, Allan Allbeury, said. That investment has yielded results: since October 1987, when the first commercial was shown, Gold Blend sales in Britain have risen by 40 percent, Mr. Allbeury said.
Now, to encourage sales of "Love Over Gold," he said, Nestle, at a cost of $1.4 million, will run two-minute montages of the 11 Gold Blend commercials on British television through Thursday.
This marriage of literature and advertising may seem strange to some, but it is something Mr. Mills expects to see more of.
"It is just a question of finding the right product," he said. "There are only certain products for which it is appropriate."

HEADLINE: Treasury to Sell Bills and Notes This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this week begins with the regular weekly auction today of new three- and six-month bills. Two-year notes will be auctioned on Tuesday, followed by a five-year note auction on Wednesday.
Traders said that by late in the day on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 2.91 percent and the rate on a six-month bill was 3.00 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year issue was being offered at a price to yield 4.01 percent and the five-year to yield 5.29 percent.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 697 words

HEADLINE: The Right Budget Track, Mostly

 BODY:
The Clinton economic plan envisions an America that provides "rising living standards for all its citizens." The lofty goal may not be reached. But that should not detract from President Clinton's achievement: He has put forward a credible, honest plan for government, after 12 years of less-than-benign neglect, to help put America's economic house in order.
Mr. Clinton's vision stakes out three objectives: speed recovery to put millions of Americans back to work as soon as possible; cut the long-term deficit to pump money into private capital markets; and retarget Government spending away from consumption and toward investment. 
 The plan -- which has gained important backing from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman -- moves on all three fronts. However, Mr. Clinton's political antennae kept him from doing more, faster. There's room for Congress to improve the plan. But it would be just fine to adopt the plan as is and fine-tune later.
Stimulating Recovery: Unemployment is higher now than when the recession ended almost two years ago. And the number of unemployed workers who will never regain their old jobs is near record levels. Mr. Clinton proposes a two-year, $30 billion stimulus package, split evenly between spending hikes and tax cuts for private investors.
To make a sizable dent in unemployment, the package would need to be twice that size in each of the next two years. And there is a danger the plan could make matters worse. Deficit reductions kick in early next year when the economy may still be too sick to weather the blow. Congress could improve the plan by legislating the deficit cuts now, but phasing them in starting in 1995.
Cutting the Deficit: Mr. Clinton's cuts are substantial and fair.
Take 1997, the end of Mr. Clinton's term, as a point of reference. The deficit would be cut from about $350 billion to $200 billion -- a fiscally safe target. And, unlike the numbers manufactured during the Reagan-Bush years, Mr. Clinton's estimates appear credible.
Under the plan, most new taxes would fall on the rich, who benefited the most from the tax party Mr. Reagan threw in the 1980's. The poor are protected. And middle-income families would pay a reasonable amount -- primarily about $100 to $150 a year in higher utility bills and gasoline prices.
Though fair, the specific proposal Mr. Clinton makes for taxing the rich creates a danger. Wealthy families would pay a tax of 40 percent or more on ordinary income but only 28 percent on capital gains income -- profit from the sale of investments. That difference will drive accountants to recreate tax shelters wiped out by the 1986 tax reform, which equalized rates on ordinary and capital gains income. The useless, but tax-subsidized, office buildings that litter the Southwest are sickening testimony to a code that rewarded investors who put their money where taxes were low rather than where productivity was high.
Spurring Investment: In 1997, Mr. Clinton proposes spending cuts and tax hikes totaling $200 billion. Yet the deficit would fall by only $150 billion. The difference -- about $50 billion -- is used to subsidize private investors and pay for new public investments. Here, Mr. Clinton would spend thinly rather than deeply, on highways, education, worker training, childhood preventive care and many other initiatives. Creative ideas from the campaign -- like national service -- would get short shrift.
Investing an extra $50 billion in a $6 trillion economy might not seem like a big deal. And tolerating deficits of $200 billion or more may seem cowardly. Indeed, the programs won't pay off big next year, or even next decade.
But what's important about the plan is its new direction. Washington will consume a bit less, invest a bit more. Private citizens will do likewise. After a couple of decades, the difference can be dramatic.
Americans once saw their living standards double every generation. At current rates of saving and investment, it would take a century or more. Small increases in savings and investment can eventually mean the difference between superpower and economic has-been. Just ask Britain.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Calling a Tail a Leg

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
If you call a tail a leg, went the riddle attributed to Lincoln, how many legs has a dog? The answer: four, "because calling a tail a leg doesn't make it a leg."
Red-eyed with lack of sleep, racing to make a self-imposed deadline like bright students cramming before an exam, the Clintonites slapped together a dog's breakfast of a budget proposal -- and did not like what they saw. 
 The trouble was that it was all tax increases and -- except for a huge extra whack at defense that they knew had no chance of getting past Senator Sam Nunn -- very few spending cuts. And the people had voted for spending cuts to reduce the deficit.
So Clinton decided to call a tail a leg. This required moving a bunch of items out of column A, "tax increases," and over to column B, "spending cuts." It wasn't honest accounting, but when you are in an impossible bind and it's late at night, you do what you have to do.
That's when the Clinton proposal to tax an additional 35 percent of Social Security benefits to those over 65 who continue to work, or who were foolish enough to have saved money for their old age, went through a miraculous name change. The additional tax was no longer to be known by the harsh word "tax"; instead, it was to be called by the admired term "spending cut." Lloyd Bentsen at Treasury attempted a convoluted rationale for this sleight of hand that embarrassed his friends.
Same trick was tried with uncapping the sum on which the Medicare tax was levied, thereby raising the tax take on the highest bracket to 43 percent. It's a tax rise, plain and simple, squeezing $12 billion out of those committing the egalitarian sin of earning money, but -- behind the blue smoke and mirrors -- there it appears, labeled "spending cut."
Why the chicanery, so transparent that not even the budget chief, Leon Panetta, could bring himself to defend it on "Meet the Press" yesterday? Because Clintonites had first promised two dollars in cuts for every new dollar in taxes, and then backed off to "rough balance" -- but in the end they had produced no balance, rough or otherwise. On the contrary, only after four dollars are snatched out of taxpayers' pockets do we see one dollar cut -- and that cut is not guaranteed.
In 60 days, the other shoe is scheduled to drop: the Hillary supplemental, with subsidies for 37 million uninsured people to be paid out of taxes on cigarettes, wine and beer and guns. And if a pistol-packing, butt-puffing Joe Sixpack cannot pay that $90 billion freight all by himself, on comes a national sales tax.
Did we vote for this? Did Bill Clinton talk about it during his campaign, except to denounce predictions of tax-and-spend economics as "shameful"?
Of course not; not for him the Walter Mondale route in 1984, blurting out publicly an intention to raise taxes. Such honesty is for losers; winners zip their lip and "discover" ever-growing deficits after the election, claiming then to be shocked, shocked at the need to raise taxes while increasing nondefense spending.
Will it fly? The polls show the customary enthusiasm for a new President who exudes energy even as he proposes taxing it. We like seeing those lights burning late, the resilient young President campaigning for his cause, whatever it is; fogies old and young find it fun to shake up the boring status quo. We tend to forgive early mistakes and little deceptions, hoping they won't grow into major blunders and a pattern of lies.
But Bill Clinton and his team, half starry-eyed and half bleary-eyed, are stumbling into an ideology that is as bad for them as it is for the nation. Does he realize where "Clintonism," as it is developing, is taking him? Price control, paternalism and protectionism lead to inflation, recession and general dismay.
Americans love the idea of Change and hate radical changes. We want a sense of movement without getting involved in a Movement.
It would be hard for any politician to prevent 1993 from being a good year, just as it will be hard to prevent Bill Clinton from attributing this year's upturn to his own election and slapdash proposals.
Stop him, Democrats, before his desire to be different combines with his talent at telemarketing to lead your party into the black hole of statism. He calls his inchoate ideology "the new direction," but calling a tail a leg doesn't make it a leg.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The Two Clintons

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
One quality above all made President Clinton's economic speech a stunning success as he delivered it. That was the self-confidence he radiated. When he ad-libbed jabs at mocking Republicans, there was an inner security that brought Franklin Roosevelt to mind.
That quality made the Clinton speech much more effective than was perceived in the blinkered vision of Washington. In Washington it brought warning that this or that interest group would be offended. In the country most people admired Mr. Clinton's courage in asking them to do hard things. 
 What is curious is that alongside that Bill Clinton there is another: a politician fearful of offending public opinion, one who will scuttle principle to protect himself from possible political damage.
It was the second Clinton who flew to Arkansas from the New Hampshire primary in January 1992 to reject the final clemency appeal of Rickey Ray Rector, a murderer who had shot away much of his own brain and been reduced to a state of mental vacuity.
In a chilling account of the case in The New Yorker last week, Marshall Frady said Governor Clinton had told a friend on the night of the execution: "It's just awful. Just terrible, terrible." But he let the mental defective be executed; and he flew home, rather than let the Lieutenant Governor deny clemency, to show how tough he was on capital punishment.
The second Bill Clinton is strikingly in evidence now, on a legal and political question stemming from the military repression in Haiti. The question is whether the United States should, and legally can, send refugees back to Haiti without giving them a chance to show that they would be in danger there because of their political views.
Last year candidate Clinton denounced President Bush's decision to intercept Haitians at sea and summarily send them back. On May 27 he said: "I am appalled by the decision of the Bush Administration to pick up fleeing Haitians on the high seas and forcibly return them to Haiti before considering their claim to political asylum. This process must not stand."
In July, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit held that the Bush policy violated a 1980 U.S. law forbidding the return of "any alien" to a country where his "life or freedom would be threatened." Mr. Clinton said the court was "right" to overturn the "cruel policy of returning Haitian refugees to a brutal dictatorship without an asylum hearing."
When he was asked about the issue after the election, on Nov. 12, he said his position was clear: "We should have a process in which these Haitians get a chance to make their case."
Since taking office, of course, Mr. Clinton has continued the Bush policy of intercepting Haitians at sea and summarily returning them. And now he is apparently going to have his Administration tell the Supreme Court that the policy is lawful despite the flat language of the 1980 law.
The Supreme Court, having agreed to review the Second Circuit decision of last July, is going to hear argument in the case on March 2, next Tuesday. And the indications are that a Justice Department lawyer will say the 1980 act covers only aliens "within the United States," although Congress in 1980 dropped those words from an earlier statute.
The issue is not just a narrow one of how to read a statute. The 1980 American law conforms with the U.N. Refugee Convention, which was drafted to make sure that there would be no repetition of the 1930's, when boatloads of fleeing Jews were forced back to Nazi Germany.
President Clinton has changed his position without a show of serious explanation. He said, "There is a difference between political and economic refugees." But how can you tell if you send people back without asking? Before the Bush interception policy U.S. authorities had found a substantial percentage of fleeing Haitians to be genuine political refugees.
The reason for the switch is sadly evident. Mr. Clinton senses a mood of xenophobia in the country. He fears he will be hurt politically if he lets poor black foreigners in, even to save them from persecution and possible death.
The absence of an Attorney General has no doubt made it easier for politics to prevail over law on this issue. But it is not too late for the President to make his policy conform with the purpose of the 1980 law -- and with the demands of decency.

HEADLINE: Now Ask What High Rollers Can Do for Deficit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I want to applaud President Clinton for submitting an economic plan in his State of the Union Message that seems based on justice rather than fairness (front page, Feb. 18).
Earlier statements that sacrifice would be borne evenly indicated that this would not be the case -- that all income levels would have to pay their fair share of the deficit. But the plan Mr. Clinton proposed last Wednesday night seems to be a just plan, in which those who benefited most from the national borrowing spree will participate most in returning the country to solvency. 
 I received a negative benefit from the excessive Government spending of the 1980's, and I feel that I have already made several payments on a national recovery.
I paid once when my position at a national nonprofit agency was eliminated as contributions dwindled in a recession induced, in part, by such Government-sanctioned schemes as leveraged buyouts and junk bonds, as well as by a savings and loan fraud whose potentially calamitous effects were reduced with taxpayer money.
I paid again as I retrained for college teaching, living on a $7,000-a-year graduate assistant stipend, supplemented with occasional adjunct teaching at $1,000 a course. I am still paying as the interest on my savings account hovers at 2 percent and the equity in my house decreases.
And I am one of the lucky ones. I changed careers in my 50's. Several friends and relatives are working part time or not at all. They have lost up to 15 years of gainful employment, years they planned to use to accumulate savings for their retirement. Taxing Social Security benefits more will unjustly subject them to a double payment on the national debt.
Most of us agree with President Clinton that our country cannot continue to operate with a negative balance sheet. But we also know that there is a lot of wealth in this country that could be tapped to reduce the deficit -- wealth that was partly accumulated through a tax structure and legal loopholes that benefited a small minority. It is time for that minority to express its appreciation for the national benevolence largely responsible for their affluence. A just economic policy would insure this.
I am sure those of us caught in the middle for most of our working years will shoulder our share and willingly contribute to the country's recovery. But we would like that share to be determined through a policy that recognizes the degree to which some segments of society benefited from the deficit we are all being asked to reduce.
 
JANICE M. CORBETT
Malvern, Pa., Feb. 18, 1993

HEADLINE: Now Ask What High Rollers Can Do for Deficit;
Health Care Wipeout?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
President Clinton's State of the Union Message was remarkable for its breadth, vision and the compelling salesmanship of his message (front page, Feb. 18). However, until Hillary Rodham Clinton reveals her health care program, the jury is out on the program's economic implications. 
 The cost of the Federal Government's providing a comprehensive safety net health care insurance program is estimated between $30 billion and $90 billion a year. Such a program would wipe out all the estimated budget deficit savings outlined.
In addition, of the $260 billion of expenditure cuts proposed by President Clinton, approximately $70 billion represents expected interest rate savings over four years from issuing more short-term Government debt and expected overall interest rate declines. What happens if interest rates go back up in the future?
The message of the electorate last November was a mandate for change, economic revival, a reduced budget deficit, and less and more efficient government. President Clinton is hoping to steer the public toward supporting more Federal Government involvement in new programs in education, job training and health care. The message that he gets back from the middle class might be, "Yes, you have indeed identified some problem areas, but couldn't many of these be handled by the private sector, with incentives like tax credits?"
 
THOMAS S. GILBERT
New York, Feb. 18, 1993

HEADLINE: Now Ask What High Rollers Can Do for Deficit;
Grand Old Hypocrisy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It was fascinating to listen to Republican Congressional reaction to President Clinton's speech. G.O.P. lawmakers spoke about cutting Government spending, intelligent oversight of programs and being fiscally responsible before raising taxes. 
 Why didn't they think about these things when they were the majority in Congress? These are the same people who stood by during the last 12 years and allowed the deficit to grow even larger, who allowed the illegalities of the Bank of Credit and Com
merce scandal and the savings and loan debacle to add billions to our indebtedness, who padded Federal bureaus with nonfunctioning workers and specious projects, whose fiscal programs benefited special interests and who showed a lack of concern for the average citizen's welfare.

To the Editor:
In "There They Go Again" (Op-Ed, Feb. 18), Ronald Reagan doesn't understand even yet why President Clinton's economic program, including some rigorous spending cuts, is urgently necessary. After all, he writes, the 1980's were the "longest period of peacetime economic expansion in our history."

HEADLINE: ON PRO BASKETBALL;
In Miami's Wali Jones, The N.B.A. Discovers It Has a Conscience

BYLINE: By Harvey Araton

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY

 BODY:
Anyone here with a young Horace Grant fan at home could be an instant hit by returning with a pair of red goggles that replicate the futuristic look of the Bulls' hard-working forward. As of yesterday afternoon, there were still plenty remaining for the non-negotiable price of $66.
"You mean $16," an interested purchaser corrected the salesman at the raucous All-Star store set up by the National Basketball Association this weekend. 
 "No, $66," said the salesman. "It's official N.B.A. merchandise."
In other words, it had the stamp of league approval, like the $250 basketball that was pumped with air and branded with the logo by some flesh-eating contraption as you waited. For a hipper athletic fashion statement, there was a $350 jacket, with logo, or the $1,500 leather version, targeted for those looking to drop some heavy cash before the feds begin demanding more.
There was, of course, the old standby for average Americans, the All-Star T-shirt, but even those began at $18, more than one veteran of the Barcelona Olympics remembers the standard T-shirt going for last summer. At least that event was quadrennial.
A welcome addition to the N.B.A. All-Star Game weekend in recent years has been the Stay in School program, which challenges kids from the host city to strive for perfect attendance in exchange for various All-Star goodies. But if those kids happened to have wandered into the All-Star store, the message instead was this: Stay in school; you're going to need a good job to afford these products.
Granted, the N.B.A. is not in business to save the world, although its global expansion is an act of divinity if it's impeding the spread of American football. Yesterday's game was beamed off the satellite to 118 countries and the news media covering the all stars was as international as that which followed the Dream Team.
But as the N.B.A. grows rich beyond its wildest dreams, its first and foremost social obligation is to the cities that have propped this league up and provided so much of its talent base.
Wali Jones, the former Philadelphia 76er and Milwaukee Buck long-range shooter who helped organize the first Stay in School program four years ago in Miami, had an idea how to at least seriously address the N.B.A.'s burgeoning gap between capitalist gain and social reponsibility. He has no problem with college dropouts like Shaquille O'Neal advising 18,000 kids at the Delta Center the other day to stay in school. The real contribution, said Jones, is doing something to help them learn something while they're there.
Again and again, the voices of superstars like Michael Jordan and Charles Barkley are heard to complain that they are entertainers, not role models for kids, which is for parents. That's logical, Jones argues, but it's not altogether practical.
"I don't care what people say ought to be," said Jones, from a Philadelphia family of nine. "The reality is that 18 percent of all children in this country do not live with a biological parent, and it's much higher in the inner city. Kids are impressionable, like it or not, and if you can get their attention with an athlete, then at least you've got their attention."
Four years ago, Jones's old 76er teammate, Billy Cunningham, offered him a position with the Miami Heat as community-relations director. This was hardly the case of extending an ex-teammate a handout. Wherever Jones was playing during his N.B.A. career between 1964 and 1976, he was working toward degrees in economics and psychology. He went to Miami with his program, the Shooting Stars, and he has no problem reporting its success.
"What I do is go to school every day," said Jones, having survived the Legends game Saturday, although, at 51, he looked in better shape than younger retirees like Otis Birdsong and Maurice Lucas. "We get 200 or so in an auditorium and I get their attention. Kids aren't stupid. Kids are lazy. We offer them rewards to do better. I sign them up."
In four years, he said, he has recruited 20,000 students from middle school through high school. Forms are given out through the school. Grades are reported every quarter. Rewards for improved grades come in various forms, like tickets to Heat games, concerts, sneakers, caps, T-shirts. According to the documentation Jones's staff has done, there has been a 67 percent improvement by the students in the program.
"This is Miami, so we're talking about Haitians to Cubans to Bolivians to Afro-Americans," said Jones. "I ask them, 'How many of you want to be professional athletes?' Almost all the hands go right up. That's when I bring in all the people we use who didn't make it but got an education and wound up with a good job.
"From my experience, these kids want challenges. They want goals. Are there bad kids in the school? Yeah, there are bad kids. But people who are saying the whole generation is lost are coping out. We have high school kids now who are going into the middle schools. Guess who becomes the role model? The older kids."
Who supplies the merchandise for Jones's program? Four years ago, the Heat donated it all. Then corporations started calling. Yes, Jones told them, if they purchase the caps and shirts, they can have "commercial considerations." Now that's an All-Star deal.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
A Sweet Lou Primer On Marge and Loyalty

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ariz., Feb. 21

 BODY:
Lou Piniella's departure from the Cincinnati Reds occurred last October, but it began a year earlier.
"It was time for me to move on," Piniella said Saturday, sitting in his office here at the Seattle Mariners' new spring-training site. "I didn't like some of the things that were done there, and as a manager, I had a chance to come back or move on and I chose to move on." 
 Marge Schott, the Reds' owner, offered Piniella a two-year contract extension, but it was what she didn't offer in 1991 that precipitated his departure.
"It just wasn't fun," Piniella, the Mariners' new manager, said, speaking generally of the latter part of his three-year tenure as manager in Cincinnati. Then he cited the specific incident that prompted his decision to leave.
"The biggest thing that didn't leave a good taste was what happened when I had the problem with the umpires," he related, speaking in a 90-minute interview. "When I got sued by the umpires, I got no backing from the organization. That started the wheels turning. I think any organization would back their manager. I got nothing, financial or anything. I went back in '92 and fulfilled my contract, but when it came time to extend, I chose not to."
In August 1991, Piniella became enraged when Gary Darling, the home-plate umpire in a game against San Francisco, reversed a ruling by another umpire and deprived the Reds' Bill Doran of a home run. After the game, Piniella, he of the legendary temper, said that Darling was biased against the Reds. Two months later, Darling and the Major League Umpires Association filed a $5 million defamation suit against Piniella.
"I realize I didn't say the right thing," Piniella said. "It was in the heat of battle. But I got no backing. It got in my craw. That was the big thing."
 
Spent Own Money
 If such an incident had occurred when Piniella managed the Yankees, from 1986 to 1988, George Steinbrenner, a boisterous critic of umpires, would probably have hired the best lawyers -- plural -- for Piniella and supported him with his own statements about the umpires' incompetence. But Schott, who on Feb. 3 was suspended from baseball for a year because of her demeaning racial and ethnic comments, has never had a history of expending money or words on her employees' behalf.
As one of her former employees explained today, she reasoned that she didn't make the comment about Darling and therefore shouldn't have had to spend her money on a lawyer to defend Piniella. So Piniella spent his own money on a lawyer and the conflict was settled, with the lawsuit being dropped and the manager's issuing a statement praising umpires in general and Darling in particular, saying he regretted making comments "that may have maligned his character in any way."
Now, at the age of 49, with six years of managing behind him, Piniella has a new job with a three-year contract. He did not remain unemployed long once he informed Schott he would not return to Cincinnati, although he had no job guarantee when he acted.
 
Willing to Take Risks
 "My wife asked, 'What if you don't get another job?' " Piniella related. "I wasn't sure I would get one. Who knows? There are only 28 jobs. It was possible I could never have managed again. You have to take chances. If you're not willing to take chances, you never know."
If the Mariners or another team hadn't offered him a job, Piniella said, he was confident he could have found something to do in baseball. If not, the business world awaited. After his first season with the Reds, the one in which the team was in first place from first day to last, then breezed through the pennant playoff and the World Series, he told Schott he was prepared to become a businessman if she didn't raise his salary. She did, nearly doubling it, and he didn't.
"I think I could have been an assistant to the general manager in a scouting, consulting sort of way," he said.
 
Still Fond of Yankees
 If no one else had offered a job, Piniella is certain his old friend, Steinbrenner, would have.
"The Yankees still have a special place," he said. "I was there a long time. If George didn't take a chance on me managing, I wouldn't be a manager. I like the guy; I really do. He's a pistol. I'm sure he likes me."
But now Piniella is the Mariners' 10th manager in their 17-year existence, an existence that has produced little life, with only one winning season (1991), which was followed by a disastrous last-place, 64-98 finish.
Woody Woodward, the Mariners' general manager, wanted Piniella because Piniella has been a winner, as a player and a manager. Winning is a foreign word to the Mariners.
"This is a first-class organization," Piniella said of Seattle. "We just have to bring a winning tradition to it. Other people before me failed. Last year they took a big step backward. That's why I'm here basically. I expect us to play well. I'm not looking at it as a rebuilding process. I'm looking at it as establishing a winning tradition."
 
Blue-Collar Player
 As a player, Piniella was never a natural at anything, hitting, baserunning or playing the outfield. But intense work and concentration on his hitting mechanics made him a career .291 hitter, alertness made him a deceptively good baserunner and all-out effort enabled him to reach more fly balls than he was expected to catch. He made himself a winning player.
"It's a commitment, it's a dedication, it's a passion," he said, defining the start of a winning tradition. "You have to have the talent; the team has to be put together the right way, but I would describe it as a commitment and having pride in what you do."
Players, though, are the ones who create the winning, not the manager, he explained. As he talked, he took off the World Series ring he wore on his right hand. "I have my Yankee ring back on, the one from 1977," he said. "I'm back in the American League so I'll put my Yankee ring back on."
 
Leaves Bosses Suspended
 But isn't he proud of what he and the Reds accomplished in 1990?
"I'm very proud of '90," he responded. "I'm exceedingly proud of '90 -- what we accomplished and what the players did. But as a manager, I have to take a backseat. I'm there to supervise, hopefully contribute, but the players are the ones who deserve the credit."
Yet Piniella remains a compelling personality. Consider the most recent unique aspect of his career. In the wake of his departure from the Yankees, Steinbrenner was suspended. No sooner did he leave the Reds than Schott was suspended.
"Yeah," he said, breaking into his eye-closing grin, "one's coming off suspension, the other's going on."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lou Piniella, right, the Mariners' new manager, speaking with General Manager Woody Woodward during the team's first practice last week. (Mike Scully for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Debt, Taxes and a Politician's Downfall

BYLINE: By Fay Vincent; Fay Vincent, the former commissioner of baseball, will be living this spring at Lord Asquith's country home near Oxford, England.

 BODY:
Is Bill Clinton the second coming of John F. Kennedy? Franklin Delano Roosevelt? Or even Abraham Lincoln, whose bust is so proudly displayed on the new President's desk? Sorry. Maybe someday, but for now his real model isn't even an American.
Look to President Clinton's real roots and those of all the Rhodes scholars and Oxfordophiles in his Administration. English history gives us the best insight into the Clinton proposals and what lies ahead. In 1909, Lord Asquith was the Liberal Prime Minister, with Lloyd George as Chancellor of the Exchequer and Winston Churchill as head of the Board of Trade. 
 Influenced by both, Asquith proposed a budget intended to achieve significant social change. According to a new book by the historian Paul Addison, Churchill greatly affected the social policies, while Lloyd George held sway on fiscal matters.
The Government was facing familiar problems: a deficit, with revenue declining after a recession. The costs of old-age pensions were rising, and an arms race (with Germany) had taken its toll. Asquith's "reforms" included much higher taxes on the wealthy and estates and new levies on liquor licenses and spirits, tobacco, motor cars and gasoline.
There is more. Asquith proposed that income taxes increase on "unearned income," and there was to be a new "super tax" on the highest incomes. The Liberals were obviously attacking the wealthier classes in England, and the budget-making process was "a turbulent affair," Professor Addison writes.
Churchill, a man of property, had to explain the policies to his family and friends whose interests were threatened. The great man was not defensive.
He wrote: "Be sure of this -- after the taxes which this budget proposes are in force, our island will still be the best place in the world for rich people to dwell in." Nonetheless, opposition to the budget was vigorous, and the Liberals failed to win a majority in the 1910 election.
One can make too much of history. But Bill Clinton's proposals surely have their roots in the far-reaching radical social policies of the Liberal Party and its 1909 budget. Faced with a deficit, there is a certain predictability to the response.
Now we will see whether the debate over the Clinton Administration's proposals and the effect on the Democratic Party will resemble that of their historical parallel. And perhaps we will have to learn more English history to follow what these former Rhodes scholars are doing for us. Next we'll have to learn the words to "Rule Brittania."

HEADLINE: Clinton Asks U.N. Chief to Meet On Plan for Airdrop to Bosnians

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Clearly intent on moving ahead with plans for an airdrop of relief supplies into Bosnia and Herzegovina, President Clinton invited the United Nations Secretary General today to meet with him on Tuesday in an effort to win his support for the initiative, Administration officials said.
Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, while not opposing the plan outright, is insisting that any relief operation be coordinated with, and under the command of, United Nations forces already in Bosnia. American officials say they have no problem coordinating with the United Nations but are clearly reluctant to cede military control of the operation. 
 The Clinton Administration has begun briefing influential Senators and Congressmen on Capitol Hill about its proposed relief operation, which appears to have bipartisan support. Administration officials have been telling the lawmakers privately, though, that they do not want to go ahead with any airlift without the expressed support of Mr. Boutros-Ghali, Western allies and the the Russians -- all of whom they believe can be brought around.
Some of the lawmakers said they were told that the Administration planned to use C-130 transport planes, dropping supplies from altitudes above 10,000 feet, and protected by American fighter escorts.
Beyond the stated aid objective of the operation -- to help 200,000 Bosnian Muslims cut off from food and medicine by Bosnian Serb militia forces -- the Administration also seems to have the political objective of enticing the Bosnian Muslim Government back to the negotiating table in New York with a strong show of American support.
The international mediators seeking to resolve the Balkan crisis have asked the Clinton Administration to grant immunity from lawsuits in the United States to the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, to encourage him to return to New York for a new round of peace talks later this week. [Page A8.]
 
Unfavorable Reaction Abroad
 Britain and France indicated today that they were unenthusiastic about the airdrop plan and the Russians are concerned that the relief operation might be construed as aimed against Serbia, historically a Russian ally.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali, who has long argued that if the United States really wanted to help the relief operation it should contribute trucks and troops to transport supplies on the ground, said that he would only support an airdrop being considered by Washington if it was fully authorized by, and under the command of, the United Nations relief coordinators on the ground.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali told reporters at the United Nations that "the authorization must be given by the United Nations so that the whole operation will continue to be centralized by the United Nations."
Who Will Command?
In a telephone interview later, the Secretary General said he would tell President Clinton that he would welcome United States participation in an airdrop operation "only as long as it is under United Nations command." The United Nations military commander in the region is General Satish Nambiar of India, commander of the United Nations Protection Force.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali warned that to introduce a wholly separate, unilateral, American-led mission in the region could "open a Pandora's box" that could complicate United Nations operations already underway.
The question of who exactly commands what will have to be finessed. This is in part because any American airdrop would involve fighter escorts that could be called upon to attack targets on the ground, if they open fire on slow-flying American transports, and it is highly unlikely that Washington would put such decision-making in the hands of a United Nations commander. It is possible that the relief operation could be under the nominal command of the United Nations, with Washington still reserving certain military decisions for itself.
 
U.S. Public Opinion
 The Secretary General also warned that a unilateral United States-run operation would be vulnerable to changes in American public opinion.
"Supposing that tomorrow an American plane is shot down?," the Secretary General asked. "What would be your position then?"
While making clear that he would support the airdrop effort if it is placed under United Nations authority, Mr. Boutros-Ghali raised doubts about how effective such a mission could be. He described such an operation as a "fall-back position" and said the ground convoys should remain the principal means of delivering assistance, which is also the position of the Clinton Administration.
Nevertheless, Mr. Boutros-Ghali added that the airdrop could be "important for the public relations point of view so that everybody knows we are doing something more."
Speaking to reporters during his visit to Seattle, President Clinton said he was close to a decision on the operation.
 
Clinton 'Still Consulting'
 "We're still consulting, we'll finish pretty soon," he said, adding that his agenda with Mr. Boutros-Ghali includes Bosnia, Somalia and a number of other issues.
While Administration officials have said they fully intend to coordinate with the United Nations, the United States delegate, Madeleine Albright, said the United States felt it had all the legal authorization it needed already. She said Security Council Resolution 770, adopted last August, permits the use of "all measures necessary" to deliver aid. "We believe we have authority under Resolution 770," she said.
Deputy Secretary of State Clifton Wharton told some lawmakers he briefed today that what the Clinton Administration is considering dropping pallets of food and medicine by parachute from C-130 transport aircraft flying at 10,000 feet, outside the range of Serbian antiaircraft guns. The slow-flying transports would by protected by American fighter aircraft.
 
U.S. Carrier Nearby
 The aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy, which carries F-14 fighters and F/A-18 attack jets, is currently in the Mediterranean and could easily move into the Adriatic Sea off the coast of the former Yugoslavia.
The proposed operation appears to have bipartisan support in Congress. Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, an influential member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said he was briefed this morning on the relief mission by Mr. Wharton, "and I indicated that I am supportive of the idea."
"It is important that if the people out there are starving and if we can be of assistance, we ought to help, Senator Lugar said. "I have been told that they can fly the C-130's in at a high enough altitude so that they would be out of range of small-arms fire. There is some hazard, but it is an important humanitarian step and we just should do it if we can."
 
Challenge to U.N.<>HE>
Senator Joseph R. Biden, the Deleware Democrat who heads the Senate subcommittee on Europe, said in a statement that he supported the airlift proposal because, among other reasons, "it will challenge the United Nations, which six months ago called for all measures necessary to facilitate relief and then refused to empower United Nations relief forces to overcome Serbian intransigence."
Senator Biden added that "for a President with a compelling interest in revitalizing the American economy, this cannot be an easy decision, but it is the right one."
Representative Lee H. Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who heads the House Foreign Relations Committee, said he thinks the proposed operation "is necessary, because determined efforts have to be made to relieve the humanitarian suffering." He added, "Our planes will have strong air cover, so the risk is small."
A British Defense Ministry official in London said there was "no great enthusiasm" in his office for the proposed American initiative. British Defense officials said they had drawn up emergency plans a year ago for such airdrops, but abandoned them as too dangerous.
"Airdrops are fine when you have masses of space as in Ethiopia or Somalia but that is not the case in Bosnia," the British Defense Ministry official said. "You cannot fly really low because of the risk of being hit from the ground so accuracy becomes difficult."

HEADLINE: CLINTON PROPOSES CHANGES IN POLICY TO AID TECHNOLOGY

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Feb. 22

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration announced today a broad new technology initiative that enthusiastically embraces Government and industry cooperation to create new technologies and nurture innovative small companies.
The program could lead to a significant change in the balance between civilian and military research and development and could generate new Government-industry consortiums modeled after a successful consortium created six years ago to help the flagging semiconductor industry. 
 "The underlying spirit is that it is time we got away from such an adversarial relationship between the Government and the private sector," said Dr. Jack Gibbons, the President's science adviser and the head of the Office of Science and Technology Policy. "Where our interests are mutual and line up, let's go for it."
 
Price: $17 Billion
 The technology initiative was outlined today by President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore in an appearance before high-tech workers at the headquarters of Silicon Graphics Inc., a computer manufacturer here.
It calls for spending $17 billion over four years and includes money to transform a Commerce Department agency to serve as a civilian focal point for incubating advanced technologies. The money for the programs was part of the President's economic plan announced last week
"To keep the United States on the cutting edge," Mr. Clinton said, "my job as President is to adjust America so we can win in the 21st century."
The appearance here, in the area south of San Francisco that is home to many of the nation's high-tech companies, was part of the President's campaign to promote his economic plan.
 
Talk of 'Industrial Policy'
 While the Administration did not explicitly call its program an "industrial policy" in which the Government would encourage certain industries over others, several high-tech industry executives were quick to greet it as an important sea change in policy.
"Fundamentally it's the beginning of an industrial policy," said Kirk Raab, chief executive of Genentech, a biotechnology company based in South San Francisco. "And I think we need an industrial policy in the U.S., as long as its perspective is one of cooperation between business and Government and not dominated by the Government."
The plan, which is closely modeled after the goals sketched by the President in a document developed with executives of Silicon Valley companies during the election campaign, proposes initiatives on many fronts. Among them are these:
*Expanding the role of the National Institute of Standards and Technology in the Commerce Department to promote joint ventures between business and government.
*Financing research leading to a national high-speed computer network, called an information superhighway.
*Developing a partnership between the Government and the auto industry to develop an "environmentally clean" car.
*Increasing partnerships between private industry and the national laboratories.
*Expanding the national network of manufacturing extension centers to help small and medium-sized businesses gain access to technology.
 
Reversing the Bush Course
 In calling for closer cooperation between business and the Government, the Clinton Administration initiative is a significant break with the policies of the Bush Administration, which gave modest high-technology grants and supported the Pentagon-led semiconductor industry consortium, called Sematech, but refused to endorse policies that would in effect pick industrial "winners and losers."
Critics of the Clinton plan said today that Government stimulus for new technologies was never an effective way to develop competitive businesses.
"The Government is going into the venture-capital business," said Allan Meltzer, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, a policy research center in Washington. "Is the Government going to do better than the private sector? I doubt it."
The Clinton program would encourage private-sector investment and technological innovation by making permanent a tax credit for the research and development spending of companies, by reducing capital gains taxes for small businesses and by changing antitrust laws to permit joint production ventures.
Making the tax credit permanent would cost the Treasury an estimated $6.4 billion over four years. In addition, the plan calls for spending $598 million on high technology this year and restoring $207 million of cuts in the budget of the National Science Foundation. It would also increase spending for the national laboratories by $47 million this year and $146 million in the next four years to focus on civilian instead of military projects.
The Clinton initiative also calls for a four-year, $272 million increase in money for the Environmental Protection Agency for private-industry development of environmental technology.
The initiative would also sharply increase financing of the National Institute of Standards and Technology, spending $1.3 billion over four years to turn the Commerce Department unit into a civilian technology agency for financing industry-led research and development.
The plan stresses building the national high-speed computer network to link businesses, schools and governments, a project Vice President Gore has long championed. He has said its construction will lead to a blossoming of new businesses and economic productivity.

HEADLINE: Congress Is Pressed to Join in Belt-Tightening

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
If members of Congress could finish all their business in one day, shut down their offices, dismiss their staffs and resign without pensions, they could save the nation's taxpayers $2 billion a year -- about the cost of one B-2 bomber.
That may be small change, but Congress is coming under increasing constituent pressure to cut down on mail privileges, leather furniture, office expenses for retired Speakers and other pork from the Capitol Hill budget. 
 Voters are telling their representatives that they cannot accept the tax increases proposed by President Clinton unless they also see cuts in Federal spending. The lingering images of lawmakers' abusing checking accounts and riding in chauffeur-driven cars have made Congressional financing a magnet for voters' outrage with Government.
 
Total of 35,000 Staff Members
 But a few powerful committee chairmen are resisting cutting back, and Republicans are skeptical that their Democratic counterparts are serious. Still, many lawmakers say the President's talk of shared sacrifice and White House staff cuts make at least modest cutbacks in the legislative branch inevitable this year and sharper cuts probable in the next few years.
Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington and Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, announced last week that they wanted to eliminate 1,400 jobs, or 4 percent, from the 35,000-member Congressional staff by 1995 and cut total administrative costs 14 percent by 1997.
Noting a direct political connection between the cuts and their hopes to pass Mr. Clinton's legislative program, Mr. Foley and Mr. Mitchell released a statement saying, "We believe that this shared effort is necessary as we move forward with our agenda of economic growth, job creation, deficit reduction and health-care reform."
Mr. Clinton returned the favor by complimenting the lawmakers' cost-cutting effort in his speech to Congress on Wednesday night, praising it as "a very clear signal to the American people." His comments cemented the notion that even symbolic changes in the way Congress does business were necessary to restore public confidence in Washington.
Republicans characterized the Democrat lawmakers' announcement as a publicity stunt to reinforce Mr. Clinton's effort to sell his economic program, noting that the leadership had not consulted Republicans before making its announcement.
 
Action on Committees
 But on Thursday, the Senate Rules Committee voted to cut $4.7 million for 19 committees in 1993. And the full Senate appears to be moving to dissolve its Select Committees on Aging and Indian Affairs, trimming an additional $1.2 million in annual spending and 58 staff members, although lobbying groups representing Indians and the elderly are resisting.
Also on the cutting block are four House committees dealing with aging, children, narcotics and hunger. They will almost surely expire next month, for annual savings of $3.6 million.
"For the Democrats to even suggest that they are willing to consider a reduction is a good sign," said Representative C. W. Bill Young of Florida, the ranking Republican on the House Subcommittee on Legislative Appropriations. "With the focus that the President and the focus that Ross Perot are putting on the issue, I think the people will be looking for a lot more than 4 percent."
Although the issue of Congress's spending on itself is more political than economic, lawmakers say cuts in committees and their staffs could make the legislative branch more efficient. They complain that they spend so much time sitting on multiple committees that sometimes have overlapping jurisdictions that they cannot focus on all the issues they would like to.
 
Hearings on Cutbacks
 The Senate Appropriations subcommittee responsible for legislative spending will begin hearings on Tuesday seeking cuts in the Congressional staff, the Library of Congress, the General Accounting Office and the Capitol Architect's Office.
Senator David L. Boren, the Oklahoma Democrat who is co-chairman of a joint Senate-House committee preparing plans to reorganize the Congress, said he would like to reduce the number of committees and subcommittees to 50, from 299, and thereby reduce the staff to 7,000 people, from 12,000, by the year 2000.
But Mr. Boren conceded that his efforts ran against the grain of many powerful lawmakers.
Among the most powerful resisters appears to be Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who heads the Appropriations Committee. After the Rules Committee called for a 6.3 percent cut in financing for committees, Mr. Byrd came back asking for a 12 percent increase for his own panel. Seven other committees, including Finance and Intelligence, also asked for more money, but Senator Wendell H. Ford, the Kentucky Democrat who heads the Rules Committee, persuaded his committee to overrule the other chairmen and approve across-the-board cuts.
The House budget mushroomed, to $700 million, from $520 million, from 1990 to 1992, while costs in the Senate rose more gradually. And the scandals over the House bank, restaurant and post office last year sharpened public outrage over perks and pork.
Congress responded by cutting down sharply on mail privileges and others and raising prices at the House restaurant and fees at the House gymnasium, among other things.
"The cuts sell back home," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, noting that his haircuts at the House barber shop now cost $12 instead of the $7 last year.
Many Congressional critics view the problem of legislative spending as an abuse of power. The average House member spent more taxpayer money on free mailings last year than the average challenger did on his entire Congressional campaign, said David Keating, executive vice president of the National Taxpayers Union.
"There's plenty of room for cutting," Mr. Keating said.

HEADLINE: CLINTON TO FIGHT FOREIGN SUBSIDIES

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EVERETT, Wash., Feb. 22

 BODY:
President Clinton today told an audience of aeronautics workers, many of them threatened with the loss of their jobs, that their livelihoods were imperiled because of unfair foreign competition, and that the Federal Government would help them.
At other stops on his road trip to promote his economic plan, Mr. Clinton has appealed for support for the tax increases that are its major feature. But this time the message was one of reassurance. 
 Mr. Clinton spoke at the Boeing factory here in this city north of Seattle just days after company managers announced that they would lay off 28,000 workers in the next 18 months. The President said that employees were not to blame for their plight and that unfair foreign competition had undercut their industry.
 
European Subsidies Attacked
 The President was especially critical of European subsidies for Airbus, the multibillion-dollar project that has left Boeing and McDonnell Douglas scrambling to compete.
"It is indeed ironic," he said, "that the United States, which for so long has led the world in the production of airplanes and in the development of sophisticated, consumer-oriented services through commercial carriers, has had three years in which more money has been lost than was made in the previous history of the airline history. And I can tell you from my study, very little of that is your fault."
Mr. Clinton and his aides made it clear that the Administration did not intend to fight subsidies with subsidies, but would seek to limit Europe's contribution to Airbus, the American aircraft industry's major competitor. The President said he had instructed the United States Trade Representative, Mickey Kantor, to begin monitoring international agreements, made last year, that would limit subsidies to Airbus.
"We need a commitment not to shield ourselves from competition but to reward ourselves when we really compete and win," Mr. Clinton told 3,000 Boeing employees who gathered to hear him speak in a cavernous hangar here.
"Countries which do that win," Mr. Clinton said. "Those which don't are punished. And we can no longer afford to wait for 10 years, while someone does something to us that we do not respond to."
Boeing announced that 28,000 of its 141,500 workers nationwide would be laid off because of declining commercial airplane sales. About 15,000 of those lost jobs are to be in Washington State. The first round of notices to employees went out here on Friday.
 
Changing the Rules
 "I think you and I know deep in our hearts that most of these layoffs -- maybe not all, because the airline industry itself has problems which are bleeding back onto you the commercial carriers -- but a lot of these layoffs would not have been announced had it not been for the $26 billion that the United States sat by and let Europe plow into Airbus over the last several years," he told the Boeing employees. "So we're going to try to change the rules of the game."
Mr. Clinton, who met privately with executives of the commercial airlines and their manufacturers after his speech here, said he supported the establishment of commission that would examine the standing of the airline industry and would ask such a group to make suggestions to revive the industry within 90 days after it is created by Congress.
Other than that, Mr. Clinton's plans for reviving the industry and providing jobs for those who will be laid off appear to rely entirely on his ability to use the economic plan he has proposed to revive the economy as a whole.
"If we do a good job, we'll be able to find more business and bring some of them back to work," he said after the meeting.
By casting responsibility for the industry's problems on the Europeans instead of on problems the Government could remedy by offering tax breaks or subsidies to the industry, Mr. Clinton portrayed himself as a champion of the middle-class employees who will lose their jobs here.
"Other nations follow targeted strategies and partnerships to pierce markets which you had dominated under a free market system but with which you could not compete," he said.
Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, said the economic plan to be presented to Congress next week would help growing companies like Silicon Graphics as well as large ones like Boeing. She said the plan would include worker retraining and other investments to make the economy more competitive.
Approval for the way Mr. Clinton is handling his job as President has risen since he delivered his economic address last Wednesday, according to a CBS News Poll taken over the weekend. Sixty-four percent of Americans now say they approve of the way Mr. Clinton is doing his job. That was up from 53 percent who said the same thing 10 days earlier. Mr. Clinton's job approval rating is now roughly what George Bush's was at a similar point in his Presidency.
The nationwide telephone poll was conducted with 923 adults who were first interviewed for a poll conducted Feb. 9 to Feb. 11. The most frequently cited reasons for those who changed their views from disapproval of Mr. Clinton in the first poll to approval in the second were Mr. Clinton's speech and his economic plan in general.

HEADLINE: Nation of Orphans: A special report;
Uganda, Scarred by AIDS, Turns to Its Youth

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUTENGO, Uganda

 BODY:
Before Julius Keeya Kintu's father died of AIDS five years ago, he taught his son how to grow coffee, squash and cassava, whose root is Uganda's staple food. Together they patched up the family's brick-and-thatch hut.
Then, a few months ago, Julius's mother, sick with AIDS and unable to care for herself, left her children and traveled to her mother's home to die. 
 Now 13, Julius has become the head of the family, the oldest boy of the seven children left to survive on their own on the two hilly acres that yield their scant livelihood.
"My father taught me how to plant and my mother, she taught me discipline," said Julius, a thin wiry boy, his voice low and serious. "When I am older I want to be a doctor. I see so many people who are sick and they die before they even get to the hospital."
A decade after AIDS was first diagnosed in Uganda, the number of orphans surviving and schooling themselves is becoming an accepted part of society. The Government AIDS Commission estimates that AIDS-related deaths have left between 1.5 million and 2 million children without fathers; most have also lost their mothers.
The Kintu family is one of more than a hundred in this district led by children 14 or younger. A 1991 census of the Rakai and Masaka districts showed that one child in four was an orphan.
The Government has resisted setting up orphanages, saying it they are economically and socially impractical. In a poor country where more than 85 percent of the residents farm, the aim is to keep orphans on their land -- their only insurance for the future -- where their communities look after them.
Orphans are but one of the many changes in the social fabric and traditions of this East African nation, one of the hardest hit by AIDS, as it struggles to cope -- medically, emotionally, socially and politically -- with an epidemic that continues to outrace prevention.
 
A 9% Infection Rate
 In Africa, as in much of the world, statistics on AIDS sometimes lack credibility, in large part because of inadequate reporting. Only 30 percent of Ugandans are in regular contact with health-care professionals.
Using 1988 projections, the Government estimates that 9 percent of Uganda's 16.7 million people carry the virus. (The infection rate in the United States is estimated by the World Health Organization and others at four-tenths of 1 percent.)
In December the Ugandan AIDS Control Program estimated about 38,500 cases of the disease, up 17,000 from the year before. But Godwill Asiimwe-Okiror, an epidemiologist for the program, said the number might be closer to 380,000.
There are no figures available for the number of deaths.
 
First, Admit the Problem
 Although its plague may be less vast than the epidemics in other countries in Africa, Uganda has become the bellwether in acknowledging its problems and trying to deal with them: over the past two years, the causes and treatment of AIDS have been demystified and awareness of the epidemic has become widespread.
"Now in Uganda virtually everyone knows they have been exposed," explained Norine Kaleeba, the founder and director of The AIDS Support Organization, which advocates the rights of people with AIDS throughout Africa. "It is self-awareness that has caused this. The question is, Have I caught it or not? It is not the blood-test results that are important; it is what you do. We all hope we can cope.
"Watching someone die of AIDS it is actually like watching a video of yourself. You wonder how long it will be before it is you, yourself."
 
Uganda Has Changed
 The epidemic has changed aspects of Uganda's social life. Kampala's brothels have closed down, and truck-stop hotels on the main highways that a few years ago were teeming with prostitutes are now hurting for business. "Positive Living" and "Love Carefully" are seen on T-shirts, walls and newspapers, and the mottoes are preached from universities to thatch huts, from President Yoweri K. Museveni to farmers.
There are political repercussions, as well. The military, the backbone of the ruling party, has been hard hit; although there are no reliable statistics because testing has been limited, epidemiologists estimate that at least 40 percent and possibly 80 percent of soldiers are infected with H.I.V. Now, as civil wars fade and more than 40 percent of the 90,000 man in uniform are being sent home, researchers worry that the infection rate will rise.
 
The Dead
A National Need For Spiritual Solace
 But in this intensely spiritual country, where two decades of civil war killed more than half a million people, the calamity of AIDS is often greeted with gentleness. There is very little guilt or blame over AIDS. The focus is very much on survival.
"I have never seen anyone fight death," said Sister Ursula Sharpe, director of the outpatient AIDS unit at Kitovu Hospital in Masaka, which serves more than 1,800 patients a week. "The spirit world here is very close. When you live in the middle of it, somehow you cope."
AIDS deaths touch every Ugandan family, mostly the young adults and breadwinners or very young children, and relief workers say fear and emotional exhaustion are overwhelming.
 
Some Witchcraft, No AZT
 The average life span after one is infected with H.I.V. is five years. Hospitals are overcrowded and there is a large market in herbal medicines and in some cases witchcraft to treat the disease. Drugs like AZT are not available; infected Ugandans have access only to antibiotics, aspirin and cortisone cream for skin rashes.
Newspapers carry pages of death announcements, most for young people and military and Government officials. Last spring 22 of 2,000 students at Makerere University in Kampala graduated posthumously.
In the villages and towns, every plot of red earth and banana palms has burial mounds. Communities are flooded by the sheer number of deaths. Funerals, once several-day affairs in which whole villages took part, now take only several hours. The year traditionally allowed for a widow to mourn has been shortened to less than 24 hours, after which it is considered bad luck to grieve.
 
The Data
Who Are Sick, Who Tends Them
 By the mid-1990's, the great majority of new AIDS cases in the world will occur in sub-Saharan Africa, where an estimated 20 million Africans will become infected, according to a State Department report in 1992. The epidemic is expected to substantially weaken the political elites and damage the economies of the hardest hit countries -- Uganda, Rwanda, Malawi, Botswana, Zambia and Zimbabwe -- all of which have H.I.V. infection rates that exceed 5 percent of their populations.
The 9 percent infection rate in Uganda varies by age and sex, and between urban and rural settings.
In Kampala one in every four adults carries the virus; in Masaka district the infection rate is about 35 percent. But in Choteru, a traders' town near the Tanzanian border where AIDS in Uganda was first diagnosed a decade ago, 60 percent of women between 19 and 24 are believed to be infected. As AIDS awareness has spread, Choteru has become almost a ghost town where truckers do not even stop.
 
High Rate Among Women
 In 1990 about $150 million was spent on AIDS prevention in Africa, nearly all from foreign donors. But because the effort is so recent, it will have only a marginal effect on the spread of H.I.V., the human immunodeficiency virus that causes AIDS.
In this polygamous and promiscuous society, young women are the most vulnerable and their infection rate is six times higher than that of young men, according to the Agency for International Development. In prenatal clinics, 30 percent of the women tested last year were infected with H.I.V., an increase of six percentage points from 1990.
Dr. Asiimwe-Okiror, of the Ugandan AIDS Control Program, said surveys in particularly hard hit regions in southern Uganda showed that about 1 percent of the population was becoming infected with H.I.V. each year.
"That's astronomical," he said, "and it might even be more than that."
 
The Struggle
 Using Condoms Is Just a Start
 The effectiveness of the fight against AIDS is difficult to assess. Ultimately, Ugandan officials and doctors agree, the real impact must come from education and a concerted change in social behavior.
There is a highly conservative approach at the upper levels of leadership. Ugandan AIDS organizations stress monogamy and a subtle approach to condoms. (There are no condom advertisements in Government-owned media.) Foreign groups, including the Agency for International Development, promote and distribute condoms and encourage blood tests.
In recent years, prevention and treatment programs have been underwritten in large part by the United States, which spent about $22.5 million from 1988 to 1992 and has budgeted $4 million this year. The World Health Organization provided $3 million in 1991 and the United Nations Development Program is planning to spend $15 million in 1991-96.
 
Calculating Results
 But the effectiveness of the extensive programs -- from condoms to blood tests to family planning -- is only now being gauged.
The marketing of condoms has had mixed results. For the rural population, condoms are either too difficult to find or too expensive, and many Ugandans do not understand the necessity of using them all the time.
The Agency for International Development plans to distribute five million condoms in 1993, but the number is deceptive. In the military, for example, 360,000 condoms were distributed between 1988 and 1991, about one per year for each of the 90,000 men in the army.
 
The Religious Hurdle
 Uganda is about 45 percent Roman Catholic, and there has been deep-seated opposition to the use of condoms from the bishops in Uganda and, most recently, from Pope John Paul II. In a recent visit he preached chastity as the only way to fight AIDS.
But President Museveni, who once openly opposed condoms, is now advocating a "quiet approach" to distribution. Catholic missionaries running AIDS clinics not only tell their patients about condoms but also supply them if asked.
As for blood tests, many Ugandans are still afraid to be tested, even community workers in constant contact with the suffering.
Rabina Ssentongo, of Kitovu's Mobile Care Unit, visits thousands of patients every week. At 31, she has also lost three brothers to AIDS.
But she says she is still too scared to be tested for H.I.V.
 
A Final Caress
 From Consolation To Inspiration
 Miss Ssentongo has watched the sickness of parents drive children to suicide, and teen-agers numbly cleaning adults who can no longer control their bodies. Her conversations are mostly about AIDS and sexual behavior. Depression shadows her work.
"I feel very sad when I work with the dying," she said. She gives everyone who stops her on her rounds a few minutes, a smile, a caress, a soothing word. "It is very special for me to work with the orphans because I know that with them they will be alive in the future."
Miss Ssentongo's four-wheel-drive vehicle jolts over the rutted red-dirt roads as she visits huts buried in the green farms, bringing dignity to death and an upbeat tone to survival.
In a square brick house, on a thin reed mattress, a 30-year-old woman lies emaciated, her body racked by a cough, her mother gently holding her hand. Miss Ssentongo eases her burly frame into a squat next to the woman, feels her chest, caresses her head, gently whispers to her, leaning forward to grasp the answers.
"I call this the speech of life," Miss Ssentongo said. "She wants an imam to come pray for her. I make sure she has made a will and that if she has children, she has left them her land. The woman has been sick for only seven months but she will probably die today. This is the situation I hate, when the body has wasted away so much."
There is only time for a few words of courage for the mother, then Miss Ssentongo must leave to visit the hundreds of orphans she looks after.
 
The Next Generation
7 Kintu Orphans Grow Up Fast
 The orphans underscore the uncertainty of Uganda's next generation. The children are expected to remain on their land, checked by community groups that monitor their crops.
But they also remain extremely vulnerable. Schooling is expensive. Many children need psychological counseling. The teen-age girls alone at home are targets for men.
"We would like them to maintain their basic rural life," said Manuel Pinto, the director of the Ugandan Aids Commission. "If you take them abruptly away and provide them Western-style home care, you will alienate them from their lineage and culture."
 
Counsel for the Orphans
 Miss Ssentongo, the health worker, checks each week on Julius Kintu and his six brothers and sisters, and on 5,000 other orphans in the district. She makes sure they have food, and focuses particularly on counseling girls reaching puberty. They chat about the future and what they want to do.
The Kintus are among the luckiest. Living in two dirt rooms under a corrugated-tin roof, barefoot and dressed in tattered school uniforms, they divide the work and rely on the know-how of Julius and his older sisters. Every day they walk two hours to school, then return to work their land.
"To be on your own without any loving people around, that is terrible," Miss Ssentongo said. "There is no one to explain to them how to grow up and when they do grow up, will they be fed up of being responsible? But now they know their problems and they cope. They'll ask for salt but never for sugar. They want to survive."
