HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Sharply to Record Low vs. Yen

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 23

 BODY:
The dollar continued its fall to record lows against the Japanese yen today as traders anticipated that the leading industrial nations would push for a stronger yen to help reduce Japan's soaring trade surplus with the United States and Europe.
But Japanese authorities, while not totally against a stronger yen, said the recent rise of the yen and fall of the dollar were too swift, and hinted they might intervene in the currency markets to stabilize wild fluctuations. 
 The dollar closed today at yet another new low in Japanese trading, ending at 116.78 yen. It was the third consecutive day the dollar had fallen to a new low.
On Monday, the dollar closed at 116.85 yen in Tokyo, plunging 2.38 yen from its Friday close and reaching its lowest level since World War II. Later in New York, the dollar went even lower, closing Monday at 116.36 yen.
In today's trading, the dollar opened at 116.40 yen and fell as low as 116.30 before regaining some ground, apparently in reaction to the comments of high Japanese officials that the yen's rise had come too fast and that finance officials of the Group of Seven industrial nations had not agreed to lift the Japanese currency.
 
Foreigners Pay More
 As recently as two weeks ago, the dollar was worth 124 yen. For an American visiting Japan, a Tokyo hotel room that cost $160 on Feb. 8 costs $170 now, and an order of fast-food fried chicken that was $5.40 now costs more than $5.70.
The prices of Japanese goods sold in the United States, however, are not likely to be affected so immediately. In the case of cars, for example, Japanese companies may decide to raise prices by about the 5 percent that the yen has appreciated. But given the competition from domestic auto makers and the weakness of the American economic recovery, the Japanese auto industry may be forced to simply absorb the currency loss, which would cut more deeply into their already narrowing profits. In any case, price adjustments for currency fluctuations take several months to reach consumers.
Until its drop in the last three trading days, the lowest level for the dollar had been 118.60 yen, reached during Tokyo trading last Sept. 30, although the dollar rebounded and was higher at the close of that session.
Currency traders here have been knocking the dollar down in reaction to comments on Friday by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen in Washington. In response to a question at the National Press Club, Mr. Bentsen said he would like to see a stronger yen to help the United States reduce its trade deficit with Japan.
Similar comments favoring a stronger yen were made earlier this month by European officials. A stronger yen would make Japanese goods more expensive abroad while goods from other countries would be cheaper here, possibly narrowing Japan's trade surplus.
The calls for a stronger yen led to the belief among traders here that the finance ministers of the Group of Seven would agree to move toward a stronger yen at a meeting on Saturday in London. But Japanese officials cautioned today that no agreement had been reached by the ministers.
 
'A Pretty Free Rein'
 "With Bentsen having made his statement, the market feels it has a pretty free rein to take it to 115 to 114," said Kenneth S. Courtis, a strategist for Deutsche Bank in Asia.
Yoshiro Hayashi, Japan's Finance Minister, called the Monday trading "quite speculative" and said the Government would watch the market closely. A Bank of Japan official said the market was moving too fast. But other than such verbal hints, which can by themselves have a steadying effect, there did not yet appear to be direct intervention by the Government to support the dollar, analysts said.
Japanese officials have mixed feelings about the rising yen, although in general they have tolerated a gradual strengthening.
On the positive side, a strong yen would over the long term help reduce Japan's politically bothersome trade surplus. In the short term, a stronger yen will help Japan's banks, which are troubled by large numbers of bad loans, achieve necessary capital levels for the fiscal year that ends March 31. Assets held by banks overseas, when measured in stronger yen, become worth less, meaning less capital is needed to support assets.
 
Some Drawbacks for Japan
 But a stronger yen hurts Japan's blue-chip electronics and automobile companies, which are heavily dependent on exports. Since exports have been one factor keeping the struggling Japanese economy afloat, a blow to exports could prolong Japan's steep economic slump. It could also hurt the stock market. And keeping stocks from dropping is also important to keeping banks healthy.
Mineko Sasaki-Smith, chief economist at Credit Suisse Japan, said Monday that Japanese companies and the Government might have been most comfortable with 120 yen to the dollar. "Quite a few exporters consider 120 to 125 manageable," she said.

Broad Loss for Dollar
 By The Associated Press
The dollar declined broadly in Europe and New York yesterday, falling to its lowest against the Japanese yen since World War II. In London, the dollar was quoted at 116.40 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 116.36 yen, down from 118.23 yen Friday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.4540, from $1.4528 late Friday. In New York, 1 sold for $1.4580, up from $1.4535 on Friday.

HEADLINE: Confidence Index Up Again

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: NEWTON, Mass., Feb. 22

 BODY:
Business confidence in the economy rose for the fourth consecutive month in February, the Cahners Business Confidence Index said today.
The index, which tracks companies' spending, production and hiring plans, increased to 68.9 in February, from 68.6 in January. It was the highest reading since the index was started by Cahners Economics in 1991, and 3.8 points ahead of the index reading for February 1992. 
 "The modest 0.3-point increase followed the substantial 3.3-point surge of January, providing further evidence that this higher level of business optimism is sustainable in the long term," the report said.
"Four of the seven index components registered gains in February, being led by a 2.6-point increase in business plans to step up spending on research and development," the report said. "However, following several months of sharp increases, the capital spending component fell back by 3.4 points."

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Price of Platinum Tumbles; Other Precious Metals Drop

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Platinum futures prices skidded to their lowest point in more than a year yesterday as economic anxiety rose in Japan, the world's largest consumer of the metal.
Prices of other precious metals also fell. On other commodity markets, oil futures rose; lumber continued to soar; livestock rose, and grains and soybeans ended mixed. 
 Platinum for April delivery plunged $19.20 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, to $338.20 an ounce, the lowest settlement for near-term deliveries since Jan. 15 of last year. Palladium sank $9, to $98.35 an ounce.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold fell $2.10, to $328.20 an ounce, and silver for March delivery dropped 3.9 cents, to $3.523 an ounce, a two-year low.
Platinum's plunge extended a steep drop posted last week on the belief that President Clinton's proposed tax increases would stifle economic recovery in the United States and reduce demand for industrial metals, particularly platinum, an important element in automobile pollution-control systems.
Also, the Japanese yen's rise to a record high against the American dollar prompted "massive liquidation" of platinum futures by Japanese investors on the Tokyo Commodity Exchange, said William O'Neill, senior futures strategist with Merrill Lynch Futures in New York.
Energy futures moved higher, with heating oil and gasoline prices rising sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Crude oil for March delivery climbed 40 cents, to $20.02 a barrel; March heating oil jumped 1.17 cents, to 56.49 cents a gallon; March unleaded gasoline rose 0.97 cent, to 54.43 cents a gallon, and April natural gas leaped 9.7 cents, to $1.849 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Lumber for March delivery rose $15 on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, to $440.70 for 1,000 board feet, the 20th straight record high.
Forecasts for another winter storm in the Plains states drove cattle futures higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Hog futures also rose.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat for March delivery rose 2 1/4 cents, to $3.69 a bushel; March corn fell 1 cent, to $2.11 3/4 a bushel; March oats fell 2 1/4 cents, to $1.36 a bushel, and March soybeans dropped 2 1/2 cents, to $5.70 3/4 a bushel.

HEADLINE: Treasury Report On Clinton Plan Labels It as Fair

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
A Treasury Department document scheduled to be made public on Wednesday takes pains to assert that fairness was a major consideration behind many of President Clinton's proposed tax changes, including one to end deductions of country club dues as a business expense.
A draft of the document, which was provided by someone outside the Treasury Department, also shows that the Administration has put some intricate restrictions into its tax breaks for business, including the new credit on investment in equipment, to prevent corporations from exploiting them. 
 The report explaining the Administration's tax proposals said deducting country club dues was unfair because activities at such clubs involved "a significant element of personal pleasure, enjoyment and social benefit."
The department also picks up Mr. Clinton's language in explaining the decision to reduce the percentage of business meals and entertainment expenses that can be deducted to 50 percent from 80 percent. The department says this new limitation is desirable because there is a "portion of these expenditures that is inherently personal in nature."
 
Limit for Pay Deductions
 The document also stresses fairness as explaining why the Administration has proposed limiting to $1 million the deductions corporations can take for pay to an individual executive, unless the pay is linked to productivity. The department argues that it is wrong for the Government to provide companies with unlimited deductions for executive pay, especially when many companies are not doing well and the wages of many workers have not kept up with inflation.
Many people have complained about the tax proposals, including restaurant owners, corporations and highly paid executives. For example, restaurant owners worry that further restricting deductions for business meals could harm their lunch business. Companies assert that increases in their taxes will make them reluctant to invest. And the executives say the free market should determine compensation without intervention by the Government.
But the Treasury report took a different view of executive pay, saying, "This unlimited tax subsidy is particularly troubling in light of concerns that in some cases, the compensation paid to corporate executives has increased despite a decline in business performance." It said the current law did not provide sufficient incentive for corporations to link compensation to business performance and added that the new proposal aimed to create a strong incentive for companies to link compensation to productivity.
The document, known as a Blue Book, is scheduled to be made public on Wednesday and aims to help legislators, accountants and other tax experts understand the rationale and details of Mr. Clinton's tax proposals.
 
New Details on Tax Plans
 The report also explains the proposal to end most deductions for corporate lobbying expenses, saying they "inappropriately" subsidize "corporations and special interest groups for intervening in the legislative process."
The report includes new details of how many tax changes will work. For example, the documents show that the proposed new tax credit for business investment will not be available for buying used equipment.
In another surprise to many tax experts, the department proposes taking back in future years some investment tax credits if companies squeeze an inordinate amount of investment into 1993 and 1994, the two years for which the credit is available, then slash investment.

HEADLINE: Christopher Visits Beirut to Affirm Support and Push Peace Talks

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher flew by helicopter to Beirut today in a gesture intended to affirm the Clinton Administration's commitment to Lebanon's fragile sovereignty and to win support for a quick resumption of the Middle East peace talks.
Mr. Christopher, the first senior American official to visit Beirut since Secretary of State George P. Shultz in 1983, flew from Larnaca, Cyprus, wearing an orange life vest over his suit. His aircraft was accompanied by armed security guards in a convoy of three United States Army Blackhawk helicopters. Along the way, he passed over the rubble of buildings bombed during the 18 years of Lebanon's war-scarred history and over new construction sites. 
 Security was so tight that the Lebanese Government was formally told of the visit only after his plane had left Kuwait and linked up with the helicopters, which are used to ferry American officials, supplies and mail into Beirut. The helicopters came in fast and low -- hovering only 100 feet above the ground to avoid detection by potential saboteurs -- before landing in an open field within the Defense Ministry complex in East Beirut.
Five hundred extra Lebanese soldiers were assigned to secure the building, an American condition for the trip, although no sounds of gunfire were heard during the visit.
 
Symbol of U.S. Support
 Mr. Christopher told reporters in Beirut that the visit "symbolizes our commitment and support for the Lebanese Government, for its effort to achieve independence and territorial integrity, for the dissolution of the armed militias and for the withdrawal of all non-Lebanese forces."
By traveling to Beirut, Mr. Christopher intended to demonstrate that the Clinton Administration did not want to treat a city with a tarnished reputation as off-limits.
His visit also indicated that he has at least some confidence that the fledgling Government of its billionaire Prime Minister, Rafiq al-Hariri, may survive. The visit helps Mr. Hariri's standing both in his own country and as a figure in the peace negotiations by treating him as someone who deserves to be dealt with in his own capital.
Mr. Christopher was also sending a message to the Syrians that Washington is committed to their withdrawal from Beirut in accordance with the 1989 Taif peace agreement, which ended Lebanon's civil war.
 
Troop Withdrawal Date Missed
 That agreement called for Syria and Lebanon to arrange the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Beirut into the Bekaa region two years after the creation of a national unity Government in Lebanon. The move would have meant the first step toward the total removal of the 35,000 troops, which Syria deployed in Lebanon in 1976, the year after the civil war began.
Much to the chagrin of the United States, the Syrians, arguing that Lebanon had not instituted enough political reforms, did not withdraw their troops as scheduled last September.
"It was exhilarating, actually," Mr. Christopher said of his brief trip after returning to Larnaca and then continuing on to Jerusalem for two days of talks with Israeli leaders about the Middle East peace negotiations.
Earlier today, Mr. Christopher flew from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, to Kuwait, where he met with the Emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah. In both capitals he issued strong statements against the Iraqi Government of President Saddam Hussein and sought to assure Kuwaiti and Saudi leaders that the Clinton Administration was not weakening in its resolve to carry out all the United Nations Security Council resolutions against Mr. Hussein.
Lebanon's leaders were eager for Mr. Christopher to make the trip, and Foreign Minister Faris Bouez told reporters that Lebanon is committed to resuming the peace talks as soon as possible. Like Egyptian, Jordanian and Syrian officials who have met with Mr. Christopher on his first foreign trip as Secretary of State, Mr. Bouez did not insist that the peace talks could begin again only after nearly 400 Palestinians deported by Israel to Lebanon last December were returned.
Mr. Hariri refused to accept the deportees when they were expelled from Israel, and they remain stranded in Lebanon between Israeli and Lebanese Army checkpoints.
Mr. Christopher also signaled that the United States would consider resuming aid to Lebanon and lifting largely symbolic sanctions.
In January 1987, as a protest against terrorism and the absence of any central control in Lebanon, the United States announced, among other steps, that American passports were no longer valid for travel to the country and closed its consular section in Lebanon.
Today, Mr. Christopher said he discussed with Lebanese leaders the possibility of extending economic aid, the training of Lebanese military officers in the United States, the purchase of excess American military equipment and the lifting of the sanctions.
But he added, "We want to be sure we don't aggravate the problem by releasing the travel restrictions at too early a date, and perhaps the fact that I've been able to come here tonight will be a favorable factor."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Dean Witter Stake Is Sold In Offering

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
In a widely anticipated public offering, Sears, Roebuck & Company sold 29.5 million shares of its Dean Witter brokerage firm subsidiary yesterday at $27 a share, or $796.5 million.
Demand for the shares was so strong that over the weekend underwriters increased the price range for the offering to between $25 and $27 a share, from an initial range of $23 to $25. 
 The shares, which include the Discover credit-card operation, were priced after the close of the New York Stock Exchange, where they will begin trading today. Morgan Stanley & Company, one of the lead managers on the deal, acted as independent pricing agent. Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. acted as lead manager for the underwriting.
 
 
$910 Million in Potential Proceeds
 An additional 4.3 million shares of the stock could potentially be offered to the public if the stock performs well once it is freed up for trading, investment bankers said. If those shares are sold, it would raise the proceeds to more than $910 million, which would be used to capitalize the new company.
Yesterday's offering represents 20 percent of the company that will be known as Dean Witter, Discover & Company. Sears, which bought Dean Witter in 1981 for $661 million in cash and stock, will spin off the remaining 80 percent to Sears stockholders in the form of a dividend within the next three to four months. The spinoff is part of Sears's plan to shed financial operations to concentrate on its core retail operations.
Analysts said they were not surprised that demand for the new Dean Witter shares was so strong.
 
 
'Top-Notch' Retail Operation
 "The company has done well over the last four or five years," said Perrin H. Long, a securities industry analyst at the First of Michigan Corporation in Detroit. "Not only do they have a top-notch retail brokerage operation, but they also have the Discover card, which is the largest retail card in the business."
The new shares, based on anticipated Dean Witter earnings of between $2.50 and $2.65 a share this year, were priced at about 10 times earnings, Mr. Long estimated. That is comparable to the earnings multiple of the shares of Merrill Lynch & Company, he said.
"Brokers are doing well, interest rates are going down and at 10 times earnings, the Dean Witter stock looks like a reasonable buy," he said.
Wall Street executives said demand for the new Dean Witter shares was particularly strong among domestic institutions.
They said Philip J. Purcell, Dean Witter's chairman and chief executive, and other company executives were particularly effective in presenting their case to potential investors.
"This was one of the great road shows in recent history," one Wall Street executive said. "Purcell and his people did a spectacular job. Every major account in the United States took a very, very hard look at deal, and a vast majority came in for shares."
Yesterday's successful equity pricing should help the sale of $4 billion worth of new Dean Witter debt securities, which is tentatively scheduled for next month, the executive said.
"This has to be seen as a great positive to people throughout the financial community," the executive said. "As such, it has to be a positive for the initial debt offering and for subsequent ones as well."
In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Sears shares closed yesterday at $53.875, up 37.5 cents a share.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Bond Yield Hits 6.93% Low

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
President Clinton's economic program may be running into some obstacles in Congress and in the corporate world. But it is having no problems in the bond market, where long-term interest rates continue to fall.
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond dropped below 7 percent yesterday for the first time since the Treasury began issuing 30-year bonds regularly in 1977, as traders and investors continued to see positives for long-term interest rates in the program the President proposed last week. The price of the bond jumped 28/32, to 10214/32, to yield 6.93 percent. 
 The 6.93 percent yield, down from 7 percent Friday, is also the lowest on any long term-term Treasury bond since the 6.80 percent yields on 20-year bonds in the spring of 1973. At the same time, the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note dropped to 6.09 percent, the lowest it has been since June 1972. Its price jumped 19/32.
The decline in long-term interest rates over the last week has been striking. Just a week ago, the yield on the 30-year bond was 7.12 percent and on the 10-year note 6.33 percent. And the drop is positive for the economy, which the President is hoping to get moving fast enough to create hundreds of thousands of new jobs soon.
 
Not 'Business as Usual'
 The break below 7 percent, said John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers, "certainly should suggest to businesses and consumers that there is something new here and that this is just not business as usual."
"This could increase confidence in the belief that we are back in the low interest rate and low inflation environment of the late 1960's," he said.
As for the pace of the recovery, Mr. Lipsky said, "lower long-term interest rates reduce the cost of capital for firms and encourage investment, which should increase growth and create jobs."
He added that Administration officials had made it clear that they were betting on lower long-term interest rates to be a major force behind the revival of the economy.
Lower long-term interest rates also mean lower mortgage costs for consumers, which can spur the housing industry, a critical part of any economic recovery. In addition, lower interest rates will reduce the debt burden that both corporations and consumers picked up in the 1980's. That debt burden is one reason why this economic recovery is sluggish compared with those of the past.
 
No Fluke, Traders Say
 The rally in the price of the 30-year bond and 10-year note was a slow but steady process yesterday that led traders to conclude that the surge was not a fluke.
But John Costas of the First Boston Corporation also said that the rally was helped by the fact that buying yesterday was much stronger than usual a Monday before the Treasury auction of two-year notes today and five-year notes tomorrow.
Mr. Lipsky argued that despite some revisions of opinions about the President's economic plan since it was announced, it still seems to present a program for long-term interest rates that is positive for traders and investors.
He said that it was now clear that the deficit reduction the President proposed was mostly achieved through tax increases and Government fees, some of which the Clinton Administration tried to count as spending reductions. For example, the tax increase on Social Security benefits was counted as a spending reduction.
Mr. Lipsky said that based on Salomon Brothers calculations, the plan would not produce any significant cut in overall Government spending until the fiscal year 1996.
But despite this, Mr. Lipsky argued that the plan could still produce significant deficit reduction, although mostly through new revenue. This deficit reduction, in turn, will act as a drag on economic growth by reducing consumer, business and government spending.
 
Good for Market
 This is positive for the bond market because slower growth means that there is less chance that inflation will begin rising again soon. And with continued low inflation, investors will begin to pay even more attention to what Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said recently in testimony to Congress: That given the levels of current inflation long-term interest rates should be about two percentage points lower than where they were then, which was around 7.20 percent. Such a belief makes long-term bonds with a 6.93 percent yield attractive buys.
In late trading yesterday in the pre-auction market, the yield on the two-year note to be auctioned today was 3.99 percent, down from 4.01 percent Friday. The yield on the five-year note to be auctioned tomorrow was 5.24 percent, down from 5.29 percent.
In the weekly Treasury auction the discount rate on three-month bills moved higher while the discount rate on six-month bills fell. The average discount rate on the three-month bill was 2.96 percent and on the six-month 3.06 percent. Following are the results of the auction.

HEADLINE: Europe Is Divided on Clinton's Plans

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 22

 BODY:
European governments are divided in their response to President Clinton's economic plan, gratified by his attempt to reduce the American budget deficit, but increasingly irked by his tough approach to trade issues.
Before the Clinton Administration came to power last month, there was widespread optimism here for improved trans-Atlantic ties. European leaders felt that economic relations had reached a nadir under President George Bush's neglect of the dollar as it drifted downward and in the failure to reach a world trade accord. 
 But as finance ministers from the Group of Seven industrialized nations prepare to meet in London this week for the first time since Mr. Clinton took office, the European optimism is already mixed with uncertainty and irritation.
 
Warning on Protectionism
 "There are extremely worrying signs on the trade front," former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France said in an interview. "And the Clinton Administration must be told very clearly that protectionism will lead to disaster."
However, Mr. Giscard d'Estaing, who is an outside candidate to head the French Government after elections next month, added, "On the other hand, Mr. Clinton's attempt to reduce the U.S. deficit is courageous and can only be applauded."
European governments, joined by the Japanese, have long been calling for measures to cut the deficit in the United States. In essence, they have argued that the mounting deficit tended to undermine the United States economy and weaken the dollar, so hampering sustained worldwide economic growth and skewing world trade.
For example, buoyed by a weak dollar that made its exports relatively cheap, United States exports to the European Community surged from $60.6 billion in 1987 to $103.2 billion in 1991.
In the same period, European exports to the United States were virtually stagnant, inching up from $84.9 billion to $86.5 billion. Thus, from a deficit of $24.3 billion with Europe in 1987, Washington moved to a $16.7 billion surplus.
 
Pushing Dollar Up
 In general, economists believe the dollar -- currently trading at 1.63 marks -- now has room for an appreciation of about 10 percent against European currencies, and that President Clinton's measures to cut the deficit will ultimately reinforce this upward trend.
"The dollar has considerable upside, and is probably heading for an exchange rate of 1.80 marks," said Kim Schoenholtz, the chief European economist for Salomon Brothers in London.
J. Paul Horne, chief economist for Smith Barney in Paris, added: "The deficit has long been a fundamental negative for the dollar because it was seen as a structural flaw in the United States economy. That should begin to change now."
Because such a change is seen as ultimately beneficial to European economies, there has been virtual unanimity in applauding President Clinton's proposed measures to cut the deficit.
Henning Christophersen, the community's economics commissioner, summed up sentiment last week when he described the Clinton package as "encouraging and full of promise -- the most serious effort in years to tackle the Federal deficit."
 
Looking for Locomotive
 Europe is worried that United States growth this year will not be strong enough to act as a locomotive for European economies still in a slump.
While the United States economy is widely expected to grow at least 3 percent this year, the community's economy may grow 1 percent at best. Thus, there has been concern that President Clinton's proposed new personal and corporate taxes could hold back United States growth.
"The Europeans are desperate for a United States locomotive," Mr. Horne said. "So they are asking, how much is this taxation going to penalize growth?"
Despite the impression here that President Clinton had done a good job in balancing the tough fiscal measures needed to reduce the deficit with stimulative economic measures, there are lingering doubts on resolving pressing trade issues.
Already, the Clinton Administration has imposed stiff duties on steel imports. And the President has said that $26 billion of European subsidies toward building the Airbus aircraft industry had served to push American people out of work.
"We have the impression that the United States under Bill Clinton will be tough and difficult negotiators on trade," said Peter Guildford, the community's spokesman for international trade issues. "But up to now we see protectionism more in word than in deed, and we hope we can still reach a global trade agreement."

HEADLINE: Clinton Backs Funds For Science Projects

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
DESPITE the Clinton Administration's hopes to achieve sharp reductions in Government spending, prospects appear to have brightened for Federal financing of some branches of scientific research and for construction of the world's largest particle accelerator, the Superconducting Supercollider.
The National Science Foundation, the Federal Government's major financing agency for small to medium-sized scientific research, would receive a special increase in its budget for the current year, which its officials say would permit real growth. Although the pace of construction of the supercollider would be throttled back, it would still receive ample financing to keep it alive. 
 As part of the Administration's supplemental financing request for the 1993 budget, the National Science Foundation would receive an extra $207 million, bringing its budget for this year to $2.94 billion, about 14 percent above its 1992 budget.
"This is great news for the National Science Foundation," its director, Dr. Walter Massey, said yesterday, adding that the money was vital to fully finance the foundation's program of applied science and technology.
 
Testimony Set for Today
 Dr. Massey is scheduled to testify before the House Appropriations Committee today in support of the supplemental financing.
The Office of Management and Budget, the Administration's budgetary arm, has also called for continued financing of the Superconducting Supercollider, provided that Congress agrees. But the financing schedule proposed by the Administration would extend construction of the accelerator by two or three years, adding to its cost.
If the Administration's plan is adopted by Congress, some $640 million would be appropriated for the supercollider in 1994, an increase of $108 million over 1993 spending. Appropriations would later increase by 3 percent a year until the planned completion of the project in the year 2003. Such a financing rate would substantially delay completion, however, and experts estimate that the project's cost would increase from its present estimated cost to about $10 billion from $8.4 billion.
Construction of the supercollider, near Waxahachie, Tex., is roughly one-quarter complete, its officials say, with nearly $2 billion spent so far. Its main component is a circular tunnel 54 miles in circumference. But the project could face major opposition in Congress this year. Last year the House of Representatives voted to withhold funds for the project, but financing was restored after a favorable vote in the Senate.
Both the Reagan and Bush Administrations, as well as Congress, had pushed for substantial foreign contributions to the supercollider's cost, but the major foreign partner the United States has tried to enlist, Japan, has so far failed to commit itself to the project. Japanese officials have said they are studying various alternative approaches to accelerator design.
Another potential foreign partner in the Supercollider, Taiwan, announced yesterday that it had decided to withdraw from the project. The cabinet's National Science Council voted against participating on the ground that its proposed $50 million share in the project was too expensive.
"Stretching out SSC construction by a couple of years probably won't damage the program," said a spokesman for the project, Russ Wylie, "but it will certainly push the cost up, which is undesirable." Mr. Wylie noted that President Clinton has said that he supported the project.
The wording of the Government's proposed supplement to the present National Science Foundation budget underscores Mr. Clinton's belief that research should have identifiable economic and social benefits. Of the $207 million sought for the agency, 55 percent, or $112 million, would be designated for "strategic research."
 
Increases in 5 Areas
 Including the proposed supplement, the 1993 appropriation of $2.94 billion would significantly increase financing of five major fields of applied research. Advanced manufacturing techniques would get $113 million, $206 million would go for biotechnology, $318 million for materials research, $261 million for high-performance computing and communications, and $163 million for global change research.
The other 45 percent of the supplementary budget, some $85 million, would be applied to "enabling research," a broad field including pure scientific research, Dr. Massey said. This money would go to individuals and small groups to finance new studies and increase funds for existing ones.

HEADLINE: Security Plan Aims Savings At Tenants

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
To encourage tenants to become more involved in curbing crime in their buildings, the New York City Housing Authority plans to let residents use money saved by safety improvements.
Sally Hernandez-Pinero, the chairwoman of the Housing Authority, describes a proposal to allow tenants to spend half of the savings any way they choose in their buildings as part of a broader security plan for the city's housing projects to be released in the next two weeks. She said she would be conducting meetings with dozens of groups of residents, community advocates and employees to fine-tune the plan. 
 Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said in an interview yesterday that part of the plan involved spending to enhance the buildings by adding locks and fences and making structural improvements that would improve security. She added that some of the proposals would include youth activities and other programs to instill a sense of community in the buildings.
 
Tenant Involvement
 "We want to encourage tenants to chart a course for their own development and to help determine how we get young people engaged," she said. "It's not just tenants' patrols, it's a question of tenant involvement, a sense of tenant community. It's the idea of people taking ownership for their own community."
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said that the savings, which would be money budgeted but not spent for items like lock repair, graffiti cleaning or structural repairs, could be used for projects ranging from youth and senior citizens' programs to landscaping.
"It is, in effect, a gain-sharing program," she said, "although tenants will not get paid. But they get a chance to decide where the savings would go in their developments. The point is to say to residents: This is your home, and the money can be reprogrammed in a way that residents think is appropriate."
 
Strengthening Organizations

 She said the Housing Authority planned to encourage residents to become more involved in organizations within their complexes, from tenant patrol groups to those who help determine policies.
She declined to discuss other details of the broader crime prevention plan, which is to be put into effect over the next three years. She said the final draft would not be completed until her meetings with residents, tenants' associations and community groups. The plan was was first reported yesterday in Newsday.
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said that the entire three-year plan would cost "tens of millions of dollars," about 90 percent of which would come from the Federal Government.
Another part of the program will focus on the Housing Authority's 2,500 police officers, she said. "We are determining if the deployment of officers represents the best way of staffing."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
PACIFIC GAS AND ELECTRIC TRIMMING WORK FORCE BY 11%

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
The Pacific Gas and Electric Company of California said yesterday that it would eliminate 3,000 jobs, or 11 percent of its work force, as part of a three-year revamping aimed at cutting $200 million in annual costs. Half the jobs will be cut this year and the rest by the end of 1995. In addition, 7 of the company's 25 operating divisions will be closed and corporate staff consolidated. 
 P.G.& E., the nation's largest investor-owned utility, cited declining revenues caused by the state's economic slowdown and increased industry competition. The San Francisco-based company will resort to layoffs among its 26,600 workers only after exhausting attrition, early retirement, job sharing and other voluntary programs, said Richard A. Clarke, chairman and chief executive.

HEADLINE: Mr. Clinton's Captious Critics

 BODY:
Over the weekend, the public got a look at the Republican response, such as it is. The G.O.P. legislators and their fellow-traveling commentators are worried -- yes, gravely worried -- about President Clinton's economic proposals.
Their arguments, boiled to basics, are twofold. They believe that his efforts to reduce the deficit rely too much on new taxes and not enough on spending cuts. And in words usually reserved for the Apocalypse, they warn that his strategy will vastly expand government's reach, cripple the markets and stampede the nation into statism. 
 Some of the criticism reflects the ruffled pride of a party that suddenly finds itself boxed into a corner. Mr. Clinton has said, Look, I'll take the political hit on the tax side; if you Republicans in Congress, who've been worried about needless spending for years, don't like my cuts, then offer something better.
True, that ploy obscures deficiencies in Mr. Clinton's plan. He wipes out no important Government programs and takes a big bite out of only one, defense. And some of the cuts aren't cuts at all, but rather higher user fees and tax increases on wealthier Social Security recipients.
Yet this much can be said for him: He does more than merely rail against the deficit. And he at least addresses those programs that account for 70 percent of the Federal budget -- Medicare, Medicaid, Social Security and defense.
His critics' main line of response is theological. The Clinton formula for revival -- higher taxes, reduced consumption, targeted Government investment -- is the work of the Devil. Better to embrace inertia than to let this heretic from Arkansas set the Government in motion.
There should be no presumption that Mr. Clinton's strategy is right simply because it favors more Government investment. But there's something disingenuous about his critics' nostalgia for Reaganomics, which managed to quadruple the national debt in four years, such that interest payments are now one-seventh of the Federal budget.
The Republicans' intellectual cupboard, to judge from what their leaders say, is barer than at any time since the Goldwater implosion. Challenged to specify cuts, Senator Bob Dole had to pull out the dog-eared script for an "across-the-board" freeze. And there was something wistful about Jack Kemp's appeal to the old supply-side voodoo that if you just cut taxes, the economy will grow its way out of the deficit. For many Americans, that didn't work the first time, and to them Mr. Clinton's counterargument seems worth a try.
Where the opposition could profitably spend its time is not in abstract potshots at government's legitimate role in American society, but in arguments over the dirty details. After all, Mr. Clinton's strategy will rise or fall partly on whether the specific spending programs he proposes are good or bad for the economy.
Should taxpayers' money be used to support research on technology? Develop programs of national service for high school graduates? Are a few billion dollars well spent on high-speed rail? Low-cost housing? Early childhood education?
Mr. Clinton has offered his choices. His critics should provide others. This is especially true of the Republicans, who had an entire decade to argue that the Magic of the Marketplace would fix every problem. In November, the voters seemed to call for a new level of government engagement.

HEADLINE: Nobody Needs Nukes

BYLINE: By Robert S. McNamara; Robert S. McNamara, Secretary of Defense under Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, is a member of the Washington Council on Non-Proliferation, which published a longer version of this paper.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the wake of the first and second treaties on reducing strategic arms, many security experts say the world can afford a long pause in nuclear arms control. They are wrong.
Worldwide, there are about 40,000 nuclear warheads with a total destructive power more than a million times that of the Hiroshima bomb. 
 Even assuming that the reductions in the Start treaties, which George Bush and Boris Yeltsin signed, are carried out, the stock of warheads of the five declared nuclear powers -- the U.S., Russia, China, France and Britain -- is not likely to be reduced below 10,000 by the year 2003. By then, the danger of nuclear war will have been lowered but not eliminated.
Firmer steps are needed to lower that risk. That was made clear by disclosures of how close the planet came to nuclear disaster during the Cuban missile crisis in 1962. It was a dramatic demonstration of fallibility -- of the degree to which all parties were captives of misinformation, misjudgment and miscalculation.
It can be confidently predicted that the combination of human fallibility and nuclear arms will inevitably lead to nuclear destruction. Therefore, insofar as it is achievable, we should seek a return to a non-nuclear world. I say "insofar as achievable" because one or more declared nuclear powers -- or an international agency -- would have to retain a small nuclear force, at most 100 to 200 warheads, as protection against blackmail by nations that would develop such weapons in secret.
More and more political and military leaders accept the idea that basic changes in the world's approach to nuclear weapons are required. Many have endorsed the idea of returning to a non-nuclear world, among them Les Aspin in a speech at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in June.
Others still believe that the threat to use nuclear weapons prevents conventional war. This was the essential position of a report, "The Role of Nuclear Weapons in the New World Order," prepared by an advisory committee for the Secretary of Defense just over a year ago. Accepting this argument means accepting the risk that if deterrence fails, a nuclear exchange, which will destroy nations, may follow.
The United Nations Security Council could play a central role in stopping the further proliferation of all types of weapons of mass destruction and the means of delivering them.
At least 20 countries possess or can produce at least two types of weapons -- whether nuclear, chemical or biological -- or their delivery systems. Most have, or are believed to be developing, a capability in three or four of these categories.
To halt this proliferation, there is no alternative to collective, coercive Security Council action. It should take this form:
The council would agree to prohibit the development, production and purchase of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons and ballistic missiles by countries that do not have them.
Countries violating this ban would be subject to strict economic sanctions. If the sanctions had no effect, a U.N. military force would be given a mandate to eliminate the production capability and destroy any stocks produced or bought.
Countries that have such weapons, including both declared and undeclared nuclear powers such as India, Pakistan and Israel, would be subject to inspection and control, and would be asked to approve a treaty prohibiting first use of nuclear weapons.
Progress on this difficult agenda would be accelerated if the U.S re-examined its own long-term strategic nuclear aims. We need to ask ourselves: What would be the rationale for having 3,500 nuclear weapons 10 years from now?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: You Can't Lock Up City Hall and Toss the Key

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Hilary Rosenberg's "Let Cities Go Bankrupt" (Op-Ed, Feb. 3) is certainly right that drastic action is necessary to halt the downward spiral of some cities. Her solutions, however, reveal a misunderstanding of both Federal law and reality.
She fails to distinguish between the role of a corporation and a municipality. In the arcane world of bankruptcy, the distinction between making money (business) and serving the public (government) makes an enormous difference. 
 It is folly to suggest that bankruptcy is like an elixir that produces miraculous changes. One might liken it to a tourniquet to stop a hemorrhage, but it is not a cure. As we taxpayers begin the 40-year process of financing the $500 billion bankruptcy of the country's savings and loan industry, no one can describe the debacle as good theory or good therapy.
Cities already can seek bankruptcy protection under Federal law, but that hasn't changed the accelerating fiscal disparities between richer and poorer communities.
A corporation can go bankrupt, shut its doors and leave its assets for the creditors to divide up. When Eastern Airlines capitulated, the pilots walked away and left their keys in the engines. Eastern simply ceased to exist, and travelers were left to find a way to get from city A to city B.
Cities cannot simply disappear or disassemble themselves; the option of locking up city hall and walking away does not exist. A city has not just assets; it has citizens. Vital services must continue; the city must work out a new financial structure. That was the premise under which Bridgeport, Conn., initiated a bankruptcy action in 1991: to assure essential services while working through a financial crisis.
While the last few years have seen record numbers of personal and corporate bankruptcies, there is little evidence these actions have reaped huge returns for the country, economy or the companies involved. Only those businesses "vulture" investors have determined could be stripped and repackaged at giveaway prices have gained the capital infusions necessary to remain in existence.
There is no quick and direct profit in taking over a purely public entity. A municipal bankruptcy forces a reorganization of the city's fiscal structure, presumably through negotiations between the city's creditors, taxpayers, employees and citizens. The process may alter some practices and procedures, but it doesn't alter the community's resources or its essential needs.
Stopgap measures may offer temporary relief, but they are not real solutions. Consider what's at stake in selling or "privatizing" the few assets the poorest cities might own. Is a onetime infusion of cash at the expense of losing a long-term asset a step toward survival or a slide toward death?
 
DONALD J. BORUT
Exec. Dir., National League of Cities
Washington, Feb. 11, 1993

HEADLINE: Effects Are Unclear In Limits On Medical Residents' Hours

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN

 BODY:
Four years and nearly $1 billion after New York State adopted the nation's strictest limits on the hours worked by medical residents, it is unclear whether the changes have helped or hurt patient care, doctors and hospital administrators say.
In many hospital departments, the rules are simply ignored, meaning that residents are working well beyond the 80-hour-a-week limit imposed by the state and are potentially more vulnerable to exhaustion and mistakes. 
 And where they are being followed, strict enforcement of the rules is resulting in a time-clock approach under which, critics charge, residents leave in the middle of procedures or delay tests because it is time to go home.
Still others, including the author of the original regulations, argue that the rules have not gone far enough and still allow residents to continue exercising too much responsibility.
The changes have cost more than $840 million so far, considered a significant figure even in the state's large health-care budget. While there is little statistical scientific evidence evaluating the changes, a few studies do exist.
 
Loopholes and Lapses
 They hint strongly at a system that does not work as planned. One small review of one hospital found increased delays in ordering tests for patients, although there was no increase in medical complications because of those delays. Sporadic surveys by the New York State Department of Health found that of 24 hospitals, more than half were not complying with the limits on working hours. And an internal review of New York City's 11 public hospitals found that compliance varied widely, with lapses attributed largely to a shortage of money.
"This is one of the grandest of experiments in medical education," said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, which represents most of the city's private hospitals. "What are the results? No one really knows."
The experiment was triggered by the death of Libby Zion in 1984, shortly after she was admitted to New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center with a high fever. Her father, Sidney Zion, a lawyer and journalist, blamed inadequate care and the errors of unsupervised medical residents for her death.
An appeals court eventually cleared the doctors of wrongdoing, but the outcry over the case led to sweeping changes in the state's system of medical education. Those changes, which took effect on July 1, 1989, were put in place over the fierce objections of many doctors and hospital administrators who feared that by reducing the hours of a residency, the state was also reducing its educational value.
Although there are exceptions, the rules essentially prohibit residents from working more than 80 hours a week, as opposed to the 110 to 120 hours that were common previously. In addition, current medical residents may not work for more than 24 consecutive hours (compared with 36 before 1989).
The Department of Health increased the reimbursement rate to hospitals by $160 million per year, according to a department spokeswoman, Frances E. Tarleton, to enable the institutions to hire more support staff and senior doctors to perform the tasks that had been performed by residents. In addition, Mr. Raske said, the hospitals have increased their own spending by between $50 million and $60 million a year, meaning that the cost of implementing the rules is $210 million to $220 million a year over each of the past four years.
Despite the cost, the rules are not always enforced. Although the Health Department has not done a comprehensive survey (one is scheduled to begin this summer), it does include checks of compliance in its standard reviews of hospital care.
In 24 reviews between July 1990 and December 1991, 15 hospitals were found to violate the limits in at least one department, said Wayne M. Osten, assistant director for health-care surveillance for the department.
One reason hospitals give for violating the regulations is money. In other hospitals, the lapses are more philosophical than economic. While it would seem self-evident that doctors' skills would deteriorate over long hours, there are no definitive studies to show that.
Among the strongest opponents of the new rules were surgeons and obstetricians, who argued that those specialties cannot run by the clock. In fact, the state made an exception to the rules for surgery departments, saying that residents there can work more than 24 hours if they get sufficient rest while in the hospital, if they are not on call more frequently than every third night and if they have at least 16 hours off after a night on call.
 
Surgeons Resist
 But even with the exceptions, surgery departments do not always follow the rules.
"No one's ever complied with the regulations at all," said one surgical resident at a private hospital who said he is on call as often as every other night and his weeks are commonly more than 80 hours long.
Some surgical residents say they consider the extra hours part of the job. "We only have a certain number of years to learn a large number of procedures, and that means operating as often as I can," said another resident at another hospital.
In those departments where the rules are enforced, the results are not always as intended. Critics of the new system say it fosters an atmosphere in which residents feel less personal responsibility for their patients, particularly at hospitals that solve the scheduling puzzle by assigning some residents to work only nights and others to work only days for specified periods, then switching them at intervals, so that residents rarely work more than 12 hours at a time.
"When you're on all day, then all night, then all day, those become your patients and you become incredibly protective," said one senior doctor, who completed his own residency just before the limits. "The residents today look at it as just a job, and you can't treat medicine as just a job."
 
Increase in 'Sign-Outs'
 Shorter work periods mean more frequent "sign-outs," periods in which the departing residents update the incoming residents on the condition of each patient. More than one resident interviewed likened sign-outs to a game of telephone, in which information gets lost as it passes from one doctor to the next.
One study at New York Hospital suggests that a result of more frequent sign-outs may be confusion in ordering tests and procedures. The researchers compared the charts of 263 patients who were discharged from that hospital's general medicine service in October 1988, before the new rules took effect, with the charts of the same number of patients discharged from the same hospital a year later, four months after the shorter hours were instituted.
The study found virtually no differences in the medical outcomes of the cases. But the patients treated under the new rules suffered more frequent in-hospital complications and more frequent delays of tests.
 
Instigator Disagrees
 Such criticisms rankle Dr. Bertrand M. Bell, a professor of medicine at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University and the chairman of the commission that created the new regulations.
The New York Hospital study, he said, had several limitations that mean it should not be taken as a definitive portrait of the current system. The study, published last month in the Journal of the American Medical Association, looks at just one institution, which Dr. Bell said was not a large enough sample on which to generalize. That one institution happens to be the one in which Miss Zion died, and "It's in their interest to prove that the regs are worse" than the status quo, he said.
Dr. Joseph G. Hayes, an author of the study and head of the residency program at New York Hospital's department of medicine, said he is a supporter of the new regulations. "If the state decided tomorrow, 'Don't do the Bell commission hours,' I'd keep doing them anyway," he said.
His study, he said, was not intended as the definitive comment on the regulations. Nor was it intended to torpedo them. "What's important is that the Bell system caused minor problems, not major problems. The next step is to address those problems."
In response to charges that the rules have fractured intrahospital communication, Dr. Bell said that the problem is not the rules but rather the quality of sign-out procedures. "If you carry that logic to the extreme then no one would ever sign out to anyone, and doctors would never stop working," he said.
The main problem with the regulations, Dr. Bell said, is something else entirely. In addition to a limit on residents' working hours, Dr. Bell's commission recommended that the supervision of medical residents be sharply increased. He does not believe that those sections of the new rules are being properly enforced.
"There has been no change," Dr. Bell said. "If you go to New York Hospital right now, you will be taken care of by residents," a situation he said exists in nearly every teaching hospital in the city. "There is no evidence to show that the attending physicians, hired with such fanfare, are really in charge; no documentation of how often the attending physician is called, of who is actually writing the orders."
Dr. Hayes disagreed. "Your basic care at New York Hospital is by an attending physician," he said. "No way are residents loose cannons in my hospital."
 
Core Belief Challenged
 Many health-care professionals disagree with Dr. Bell's core belief that care by residents is worse than care by senior attending doctors. Senior surgery residents, they say, have had four years of training in medical school and five years of post-graduate training. And because medicine changes so rapidly in this era of virulent technology, many argue that those most recently out of school are actually the most up to date, despite continuing education requirements.
"Age is completely irrelevant," said one third-year surgical resident at a large private hospital. "I know 25-year-olds I wouldn't trust to cross the street safely, and I know 25-year-olds who are the most brilliant doctors you could know. I am cocky. I am good at what I do." Because it is not completely clear who is doing the treating and the teaching in the state's hospitals, the Health Department plans to begin a study this June, conducted by Johns Hopkins University, the University of Pennsylvania and Harvard University.
Dr. Alfred Gellhorn, director of medical affairs for the department, said the study is intended to replace speculation with statistics.
"Medicine is science," he said. "It's time we knew -- scientifically -- the effects of what we have done."

HEADLINE: Keep Japanese Presence in New York City, Dinkins Urges Leaders in Tokyo

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 23

 BODY:
At the start of his term, Mayor David N. Dinkins recalled today, he often had to answer critics who complained that the Japanese were buying up New York. This afternoon, walking from office tower to office tower in downtown Tokyo, Mr. Dinkins told Japan's leading bankers and business executives that in the 1990's they should hold on to what they bought.
"It is very clear to me that the Japanese presence in our city is absolutely essential to keeping New York a dynamic, global city of opportunity in the 21st century," he told a group of some of the country's most powerful executives today. And in the face of an unexpectedly severe economic downturn in Japan that is leading many companies to think about selling some of the Manhattan properties they bought in the 1980's, Mr. Dinkins repeated time and again today that "we want you to stay and to grow in our city." 
 Mr. Dinkins's appeal to Keidanren, the politically powerful organization of Japan's largest businesses, came on the third and most important day of his weeklong tour of Japan. And while he found a largely receptive audience, with companies telling him that they would stick it out, he also heard warnings that philanthropic contributions and expansion plans would be cut back until Tokyo emerges from its economic mire.
 
A Week of Buyouts
 In fact, only one major Japanese investor, an auto parts maker, has pulled out of the New York metropolitan region recently, and the New York real-estate executives accompanying the Mayor seemed particularly relieved that no one else was talking about major property sales that could drive the market -- and tax revenues -- down.
Nonetheless, Mr. Dinkins arrived during one of Tokyo's tougher weeks, when business leaders were eliminating unprofitable divisions and buying out workers over 50. Mr. Dinkins did not even try to ask for more Japanese investment in New York City. And wherever the Mayor went, he was peppered with questions about the prospects for President Clinton's economic-recovery package -- Mr. Dinkins said he thought it would bring New York more than $500 million in additional Federal aid -- and whether the new North American Free Trade Agreement would put Japanese businesses at a disadvantage.
But several questioned him on his plans to attack crime, drugs and dirt on the streets of New York, reminding a few people in his entourage that the city's image on Japanese television is still overwhelmingly negative.
"It's quite amazing how many of these executives have lived in New York and regard it as a sort of second home," Deputy Mayor Barry F. Sullivan said as Mr. Dinkins circulated among Japanese executives who were once based in New York. "They know the city well, and they ask tough questions."
 
Tours and Food
 Mr. Dinkins himself has spent some time investigating what keeps Tokyo from being overwhelmed by the sheer density of its population: Roughly 30 million people live in the metropolitan area, though only a little more than 8 million in Tokyo's 23 wards. He visited the newly built high-tech skyscraper that houses Tokyo's metropolitan government and, on Monday evening, sat down to a lavish, traditional Japanese meal sponsored by the the city's governor, Shunichi Suzuki. Perhaps fearful that the city had ordered too much food, the governor also invited Akebono, the 470-pound Hawaiian who recently became the first foreigner ever made a grand champion in sumo wrestling.
Mr. Dinkins's main message, he said, was to thank the Japanese for what he called a growing contribution to New York's cultural life and its charities.
"This is a practice that is relatively new to the Japanese," he said, "but it is one which they have taken to with vigor. The fact is that they are becoming some of our best corporate neighbors."
On Wednesday night Mr. Dinkins will take his entourage to Osaka, Japan's second-largest metropolitan area, for two more days of touring and meeting with the business community.

HEADLINE: Administration Completing Plan To Ease Rules on Bank Lending

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23

 BODY:
President Clinton and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the Administration and banking regulators were completing a plan to ease banking regulations to encourage more lending, especially to small businesses.
According to interviews with officials in the Administration, Congress and the Federal Reserve, the plan would make it easier for bankers to lend to people they know based on the borrower's character rather than a strict analysis of their collateral, cash flow or credit history. The plan would also lessen paperwork and ease other restrictions for small-business loans. 
 In separate appearances today, the President and Mr. Greenspan said that the plan would be released soon and was meant to help small business -- which the President has repeatedly said is the main engine of job growth in the nation. The plan could also be a way to stimulate the economy without the Government having to spend a cent.
 
Breaking 'Credit Crunch'
 "I hope we will have something useful reasonably soon," Mr. Greenspan said in testimony before a subcommittee of the House Banking Committee, adding that the plan would include "newer ways to break the back of the credit crunch."
The so-called crunch developed in the wake of the savings and loan crisis as regulators cracked down on banks and bankers grew nervous about lending. Many economists say banks' reluctance to lend has slowed the recovery in New England and other regions, and both the White House and Fed have faced intense pressure to do something about it.
Administration officials said the plan would not require new legislation, relying instead on changes in banking regulations. Several officials said the Administration had originally contemplated more sweeping changes in bank regulations to encourage more lending, but shunned that approach, fearing that a major reduction in regulation could weaken the banking system.
The plan would ease some of the requirements on appraising collateral for small business and would make it easier for bankers to challenge decisions by examiners that loans had been provided without sufficient collateral.
Banking executives were happy about the plan, but said they wanted even more regulations swept away.
"It would be welcomed by the bank industry," said Kenneth Gunther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association, which has 6,000 small- and medium-sized banks as members. But he added that the "current regulatory burden" would remain until existing laws were amended.
The new plan is expected to take some political pressure off both the Administration and the Federal Reserve. President Clinton pledged during the campaign to make it easier for small businesses to obtain loans. And Mr. Greenspan and the Federal Reserve have faced severe criticism for not doing more to encourage bank lending.
Speaking today before executives at the United States Chamber of Commerce, President Clinton said, "In the next few days, we will be announcing some initiatives that we're going to take from a regulatory point of view to try to deal with the credit crunch, to try to make it possible for banks to loan money to businesses again, to try to release the energies for the old-fashioned character small-business loans, to try to reduce the fear that a lot of banks have that if they make sensible loans the Government will come down on them."
 
Plenty of Paperwork
 In his Congressional testimony today, Mr. Greenspan said the pendulum might have swung toward over-regulation after laxness a decade ago helped produce the savings and loan crisis. He and other Fed officials have often said that banks face so much paperwork on small-business loans that they are discouraged from making such loans.
The Federal Reserve and the Bush Administration eased some regulations last year, but many small businesses said those moves did not go nearly far enough. The Federal Reserve cannot change all the regulations itself because it shares responsibility for bank regulation with the Comptroller of the Currency, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Office of Thrift Supervision. The Treasury Department is coordinating efforts to alter the regulations.
Several officials said the Administration and regulators were also thinking of making it easier for small banks to lend money to members of their boards. Federal banking laws passed two years ago severely restricted this practice, but business executives from small towns -- many of whom sit on the board of the one bank in their town -- assert that this restriction unduly limits lending and hampers economic growth.
Some officials are uneasy about changing this rule. "One of the things we saw in failed banks and thrifts was a lot of insider dealings," said Charles A. Bowsher, the Comptroller General of the United States, the nation's top auditor. "So I think this has to be done very carefully."
Officials said the plan outlined today would give banks with a solid capital base the most latitude to make loans based on character. This change is expected to apply for the most part to loans to small business, and not to large corporations.
According to several officials, the plan is likely to make it easier for banks to appeal unfavorable decisions by bank examiners. For example, if an examiner finds that a bank has insufficient collateral on a loan, a bank can often appeal to the examiner's superior -- a move that often makes examiners even angrier at a bank. Administration officials are developing a plan to allow an appeal or second opinion outside normal channels, perhaps from an independent review board.
 
Must Set Aside Funds
 When an examiner finds that collateral for a loan is insufficient, the bank often must set aside some cash to cover that loan. That hurts profits because the bank cannot use that money for regular banking purposes.
The plan is also likely to tighten regulation and enforcement in several areas, including consumer protection and banks' exposure to interest rate risk. Many regulators fear that banks have bought so many Treasury bonds that they might get hurt by a sudden swing in interest rates.
Some banking experts insist that regulation is not the cause of the credit crunch. In their view, banks are reluctant to lend for two reasons: the economy is so shaky and many banks have found it is more profitable and less risky to buy Treasury bonds.
After many executives complained to them about the credit crunch, members of Congress said they were pleased by word of the plan. "The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation Improvement Act may have swung a little too far, particularly in the way it was interpreted by regulators," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who is on the House Banking Committee.
David Berry, director of research for Keefe Bruyette & Woods, a brokerage firm specializing in bank stocks, said the plan could increase bank lending by several billion dollars, perhaps by several tens of billion. But he said he doubted the plan could raise lending by close to $86 billion a year -- the amount by which one banking executive told Mr. Clinton lending could be increased as a result of eased regulations.
Mr. Greenspan said he was interested in proposals to create a secondary market for small-business loans in which financial institutions would buy the loans from banks, freeing up additional bank funds for such loans.

HEADLINE: Deal Is Reached on Timing of Votes: Cuts and Taxes First, Then Stimulus

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23

 BODY:
Seeking to demonstrate President Clinton's determination to cut old programs before adding new ones, the White House announced today that Congress would vote on a budget resolution supporting the President's proposals to trim spending and raise taxes a few days before it voted on new spending for his economic stimulus package.
Both votes would come by the end of March, White House officials said. 
 Lawmakers had originally planned to act in March on the short-term stimulus package, which calls for spending $16 billion, with the vote on taxes and spending cuts coming a month or more later.
White House officials said they hoped the new timing, worked out in negotiations between Administration and Congressional officials, would quiet some conservative and moderate Democrats who had threatened to oppose the plan out of concern that the package raised taxes too much, or out of suspicion that the spending cuts would never be made.
 
A Victory of Timing
 White House officials said the maneuver was an important victory in their strategy to get the plan approved by Congress.
"We didn't want the process bogged down in any kind of gridlock," a senior Administration official said. "The public needs to be persuaded that the spending cuts are very real. This makes that very clear. The best way to demonstrate our earnestness is to proceed with a plan that has tough reductions."
The deal was announced hours after Mr. Clinton opened a drive to win over skeptics in an hourlong appeal to the United States Chamber of Commerce. The speech was part of an effort by the President and Cabinet officials to deliver high-intensity pitches for the economic plan, even to potentially skeptical audiences.
The timing strategy was disclosed after it was agreed upon by Mr. Clinton, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley and George J. Mitchell, the Senate Democratic leader.
George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said the President had asked Congressional leaders to accelerate the budget vote "so we could lock in the spending cuts as soon as possible, and they have agreed."
The strategy gives reluctant lawmakers one less excuse to vote against the package, since they would have a harder time raising concerns that tax increases might be enacted without spending cuts.
White House officials said they had impressed on Congressional leaders the strong public support Mr. Clinton had received for his budget plan. "You strike when the iron is hot," one official said.
 
Nothing Etched in Stone
 The precise cuts will not be locked in, however, because the budget resolution does not have the force of law and is only a road map for Congress. But Mr. Stephanopoulos said, "Especially in the present environment, we consider it highly unlikely that anyone would attempt to exceed the spending level set in the budget resolution."
Mr. Foley told reporters that the agreement meant that the stimulus package would be voted on a week or two later than initially planned and that the budget resolution would be taken up a month earlier. He said he and the President believed that "before the stimulus-investment package is considered by the House, it's important for members and the country to understand we've committed to the broad program of the President's initiatives, including the spending cuts."
 
'The Right Direction'
 Some Democrats who had raised concerns about the President's economic proposal welcomed the agreement. Representative Timothy J. Penny, a conservative Democrat from Minnesota, called it "a step in the right direction."
"It is important that we show we are taking a bold direction in deficit reduction," Mr. Penny said.
In his speech to the Chamber of Commerce, Mr. Clinton sought to convince a predominantly Republican audience of business people that they would ultimately benefit from his plan to raise taxes and cut spending. And for the first time he said there were "more cuts coming." He did not elaborate on what they would be.
Though he spoke mostly of sacrifice, Mr. Clinton offered an enticement, saying he would soon announce plans to ease regulations on banks to make it easier for business to get loans.
The business group gave Mr. Clinton the sort of friendly reception it usually reserves for Republicans. White House officials said that they met earlier in the day to discuss the efforts to sell Mr. Clinton's plan and that they were pleased with the generally positive public feedback to the plan so far. But the officials said they had also agreed that the President needed to maintain a sustained drive to generate support and enthusiasm, particularly among people who would not be his natural allies.
"This is not about preaching to the choir," said Marla Romash, the press secretary to Vice President Al Gore, who will devote much of his time seeking support for the program. "This is about reaching out to Americans all over the country."
 
Dozens of Interviews
 Early next week, for example, Mr. Clinton is scheduled to meet with Republican lawmakers who have been openly critical of his proposal. Administration officials have been made available to local television stations for dozens of interviews on the plan, and Jeff Eller, the White House director of media affairs, said that if the schedule permited, Mr. Clinton would sit down for interviews by local stations.
Besides weekly trips around the country by Mr. Clinton, officials said, Cabinet members will continue heavy travel schedules. Seven were on Capitol Hill today lobbying for the plan.
"It is important that we pay attention to who is supportive and who is not supportive," said one official who attended the meeting. "There's a logic to what's going on. And the message to people who are skeptical is that the plan is the best chance of significant deduction that's out there."
The President told the Chamber, "I came here today to ask for your support for my economic plan to take this country in a new direction because I believe it will make businesses more competitive and workers more productive, and will help us to deal with some of the principle problems that we have faced over the last several years."
He drew applause when he said, "We have to change the way Government operates and relates to the private sector in very fundamental ways."
While the Chamber of Commerce had warned last year that Mr. Clinton's election would increase Government regulation and saddle companies with new Federal restrictions, the audience today interrupted the President's speech with applause several times. The chamber's board of directors issued a statement today saying it "applauds President Clinton's goals of reducing the deficit, cutting spending, creating jobs and stimulating the economy. The spending cuts can and should be expanded."
 
Engine of Growth
 Anticipating that concern, Mr. Clinton repeatedly assured his audience that there would be no tax increases without spending cuts.
"Let me be clear again," he declared. "This Administration understands clearly that the private sector is the central engine of economic growth. I have tried to put together a plan that will enable you to succeed."
Several chamber members, most of them Republicans, who were interviewed at random after the speech had only encouragement for Mr. Clinton. "He got a much better reception than I though he would," said Kenneth H. Busz, executive director of the Eastern Monmouth Area Chamber of Commerce in Red Bank, N.J.
"He played it well. It was a much warmer reception than two weeks ago when he spoke to the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce."
Asked why businesses were ready for tax increases, he said that something had to be done, because "we're choking ourselves to death now."
Lothar Bacher, who owns a small metal-processing business in Chicago, said, "I think the plan is very good. I just hope he's able to get it through. Too many businesses are just too greedy."
