HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
A plan to ease banking regulations and encourage lending, especially to small businesses, is being prepared, President Clinton and Alan Greenspan said in separate appearances. The plan is said to make it easier for bankers to lend based on a borrower's character, rather than a strict analysis of financial data. [Page A1.]
President Clinton's plan to bolster industrial technology involves almost no increase in total spending on research, but it would redirect billions from military programs. [A14.] 
 Consumer confidence in the economy tumbled 8 points in early February, as a wave of layoffs at some of the nation's best-known companies shook Americans' faith in the recovery. [D1.]
New York State is knitting together millions of dollars in inducements to keep General Motors from closing a mini-van plant in Tarrytown that employs 3,000 workers. [B1.]
A Washington tax lawyer was nominated by President Clinton to be the new Commissioner of Internal Revenue. [D2.]
 
International
Japanese business leaders are warning the Government that a stronger yen is not the answer to the country's widening trade surplus and that the currency's recent run-up will bring layoffs and bankruptcies, making a bad economy worse. [D1.]
President Clinton's criticism that European governments subsidized the Airbus aircraft consortium at the expense of American jobs was greeted with scorn in Europe. [D1.]
 
Business Technology
A $1 billion market by 1996 is expected for heart defibrillators, which deliver electric shocks to correct irregular heartbeats. Patients say the shocks feel like a kick in the chest by a horse. [A1.]
The retail industry's attempt to adopt a single technology for electronic anti-shoplifting systems has incited a battle. [D7.]
 
Companies

Lucasarts will spin off Industrial Light and Magic, its movie special effects unit, and Skywalker Sound, its audio unit. [D5.]
Nissan will cease automobile assembly in what was once its flagship Japanese factory and cut 5,000 jobs in three years. [D5.]
Home Shopping Network named the vice chairman of Whittle as its next president and chief executive. [D6.]
 
Markets
Treasury bond prices continued their surge. The yield on the 30-year bond dropped to 6.82 percent, and the 10-year note fell to 5.89 percent, the lowest level since January 1972. [D1.]
The shares of retailers and others that depend on consumer spending were battered. The Dow lost 19.72 points. [D8.]
The dollar was mixed in hectic trading, remaining under pressure from tumbling bond yields. Gold was mixed. [D18.]
Wheat and soybeans rose on optimism that American officials would offer food aid to Russia or resolve its debt problem. [D18.]

HEADLINE: Colleges Battle Culture And Poverty to Swell Hispanic Enrollments

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OBERLIN, Ohio

 BODY:
When Juan Morales graduated from a high school in California three years ago, he set his sights on Oberlin College, a small liberal-arts college in Ohio. He had no way of knowing what a difficult journey it would become for him, or for Oberlin.
Mr. Morales had only a C average, but the college, which is known for its academic excellence, accepted him anyway, based on his potential. He could not afford the $24,000-a-year tuition, so Oberlin supplied most of that. When he cried twice in his first year because of homesickness and considered leaving, he was buoyed by a Hispanic counselor. 
 "I was so desperate for my community," said Mr. Morales, now a junior chemistry major who has a B average and wants to teach in public schools. "I came here, and there were no Mexican people, and I felt alone. But I thought, If I'm to improve my life, this is my chance."
 
Accelerated Recruiting
 As colleges and universities cast ever wider nets to attract more Hispanic students, Mr. Morales's account underscores how difficult that effort can be, even for a college that recruits as aggressively as Oberlin does.
Since the mid-1980's, campus recruiters have accelerated and improved their efforts by making more trips to the Southwest and West, for example, and by arranging a wider array of services, like counseling and tutoring, to retain students. But their efforts have had little impact.
Eighteen percent of Hispanic people between 18 and 24 are enrolled in four-year colleges, compared with 34 percent of whites and 24 percent of blacks, according to the American Council on Education.
Of the nearly nine million students enrolled on four-year campuses, 17.8 percent are Hispanic, 23.4 percent are black and 36.8 percent are white, according the Department of Education.
There are no reliable statistics on how many Hispanic students who enroll ultimately graduate, but educators note that only a small percentage of college graduates are of Hispanic descent. Just 3.1 percent of all bachelor's degrees awarded in the country in 1990 went to Hispanic people, who make up 8.4 percent of the adult population.
That compares with 5.8 percent for blacks, who make up 11.3 percent of the adult population, and 84.3 percent for whites, who comprise 84.8 percent of the adult population, according to Education Department statistics. Asians, who represent 3 percent of the adult population, earned 3.7 percent of all bachelor's degrees awarded in 1990.
"It doesn't come easy," David Arredondo, the associate admissions officer at Oberlin, said of recruitment and retention efforts. "It takes a lot of work to do both, and sometimes some of the kids don't make it."
 
Strength of Family Ties
 College officials say they continually bump into one obstacle they had not fully grasped until recently: the Hispanic culture, in which the family comes first, often frowns on a son or daughter leaving home to attend school.
College and university officials tell of recruiting Hispanic students only to have their parents block their enrollments. Last spring Carlos Ayala and Maria de Jesus Ayala in El Paso refused to let their daughter, Alicia, attend the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, saying that her place was at home. Telephone calls from M.I.T. and officials of the El Paso schools did not sway the parents, whose daughter now attends the University of Texas at El Paso.
 
Problems on Campus
 Once enrolled, Hispanic students are more likely than others to drop out to take jobs to help support their families, admissions officers say, and others leave because they cannot function outside an extended family.
Retention rates are also kept low by academic problems, as some students are unable to do college work. That is not surprising, college administrators say, because a preponderance of Hispanic students attend public schools in underfinanced districts that cannot afford the college-preparatory courses.
Some students say that racism also takes its toll.
At the University of Notre Dame last year, Lonnie Limon, then a freshman from Austin, Tex., said a classmate who was giving a party called him a wetback and threw him out.
"I called my Mom and told her I wanted to come back to Austin and go to U.T.," said Mr. Limon, referring to the University of Texas. He turned to Hispanic classmates for support. "If I hadn't been strong," he said, "I would have left."
The tangle of issues is difficult to unravel, experts said, "but the critical ingredient to success is strong leadership from the college presidents who are willing to commit the resources," said Jaime Chahin, an associate vice president for human resources at Southwest Texas State University in San Marcos. "At this point there are very few exemplary institutions."
 
Easier for Catholic Colleges
 Oberlin is an exception, Mr. Chahin said, as are Roman Catholic colleges and universities.
"Catholic institutions have an easier time because of the Catholic tradition most Hispanic families share," said Mary Pat Nolan, president of the Catholic College Admissions Association, whose membership includes nearly all the nation's 222 Catholic colleges and universities. "As a result, distance and cost is less of a factor for us."
A recruiter from Notre Dame recounted how the parents of a student in El Paso had refused to let her attend the University of North Texas, 600 miles from home, but had readily agreed to let her enroll at Notre Dame, about 1,500 miles away, because of its Catholic affiliation.
But for the vast number of campuses, recruitment and retention are bumpy paths, fraught with problems that can leave even the most forward-thinking institutions frustrated. Oberlin, for all its effort, is a case in point.
Five years ago, the private college of 2,800 students accelerated efforts to improve its Hispanic enrollment, using people like Mr. Arredondo on recruiting campaigns that increasingly involved visiting prospective students' homes. As a result, Hispanic enrollment increased to the current 86 from the 71 it had been five years ago, and graduation rates improved to almost 70 percent, from less than 60 percent.
 
Results Still Mixed
 "I've gone to sit in parents' kitchens," Mr. Arredondo said. "I've talked to them on the phone, traveled to meet them."
And still, he said with a sigh, the results were mixed. Last year he visited a family in nearby Lorain, Ohio, to plead with a student's parents to let him attend Oberlin. They would have had to pay only $2,000 of the $24,000 tuition because of a generous aid package, but the parents would not budge.
"The objections from the parents were that he should probably get a job and help the family," Mr. Arredondo said. The underlying problem, he said, is that "there just aren't enough Latino parents around with college degrees, and that's significant."
"They don't understand that a college education can have long-term economic payoffs," he added.
This is also reflected in the high school dropout rate for Hispanic students, which, at 35.3 percent is far higher than for most other ethnic groups.
 
Trips to West and Southwest
 Increasingly, the Ivy League institutions, the so-called public Ivies, like the University of Michigan, and other colleges say their representatives or alumni recruiters are making sweeps through the Southwest and West, where most of the nation's Hispanic population lives. Notre Dame does that and more by dispatching Maria Fuentes to cultivate recruits.
"When parents look at me, they see their daughter or son," said Ms. Fuentes, 25, a Notre Dame alumna whose fluency in Spanish helps overcome barriers. Ms. Fuentes said that despite the built-in advantage of Notre Dame's Catholic ties, "the problem I have to deal with is parents think their son or daughter won't care for them or their family as much when they go away to school."
Notre Dame's efforts have resulted in a Hispanic enrollment of more than 400 students out of a student body of about 7,600, compared with about 200 five years ago.
But recruiting students may be just a battle half won. Pepperdine University in Malibu, Calif., has learned that to retain Hispanic students it needs to offer extra academic and emotional support. It created the Cultural Enrichment Center 18 months ago to give minority students tutoring, counseling and a place to meet socially.
Marissa Favila credited the center with guiding her through a difficult first year. Now a sophomore, Ms. Favila said the center put her in touch with other Hispanic students when she was working at a part-time job to help pay the $24,000-a-year tuition. Her absence from campus events, she said, made her feel alienated from other students.
"Just knowing there is someone else going through the same thing you are helps a lot," Ms. Favila said.
Other institutions are even more aggressive, inviting students to campus before the fall semester for a sort of boot camp on college life.
At St. Edward's University in Austin, for example, students are helped with academic basics and the intricacies of financial aid and dormitory living, all in 10 days. Administrators also monitor the students' academic and social progress in the first semester. And at Christmas, St. Edward's pays travel expenses for students to go home.
Seventy-nine percent of Hispanic freshmen who attended the program returned for their sophomore year, compared with a 62 percent return rate for all members of the freshman class.
For Angel Maldonado, a freshman from McAllen, Tex., the university's services were crucial. "At first I was very homesick," said the 19-year-old accounting major. "It was difficult for my family, too. My sisters wanted me to come home every weekend. But the program helped me meet other people and make friends. And my parents, as much as they miss me, now want me to finish."
To the relief of recruiters, the attitudes of Hispanic parents seem to be changing slowly. David Villarreal said that when M.I.T. accepted him in the spring he did not want to leave his hometown of El Paso. But "my parents said, 'No, you should go.' They insisted." His mother did not go to college, and his father attended the University of Texas at El Paso for 18 months.
"They wanted what was best for me," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "I came here, and there were no Mexican people, and I felt alone," said Juan Morales, a junior chemistry major at Oberlin College in Ohio. "But I thought, if I'm to improve my life, this is my chance." HEADLINE: Banks Lower Deposit Rates Slightly

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by banks on money market accounts and certificates of deposit for the week beginning today are modestly down from those offered last week, particularly in the longer maturities and at commercial banks.
In the New York market, six-month C.D. rates were lower than those at 20 major banks across the country, with the decline in yields on money market accounts about the same everywhere. 
 At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, average discount rates were mixed, with the three-month bill up slightly and the six-month down. The Treasury's auction is regarded by many as a harbinger of bank deposit rate changes in coming weeks.
The average rate at auction yesterday was 2.96 percent for a three-month Treasury bill, up 3 basis points, and 3.06 percent for a six-month bill, down 2 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, the rate publication, said the recent declines in long-term rates were showing up in six-month C.D.'s at New York banks, whose rates have fallen 5 basis points.
"The downward pressure on returns is coming from a general easing of interest rates worldwide, especially on the long maturities," he said.
According to the latest survey by The Bank Rate Monitor, yields on money market accounts in the New York area have fallen in the last week an average of 2 basis points, to 2.62 percent. Yields on certificates of deposits have also fallen by 2 basis points, to 2.73 percent on three-month maturities and 2.93 percent on six-month maturities.
Chase Manhattan Bank posted the sharpest change among New York banks. The yield on its money market accounts fell by 20 basis points, to 2.33 percent, while three-month certificates dropped by 25 basis points, to 2.38 percent. For a six-month certificate, the yield this week is 2.43 percent, down 26 basis points.

HEADLINE: Sasebo Journal;
'Quiet' Navy Base in Japan: Now, the Shock Waves

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SASEBO, Japan, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Ever since American bombers razed a large part of this once-huge naval port at the end of World War II, the United States Navy has used it as a modest-sized support base, a handsomely situated outpost that some sailors sought out as a refuge from the often wilder American bases spread across Japan.
Suddenly, times have changed, and nobody seems very pleased about it. 
 The storms of the cold war may have left the base largely untouched, but a string of violent acts by sailors in the last four months has left this sleepy town battered by swells of dismay and its residents angrily wondering what went wrong.
Just as a flustered Navy was struggling to combat the base's bad image after a serious brawl and then the killing of a gay sailor last fall, a 13-year-old American girl was raped here on Feb. 13. An American sailor has been arrested for the crime.
 
A Brutal Slaying
 That followed the unusually brutal killing last Oct. 27 of the sailor, Allen R. Schindler, a radioman who was about to be discharged from the Navy after having admitted he was homosexual. The case attracted a flood of publicity after President Clinton announced that he had decided to lift the ban on homosexuals in the military.
Two other young sailors from Mr. Schindler's ship, the Belleau Wood, were arrested in the killing, but not before they led the military police on a chase through the town and engaged them in a fight in the middle of a city street. The killing, along with the melee on the base a few weeks earlier, prompted the Mayor of this city of 250,000 in southwest Japan to issue a withering rebuke to the base's commander at the time, Capt. M. K. Collins.
"Under these circumstances, I would like to ask you that you would give your further attention to the education and the discipline of the crew members of the ships lest such incidents take place again," the Mayor, Kumashi Kakehashi, said in a letter written in slightly broken but still expressive English.
Now the base is nervously awaiting the arrival late this month of the Independence, an aircraft carrier that will more than double temporarily the base's population of 4,000 and, some fear, lead to new incidents. All this has left some American sailors and Japanese residents tired of the unwanted attention from the American press, even surly when questioned, but also wary of the evidence of how volatile a military base can become.
 
Yearning for Old Times
 For some Japanese, these unsettling events have lent weight to questions about why the United States Navy still needs to occupy the choicest property in this town now that the cold war is over.
"Economically speaking, some people are saying it is about time we thought about the prosperity of this city instead of national policy," an official in the local government said.
The sailors, for the most part, simply want a return to the soporific pace that attracted many of them in the first place, and many have become edgy when approached by American reporters.
"We keep trying to put this stuff behind us because it's just not what Sasebo is like," said an officer from one ship, who admitted sharing some of the resentment toward the press that sailors have been expressing. "But it's hard not to be concerned."
A sailor chatting with a small group at a popular spot in the bar district known as Sailor Town said to a reporter: "I don't want to talk, and I don't think you should be here. You're just hurting a lot of good guys who had nothing to do with this stuff."
 
Interviews Are Denied
 The Navy has denied all requests for interviews and refused to permit reporters to tour the Belleau Wood, a courtesy normally extended to visitors. Many sailors and officers have been willing to talk, but only if their names are not used.
The Navy's closed policies have attracted some criticism, particularly from Mr. Schindler's mother, Dorothy Hajdys of Chicago Heights, Ill. She has expressed concern over what she has said is evidence that the Navy might be covering up the possibility that Mr. Schindler was killed because he was gay. She has been joined by members of some gay rights groups, who have seized on the case to advance President Clinton's efforts to end the military's ban on homosexuals.
Sasebo was little more than a tiny fishing port in a magnificent natural harbor until 1889, when the Imperial Navy began to transform it into what would become the largest naval base in the Far East. Sasebo eventually contained an enormous dry dock installation and was used as a support base for some of the major sea battles of World War II.
It escaped the cataclysm that befell nearby Nagasaki, which was the second and last city to be hit with an atomic bomb, in August 1945. But by the time the Americans arrived here shortly afterward, much of the base lay in ruins as a result of waves of conventional bombing.
 
War Doesn't Stay Buried
 The Japanese had grown so desperate in the war's closing months that they had turned the kilns of nearby Arita, once a famous porcelain center, into factories for producing grenades. The thick porcelain shells were buried in haste as the Americans drew close, and today sailors say they are still unearthing thousands of the blue and pink casings.
Until recently, collecting these odd souvenirs of a distant time was entertainment enough for some of the sailors. It was quiet then, and news of barroom violence and sadistic crimes was somebody else's problem. Such things, it was believed, just did not happen in Sasebo.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A rash of violent crime connected with the United States Navy base in Sasebo, Japan, has Japanese residents concerned and has put Americans there on the defensive. The base, above, is expecting the arrival this month of an aircraft carrier that will more than double the base's population. (James Sterngold/The New York Times)
 
Map of Japan, indicating Sasebo.

HEADLINE: For Consumers, a Wobbly Faith

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
A wave of layoffs at some of the nation's best-known corporations shook Americans' faith in the economic recovery earlier this month, raising the specter that consumers will pull back on spending.
The Conference Board's index of consumer confidence tumbled eight points in early February, to 68.5, the New York-based business research group said. The fall reversed more than half of the surge in consumers' spirits in the two months after the Presidential election, though the index remained well above recession readings of 50 or lower.
 
Some Question Findings
 But retailers and economists said the Conference Board results had to be taken with a large grain of salt. 
 "We haven't noticed any decline in traffic or sales," said Mark Hunter, general manager of the Woodland Hills Mall, Oklahoma's biggest shopping center. "Just looking around the mall and talking to merchants, there doesn't appear to be a dramatic shift either way. It's more of a wait-and- see attitude."
Ira Silver, planning manager at the J. C. Penney Company, offered a similar assessment. "We had a lot of momentum in January," he said, "and we seem to have decent momentum in February."
One weekly monitor of actual sales, the Johnson Redbook Service, reported that sales were climbing in mid-February from the previous month.
 
Polled Before Clinton's Address

 
 The Conference Board survey was based on 5,000 mail interviews conducted in the first two weeks of February, several days before the President's speech to Congress on Feb. 17. But Fabian Linden, executive director of the Conference Board's consumer research group, and others say the President's speech may have bolstered the outlook of consumers.
"In the last few days, as more of Mr. Clinton's program has become clear, there seems to be a positive response," Mr. Linden said.
The Conference Board is now busy sifting 600 questionnaires that were completed after Mr. Clinton's speech outlining his economic attack plan. "We'll issue a revised figure shortly," Mr. Linden said.
Two readings of the consumer mood taken after the Clinton speech, one by ABC/Money Magazine, the other by the University of Michigan, are coming out later this week.
Spirits slipped in most of the country, especially in the Midwest and New England in the first half of February. The decline in the Middle Atlantic region, which includes New York and New Jersey, was a bit more severe than in the nation as a whole.
"The loss in consumer confidence, and particularly the sharp decline in expectations, is disconcerting," Mr. Linden commented.
The slippage in the confidence numbers was not a total surprise. Many economists had been waiting for some of the post-election euphoria to wear off. "I've been expecting it to come off the highs," said Chris Probyn, a forecaster at DRI/McGraw Hill. "The surge in confidence was partly psychological. A lot of it was based on the assumption that effective Government policies would be put in place."
Furthermore, the Conference Board survey -- the one most closely followed on Wall Street -- is the most volatile of the three major consumer sentiment polls, and the other two have not declined. The University of Michigan Consumer Sentiment Index was relatively flat -- up half a point to 90.5 -- in first two weeks of February, after strong gains in November and December and a plateau in January. And in the week before the big Clinton speech, the weekly ABC/Money Magazine Consumer Comfort Index showed its first uptick in seven weeks.
While consumer confidence figures are watched closely, spending has not tracked the confidence readings all that closely. Other factors, like income and interest rates, also affect spending.
"The consumer confidence indexes haven't been particularly good leading indicators in the past couple of years," Mr. Silver of J. C. Penney said.
 
Concern Over Job Cuts
 Consumers were clearly discouraged, however, by dramatic announcements in recent weeks by some corporate giants, including I.B.M., Sears and Boeing, that more than 100,000 jobs would be slashed in coming months and years.
The proportion of survey respondents who thought jobs would be hard to get, which had been edging down toward the end of the year, jumped higher. Meanwhile, the percentage of respondents who thought jobs would be plentiful shrank sharply from 7.8 percent to 7.1 percent.
"These are big numbers and people become fearful about the jobs situation when they read about them," said Rosalind Wells, an economist at NPD Group, a Port Washington, L.I., market research company.
The weaker Conference Board reading may well signal some easing from the robust 4 percent pace of spending in last year's second half -- something most economists were predicting.
"Last February's plunge in the Conference Board's index did not portend a disaster," said Mr. Probyn at DRI/McGraw Hill, "but it did accurately foreshadow a slowdown in the rate of increase in consumer spending." He expects outlays to rise at a moderate 3 percent annual rate this quarter and next.


GRAPHIC: According to the Conference Board's index of consumer confidence, recent weeks have seen the public turn gloomier. In the University of Michigan's surveys, the change is more of a pause than a plunge. But post-recession mood swings in both surveys have not yet had much effect on consumer spending, which has grown fairly steadily.

HEADLINE: Giving More Than Once to Neediest Cases Fund

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
In recent weeks, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has received scores of checks from contributors who were giving for a second time because they feared that the current campaign would fall short of its goal, forcing charities to turn away thousands of people.
They responded because they envisioned a New York City scarred by cutbacks in social services: fewer soup kitchens for the hungry, no medical care for some poor children and reduced job training for homeless men and women who desperately want to get off the streets. 
 They reacted to the news that the fund was hundreds of thousands of dollars behind last year's pace because they wanted to insure that people like Damien C. have a chance.
 
Multiple Physical Disabilities
 Damien, 21 years old, has multiple physical disabilities and is mentally retarded, but after receiving training from the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, one of seven charities aided by the fund, he now works in the packaging division at the Pfizer pharmaceuticals company in Brooklyn.
Damien is far less dependent on relatives and social service agencies now than he was before he began taking courses at the Brooklyn Bureau. "I have learned to take my job very seriously," he said the other day day as he stood near the assembly line wearing a white uniform, hair net, goggles and gloves.
In letters to the Neediest Cases Fund, donors write that their second checks symbolized their commitment to New York City and their belief that they must not forget those who are suffering, particularly during an economic slump that has thrown so many people out of work.
"Like many I felt saddened that the fund might not reach last year's total," wrote Irene E. Siotka of Manhattan, who gave $50. "I faithfully read the Neediest Cases column, and it is a daily reminder of how much I have both literally and figuratively."
 
'Second Extra Bonus Check'
 Caroline D. Janover of Ridgewood, N.J., also sent $50. "When I read that your fund-raising this year is behind the total for last year (and the need is so very great), I decided to send a second extra bonus check this year," she wrote. "I know you will spend it wisely."
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund helps thousands of people who are facing homelessness, unemployment, drug addiction and chronic illnesses. The Times pays the fund's expenses, so all contributions go directly to seven charities.
This year's campaign is down about $440,000 compared with last year's contributions at this point. But there is still time to give: the current appeal, which began on Nov. 29, ends on Sunday.
Gladys and Frank Parker of Larchmont, N.Y., gave $50 to the Neediest Cases.
"Although retired, I am grateful that my husband and I can meet our expenses," Mrs. Parker wrote. "We are aware that too many others are not so fortunate. Therefore, we are enclosing an additional contribution to help out with the shortfall. We hope other contributors will do the same."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Retailers with strong profits are rewarded with declining stocks.

BYLINE: By Stephanie Strom

 BODY:
THE market momentarily punished several retail stocks yesterday, despite strong fourth-quarter results and reports from merchants of good February business.
By the time the stock market had closed, the stocks had recovered some of their footing, although most ended the day with losses. Oddly enough, some companies that had difficult or lackluster fourth quarters, like the Kmart Corporation and Gap Inc., escaped the roller-coaster ride. 
 So far this year, retail stocks have dropped 5 percent, compared with a two-tenths of 1 percent drop in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, according to Salomon Brothers.
Some analysts were puzzled by the continuing decline in the stocks of the stronger retailers. "There's no real good reason for what's happening," said Jeffrey M. Feiner, a Salomon analyst.
Yesterday's stampede out of retail shares seemed at first to be part of a general exodus from growth stocks. By midafternoon, Home Depot had fallen $4.75, a loss of 7.9 percent of its market value since reporting a 43.6 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings on Monday. But Home Depot rebounded to close at $59.50, down only 25 cents.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's largest retailer, reported fourth-quarter earnings that exceeded most analysts' estimates and it filed an income statement that was a textbook example of cost control. In the quarter, Wal-Mart's profits rose 24.4 percent, to $749.6 million, or 65 cents a share, from $602.4 million, or 52 cents a share, a year earlier.
Still, its stock dropped $2, to $58.75, after the announcement, even though many analysts say that discounters like Wal-Mart will fare better than other retailers under President Clinton's economic and fiscal proposals. By the close, Wal-Mart was back up to $59.875, down 75 cents for the day.
"I guess you could say that the Government budget proposals are going to raise corporate tax rates, raise the minimum wage and increase health-care costs, which would mean future cash flows would get hit," said William W. Whyte, who follows Wal-Mart for Stephens Inc. in Little Rock, Ark. "But since there's nothing definite on that yet, all the activity today is a little premature."
Yesterday's report that consumer confidence fell this month also took its toll on some retail stocks, although confidence levels have not precisely forecast spending recently.
The stocks of those retailers most sensitive to economic ups and downs were among those taking a pounding yesterday. May Department Stores Inc., the largest operator of department stores, announced its 18th consecutive year of record earnings. Fourth-quarter earnings rose 19.9 percent to $319 million, or $2.53 a share, from $266 million, or $2.12 a share, a year earlier. Nonetheless, its shares tumbled $2.75, to $67.75, before closing at $68.625.
"They've closed a number of their poorer-performing stores, which should be a big plus to their comparable-store sales over the next several months no matter what happens to the economy," said Kim Walin, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers. "The way I look at today, it's a great buying opportunity for investors interested in this industry."
She noted that shoppers have for three years been paring their debt, which should restore some of their spending power.
Analysts did fully understand why there was a selloff in Nordstrom Inc. The company told them on Monday night that their estimates for 1993 were too high and that February sales were below expectations. The market took the company at its word and drove the stock down about 16 percent, or $5.75, to close at $32.875.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long Bond Surges On; Yield 6.82%

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices continued their surge yesterday, pushing yields down across the board and leaving many traders marveling at the lowest interest rates they have seen in their careers.
The rally is also giving the Clinton Administration more help than it could have expected, because a sustained decline in long-term interest rates is crucial for the success of the President's economic program. Lower rates will both stimulate business investment and lessen the debt burden on companies and individuals. 
 The yield on the 30-year bond dropped to 6.82 percent, only its second day below 7 percent since the Treasury began regularly issuing 30-year bonds in 1977. At the same time, the yield on the 10-year note fell below 6 percent, to 5.89 percent, the lowest level since January 1972.
 
Unfamiliar Territory
 "Most traders on Wall Street have never seen these levels before," said Stephen C. Leslie, a 40-year-old trader at M. R. Beal & Company who has been in the business for 15 years.
There are several explanations for the rally, which began in earnest after President Clinton introduced his economic plan last week and has pulled down the yield on the 30-year bond from 7 percent last Friday.
Yet at the heart of the buying seems to be a touch of perversity in the bond market , where bad economic news can be good.
For example, the Treasury market received its first lift yesterday morning, when the Conference Board reported that consumer confidence had declined sharply in early February. The report helped push stocks lower. [Page D8.]
Mr. Clinton's plan could aid the bond market even if does not reduce the deficit as much as he would like.
On the one hand, cutting the deficit is good for traders and investors. In the long term, it means the Government will borrow less, which would make existing bonds and notes a little more valuable.
On the other hand, economists and traders are betting that the proposed tax increases in Mr. Clinton's plan will be a drag on the economy even if the spending cuts are not approved and the deficit reduction is less than hoped.
With the economy growing only moderately, there is little risk that inflation, which is hovering about 3 percent a year, will accelerate, which is the bond markets worse fear. So what may be unhappy economic news for Mr. Clinton is good for bonds.
 
No-Lose Situation
 "Heads you win, tails you win," said David L. Murphy, a portfolio manager at Fidelity Investments in Boston. "If you get the program in place, and there is serious budget deficit reduction, that is positive. And even if you don't get serious deficit reduction, the tax increases will slow the economy and that will be good for the bond market."
Another reason for the recent surge, traders said, is that many portfolio managers who own securities backed by home mortgage payments are selling them and buying Treasury bonds and notes. The recent drop in interest rates has set off a new wave of mortgage refinancings, which means that these securities will be paid off much sooner than expected. The quickest way for investors to protect the value of their portfolios is to buy Treasury bonds and notes, which cannot be paid off early.
Mr. Clinton and other government officials contributed to the bond buying spree. Lloyd Bentsen, the Secretary of the Treasury, and Mr. Clinton helped by saying that they wanted more spending cuts in their economic plan. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, helped by indicating that it is too early to say that the economic recovery is secure.
 
A Note of Caution
 Upon entering unfamiliar territory on interest rates, some bond traders were becoming cautious in their buying. But they seemed to be overrun by investors who have cash and who missed the beginning of the rally.
"You have to be concerned when you have such a move," said Mr. Murphy of Fidelity. "It has the effect of bringing people into the market, and that has the effect of carrying you beyond where you ought to go."
The Treasury rally was slowed only briefly during the day. That hitch came after the results were released of the Treasury auction of two-year notes. Because the bidding appeared weak, the prices of other Treasury securities slid somewhat. But then the run-up resumed.
The 3.94 percent yield at the auction was the lowest since the Treasury began regularly selling two-year notes in September 1974. By the end of the day the Treasury rally had pulled the yield down to 3.90 percent in the pre-auction, or when-issued market.
In late trading, the price of the 7.125 percent 30-year bond was up one point and 13/32 to 10327/32 . The yield of 6.82 percent was down from 6.93 percent Monday and from 7.47 percent on Jan. 12.
The price of the 10-year note was up one point and 8/32 . Its 5.89 percent yield was down from 6.06 percent the previous day.
 
Other Bonds

The corporate and tax-exempt municipal bond markets followed Treasury prices higher and yields lower yesterday, despite the sale of billions of dollars of new issues in both markets. A total of $3.4 billion in new municipal bonds were sold, while corporations moved $3.6 billion in new bonds. Municipal bond prices were up 5/8 to 3/4 point, while the yields on corporate securities kept close to the advances in the Treasury market.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of two-year notes.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A.T.& T. Signs Pact In China

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
In a deal that could be worth billions of dollars over the next several years, China agreed yesterday to discuss buying a wide range of equipment from A.T.& T., including switching and transmission systems, cellular telephones, and business phones and computer networks.
Formally, the agreement signed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday with the State Planning Commission of China is merely a memorandum of understanding to study possible investments. 
 But Randall L. Tobias, vice chairman of A.T.& T., said a major project would be announced "within a matter of months because we're moving at warp speed."
 
Equipment Sales Limited
 The cold war, however, still looms over the deal. Cocom, the 17-nation Western trade organization that polices high-technology exports, limits the kind of telecommunications equipment that China can buy.
When A.T.& T. gets down to negotiating a specific deal on fiber-optic transmission lines, for example, it may find that it can supply only a line that carries 1,900 simultaneous conversations, a 10-year-old technology that A.T.& T. is about to phase out of production. Export to China of the more modern cable, for 8,000 conversations, is illegal.
Still, the agreement yesterday represents a significant advance for A.T.& T., which despite its $64 billion in revenue last year, has relatively little foreign sales except from its NCR computer subsidiary.
The world's most populous country would be the largest potential market for any company, but especially so for A.T.& T. The company's largest overseas market for phone equipment has been in Spain, one of the tiniest European markets for such sales.
For China, the agreement promises a major technological jump-start to an already fast-growing economy. A.T.& T. has also agreed to make computer-switching equipment and integrated circuits in China, combine corporate telephone systems and computer networks, and provide services like voice mail and toll-free "800" numbers.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Randall L. Tobias, right, vice chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was in Beijing yesterday with Jiang Zemin, Secretary General of the Central Committee of the Communist Party, who agreed to discuss the purchasing of equipment from A.T.& T. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Japanese Business Sees a High Cost in Rising Yen

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 23

 BODY:
The last time cries of "endaka!" -- the term for the surging strength of the Japanese yen -- reverberated here in the mid-1980's, Japan's economy was booming and the United States was searching for a quick way to reduce its vast trade deficit with Tokyo. The monetary solution helped a little, but only temporarily.
Now Japan's trade surpluses are growing again, largely because the country's economic slowdown has squeezed the consumption of American goods here to a trickle. And once again, Japanese officials say they are hoping that a powerful yen will buy them brief political peace in Washington by lowering the trade deficit and with it the pressure for protectionism. 
 This time, however, a surging yen may have an enormous cost. All day today, Japanese business leaders barraged the Government with warnings that the yen's extraordinary run-up in recent days would result in new rounds of layoffs and bankruptcies and would make a bad economy worse.
 
 
Few Benefits From Strong Yen
 Few seem to believe that the main objective of strengthening the yen -- reducing Japan's trade surpluses by making Japanese goods more expensive in America -- will be accomplished. The 6 percent increase in the value of the yen over the last two weeks, they say, will at best knock a few billion dollars off Japan's $47 billion trade surplus with the United States, maybe a bit more if the yen strengthens more in coming days. It closed today in Japanese trading at 116.78 to the dollar, the lowest the dollar has been since exchange rates were established after World War II. Later, in New York trading, the dollar recovered to 117.05 yen.
"The critical issue is what it will do to the Japanese economy," said Minoru Makihara, president of the Mitsubishi Corporation, the company at the pinnacle of Japan's largest industrial group. "I'm afraid that there may not be much of a political benefit, and it will cause a lot of pain."
Japanese executives, however, said today that if the strong yen did cut into foreign sales, it might force the Government of Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa to adopt a large-scale plan to stimulate the economy, a move he had been resisting.
Mr. Miyazawa conceded today that some emergency measures would have to be taken -- something that business leaders had been saying for months -- but he had yet to come up with a plan. Executives who usually shy away from criticizing the Government are calling reporters these days to blame Mr. Miyazawa for failing to articulate an economic strategy and for reacting to economic events rather than shaping them.
 Meanwhile, the costs of Japan's economic slump are rising: Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, the country's communications giant, said today that it would reduce its workforce by 30,000 employees in the next four years, including the early retirement of workers between the ages of 45 and 55. That would reduce NTT's work force to about 200,000.
In an interview recently, Japan's Foreign Minister, Michio Watanabe, estimated that up to one million Japanese workers were seriously underemployed even though they had not been dismissed by their companies.
Under such conditions, company officials said, the 6 percent increase in the value of the yen could strike a major blow by making the export of many products unprofitable.
"We are at the point where the more we export, the more we lose money," a senior officer of Hitachi , the electronics giant, said today. "A few years ago, the answer to that problem was to build a factory in America. But now no one wants to spend the money to build factories."
This time, the fallout from the greatly strengthened yen, if it lasts, will likely be very different from the last onset of endaka.
 
 
Yen Fueled 1980's Boom
 In 1985, when 240 yen bought $1, monetary officials, gathering at the Plaza Hotel in New York, decided that a rapid strengthening of the yen was the only quick way to restore American competitiveness. Instead, the yen nearly doubled by 1988, to around 125 yen to the dollar, and the result was improved Japanese competitiveness and vastly increased Japanese political power.
Almost overnight, the appreciation of the yen made it far cheaper for cash-rich Japanese companies to buy American rivals or snap up real estate and technology. Japan quickly became the dominant economic power in Asia, building factories in Thailand and Malaysia, where wages were lower, and gaining enormous political clout there as well. Japan also surpassed the United States to became the largest donor of foreign aid, measured in dollar terms. Most important, the strengthening of the yen forced Japanese manufacturers to become far more efficient as they invested huge sums in new plants and equipment.
 
 
Cheaper Imports
 But this time, no one expects the Japanese to go on a buying spree with their record-strong currency. And cheaper imports are not likely to impress many consumers here.
"In a recession like this, Japanese are not going to import more just because foreign goods are a little cheaper," Takashi Miura, the chairman of the board of Tokyo Senpaku Kaisha Ltd., a leading shipping company, said today.
Many economists noted that during the mid-1980's, Japanese companies also cried doom about the rising yen. At that time, however, the Japanese and American governments seemed far better coordinated in dealing with the currency markets. In contrast, the most recent rise was sparked on Friday by an apparently offhand comment by the United States Treasury Secretary, Lloyd Bentsen, that he favors a stronger yen.
For the Clinton Administration, the sudden appreciation of the yen presents a stark choice: whether to try to manage the trade deficit by managing the dollar or by pressing the Japanese to open more of their markets to foreigners. For four years, the Bush Administration wavered on that point, using macroeconomic monetary tactics sometimes and pushing to open the Japanese market at other times. So far, the Clinton Administration has said very little about how it would mix the two approaches.


GRAPHIC: Theoretically, the dollar's long-term slide against the Japanese yen should have spurred now-cheaper American exports to Japan and deterred now-pricier Japanese exports to the United States. The actual trade figures show that exchange rates are not the only factor determining patterns of trade between the United States and Japan, and further weakening of the dollar may have little effect.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Stays Under Pressure But Manages a Mixed Close

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed in hectic trading on world currency markets yesterday and remained under pressure from tumbling yields in the bond market.
Gold prices were mixed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $331.10 a troy ounce, up $2.90 from Monday. The Republic National Bank said gold added $2.65 an ounce, to a late bid price of $330.50. 
 The dollar managed to rally off its lows but was restrained from posting further gains as bond prices soared for the second day and a Conference Board report showed consumer confidence in the economy tumbled in February.
"That report helped bring the dollar a bit lower," said John McCarthy, foreign exchange manager at the ABN AMRO Bank.
 
Spotlight Off Yen
 Investors spent much of the session focusing on the European currencies, he noted, taking the spotlight off the Japanese yen, which has surged in recent days.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 116.78 yen, down 0.07 yen from Monday's close and the lowest closing there since modern exchange rates were established after World War II.
Later in London, the dollar was quoted at a lower rate of 116.65 yen. But in New York, the dollar recovered to 117.05 yen, up from 116.36 yen on Monday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.4585, from $1.4540 late Monday. In New York it cost $1.4530 to buy one pound, less expensive than Monday's $1.4580.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's late rates, included: 1.6230 German marks, down from 1.6233; 1.4975 Swiss francs, up from 1.4860; 5.5100 French francs, up from 5.5060; 1,583.25 Italian lire, up from 1,566.60, and 1.2533 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2593.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $329.60 a troy ounce, from $330.00 bid late Monday.

HEADLINE: Jump in Profits for Unilever

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 23

 BODY:
Unilever, the British-Dutch food and detergents giant, said today that its pretax profits jumped past 2 billion last year for the first time.
Strong growth in North America, Latin America and Southeast Asia helped make up for difficulties in Europe, the company said. 
 "Economic recovery proved to be an illusion in many of our markets, and 1992 was the third year in succession to be affected by recession," Unilever's chairman, Michael Perry, said. He held out little hope for a speedy economic turnaround in Britain and said the downturn in Germany had proved much sharper than expected, bringing a drop in profits.
But in North America, Mr. Perry said, the group was more optimistic about the future of the United States economy than it had been for some time. Sales revenue from this region rose by 3 percent, profits surged and margins increased.
The group's overall pretax profit rose 13.4 percent, to 2.03 billion ($2.96 billion), from 1.79 billion a year earlier, mainly from gains in consumer food like ice cream and a recovery in personal-care products.
Sales increased 6.6 percent, to 24.7 billion ($35.97 billion), compared with 23.16 billion the previous year.

HEADLINE: No Roast Aardvark, No Grilled Zebra, Still, Queens Has an Alphabet Soup

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE

 BODY:
IN Queens, the most ethnically diverse borough in New York, taste buds cannot be jaded. Indians bake breads until they puff into golden clouds, and Chinese serve up steamed dumplings that burst open with broth on first bite. Jewish delicatessens cure beef or pastrami with black peppercorns and garlic, and Koreans grill prime beef after marinating it in the Oriental trinity of seasonings: soy sauce, sesame oil and sugar.
The food of Queens, from American seafood to zucchini fritti, offers an A-to-Z primer to the 1,951,590 people from 178 ethnic groups who live in Queens, according to Census figures and Mayor David N. Dinkins's office. 
 "If there are 178 groups in the city, that's what is in Queens," said Frank Vardy, a demographer for the Department of City Planning and a co-author of "The Newest New Yorkers: A Look at Immigration," published by the department last year. From 1982 to 1989, immigrants to the Elmhurst section of Queens alone came from 112 different countries, Mr. Vardy said.
It's the middle-class dream that draws people to Queens. "One- or two-family houses, sandbox, garage, driveway -- or fairly spacious apartments," Mr. Vardy said.
Jacqueline Newman, a professor and coordinator of the graduate program in home economics at Queens College in Flushing, says ethnic diversity in Queens has soared since the 1960's, when immigration laws were relaxed. "It's like a stone rolling down a hill, gathering moss," she said. "They take in relatives and friends until they get on their feet; they find apartments for each other, and their mobility is in the area where they've been taken in." And with the people come the food of home, whether home was Port-au-Prince, Madras or Seoul.
Although a Chinese may live next door to a Haitian, an Indian in the same building as a Vietnamese, some neighborhoods, residential and commercial, are distinctly ethnic. Greeks populate Astoria. Indians live all over the borough but have transformed 74th Street in Jackson Heights into a shopper's Little India, bustling with 82 stores selling saris and gold bracelets, poori and tandoors. Koreans and Chinese have restaurants all over the borough, but they each staked out their main turf on Main Street in Flushing, turning it into a Little Korea and a Little Chinatown.
Eating in Queens is largely a homey, casual affair. Three generations are found at every kind of restaurant, where waiters and waitresses actually seem happy to see children. Perhaps sensing this, children eat quietly, talk in normal voices and do not scream or fidget. For the most part, these restaurants do not require reservations, and there are no dress codes. Jeans and a sweatshirt will do.
Throughout the borough, delectable foods are served in places humble or elegant. Alphabetically, here are 26 dishes from 15 Queens restaurants:
American Seafood. In 1962, when Leonard Barnes, a Cockney, opened LONDON LENNIE'S in Rego Park, he dazzled his wife, Joan, with scallops, tiny Nantucket bay scallops. "I never knew that scallops could be so sweet," Mrs. Barnes recalled. "With a bit of lemon juice, a bit of butter and broiled, I thought I was eating sugar." Today, the specialty at Lennie's is simple, perfectly cooked, fresh seafood. Lennie is deceased, and the Barneses' son, Les, carries on, serving the scallops dipped in flour, swiftly sauteed and served with a wedge of lemon on the side ($17.95). The flavor? Startlingly sweet.
Bulgoki. At DAE DONG, a spacious Korean restaurant in Sunnyside where each wood table is equipped with a grill, the sweet meat from prime rib is sliced paper thin, marinated in soy sauce mixed with sugar, scallions, garlic, sesame oil and sherry, and then grilled to produce bulgoki, a Dae Dong speciality. Each piece is wrapped in a lettuce leaf, the hot meat contrasting with the cold, crisp lettuce ($12.95).
Chicken and Coconut Milk Soup. From Thailand, this addictive soup has bits of poached chicken adrift in a broth made from coconut milk, lemon grass, coriander and chilies ($7.25). The soup is hot and sour, its texture creamy yet thin. JAI-YA, a Thai restaurant in Elmhurst, has served the soup since 1978.
Dumplings. Of the many dumplings in the Chinese dim sum repertory, soup dumplings are among the most esoteric and delicious. As the dumpling is folded by hand, broth in gelatin form is tucked in along with pork, shrimp or crabmeat filling. As the dumpling is steamed, the gelatin melts. Bite into the dumpling and it explodes with liquid. The dumplings have no shelf life, cannot be frozen and are therefore hard to find. The NEW FLUSHING SEAFOOD SHANGHAI CUISINE in Flushing serves two varieties: Shanghai steamed buns filled with ground pork ($3.95) and crabmeat steamed buns ($4.95).
Eggplant. Eggplant has a silky, meaty quality, and at LA PIAZZA, a northern Italian restaurant in Kew Garden Hills, it is sauteed with olive oil, garlic and parsley and drizzled with balsamic vinegar ($7.75). Dominick Domiani, the owner and chef, beamed as he watched his restaurant fill up late on a recent Saturday afternoon. He quoted his grandmother: "Cooking food is simply delicious, and eating food is deliciously simple."
Fish Cakes, Thai Style. The fried fish cake is a crunchy, slightly chewy, textural, spicy morsel. At Jai-Ya, meat from a fish that the waiter called "spotting fish from Bangkok" is minced, then mixed with curry paste, long beans and other spices, made into cakes about two inches round, fried and served with a sauce of chili, garlic, cucumbers and crushed peanuts ($7.95).
Guanabana. Guanabana is Spanish for soursop, a tropical fruit with a hint of vanilla flavor. At CALI VIEJO, a Colombian restaurant in Jackson Heights, the pulp of the fruit is turned into a celestial milkshake. Tossed into a blender with milk, sugar and ice, it is transformed into a frothy, creamy drink called, in Spanish, batido ($2).
Hong-a Hwe. Koreans marinate paper-thin slices of raw puff-fish in vinegar, then mix them with a sauce of red pepper, sesame oil, garlic and scallions to produce the dish called Hong-a Hwe ($9.95 at Dae Dong).
Innards. Some love innards, and some loathe them. At TAYGETOS, a Greek restaurant in Astoria, magaritsas is a creamy egg lemon soup with a slightly peppery zest, flecked with tiny minced bits of lamb kidney, liver and heart ($2.75). Depending on the diner's view, the innards (1) offend or (2) add texture and flavor to a classic soup.
Jewish Food. PASTRAMI KING in Kew Gardens offers a few of the classics of Eastern European Jewish food: pastrami, corned beef, dill pickles, rye bread. For 32 years, Pastrami King, an unprepossessing place with Formica tabletops, has been making what some devotees consider the best pastrami in New York City. Its alchemy takes 10 to 16 days. Meat from the beef neck and shoulder is soaked in brine for three to five days, then spread with a thick paste of half-cracked black peppercorns and fresh garlic and cured for another three to five days. Then it is spiced with yet more peppercorns and garlic and again cured for three to five days. Finally it is smoked over cedar sawdust for four to six hours. Once steamed, it's ready to eat. The pastrami is moist yet firm, flavorful and addictive. Eat one slice. Eat two. Gluttony lurks nearby ($5.95 a sandwich).
Kefalograviera. This slightly salty hard Greek cheese is best eaten fried. The white cheese is dipped in flour, then fried until it is crisp on the outside and meltingly chewy inside ($3.50 at Taygetos).
Lulo. This is what Colombians call the lime green orange -- an orange that when grown in the tropics keeps a green skin even though it's fully ripe. At Cali Viejo, the pulp of the lulo is made into a batido, a milkshake, and whipped until frothy ($2).
Maryland Crab Cakes. At London Lennie's, the fresh sweet meat from the blue crab claw is folded into a blend of mayonnaise, egg yolk, fresh parsley and a mix of perky spices called crab boil: paprika, peppers, onion, thyme and garlic. The cakes, three inches in diameter, are dipped in flour, sauteed until golden brown and served with an herb mayonnaise ($14.95).
Naeng Myon. In North Korea, people are so devoted to naeng myon -- cold rice vermicelli served in beef broth with shredded egg cake, paper-thin sliced beef and a drizzle of hot chili sauce, vinegar and sesame oil -- that they eat it even on the most frigid days. "They wrap themselves inside a warm blanket," said Jenny Kim, co-owner of Dae Dong, where customers can taste naeng myon without need of blanket. Each time someone orders the dish, someone in the kitchen presses the button on a noodle machine and out comes a handful of rice noodles that plunge directly into a pot of boiling water ($7.95).
Onion Kulcha. Kulcha, one of India's famous breads, is made of leavened flour and stuffed with cheese and herbs or vegetables like potatoes or onions. Onion kulcha prevails at JACKSON DINER, a restaurant in Jackson Heights whose name and decor (red-and-white-checked plastic tablecloths and pink walls) are eclectically American, but whose food and location are strictly Indian. The kulcha is stuffed with chopped onions, ginger and coriander, then baked until puffy ($2.50). A cup of tea is a natural accompaniment.
Pork Satay. Satays -- skewered grilled meats like pork, chicken and beef -- have become cliches of the American cocktail party. But the origin is Thai, and at Jai-Ya, the pork satay ($7.25) is especially delectable, no matter how often you may have had it. Cubes of pork are marinated overnight in curry powder, coconut milk, salt, pepper and sugar, then placed on the skewer and grilled until they have a light crust but are tender and juicy within. The dish is served with its usual accompaniment of a sauce made from curry paste, tamarind juice, sugar and peanut butter.
Quick-Fried Baby Shrimp With Pea Sprouts. When a Chinese cooks his shrimp quickly, he does it in a blindingly fast 30 seconds. At the New Flushing Seafood Shanghai Cuisine, this simple dish, which sounds so ordinary on the menu, can be extraordinary if the shrimp are fresh and pea sprouts are in season. Fresh shrimp have a silkier texture and sweeter flavor than frozen shrimp. When available (and do ask for them) the shrimp are sauteed in 30 seconds with ginger, garlic, salt and a splash of chicken broth. The tender sprouts of the pea plant get their own rapid-fire, 30-second treatment with a little salt, sugar and wine. The platter is served with the pale pink shrimp on one side, the jade green sprouts on the other ($13.95).
Rice and Beans. Any notion that rice and beans must be moist and saucy to be delicious is laid to rest at LA DETENTE, a Haitian restaurant in Elmhurst. On Sunday, the restaurant offers a brunch buffet to the accompaniment of a jazz trio or quartet and to the giggles of little children, the girls in party dresses, the boys in coats and ties, seated with doting parents and doting grandparents. On a table that runs the width of the room are chafing dishes of plantains, chicken creole, fried goat -- and rice and beans. The rice and beans are cooked together, and are served somewhat dry but deeply flavored with parsley, hot sauce, onions, salt and bell peppers ($4). During the week La Detente has table service, and food is ordered a la carte.
Soul Food. CARMICHAEL'S DINER AND COCKTAIL LOUNGE in Jamaica looks like an ordinary diner, with a bright orange interior, Formica-covered tables, paper napkins and a menu whose cover says it specializes in lobster, steaks and chops. But a peek inside Carmichael's menu discloses its unadvertised secret. Carmichael's specialty is soul food. Except for chitterlings, the staples are here: collard greens, grits and pork chops breaded, fried and served smothered in a brown gravy ($6.10).
Teriyaki Squid. Each chef has a closely held secret recipe. At ROBATA, a Japanese restaurant in Forest Hills, Kanae Shirakawa, the chef and owner, prides herself on her teriyaki sauce. She is 67, has cooked for 27 years and will say only that it is made of sugar, soy sauce and chicken broth, cooked for five hours. There is little she doesn't serve with the sauce: chicken, beef, pork, scallops, swordfish, lobster, tuna -- and squid. Cut into circles, the squid is cooked for a brief moment, so the flesh is tender. It arrives at the table piping hot, with each circle burnished by the glistening, mahogany-colored, piquant but mellow sauce ($10.95).
Uttapam. In southern India, uttapam is a crisp savory pancake. At the Jackson Diner, uttapam made from rice and lentil flours is poured onto a hot griddle, sprinkled with chopped onions, tomatoes and peas, and cooked until golden and crisp on both sides ($4.75).
Verde, Salsa. At O LAVRADOR, a Portuguese restaurant in Richmond Hill, salsa verde, a green sauce made of minced parsley, garlic and olive oil, envelops lobsters, shrimp, clams and mussels -- either separately or together. It is a classic sauce found also in Spanish cuisine. In O Lavrador's mariscada em salsa verde, all the seafoods are served in the green sauce, each species of shellfish tossed into the sauce at the appropriate moment so none overcooks ($14.95).
Wiener Schnitzel, Tyrolean-Style. Enter the TRIANGLE HOFBRAU, an 1864 Queen Anne-style wood and white stucco building in Richmond Hill with leaded glass windows and a gabled roof, and you are suddenly in a German beer hall, with wooden barrels and beer steins the decorative elements. Never mind that the men at the bar are imbibing; there is food. The owners, members of the Four family who emigrated from Alsace-Lorraine in 1914 and bought the restaurant in 1920, serve a perfect version of Tyrolean Wiener schnitzel, a breaded and fried thin veal cutlet served with melted cheese, sauteed sliced mushrooms and a brown gravy made from veal stock. The cutlet is delicate and tender, the crust crisp, the sauce rich and earthy, and an accompaniment of spatzle, tiny twists of egg dough, appropriately neutral ($18.95).
Xunta Maryayu. In a dialect of Spanish, xunta means mixture, so this soulful soup is a mix of sea (mar) and garlic (ayu, a variation of ajo). At DON PELAYO, a Spanish restaurant in Long Island City, the chef, Jose Javier Menendez, interprets the soup as a rich, redolent clam, garlic and bread soup. He sautes garlic and fresh croutons in olive oil, and then adds paprika, water and salt. The soup simmers for 20 minutes; the bread softens. Then come the clams and, at the very last moment as the shells spring open, a sprinkle of parsley and a drizzle of beaten egg, which as it cooks turns into pale yellow threads and clouds ($5.95).
Yellow Fish, Smoked. The yellow fish, named after the river in China that is its habitat, arrives frozen at New Flushing Seafood Shanghai Cuisine, where it is thawed and transformed into a classic Shanghai-style appetizer. The fish is fried in oil, then simmered for two hours in sugar, vinegar, soy sauce and other seasonings, and then, finally, smoked for 15 minutes over tea leaves and spices ($6.95).
Zucchini Fritti. The Italians fry zucchini as the French fry potatoes: in crisp, golden, slender strands. At La Piazza, the zucchini arrives hot, tucked into a basket lined with a white linen napkin, with wedges of lemon on the side ($4).

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
A Stealth Industrial Policy It Makes Sense, If Done Cautiously

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN

 BODY:
First there was the uncola. Then the non-bank. Now, courtesy of President Clinton, America has its first non-industrial policy.
Under a real industrial policy -- of the type scorned by three successive Republican Administrations -- the Government picks winners by subsidizing selected industries. But in announcing his own policy this week, Mr. Clinton never uttered the phrase "industrial policy," perhaps because he doesn't call for picking winners. He calls for picking high-wage, high-tech enterprise. There's a difference there somewhere. 
 It's easy to ridicule industrial policy. As conservatives never tire of repeating, private markets do usually know best. Investors betting with their own money will beat Government bureaucrats betting the taxpayers' money nearly every time -- especially when the Government bets at the behest of money-dispensing lobbyists.
But ridicule is too easy, too quick. There is a cautious case to be made for Government to pick up the slack in situations where the private market doesn't automatically know best. Caution is in order because the economic benefits are far from certain and the political pitfalls immense.
Mr. Clinton wants to underwrite the development of commercially useful technology. He seems to have in mind the birth of several outfits like Sematech, the Government-industry consortium that is often credited with reviving semiconductor manufacturing in the U.S. The idea is to put up small amounts of Federal money that would be matched by private investors in pursuit of risky innovation.
The idea makes good sense -- at least up to a point. Modern commercial success depends less and less on natural resources, like fertile soil, than on opportunistic research and commercialization of breakthrough technologies. But research on clean automobiles and next-generation computer software could be hugely expensive and risky.
Private investors might be reluctant to bear the risks if, as is often the case, the benefits of the research and eventual product development might slip away to competitors here or abroad. In such situations, targeted Government intervention might tip the calculations of private investors in the other direction.
The danger is political. Philosopher-kings sitting in an ivory tower might well target subsidies where they produce huge social benefits. But Washington is more likely to direct them to the politically powerful. Mr. Clinton's challenge is to design intervention to minimize the political risks.
What if Washington put a modest amount -- say a few billion dollars a year -- into a fund administered by a panel of experts? The fund would invite partnerships of businesses and universities to bid for grants to pay part of their research costs. The projects would be chosen on the basis of which would not be undertaken without the subsidy but have the potential of throwing off huge benefits to the economy at large.
Structured in this way, the policy would doubly protect taxpayers. The size of the fund would be limited. And silly projects would be weeded out by requiring that private investors put up most of the cost of each project. Without these safeguards, taxpayers should run for cover.
The idea of subsidizing commercial enterprise won't sit well with many Americans. Industrial policy, no matter how camouflaged under the mantle of high tech, can turn into a slippery slope in the hands of lobby-beholden legislators and officials.
Yet the policy is worth trying. The United States is rich. It can afford to gamble away a few billion each year in pursuit of a clean car or other commercial products that can change the lives of millions of Americans. The key is keeping the policy small. No matter how many safeguards Mr. Clinton thinks he can build into the system, there remains the real possibility that the politics will drive the policy to waste.
Mr. Clinton's non-industrial policy marks the second time in a week that he has spat in the eye of the Reagan legacy of non-activist government. First he called for raising taxes to pay for new spending on infrastructure, training and education. Now he calls for a policy that would have Washington pick winning technologies.
In both instances, the case for activism stands or falls on Washington's ability to make choices. Contrary to Reagan-Bush, the issue is not whether government investment and subsidies can make sense; of course they can -- in theory. The question is whether Mr. Clinton can figure out a way to drive the decisions toward the economically dynamic, not the politically wired.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Let's Work With Clinton's Plan

BYLINE: By Herbert Stein; Herbert Stein, senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, was chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers under Richard Nixon and Gerald R. Ford. This is excerpted from an article to appear in the March-April 1993 issue of The American Enterprise.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Bill Clinton's economic program is probably the most far-reaching effort ever made by a President to control the Federal budget deficit. In light of the challenge and opportunity facing him and the country, it is disappointing.
Still, the plan is the only place we have to start, and it needs support. For those seriously concerned about the deficit, the responsibility now is not to defeat the plan but to try to strengthen and improve it. Here are some suggestions and observations. 
 * The deficit reduction proposed is much too small. Even by the Administration's own estimate the plan would leave a large deficit in 1997 and, more important, it would rise thereafter. The budget target for 1997 is arbitrary. It provides no basis on which to resist the inevitable temptations to try to scale back the deficit reductions.
The President's program would have been more defensible if its goal had been to reduce the deficit to zero, even if this had to be accomplished over a period of six or eight years.
* The program does not take advantage of reasonable options for substantially reducing the deficit. These include cutting the Federal subsidy for Medicare, limiting or eliminating the exclusion of fringe benefits from taxable income and cutting spending more sharply for the space station, supercollider and farm price supports.
The energy tax, chosen as the broad-based levy that most people would pay, could have been imposed at a higher rate without a severe burden on anyone.
* The proposed rate increase in the corporate profits tax, from 34 to 36 percent, only worsens the current "double taxation" inequity and would be an obstacle to the growth of investment that is one of the program's main goals. Profits are already taxed at the corporate level and at the individual level, in the form of dividends or capital gains.
* Applying a proposed tax to the use of energy by businesses would deter investment, because production that uses much capital also tends to use much energy. In addition, taxing energy used by business would drive energy-intensive production, like aluminum smelting, out of the country.
* The proposed investment credit for businesses would be highly discriminatory. It would reward businesses that invested little last year; that invest in physical capital rather than in research and training; that invest in short-lived assets, and that invest in equipment rather than structures. This is as likely to result in a loss of efficiency as it is in a gain.
* The Administration program is dotted with little give-aways, like tax breaks and soft loans for small business and supports for particular ventures such as high-speed trains. These give-aways, which would add up to tens of billions of dollars a year, would undermine a comprehensive effort to deal with the deficit.
Most of them could properly be described as investments -- which is how the President describes them. But many are unlikely to be as productive as the private investment that would result if the same amount of money were devoted to deficit reduction, which helps the overall economy. In general, the Administration's strategy shows an unjustified preference for government, or government-directed, investment over market-determined private investment.
* The selling of the program to the public relies heavily on the argument that the more progressive the tax system is, the fairer it is. That is not only a simple-minded view of fairness. It is also a dead end for budget policy. It means that when the economic limits of taxing the rich are reached there is no possibility of getting more revenue from the middle class, because that would reduce progressivity.
Despite these criticisms, the Clinton plan is the only deficit-reduction plan with a chance of being adopted. Some people, including leading Republicans, will say that they have an alternative plan to cut spending much more sharply than Mr. Clinton proposes to do.
But their plan is always described in general terms -- "across-the-board cuts," "a freeze on total spending" or some such formula -- never specifying what exactly is to be cut. The proponents of such "plans" have no more stomach than Mr. Clinton does for attacking the large middle-class benefits that are the essence of the budget problem.
This judgment may be too pessimistic. Some Republican leadership in Congress may arise to push strongly for significant specific cuts. If that happens, the President, given political cover by Republican support, may accept and possibly even welcome the reductions. In that case we could get a better program than the one the President has proposed.
But there is no sign of such a development and therefore little chance of getting a better deficit reduction package than Mr. Clinton's. Moreover, the President's package has every chance of being defeated. Elements of the program that save the most money will be vulnerable to opposition, because they are the most painful to the most people.
Advocates for the elderly will resist higher taxation of Social Security benefits. All kinds of users and suppliers will resist the energy tax. Unless some forces in the country and Congress are sufficiently concerned about the deficit to support the President's proposals -- however much they dislike other parts of the package -- the whole deficit-reducing effort could collapse.
If this effort fails we will probably not see another one for some time. The lesson will be that the system rejects even a cautious attempt by the President to exercise fiscal responsibility and to make a few tough decisions. And the public will once again see that no one really cares and that all the talk about the national interest in reducing the deficit is only a cover for the struggle of everyone to get his.
If the present effort succeeds, however, there will have been a demonstration of the willingness of Congress and the public to accept some sacrifice. Some budget untouchables will be seen to have been not so untouchable.
Discussion of the steps needed to reduce the deficit further can resume, one may hope, in a less demagogic and emotionally charged atmosphere than today. In that case we may yet say that 1993 was a turning point away from the disintegration of budget policy that has been going on for the past 25 years.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
