HEADLINE: Time to Stop the Posturing Over Welfare

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Caution on Welfare?" (news analysis, Feb. 3), about President Clinton's proposed welfare reform, is appropriately skeptical, but doesn't go far enough to unmask the posturing over this contentious issue. 
 Two important points about welfare -- Aid to Families with Dependent Children -- need to be made explicit in the debate: (1) We as taxpayers are unwilling to support legislation that may ultimately abandon single mothers with children. (2) Expenditures on A.F.D.C. represent a tiny part of Federal and state spending.
On the first point, the two-year limit in the new proposal misses the mark. Some political hay may be made in posing as an opponent of long-term welfare, but the problem is that such a policy does not deal with the inherent contradiction of welfare. We as taxpayers wish to provide some economic well-being for single mothers with children, yet we also believe in self-reliance and don't like dependence on government aid.
Recent trends underscore this argument. We have allowed the value of A.F.D.C. benefits to fall 43 percent over the last 20 years. We have tightened eligibility standards and required worker training. Yet even through the most conservative administrations, totally reeling in the safety net has never gained serious consideration. Americans, to our credit, are not going to let single mothers with children starve, even if they refuse or are unable to work.
As for welfare's costs, in recent years the Federal share of A.F.D.C. has accounted for less than 1 percent of Federal expenditures. The average state share has accounted for slightly more than 1 percent of state expenditures. Meanwhile, tax expenditures for interest on mortgage payments (a welfare program for the middle class and up) were close to four times that of Federal A.F.D.C. spending in 1991.
We must ask ourselves if a comparatively modest program like A.F.D.C. is a fire worthy of so much smoke. At best, welfare provides a poverty-level life style for single mothers and their children, the vast majority of whom use welfare episodically. Americans will not accept abandoning these vulnerable people. So let's stop the posturing.
 
JARED BERNSTEIN
Economist, Economic Policy Inst.
Washington, Feb. 11, 1993

HEADLINE: Incentive Plan Seeks to Save G.M. Plant

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 23

 BODY:
In a long-shot effort to keep the huge car assembly plant here from closing, New York State officials are knitting together a multimillion-dollar package of inducements for the General Motors Corporation, including financing for the plant's retooling and the building of a companion parts-making plant an hour away.
The state is trying to avert the loss of 3,000 jobs and a $122 million payroll when G.M. closes the plant in 1995. The loss, wrenching for the local economy, would have repercussions statewide because of its effect on tax revenues. But executives at G.M. said they knew of no changes in the plan to close the plant. 
 Vincent Tese, the state's Economic Development Commissioner, said in an interview that he recently asked for a meeting in Detroit with John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s new chief executive officer, to discuss incentives that would cost about $100 million.
 
Cuomo Eager for Role
 Gov. Mario M. Cuomo would be eager to make the pitch personally to General Motors officials, Mr. Tese said.
"We would be willing to work with G.M. in a financial way to keep Tarrytown open," Mr. Tese said.
If General Motors refuses this carrot, Mr. Tese said, the state is considering the stick of suing the company for breaking promises to stay on that it made in return for tax abatements given the Tarrytown plant in 1985. A similar suit against General Motors brought by government officials in Ypsilanti, Mich., was successful two weeks ago in a county circuit court and is being appealed.
 
Two Letters
 Officials at General Motors said today that they had received two letters from Mr. Tese, but had not seen a firm detailed offer. Still, they seemed not to be moved by the new overtures.
"We have too many production facilities as it is," said William B. Winters, a spokesman for the automobile maker. "The plant is closing in 1995. I'm not aware of any rationale to keep that plant open."
Although New York's package has yet to be refined, Mr. Tese said it would include low-interest financing for the retooling of a plant that now manufactures 225,000 Chevrolet, Pontiac and Oldsmobile minivans whose sales have fallen short of the car maker's hopes. The revamping, whose cost has been estimated at $150 million by the state, would permit the company to turn out a newly designed generation of the minivans.
Mr. Tese said financing and free land could also be made available for the building of a new parts-stamping plant at Stewart Air Force Base in Newburgh, N.Y., which is used by the state's Air National Guard and is only an hour's truck ride away from Tarrytown. The absence of a nearby parts plant, Mr. Tese noted, was one of the reasons the Tarrytown plant was chosen for closing a year ago rather than comparable G.M. plants.
 
Cheap Electrical Power
 Other sweeteners, he said, would include tax abatements, cheap electrical power provided through the State Power Authority, money for road and other infrastructure improvements around the plant and training to improve the skills of the current work force.
Mr. Winters, the G.M. spokesman, said General Motors had already made plans to turn manufacturing of the minivan over to a plant in Doraville, Ga., and was deep into planning for the shutdown of the Tarrytown plant and the relocation of workers.
Tarrytown was a leading candidate for closing, he said, because it is General Motors' oldest plant. He also expressed doubt that the company would be interested in another parts-stamping plant since it already has too many.
"I think the die is cast," he said.
In response to the threat of a state lawsuit, a G.M. spokeswoman, Margaret G. Holmes, said G.M. felt it would win such a suit because, in return for abatements, it had promised to stay in Tarrytown only until 1995.
 
Change in Management
 The state's initiative comes on the heels of a major management change at General Motors. Robert C. Stempel, who announced plans to close Tarrytown and 11 other factories, resigned as chief executive officer last fall. He was replaced by Mr. Smith, who is under a mandate to close a total of 23 of the company's 136 plants in response to G.M.'s declining share of the automobile market.
Donald Martino, president of Local 664 of the United Automobile Workers in North Tarrytown, approached Mr. Smith earlier this month and urged him to talk to a 23-member state task force appointed to deal with the Tarrytown closing. Last Friday, Mr. Tese followed up by writing Mr. Smith to remind him that the state was still standing by an offer of substantial assistance made last June.
"As I am sure you understand," the letter said, "the planned closing of the North Tarrytown plant poses a serious economic setback for this community. Anything that can be done to prevent or to ameliorate the effects of this planned closing is worthy of investigation."
When interviewed, Mr. Tese acknowledged some frustration because G.M. officials have not let him know what it would take to make Tarrytown more cost-effective. He and other state officials, working with industry experts, have had to devise solutions to a problem whose dimensions are fuzzy.
 
'Whatever They Want'
 "We'll work with them on whatever they want," he said of G.M. officials. "We have no idea what they want. But we need to engage them."
One difficult problem that they know G.M. faces is that the fiber-glass slant-nosed minivans have not proved as popular as minivans made by competitors, and General Motors needs to redesign the styling and construction and build the minivans at a plant that can better handle metals, like the one in Georgia.
The potential Tarrytown offer would not be the first time that the state has assembled economic packages to lure the car business. Mr. Tese recalled that the state had put together inducments totaling $100 million to persuade General Motors to locate its Saturn operation in the state and that it had pieced together a similar $88 million package for Toyota. In both cases, New York lost out to other states.
This village of frame houses huddled on a slope overlooking the Hudson River is bracing for the devastation that would be wrought by the closing of the plant, which occupies a colossal white box of a building on a 96.5-acre site on the river's bank. The merchants along Beekman Avenue feed and quench the thirst of the plant's workers, and dozens of larger businesses in the area supply the G.M. plant. Seat cushions for the minivans, for example, are made in Suffern, about 15 miles away across the Tappan Zee Bridge.
General Motors pays the village $1.1 million in lieu of taxes, about 19 percent of the village's annual budget, and it pays the school district $1.8 million toward a $24 million budget.
"It would mean a lot of hardship," Frank J. Rey, the village's Mayor, said of the closing.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 9, 1993, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article Feb. 24 about the General Motors plant in North Tarrytown, N.Y., misstated an agreement about the company's obligations. According to a G.M. spokeswoman, Margaret G. Holmes, the company promised to make certain payments in lieu of taxes from 1985 to 1995. It was not required to stay in North Tarrytown until 1995.

HEADLINE: Mulroney Quits Post in Canada; Urges 'Renewal'

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OTTAWA, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Brian Mulroney, Canada's 18th Prime Minister, who solidified free trade with the United States but failed to reinforce unity between English- and French-speaking Canadians, announced today that he is retiring after eight and a half years in office.
The Canadian leader, who has been dogged by a weak economy, high unemployment and the lowest support in opinion polls for any Prime Minister in this century, said he was stepping down to make way for a leadership convention in mid-June and a rapid makeover of his Progressive Conservative party for elections this fall. 
 There was no indication that Mr. Mulroney had been forced out; in fact in recent weeks, the Conservatives have been rising in the polls, though they still trail the Liberal Party. Mr. Mulroney said in an interview that he had decided to resign because he had run out of enthusiasm for politics, and felt the mantle should be handed over to someone else.
 
Those in the Wings
 Among those seen as potential leaders of the party are a group of younger standouts who are likely to vie for power at the party convention.
They include Defense Minister Kim Campbell, 45, from Vancouver, British Columbia, who would be the first woman to head the party; Communications Minister Henry Perrin Beatty, 43, from Toronto, and Environment Minister Jean Charest, 35, from Sherbrooke, Quebec.
One of Mr. Mulroney's main achievements was the successful negotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement with the United States and Mexico. He said in interviews today that his departure would not affect ratification of the treaty, and pledged to get it through Parliament before the convention.
"Renewal is the very essence of democracy," the 53-year-old Prime Minister declared, saying two full terms in office were "just about the maximum length of time a political leader should serve as Prime Minister." Mr. Mulroney has had the fifth-longest term among Canada's Prime Ministers.
Mr. Mulroney, whose election victories in 1984 and 1988 produced the first back-to-back majorities for a Canadian leader in 35 years, will become the first elected Conservative chief to voluntarily turn over a Conservative Government to a successor.
His decision, announced to close friends last night at a dinner at 24 Sussex Drive, his offical residence, ended months of speculation about his future. He will serve as Prime Minister until the new leader is chosen and remain a member of the House of Commons until the elections.
 
A Very Busy Man
 The decision writes finis to a remarkable political career. Mr. Mulroney created a new Tory coalition of Quebec nationalists and western conservatives, and led Canada through wrenching economic change, not only lowering import barriers but also reforming the tax structure, deregulating energy, transporation and financial services, cutting the budget deficit and supporting the zero-inflation policy of the Bank of Canada.
The change was as radical as what President Clinton envisages for the United States. "I was exactly like Clinton 10 years ago," Mr. Mulroney said in an interview in his office in the House of Commons after the announcement. He had spoken with President Clinton earlier in the day, as well as with former Presidents George Bush and Ronald Reagan, and Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts. "I approached my problems then with exactly the same enthusiasm as President Clinton is approaching his problems today."
But, he added, explaining some of the thinking behind today's decision: "I think that after 10 years you lose some of that enthusiasm, and you shouldn't. My enthusiasm didn't evaporate; I spent it in great causes for my country."
Yet so sharp are the divisions caused by some of his enthusiasms that his political opponents expressed little of the customary good will shown to departing national leaders.
 
Enough, Say Opponents
 "Two terms of Brian Mulroney has brought the country and the Conservative Party to their knees," said Sheila Copps, deputy leader of the Liberal Party. Audrey McLaughlin, leader of the New Democratic Party, said Mr. Mulroney was leaving a "devastating record for Canada."
Although some influential Conservatives have called on Mr. Mulroney to bow out, there was no indication that he was actually pushed.
Unlike the situation with Margaret Thatcher in Britain, who fell out of favor with her Conservative party and was replaced as Prime Minister by her protege John Major, Mr. Mulroney is handing over the reins at a time when Conservative fortunes in Canada appear on the rise.
The economy is recovering slowly, which has moved the party into second place in the polls, behind the Liberals. But it is a distant second: The latest Gallup poll showed the Liberals, led by Jean Chretien, at 49 percent and the Tories with only 21 percent.
Still, many in the party had privately regarded Mr. Mulroney, once the most positive Tory asset, as a burden. For many he personalized the low standings in the polls.
The Prime Minister said he had been considering resignation for two years, but had been delayed by the problems over English and French unity and other challenges.
 
A Question of Timing
 If he had waited longer, the party would not have had enough time to sell a new leader to the electorate in November; to have acted sooner would have been tacit admission that the rejection of a constitutional referendum last October was a rejection of him that needed redressing.
The change in leadership is unlikely to alter the Government's position on the North American Free Trade Agreement. Even though the accord is unpopular in Canada, the Government is expected to push ratification through Commons this spring -- and has the votes to do it.
Mr. Chretien, the Liberal leader, has been vague about his plans for the trade pact, but most analysts say he will not scrap it if he becomes Prime Minister. Mrs. McLaughlin, of the New Democrats, the third party, has been absolutely clear -- she would tear up the agreement.
The June convention promises to have many of the attributes of an American nominating convention. More than 8,000 party loyalists will attend, and Mr. Mulroney said he expected it to be "civilized." He declined to say whom he would support.
The last time the Tories elected a leader was in 1983, when they chose Mr. Mulroney over former Prime Minister Joe Clark. Less than a week ago Mr. Clark, who served as External Affairs Minister and most recently as Minister of Constitutional Affairs, announced his own retirement from politics.
 
Speaking in Two Tongues
 Mr. Mulroney's departure could weaken the Conservative party in Quebec and lead to further gains by the separatist Bloc Quebecois. He is a bilingual Quebecer, born in Baie Comeau, on the north shore of the St. Lawrence. His parents were Irish immigrants, his father an electrician in a lumber mill.
While many English-speaking Canadians expressed a visceral dislike of him, he was admired in Quebec, and it is unlikely a successor will be able to campaign as strongly in the province.
As Prime Minister Mr. Mulroney sought to bridge the rift between Quebec and the rest of the country by negotiating first the Meech Lake Accord and then the Charlottetown Accord, under which Quebec's distinctness would have been recognized in the Constitution. The collapse of these two agreements, the latter in the constitutional referendum in October, were among his greatest disappointments.
Mr. Mulroney said he had no specific plans for the future. Last year he weighed and then rejected the possibility of seeking to become Secretary General of the United Nations.

Chronology/Photo: "Lawyer and Politician"
1939 -- Born on March 20 in Baie Comeau, Quebec.
1972 -- Made a partner at Montreal's largest law firm, Howard, Cate, Ogilvy.
1976 -- Loses Progressive Conservative Party leadership race to Joe Clark.
1977 -- Appointed president of Iron Ore Company of Canada.
1983 -- Elected leader of the Progressive Conservative Party.
1984 -- Becomes Canada's Prime Minister after his party wins a record number of seats (211 of 282 members of Parliament).
1985 -- Begins negotiations with the Americans United States on free trade.
1988 -- Wins second majority mandate (169 of 295 seats).
1989 -- Signs a free trade agreement with United States.
1991 -- Signs an acid rain agreement with United States.
1992 -- The Charlottetown accords, under Quebec's distinctness would have been recognized in the Constitution, is voted down in a national referendum on Oct. 26.
1993 -- Announces on Feb. 24 that he is resigning as Tory leader and Prime Minister, with rating in public opinion polls in single digits in a country troubled by high unemployment and a three-year recession.

LENGTH: 1126 words

HEADLINE: New Momentum for the Race to Refinance

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
All across America, corporate managers, municipal officials and homeowners are scrambling to take advantage of the sharp decline in long-term interest rates to levels that most have never before seen. They are trading in their old debt for new, and in some cases are cutting their interest costs in half, a move that will save them money and give the economy a lift.
The race to refinance, under way for more than a year, gained new momentum in the last week as investors focused on the deficit-cutting plans in the economic program President Clinton presented to Congress. The rate on 30-year Treasury bonds, a commonly used yardstick, has plunged below 7 percent for the first time in 16 years. On Tuesday it hit 6.82 percent. Yesterday, the bonds finished the day at 6.88 percent.
 
Lower Rates 'Like Magic'
 "Declining interest rates over time are like magic," said Allen Sinai, the chief economist at the Boston Company. "They never fail eventually to revive a sick economy so long as inflation remains quiet." 
 He and other economists estimate that the lower rates will not only make the economy grow faster, but will be especially useful in lessening the drag on the economy from the higher taxes proposed in the Clinton economic plan.
The lineup of borrowers reaching for the lower-priced money ranges from companies like Time Warner and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation to governments like New York City and Massachusetts to homeowners and utilities.
The News Corporation, for example, owner of 20th Century Fox and a leading newspaper publisher worldwide, sold $500 million in new bonds on Tuesday at 7.5 percent, well below the rates of its existing debt. In the last eight weeks, the company has sold $2 billion in new corporate bonds.
Paying less for the money it borrows allows the News Corporation, like other companies, to raise its earnings and improve its balance sheet over time, opening the door to more investment and hiring.
"Every corporate chief financial officer ought to be looking at this," said Roberto C. Goizueta, chairman and chief executive of the Coca-Cola Company. He said that his company was considering refinancing some of its debt.
Cities, towns and utilities are doing the same in the tax-exempt municipal market, where interest rates are about a third lower than taxable market rates. Massachusetts, for example, on Tuesday sold $890 million of bonds. That will allow it to retire higher interest rate debt for a saving of $45 million over the next three years.
New York City is preparing to refinance some of its more costly borrowings in the next several months. "This will substantially improve the economics for us," said Darcy Bradbury, the Deputy Comptroller for Finance for the city.
The Intermountain Power Agency of Murray, Utah, just refinanced $670 million of its debt at lower rates, allowing it to pass along savings of $3.8 million a year to its customers in financially hard-hit Southern California. Savings on utility bills will allow customers to spend the money in other ways.
John Sager, the company's manager, said his colleagues were skeptical that rates would get low enough "to pull the trigger." But this week they did.
 
A Rage to Refinance
 Consumers are flocking to banks and mortgage brokers to lower their monthly mortgage payments.
The flood of consumers seeking less costly mortgages was evident yesterday morning at Countrywide Credit, a lender in Pasadena, Calif. The number of calls seeking to refinance mortgages jumped to 190 an hour, up from 150 just a week ago. And the 150 was three times the normal rate.
Many economists predict that the savings on mortgage payments will be one of the first sources of spending to foster growth this year.
But while economists are counting on lower rates to help revive the economy, not everyone is applauding. The sharp fall in short-term interest rates in recent years has already squeezed people on fixed incomes, mostly the elderly. Many of them had turned to longer-term investments to raise their incomes, since rates there had not fallen as much. The decline in longer-term rates now is reducing their alternatives.
Jeri Mellon, 68, a retired hospital administrator and former nurse, had previously kept $50,000, about half her savings, in a certificate of deposit paying 9.5 percent. When that matured in 1991, she put her savings in National Fund, a bond mutual fund that pays 12 percent, giving her a $300 monthly income.
"There's no way in the world I could survive on the 4 or 5 percent I'd be receiving," in the C.D., said Ms. Mellon, of Henderson, Nev. "It's deplorable what's happening to people who've worked hard all our lives, saved money and now have to practically live on welfare to survive."
For the economy as a whole, however, lower rates are clearly a plus. But economists worry that the gain from the drop in interest rates will still not totally offset the restraining impact of Mr. Clinton's plan to reduce the deficit. Mr. Sinai, for one, said the plan could knock as much as a half a percentage point a year off expected economic growth in the the mid-1990's.
For the decline in rates to have any sustained impact, rates have to remain low, and that depends in the short term on the President's success in getting his program approved.
But for now, the markets are optimistic, and rates have continued their downward march.
Their decline is already making a huge difference to the corporate community. Profits of banks have soared, as they borrow more cheaply but cut their own lending rates more slowly.
Corporate borrowers, who set a monthly record in January, are seeing their profits and internal cash flow rise as their debt payments fall. The extra profit margin is giving many more confidence in the economy and the ability to invest.
For the News Corporation, like other companies, the lower-cost debt has led to an improved credit rating, which should further reduce their borrowing costs in the future.
 
Time Warner's Savings
 Time Warner has saved about $200 million a year with the $3.5 billion it has borrowed at low interest rates since December, according to a spokesman, Edward Adler.
Ms. Bradbury of New York City said the city would have to pay only 6 percent now on long-term city bonds, down from more than 7 percent that it paid nine months ago, and lower than the rates assumed in the city's budget. But she said the city would probably hold off on refinancings for at least a few months because it has a regularly scheduled borrowing in the next few weeks. But she is not worried about losing the chance to refinance other debt. "We feel relatively confident that this level of interest rates will last for several months," she said

HEADLINE: New York Unemployment Fund About to Run Out

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 24

 BODY:
The fund used to pay unemployment benefits in New York State will run out of money this week, and a Cuomo administration official today proposed a significant increase in business taxes to keep the system solvent.
New York is the fifth state whose unemployment insurance fund has gone into the red since the start of the national downturn in 1990. 
 The state will have to borrow $400 million from the Federal Government this year at an interest rate of 7.5 percent to continue paying benefits to New Yorkers who have lost their jobs, State Labor Commissioner John F. Hudacs said today. Mr. Hudacs stressed that recipients of unemployment benefits -- there are 290,000 people currently receiving regular benefits and 160,000 receiving extended benefits -- will not be hurt by the shortfall.
 
Employer's Tax Would Rise
 But in order to pay back the Federal loans and replenish the state fund to avoid further borrowing, Mr. Hudacs proposed raising the unemployment insurance taxes paid by businesses.
The new taxes would raise an additional $500 million in 1994, above the $1.6 billion employers in New York paid in 1992 in unemployment insurance taxes. The taxes are paid as a percentage of a company's payroll, varying according to a company's record of layoffs.
Under Mr. Hudacs's proposal, the unemployment insurance taxes paid by employers, which currently averages $316 a worker, would rise to an average of $399 in 1994, $450 in 1995 and $528 in 1996. The increases would be larger for companies with histories of heavy layoffs, meaning that seasonal industries like apparel, construction, tourism and canning would be particularly hard hit.
The tax increase requires the approval of the Legislature, and was greeted with considerable skepticism today in the Republican-controlled State Senate.
Even Mr. Hudacs's boss, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, has not formally endorsed the bill, leading some legislative aides to suggest that the Governor had allowed his surrogate to float a trial balloon while keeping some personal distance. Mr. Cuomo has vowed to oppose any broad-based tax increases this year.
Business leaders, who have considerable influence in the Senate, complained that the tax increase would ultimately be self-defeating, because it would cause companies to retrench and lay off more workers, which in turn would require the state to pay more in unemployment benefits.
"The best way to deal with the unemployment compensation problem is to deal with the unemployment problem," said Robert J. Bellafiore, director of communications for the Business Council of New York State. "And you can't make it easier to provide a job by making it more expensive to provide a job."
The insolvency of the unemployment insurance trust fund is just the latest sign that the national economic recovery, which is accelerating in other states, is moving at a very slow pace in New York.
The state's unemployment rate, which averaged 8.5 percent for 1992, rose to 9.3 percent last month, the highest rate during the economic downturn that economists say began in 1990; the recession officially ended in 1991. By comparison, the national unemployment rate was 7.4 percent for 1992 and 7.1 percent for January. Unemployment in New York City, which has 37 percent of the state's jobs, was 13.4 percent in January, a city record.
 
Something Missing in Upturn
 "This is a recovery without job creation," Mr. Hudacs said today.
When New York's unemployment insurance trust fund officially goes into the red, New York will join the funds of Connecticut, Massachusetts, Missouri, Michigan and the District of Columbia in the ranks of insolvency. Maine's fund is also expected to go broke this year.
State officials were not sure exactly which day the fund would be depleted. The fund, which held more than $3.4 billion at the end of 1988 had fallen to about $600,000 this morning. The state has been paying between $6 million and $11 million a day in unemployment benefits.
The erosion of the fund resulted from both an increase in the number of jobless New Yorkers and a decrease in their employers' payrolls -- and thus the tax base. The net result was that in 1991 and 1992, the state paid about $1.80 in unemployment benefits for every dollar in unemployment insurance taxes it collected.
 
Only Employers Pay
 The only other time New York's fund was depleted was in 1977, when the state had to borrow $336 million.
A 1935 Federal law established an unemployment insurance trust fund in every state. The fund is supported solely by employer taxes, with the rates varying from state to state as determined by the legislature.
New York's tax, which consists of three parts, currently ranges from a low of 2.5 percent to a high of 7 percent on the first $7,000 in wages paid to each employee. New York is one of 14 states that apply the tax only to the first $7,000 in wages, the lowest amount allowed by Federal law.
Employees who have worked in the state at least 20 of the last 52 weeks, who have been receiving at least $80 in average weekly wages and who lose their jobs by no fault of their own can qualify for unemployment benefits. They can receive about 50 percent of their wages, up to $300 a week in benefits, for a maximum of 26 weeks.
 
Bush Agreed to Rise
 Starting in 1991, Congress and President George Bush agreed to extend the benefits past 26 weeks, with the Federal Government raising money through employer taxes to pay for the extension. In New York, recipients can qualify for 20 weeks of extended Federal benefits, and the Clinton Administration is considering extending them even longer.
Mr. Hudacs's tax proposal would raise costs for employers in several ways. He would raise the taxable wage base to $8,500 from $7,000 in 1994, to 10,000 in 1995 and to $12,000 in 1996. He also would raise rates for two of the three components of the tax and would make the overall rate more reflective of a company's history of layoffs.
Mr. Hudacs warned that without such a plan, the state would have to "continue to borrow ad infinitum." And if another recession hits before the fund is replenished, he said, the state will face a severe problem.
 
U.S. Can Impose Tax
 If the state does not repay the loans on schedule, the Federal Government can impose business taxes of its own, to cover the interest as early as this fall and additional taxes to cover the principal in 1995.
But some business leaders and legislators suggested it would be less burdensome for businesses to pay the Federally imposed taxes than those recommended by Mr. Hudacs.
Senator James J. Lack, a Republican from East Northport, L.I., and the chairman of the Labor Committee, questioned whether the state needed to build the reserves in its unemployment insurance fund back up to pre-recession levels and whether it was wise to increase business taxes while the state is losing jobs.

HEADLINE: Japanese Cars Get British Accents

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BURNASTON, England

 BODY:
The Japanese auto makers, having entrenched themselves in the United States, are turning to what is perhaps the world's most hotly contested and most promising market: Europe.
Following the same basic strategy that helped push their share of the United States market to 30 percent from 20 percent during the last decade, Toyota, Nissan and Honda are starting to produce cars in large numbers in Europe. They are building efficient new plants in British towns like this one in the English Midlands, home to a $1 billion Toyota factory that opened in December. The goal, as it was in the United States, is to sidestep "voluntary" quotas that limit their exports from Japan. 
 As in the United States, their plants set standards for productivity and quality. They are also forcing rivals like Volkswagen, Peugeot, Renault, Mercedes-Benz, BMW and Fiat, as well as General Motors and Ford, to shape up or risk withering away.
 
Setting a New Standard
 "The presence of the Japanese provides an entirely new benchmark for manufacturing in Europe," said Daniel T. Jones, a professor of motor industry management at the Cardiff Business School at the University of Wales.
Despite a deep slump in car sales in Europe that is expected to persist this year, forcing cutbacks and layoffs among the European companies, the Japanese auto makers are banking on a rebound starting next year.
Most forecasters predict that the European market will grow 2.5 percent a year or more for the rest of the decade, faster than in Japan or in the United States. The manufacturers also see long-term growth coming from the formerly Communist nations of Central and Eastern Europe.
In addition to its car plant here, Toyota opened an engine factory in Wales in September. Honda started producing cars in Swindon, in western England, in October, and owns 20 percent of Rover, the British auto maker. Nissan has had a plant in Sunderland, in northern England, for six years and is trying to more than double production there by next year. In its slumping home market, by contrast, Nissan has announced plans to shut down what was once its flagship Japanese factory.
 
 
Room to Grow
 Of the 13.2 million cars sold in Europe last year, about 11 percent, or 1.45 million, were Japanese, all but several hundred thousand of them imported from Japan. By the middle of the decade, the Japanese plants in Britain will have the capacity to make at least 600,000 cars a year. These Japanese "transplants" plan to export 70 percent or more of their production to Continental Europe.
"From Europe, the view is that the U.K. is the aircraft carrier from which the Japanese can attack the Continent," Mr. Jones said.
Some analysts think Japanese production in Britain will ultimately go even higher, perhaps to one million sometime after the turn of the century, giving the Japanese potential sales of two million units or more even if they do not increase exports from Japan when the quotas expire in 1999. The European Community has pledged that by 1999 its automobile market will be fully open to foreign competition. The quota, which is renegotiated each year, was around 1.2 million last year, and will probably be lower this year to reflect the downturn in the overall market.
Cars made in Britain are not counted in the quota, but there are lingering questions about how a big rise in sales would be received in France and Italy, which have long had strict protectionist policies on autos.
 "The Japanese have invested a lot of money in the U.K., and they did so in an atmosphere of restraint regarding exports from Japan to Europe," said Karl E. Ludvigsen, a former executive of the Ford Motor Company who now runs Euromotor Reports Ltd., a consulting firm in London. "They felt that the restraints would continue for some time and if they wanted to get the most from the European market they would have to produce here."
European auto makers are worried not just by the potential scale of the Japanese plants in Britain, but by their efficiency and the ensuing flexibility that Toyota, Nissan and Honda can gain in pricing. Having built their factories from the ground up, with the latest in technology, and having found British workers quick to adopt the Japanese approach to car building, the plants in Britain are a match in efficiency, or nearly so, for their counterparts in Japan. (The Japanese companies said the flexibility of the work force in Britain and its being an English-speaking country were crucial reasons for putting plants there rather than on the Continent.)
"We are up with Japan or rapidly catching them in all aspects of our business," said John Cushnagham, the production director at Nissan's Sunderland factory.
Mr. Jones said that at this plant, 18 man-hours were needed to weld, paint and assemble a car, compared with 17 hours at its best plants in Japan. By contrast, most European plants require 30 to 35 man-hours, although a few, including Ford's most efficient European plant in Germany, have brought this down to the mid-20's.
 In response, auto makers in Europe are investing in new plants that they hope will keep them competitive. They are adopting Japanese-style management and production techniques to improve quality and productivity. And in some cases they are merging or forging joint ventures.
 
General Motors in Germany
 General Motors opened a $600 million plant in eastern Germany in September, drawing on its experience in a joint venture factory with Toyota in Fremont, Calif., to reduce production times and costs.
To respond more rapidly to changing consumer demand, Peugeot is trying to reduce development times for new cars from four and a half years to three, the Japanese standard. Renault of France and Volvo of Sweden are working closely together and for several years have been discussing a merger to bolster their finances and technology.
 The Japanese push comes as most auto makers in Europe are reeling from a recession that is expected to push car sales down at least 5 percent this year, to 12.5 million. Ford said in December that it would cut nearly 10,000 jobs in Europe this year, or more than 10 percent of its work force. Volkswagen said it would cut its work force by 30,000, or more than 10 percent, over several years.
But the Japanese auto makers, too, will be restricted in their ability to begin a full-scale assault on Europe. Weakness in Japan and sluggishness in the United States have sapped profits, leaving them with little additional money to put into efforts here.
At the same time, fearing that Italy, France and others might put up trade barriers even on British-made vehicles, the Japanese are clearly taking a go-slow approach and trying to play down the threat they represent to indigenous competitors.
 "We're not a big player by any definition," said Bryan Jackson, the director of corporate affairs for Toyota Motor Manufacturing U.K. "There are some very big players in Europe who make very good products, and we don't see ourselves so much competing with them as sharing in the growth of the market."
 
Better Days Seen for Japanese
 Most analysts project that the Japanese share of the overall European market will rise over the next five to seven years to about 16 percent, from 11 percent now.
The most encouraging statistics for the Japanese come from nations that do not impose individual limits on Japanese imports, in most cases because they have no significant domestic auto industries. In those nations -- Belgium, Denmark, Greece, Ireland, Luxembourg, Austria, Switzerland and the Scandinavian countries -- Japanese manufacturers had a market share of 28.3 percent in 1990, according to Euromotor Reports.
By comparison, in Germany, where there are no limits except for vigorous competition from the domestic producers, the Japanese share in 1990 was 15.9 percent. In Italy, where there are strict protectionist limits, their share in 1990 was 2 percent.
In contrast to their strategy in the United States, where the Japanese spent years competing only in small and less-expensive cars, they are going after a wide swath of the European market right from the start, with subcompacts like Nissan's Micra and mid-sized sedans like the Honda Accord, Nissan Primera and Toyota Carina.
The Japanese have already overcome their first big hurdle: convincing consumers that they can build cars with the tighter handling and less angular styling that European drivers are used to. All the companies have design studios or consumer-research operations in Europe.
Last year, Nissan's new subcompact, the Micra, won the European Car of the Year award, the first time that the prize, which is awarded by automotive journalists, has been given to a Japanese car.

HEADLINE: Democrats Aim for Vote by April On General Budget and Job Plan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Clinton Administration officials and Democratic lawmakers expressed confidence today that by early April Congress would approve a general budget framework and measures to give the economy a quick stimulus.
The tougher part of President Clinton's economic plan, tax increases and spending cuts intended to lower the budget deficit, will not be voted on conclusively until this summer at the earliest and possibly not until the fall, the officials and lawmakers said. 
 "We're dealing with a very small window of opportunity," Leon E. Panetta, Mr. Clinton's budget director, said in an interview. "You've got to move quickly. If you don't, it will die a death of a thousand bites."
Evidence of just that kind of nibbling came at a hearing of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, called by Senator J. Bennett Johnston, the Louisiana Democrat who heads the panel, to give himself and colleagues from energy-producing states the opportunity to denounce Mr. Clinton's proposal for a new tax on all forms of fuel.
 
National Sales Tax Preferred
 Senator Johnston said he preferred a form of national sales tax, or value added tax, which he said would raise more revenue and be fairer.
Mr. Johnston, whose committee has no jurisdiction over taxes, received some support from other Senators, including Mark O. Hatfield, a Republican from Oregon, where hydroelectric prices would rise, and Richard C. Shelby, an Alabama Democrat whose state depends heavily on coal for electricity.
But the consensus at a luncheon meeting of Democratic Senators was that a tax on all forms of fuel was the least politically painful way to raise taxes. Mr. Johnston is a strong supporter of Mr. Clinton, and colleagues said his opposition to a new energy tax could probably be overcome.
One element of the President's economic stimulus proposals -- an extension of unemployment benefits to people who have been out of a job more than six months -- was approved by the House of Representatives today by a vote of 254 to 161.
Under the bill, which would renew a law about to expire, workers who exhaust their standard 26 weeks of benefits would be eligible for benefits for up to 26 more weeks. As many as two million workers could be helped by the latest figures, Congress estimates.
 
Defections in the Ranks
 The White House initially wanted a final vote in mid-March on Mr. Clinton's stimulus package, which includes tax cuts for business investments and new spending for highways and other public works projects, and a vote a month later on a budget resolution.
But, faced with defections in their ranks, Democratic leaders in the Senate and the House, with the concurrence of the White House, decided Tuesday evening to have both votes just before the Easter recess, which begins April 2. The budget vote will come first, the leaders said.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, said today that the change in schedule was a sign the economic plan was in trouble, but Democrats disputed that.
Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington and Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said support for the plan among Democrats was solid. Random interviews with a dozen Democratic lawmakers validated that view.
The main reason for the schedule change, Democrats said, was to provide political cover for lawmakers who did not want to be seen as expanding Federal spending before they dealt with the deficit.
The budget resolution will merely set the overall figures for spending and taxes, not the politically trickier specifics of which programs would be cut and which taxes raised. Still, Democrats intend to use the vote on the resolution to emphasize their determination to cut the budget.
Some Senators suggested that Mr. Clinton had miscalculated by thinking that popular spending and tax cut measures were immediately needed to give lawmakers an incentive to support long-term deficit reduction.
But Roger C. Altman, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, said the new spending and tax reductions "had nothing to do with sugar-coating the medicine."
"The stimulus," he said in an interview, "is an insurance package against an economic relapse."

HEADLINE: Cheers From States for Clinton's Plan

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
President Clinton's economic plan is drawing praise from a bipartisan collection of governors and from experts on state fiscal policy, who say that for the first time in years Washington has stopped trying to shift costly programs to the states.
Of two dozen Governors who responded to inquiries over the past week, Democrats uniformly approved of the President's plan, and even Republicans who opposed it on the ground that it would increase taxes on income and energy nevertheless welcomed its proposed infusions of Federal money. 
 Gov. Jim Edgar of Illinois, a Republican, applauded Mr. Clinton's "infrastructure initiatives to stimulate economic recovery." And Gov. Pete Wilson of California, another Republican, said he found "much to like, much to applaud," including plans to reduce the deficit and reorganize welfare as a two-year job-training program.
 
Reversal of Recent Policy
 The experts in fiscal policy said Mr. Clinton's plan would radically change 12 years of Federal-state relations, a period in which the Federal Government transferred more responsibilities to the states than at any other time in American history, according to the United States Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations.
As Governor of Arkansas, Mr. Clinton spearheaded some of the governors' losing battles over shifting programs to states without paying for them. As a Presidential candidate, he complained that the Federal Government was creating too many inflexible and costly programs that reduced a state's ability to cope with social and financial problems it considered more pressing.
Mr. Clinton is not proposing to roll back 12 years of Federal mandates, but he does not add new ones. In addition, his economic stimulus package calls for spending about $15 billion in the states in the fiscal year that ends Sept. 30, including $3.75 billion for transportation, $850 million to comply with Federal clean-water standards, $300 million for immunizations and $1 billion for summer employment.
In the 1980's, by comparison, the Reagan and Bush Administrations reduced Federal aid to the states by 15 percent and to local governments by 55 percent, after accounting for inflation.
"It looks like a new ball game for the states," said Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States at the Rockefeller Institute in Albany. "At least in the first inning, the Federal Government is proposing to help the states instead of shifting burdens to them."
 
'Element of Fairness'
 Arthur L. Jones, a deputy press secretary to Mr. Clinton, said, "It had always been the President's idea to have the element of fairness measured at every level, including the relationship between the Federal Government and the states, and I think that has been accomplished."
William T. Pound, executive director of the National Conference of State Legislatures, noted that the Clinton plan would not rely heavily on increased excise taxes, unlike Federal budgets in the Reagan and Bush years. Excise taxes, like those on beer, are relatively more important to states than to the Federal Government, he said, and an increase in Federal excise taxes tends to decrease consumption and thereby reduce state tax collections.
In 1990, for example, the Federal Government raised taxes on distilled spirits, wine, beer, cigarettes and gasoline that were estimated to decrease state tax revenues by $4.3 billion over five years.
Even though the Clinton plan would raise taxes on energy -- an increase that distresses many governors -- Mr. Pound said it was important to the states that the tax was broad-based and not a specific one on gasoline.
"It's a pretty good plan," Mr. Pound said. "No, strike the 'pretty.' It's a good plan."
 
Looking at the Benefits
 Of the two dozen governors who were interviewed or who responded through their spokesmen, nearly all said the Clinton plan had something to offer their states. Gov. George V. Voinovich of Ohio, a Republican, said full financing of Head Start, the educational program for young children in low-income families, would save his state millions of dollars. He also praised the proposed job training for people leaving the military, which he said would help 100,000 Ohioans in the next few years.
Even in Connecticut, which is facing a $400 million deficit in the current fiscal year and stands to lose heavily from cutbacks in military spending, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said he supported most of Mr. Clinton's plan.
"We'll get hurt," Mr. Weicker, an independent, said of the cuts in military spending and the higher taxes on wealthy individuals. "But having said that, I am not going to lead the whining parade. This is a national problem, and we have to commit to its solution."
Still, the praise for Mr. Clinton's plan was hardly unqualified. Some Governors said they feared that new income and energy taxes could harm their regions and choke off the economic recovery, though none complained about the $7 billion proposed for public-works projects or the $6.5 billion for investment tax credits for businesses.
And the Governors and public-policy experts cautioned that the plan had to be considered in context.
"What we heard the other night was the first part of the President's plan," said Brian M. Roherty, executive director of the National Association of State Budget Officers. "But the trailing parts -- his budget and health-care plan -- are the ones that could have the most impact on states."
 
Gains and Losses
 No state has yet calculated the full financial impact of the Clinton plan. Aside from the increased Federal spending on certain programs, some states could see an increase in state tax revenues because they link their income-tax rates to Federal ones. Others would lose some revenue because they let taxpayers deduct Federal tax payments from taxable state income.
"States may gain or lose in some individual parts of the program," Mr. Gold said. "But the gains and loses tend to offset each other."
Higher energy taxes, which would include an estimated 7-cent-a-gallon increase in the price of gasoline, would disproportionately hurt Western states, Mr. Gold said. On the other hand, higher Federal taxes would do more harm to states with high per-capita incomes, and the five wealthiest states are on the East Coast: New Jersey, Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Hampshire and New York.
"On balance the states' most important consideration is what this plan will do for the national economy," Mr. Gold said. "If the national economy becomes more stable and grows, that is very positive for state resources."

HEADLINE: A Simmering Argument Despite Two Similar Pasts

BYLINE: By CRAIG WOLFF

 BODY:
John Rodriguez and Angel Jimenez shared common problems that could have bound them as friends. The two 15-year-olds were both in a special-education program for emotionally troubled students at Junior High School 25. Both came from families that have struggled to overcome financial troubles while trying to give their children an education. Both seemed to be searching for a place for themselves on the Lower East Side.
Somehow, they wound up enemies, consumed by the sort of adolescent rivalry that sometimes explodes if left unchecked. School officials and classmates said the stabbing of Mr. Jimenez was a final confrontation in a feud between the two youths that had been simmering since September. No one claimed to know how the bad blood began. 
 As family friends poured into the East Sixth Street apartment of the victim's mother, Evelyn Jimenez, last night, relatives of Mr. Rodriguez said that Mr. Rodriguez had long been the victim of Mr. Jimenez's attacks and taunts.
The mother of the suspect, Rosa Vargas, said her son had been beaten by Mr. Jimenez at least twice. She said that two months ago she had gone to the police and to the school seeking an order of protection, but she had been told that because the case involved minors who were not related, no such order could be given.
Late yesterday morning, shortly after the teen-agers attended the same shop class and only minutes before the stabbing, Mr. Rodriguez's mother said that Mr. Rodriguez called his father on the phone to say that he wanted to leave the school and that his life had been threatened.
 
'Seemed to Be Building'
 William Ubinas, the school district superintendent, said that Ms. Vargas had gone to the Seventh Precinct station house "at some point" in the last several months to show them photographs of Mr. Rodriguez beaten up. But he said it was unclear who had done the beating.
"One thing is certain," Mr. Ubinas said. "This seemed to be building for this young man."
In the family's three-bedroom apartment in the Lillian Wald Houses on East Sixth Street, the victim's mother sat on a couch sobbing heavily and railing against the dangers in the schools.
"How many kids have to die before they do something about security?" Mrs. Jimenez said. "It's safer in the streets than in the school."
She showed a recent photograph of her son, a husky young man in black jeans and a yellow T-shirt. And she said that she often worried about sending her three other children outside to the street, including Angel's fraternal twin, Luis.
In the boys' bedroom, there were two bright red mountain bikes, a collection of matchbox cars and works of graffiti-style art.
An uncle, Raymond Jimenez, said that Mr. Jimenez's father had last worked as a parking garage attendant, but he was now unemployed. He said Mr. Jimenez had sometimes gotten into fights, but he said no one in the family knew of any kind of running feud.
 
Account of Harassment
 Not far away and also in tears, an aunt of the suspect, Odalys Rodriguez, stood on a stairwell outside the family's two-bedroom apartment in a walkup tenement building at 143 Ludlow Street, just two blocks from the school.
She said that the victim was the ringleader of a small group of youths who had noticed that her nephew had a slight, gangly build, and had marked him as a "pushover." Her account was echoed in interviews with six students outside the school yesterday.
She said the family, frustrated in their attempts to get protection from the police, recently kept Mr. Rodriguez out of school for two weeks.
A police investigator who insisted on anonymity said the Rodriguez family had filed complaints that the youth had been harassed, but the complaints had nothing to do with Mr. Jimenez.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Rodriguez after his arrest in the slaying of Angel Jimenez. (Steve Hart for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S., Seeing Progress, Acts to Restart Peru Aid

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration will take part in a $2 billion loan program for Peru and is moving toward extending economic aid to that country, officials said today.
Administration officials said the loan would be used to help Peru become current on loans to multilateral financial institutions like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. The officials added that the loan would be the first economic aid given to Peru since the United States cut off aid to protest President Alberto K. Fujimori's seizure of nearly dictatorial power in April. 
 The officials said the loan and direct aid would be in response to Mr. Fujimori's changes to tame rampant inflation and keep debts to the World Bank and Inter-American Development Bank from worsening.
In addition Administration officials said, Mr. Fujimori has held elections in recent months for a Constituent Assembly. This week his Government pledged to widen access for monitors checking allegations of human rights abuses by security forces.
 
2 Ministers at State Dept.
 On Tuesday, Economic Minister Jorge Camet and Justice Minister Fernando Vega Santa Gadea met with State Department and White House officials. Administration officials said the ministers had pledged that their Government would carry out steps like allowing the International Committee of the Red Cross access to all political detainees, requesting advisory services from the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, holding regular meetings with domestic rights groups and stopping the the harassment of representatives of international groups like Americas Watch and Amnesty International.
"We think these are important human rights commitments and, hopefully, another step toward the re-establishment of full democracy in Peru," a State Department official said.
Administration officials described the bridge loan, which is being made by the United States and Japan, as a means to go around rules by international lending institutions against rescheduling debt. The $2 billion will be transferred to an account controlled by the Peruvian Government, which will pay the money to I.M.F. and the World Bank, which turns around and lends money to Peru. Peru then uses that money to repay the United States and the Japanese. The whole transaction will take no more than a few hours, officials said.
They payments on the loan to the I.M.F. and the World Bank are important because they let Peru re-establish a sense of credit worthiness with international financial institutions. Multilateral institutions have stopped extending new credits to Peru since former President Alan Garcia sharply limited payments on loans in 1989.

HEADLINE: West's Drought Ends, the Political Terrain Altered

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24

 BODY:
With yet another winter storm having pounded the West Coast Tuesday, creating mudslides, urban flooding and towering snow drifts in the High Sierra, the drought that has punished the West for six years has come to a drenching end.
After two months of relentless rains and snows, Gov. Pete Wilson made it official today by declaring the drought over because the reservoirs are expected to reach 90 percent of average for the month by April. "The end of rationing does not mean the end of conservation," he said. 
 The drought left behind a fundamentally changed political landscape across the West, breaking the lock that agriculture has long held on water and diverting more to cities and to environmental protection. Despite raging rivers and filling reservoirs, many California farmers say they now face years of hardship under a "regulated drought" in irrigation.
Increasingly, legal and economic barriers against transferring water from farm use are coming down -- in Colorado, Utah, Arizona, Nevada and now, most dramatically, California. It is a trend that is likely to quicken under the Clinton Administration.
 
Nowhere to Look
 "There is no place else to look for water now, so the only solution is to move around water already in use," said David H. Getches, an expert in Western water law at the University of Colorado School of Law in Boulder.
For now, though, there is too much water. Since December, rain and snowstorms have blanketed the Western United States and Mexico from the Pacific Coast to the Rocky Mountains, causing flooding in Las Vegas, Los Angeles and San Francisco and crop damage in the Arizona desert.
Since Jan. 1, Phoenix has had more rain than perennially soggy Seattle. Some 3,500 people were evacuated today along a 90-mile stretch of the raging Gila River in Yuma County.
Rain and snow are well above average through much of the West except for pockets in Washington, Oregon, Idaho and Montana, said Anthony Willardson, associate director of the Western States Water Council, which represents the governors of 16 states.
On Friday, Governor Wilson declared an emergency in Los Angeles County after flooding killed four people and swamped homes. In Northern California, the snow shut down Interstate 80 on Saturday, cutting the main route between San Francisco and Reno. On Tuesday, rain caused mudslides in the Santa Cruz Mountains south of the San Francisco Bay Area. More rain is forecast.
 
Deep Snow in Mountains
 Most water used by California cities, industries and farms comes from the runoff from snow in the mountains, which is captured in reservoirs and channeled south and west in great aqueducts. According to the California Department of Water Resources, the water content of the snowpack on Feb. 18 was more than 150 percent of the historical average statewide and seven times what it was in the worst of the drought in 1991. Los Angeles and many other cities have lifted restrictions.
More than two feet of snow fell on the 7,000-foot Huntington Lake area of the Sierra, above Fresno, last weekend, sending drifts over resort cabins; another two feet fell Monday.
But in the valley below, the snow means nothing but frustration for farmers like Larry C. Turnquist in Cantua Creek. Like hundreds of other farmers in the Westlands Water District, he can see snow in the mountains but can expect little benefit.
Farmers in the southern part of the Central Valley have been told they will get only 25 percent of normal irrigation water this year from the Federal Central Valley Project because of new laws and rules that divert water to protect fisheries and repair environmental damage to wetlands. Mr. Turnquist says he will have to fallow much of his land and lay off hands.
 
Alliance Breaks Down
 The drought accelerated forces that had been building for years as the West urbanized, forging a new alliance between urban and environmental interests. The once powerful political alliance between cities and farmers that has long pushed for new dam projects has broken down.
"The next decade and beyond represents a different climate in which agricultural and urban interests will not be 100 percent in lockstep," said Patricia Mulroy, general manager of the Las Vegas Valley Water District and chairwoman of the newly formed Western Urban Water Coalition. "They are essentially competitors for the same scarce resource."
Odd new allies have emerged. Water authorities in thirsty Southern California found themselves in league with their arch enemies in Northern California and the environmental movement to fight the farmers, who consume more than 80 percent of California's available surface water.
And last year, urban water districts in the West broke ranks with rural ones and supported a bill in Congress that revamped the Bureau of Reclamation's Central Valley Project, California's largest water system.
 
Farmers Paying More
 The bill, sponsored by Representative George Miller of California and Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, both Democrats, made farmers pay more for water, diverted more to protect endangered species like the winter-run salmon and created a kind of free market in water. The bill also included nearly $1 billion to complete the Central Utah Project, originally meant for agriculture but now redesigned mainly to supply Salt Lake City and aid the environment.
In addition, last December the California Water Resources Control Board, in an effort to repair environmental damage in the San Joaquin Delta and San Francisco Bay, ordered further reductions on water to farms.
"What is more revolutionary than water transfers is the elevation of wildlife to a status equal to other uses," said Marc Reisner, a San Francisco author who crusades against what he sees as water waste by farmers.
But farmers see unfairness in all this, particularly in the Westlands Water District, a region the size of Rhode Island that produces tomatoes, cotton and other crops. The district's 650 farms rely on Central Valley water, pumped south from the delta. Other farms that had original water rights before the project was built in the 1940's have first claim on the water.
But those like Larry Turnquist who contracted for the new water find their allocation cut to 25 percent of normal because of the new rules, though continued snow and rain may raise it to 40 percent. Mr. Turnquist has struggled to survive the drought years, spending $165,000 on wells to replace lost surface water, fallowing land and, this year, planting only tomatoes and cotton. With water uncertain, he says, banks are reluctant to lend for planting.
 
Calamity Is Predicted
 He agreed there were environmental problems but says the farmers have been political victims: "Congress has a mental attitude that it is important to be environmentally correct, and fish reign supreme."
Not far away, in Riverdale, Daniel Errotabere, general partner of the family-run Errotabere Ranches, says he laid off one-third of the hands on his 3,000-acre farm and foresees calamity for the region, already suffering unemployment around 20 percent.
Such complaints get no sympathy in Los Angeles, 210 miles to the south. Michael J. Gage, chairman of the board of the politically powerful Metropolitan Water District of Southern California, the wholesaler that serves 15 million urbanites, says more efficient farming is long overdue.
"Agriculture is producing more than it did 10 or 20 years ago with the same water," he said. "But it's clear they still resist the best management practices. Even if the drought is over, Californians have learned that water is a finite resource."

HEADLINE: Europeans Welcoming U.S. Help in the Balkans

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Even before President Clinton's expected announcement of a decision to airdrop relief supplies to civilians in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Western European leaders welcomed it today as a sign that the United States was not going to leave them alone with the seemingly impossible task of stopping the war in the Balkans.
Both the French and British Foreign Ministers called Mr. Clinton's move "good news" today, and Prime Minister John Major of Britain met with Mr. Clinton in the White House. But European leaders also see risk as well as consolation in the President's decision. 
 "This is a big military involvement by the Americans," said David Howell, the Conservative chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee in the British Parliament. "It's very dangerous."
It would be most dangerous of all, some diplomats said, if it failed to have any effect on the fighting. A European diplomat summed up the stakes this way: "The Americans are now in the game; American prestige is engaged."
 
More Active Role Unclear
 What is unclear, to the Europeans as well as to the Serbian forces whom the Western allies hold responsible for most of the fighting, is whether the airdrops represent a step by the United States toward active military involvement -- peacemaking, which the Europeans have given lip service to but shied away from up to now.
"The Serbs know now that the Europeans are not going to get involved militarily," a diplomat said today. "But the Serbs don't know what the Clinton Administration might do."
The British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said in Paris that he welcomed the prospect that the United States would now be taking part in a relief effort to which both Britain and France had already committed thousands of soldiers serving with United Nations forces in the Balkans.
The implication of remarks like these from British and French officials in recent days was that the European allies had not just been sitting on their hands watching the belligerents kill one another, and that the United States would now find out for itself just how hard it was to get them to stop.
Neither Britain nor France has indicated willingness to take part in the planned airdrop missions to Muslim areas in eastern Bosnia and Herzegovina. Diplomats said the reason was that if Serbian forces there fired on the American C-130 planes dropping supplies, and their escort planes fired back, the Serbs might take revenge on British and French soldiers in the United Nations forces on the ground.
 
Yugoslav Army Protests
 "American interference is becoming increasingly drastic and unbearable in Yugoslavia," the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav Army said in a statement in Belgrade today, warning that it would take unspecified "appropriate steps."
Mr. Clinton's reported consideration of airdrops to Bosnian-Serb and Croatian villages was seen here as a move to make the missions seem to be aimed at all suffering civilians on the ground, not against the Serbs alone.
Mr. Clinton's apparent gamble is that the threat of American involvement alone might finally lead all factions in the Balkans to be more amenable to a peaceful settlement.
The most likely possible framework for a settlement in Bosnia, the Europeans believe, is the one worked out in January by the United Nations negotiators, Lord Owen of Britain and former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance.
The Clinton Administration's special envoy, Reginald Bartholomew, is scheduled to meet with representatives to NATO in Brussels on Friday to discuss proposed American modifications to the plan. The NATO Secretary General, Manfred Worner, supported the United States plan to airdrop relief supplies to Bosnia and said today that he hoped that it would "contribute to achieving a settlement of the conflict."
 
Problems for Germany
 What to do if the fighting continues despite all the political, economic and military measures so far is far from agreed on in the alliance. If American supply planes were shot at over Bosnia and NATO air traffic control planes coordinated retaliatory air strikes by American or other allied planes, Germany, for instance, would immediately face a domestic political crisis.
The German coalition Government is divided over whether the 1949 Constitution bars German soldiers from taking part in either combat or peacekeeping missions beyond their borders, and Germans make up about a third of the crews of the NATO Awacs air traffic control planes.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Defense Minister Volker Ruhe, both Christian Democrats, say German crew members on the NATO air control planes that monitor Serbian air traffic could stay aboard if the planes directed air strike missions under United Nations authority. But Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel and his Free Democrats insist that without a constitutional change, or a ruling from the German constitutional court, the German crew would have to disembark.

HEADLINE: Orders Down 1.7% in Month For Durables

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Plunging aircraft purchases dragged factory orders for durable goods down 1.7 percent in January, the Government said today.
But excluding the volatile transportation sector, orders rose for the third month in a row. 
 "If you look at the underlying trend," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, "it shows a pretty solid upward trend in demand. In fact, manufacturing is doing quite nicely."
Testifying before Congress, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, concurred that the economy's current prospects were "reasonably good," but cautioned that the recovery was still not accelerating strongly. [Page D7.]
 
Biggest Drop Since July
 The Commerce Department said orders for durable goods -- items like trucks and turbines expected to last more than three years -- totaled a seasonally adjusted $132.8 billion, down from $135.1 billion in December. The drop was the biggest since a 2.7 percent decline last July.
But the department also said the December advance was 9.6 percent, even larger than the 8.7 percent in its original estimate. It was the biggest jump since a 12.1 percent advance in July 1991 and, analysts said, could not be sustained.
Orders, a key barometer of manufacturing activity, had fallen 1.6 percent in November after jumping 4.6 percent a month earlier.
The December advance was propelled by a 24.6 percent surge in transportation orders, including a big increase in aircraft. The January decline was driven by an 8.2 percent drop in transportation, primarily in aircraft.
Excluding the transportation sector, orders were up seven-tenths of a percent in January, 5 percent in December and 1.5 percent in November.
Analysts also noted a four-tenths of a percent increase in unfilled orders, the third gain in four months, meaning that factories are having a harder time meeting demand using current capacity and manpower.
"It suggests that we could be getting increases in employment," said Evelina Tainer of Prime Economic Consulting in Chicago.
In fact, orders for nonmilitary capital goods excluding aircraft were up two-tenths of a percent, the third straight advance. These orders are often a barometer of industry plans to expand and modernize.
Military orders, which are also volatile, rose 12.1 percent in January after increasing 17.5 percent a month earlier. These orders had plunged 9.1 percent in November. Excluding the military component, orders were down 2.6 percent.
Orders for primary metals jumped 7 percent after rising 9.2 percent a month earlier.
Industrial machinery and equipment orders were up 4.8 percent after a 3.5 percent gain in December.
Orders for electronic and other electrical equipment, on the other hand, fell 3.2 percent, wiping out nearly half of the 7.1 percent advance the previous month.

HEADLINE: Modest Growth for '93 Forecast by Greenspan

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress today that the economy was growing more slowly than in the second half of last year and that its momentum was still not strong enough to be self-sustaining.
"The basic momentum of the recovery," he said, is "not yet secured" because of cutbacks in military spending and strains created by large business and household debt. 
 Nonetheless, he forecast moderate growth for all of 1993 and said new data suggested that the economy grew even faster in the fourth quarter than the 3.8 percent the Commerce Department had originally reported.
"The prospects are reasonably good for continued economic growth and declines in unemployment in 1993," he told the House Budget Committee.
 
Clinton Package Praised
 For the third time in less than a week, Mr. Greenspan praised the Clinton deficit-reduction package, but he told Congress that additional deficit reduction measures would be needed because he foresaw the budget deficit rising again after 1997.
"The case for bringing down the structural" or underlying "budget deficit is compelling," he said. "The deficit has for some time been eroding the foundations of our economic strength."
Failure to approve a major deficit reduction plan, he said, will ultimately undermine the nation's living standards and levels of investment.
The Federal Reserve chairman repeated his view that the best way to reduce the deficit was through spending cuts; he fears if taxes are increased, spending will be allowed to rise in tandem.
 
Spending Cut Held Preferable
 "If one is looking at the probability of a sustained reduction in the deficit, the probability is higher if it is done from the expenditure side than from the tax side," he said.
Mr. Greenspan said the package the Clinton Administration and banking regulators were working on to encourage more lending should help reduce the so-called credit crunch.
The plan, which Administration officials say will be released in a few days, will aim to spur more lending to small business by reducing burdensome paperwork imposed on banks and by making it easier for financial institutions with a strong capital base to lend to entrepreneurs based on their character, rather than on their collateral or credit history.
The plan is also expected to make it easier for banks to appeal unfavorable decisions by banking examiners.
"The results to date in trying to break the back of this credit crunch have not been acceptable," he said. "There has been some improvement but clearly nowhere near enough."
"The major problem we have here is fear on the part of bankers, and that is not easy to resolve," he said.
