HEADLINE: A Skittish Rally Raises the Dow 33.23 Points, to 3,356.50

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Seldom has the stock market had a rally as joyless as yesterday's. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 33.23 points, or 1 percent, to 3,356.50, and most other averages rose proportionally more, but few analysts let themselves cheer.
The market's jagged performance of late -- often hanging on every White House rumor or pronouncement -- left few so bold as to say whether the rally would continue. 
 "We have a Jekyll-and-Hyde, schizophrenic market going on here," said Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/Twenty-First Advisers.
Yesterday was Dr. Jekyll's day, as Big Board gainers bested losers by about 12 to 7, on heavy volume of 316.8 million shares traded. The Nasdaq Composite index was up 11.06 points, or 1.7 percent, to 662.46, led by the large computer and biotechnology issues.
Other stocks that have recently suffered in health care, retailing and tobacco, also recovered smartly yesterday, a sign that investors were shopping for discounted merchandise.
Some strategists said that economic optimism pulled stocks up, after yesterday's report that durable goods orders for January, while lower, were not as bad as expected after December's huge rise. The same optimism might have caused a decline in the bond prices yesterday, which usually fall on expectations of economic strength.
But Steven G. Einhorn, co-chair of the investment committee at Goldman, Sachs, portrayed a stock market supported by low interest rates yet limited by worries about the news from Washington. After all the jumps and plunges of the last couple of weeks, he said, the Standard & Poor's 500 index is almost where it was when details of President Clinton's budget plans started coming out at the beginning of last week.
"The market is kind of stuck where it is," he said. "You're going to have a fair amount of volatility, but little travel."
Among the medical stocks that came some distance yesterday, Abbott Laboratories rose 1 3/4, to 26; Johnson & Johnson 2 1/8, to 42 1/4, and U.S. Healthcare 4 3/8, to 44 1/2. Most still remain far below the highs achieved before investors began worrying about Administration plans to control health-care costs.
Richard Eakle, whose money management firm bears his name, still advised against hunting for bargains among medical issues. "They're broken stocks," he said, saying that buyers had better capture any profits in the very short term before they become vulnerable to further declines. He compares these stocks to open-heart surgery patients, with risky, prolonged recoveries.
Tobacco stocks, depressed by fears of higher taxes to pay for better health care, also moved up yesterday, as Philip Morris gained 2 5/8, to 66 1/4, and RJR Nabisco Holdings 5/8, to 8 3/8.
Auto stocks, with some renewed backing from analysts, recovered from a selloff on Tuesday; Chrysler rose 2 5/8 to 38 1/2. Retailers, hurt on Tuesday by a report of lower consumer confidence, also rebounded, as Wal-Mart gained 2 5/8, to 62 1/2. News of a major agreement with Taiwan helped A.T.& T. add 1 3/4, to 56 1/4.
Nasdaq's beaten-down biotechnology stocks continued an advance that began yesterday, as Chiron added 2, to 49 1/4, and Biomet 3/4, to 12 1/2. Amgen rose 2 3/4, to 46 1/4, but a company executive said after the close that first- quarter earnings would run 10 to 15 percent behind Wall Street's expectations. Amgen shares then plunged 9, to 37 1/4, in after-hours trading.
Many Nasdaq computer stocks marched ahead, with Microsoft up 4 3/8, to 83 7/8; Intel up 4 1/2, to 117 3/4, and Oracle up 2, to 31 5/8.
But Dell dropped 6 1/8, to 30 1/8 ,after withdrawing its plan to sell more stock. Compaq, on the Big Board, dropped 2 3/8, to 45, after a downgrading by Wall Street analysts.

HEADLINE: Assembly Revenue Figure Is at Odds With Cuomo's

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Releasing its forecast for New York State's economy, the State Assembly said today that the state's revenues in the fiscal year beginning April 1 would be $550 million higher than Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has predicted.
In putting out a number so at odds with the Governor's, the Democratic-controlled Assembly has thrown down the gauntlet in what is already shaping up to be a brutal battle over next year's budget, which is due on March 31. The Republican-led Senate has yet to release its revenue estimates, but they are expected to be even higher than the Assembly's, perhaps by as much as several hundred million dollars. 
 Mr. Cuomo is to release revised projections of his own next week, but he is very likely to continue taking an extremely conservative approach despite signs that the economy is improving.
"We anticipate that the budget will stay tightly balanced, and we only want to make changes that we see as reasonable and prudent," said Claudia Hutton, a spokeswoman for the State Division of the Budget. Because of unexpected revenues, the state is projecting that it will end the current fiscal year with a $184 million surplus -- money that will immediately be applied to next year's budget gap.
 
Courting Conservativism
 In January, Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat, proposed an austere, $31.5 billion budget that would impose a variety of new taxes and fees; postpone scheduled cuts in personal and business taxes; carve hundreds of millions of dollars out of the state's school-aid and Medicaid programs, and wrest $516 million from a fund that is supposed to be dedicated to transportation.
Mr. Cuomo is deciding whether to run for re-election in 1994 and he would like to be able to present himself as a fiscal conservative who has kept spending down. The Legislature, in turn, would like to be able to spend more money to restore some of the deep cuts Mr. Cuomo has proposed.
On Tuesday, Mr. Cuomo accused the Legislature, and particularly the Senate Republicans, of imprudent spending practices. "I would think that given traditional political rhetoric the Republicans would immediately say, 'We should spend less than the Governor wants,' " he said. "I suspect that, as usual, the Legislature may feel the necessity to spend more."
The Governor, the Assembly and the Senate have yet to sit down and hash out their differences over the revenue estimates, a dispute they must resolve before they can begin to discuss the meat of the budget.
 
Economy a Factor
 Steven Greenberg, a spokesman for Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, a Queens Democrat, said the Assembly's figures did not mean that the state was suddenly awash in cash, but only that the projected $3.7 billion deficit had been reduced by $550 million.
"This is not the doom and gloom that it's been for the last few years, but it's not sunshine and happiness either," said Mr. Greenberg, who said that the Assembly had based its figures on an increase in tax receipts in December and January as well as on rosier predictions for the economy.
Last week, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, a Republican, reported that the state had taken in $1.26 billion more in revenues over the last 10 months than expected. Mr. Cuomo's office responded by saying that the new money had arisen because people were seeking to pay their taxes before President Clinton could impose new taxes, not because of a significant upturn in the economy.
"The way he presented it would lead people to believe that we've got $1.3 billion just sitting around in Pat's shoe," said Miss Hutton, referring to the State Budget Director, Patrick J. Bulgaro. "But what it really means is that people are paying us earlier, and they're not going to pay twice."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Vehicle Sales Increase 8.7% In Midmonth

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Sales of domestically produced vehicles rose 8.7 percent in mid-February, reflecting a steady recovery of automotive demand, particularly among buyers of light trucks.
Sales of pickups, mini-vans and sport-utility vehicles rose 26.5 percent, to 123,361, in the Feb. 11-20 period, compared with the period a year earlier. Car sales were weak, dropping 1.3 percent, to 171,799. 
 The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales was 6.5 million, compared with 6.2 million a year earlier. But analysts asserted that overall sales, including light trucks, have been running at an industry average of about 14 million, compared with total sales last year of 13.1 million.
 
 
Not Raising Estimates
 "Frankly, sales this year are higher than we expected," said Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York. But Mr. Heinbach said his brokerage firm was not raising its estimates of industry sales out of concern that President Clinton's economic package could hurt sales later on.
Automotive demand has not been uniformly strong across the nation. "We're still deep in an automotive recession on the West Coast," said Kent Hagan, who operates Midway Ford in Los Angeles. "Every department of my dealership has dropped dramatically in the last 7 to 10 days."
Among the Big Three, the Ford Motor Company added to its share of the market, while the General Motors Corporation gave up ground.
G.M.'s domestic car lines were off 8.5 percent, to 68,803. The biggest losers were the Oldsmobile and Buick lines; Saturn was the only G.M. car brand to gain sales from a year earlier. An industry publication, Ward's Automotive Reports, had said on Monday that G.M., with growing inventories, might trim domestic car production in March and April.
 
 
Gain for G.M. Trucks
 G.M.'s light-truck sales gained 23.9 percent, to 42,473, largely because of stronger sales of full-size pickups, Chevrolet Suburban utility vehicles and compact pickups.
Ford Motor's car sales rose 4.9 percent, to 53,350. Ford's light-truck sales rose 15.5 percent, to 40,294.
Ward's provided estimates of the Chrysler Corporation's domestic sales: a 28.1 percent gain in cars, to 22,100, and a 42 percent increase in light trucks, to 32,300. Chrysler posts its sales results only once a month.
The Honda Motor Company, which builds cars in the United States and Canada, saw sales of domestic models fall 27.3 percent, to 9,024.
The Toyota Motor Corporation posted a decline of 13.2 percent in car sales, to 9,129. Sales of domestically built Toyota pickups was 2,828, more than a fourfold increase over last year. The Nissan Motor Company reported a 67.1 percent increase in car sales, to 5,411.
For reporting purposes, vehicles assembled in the United States, Canada or Mexico are considered domestically made.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Firmer Against Yen In Mostly Technical Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was firmer against the Japanese yen and other major foreign currencies yesterday in dealings inspired more by technical trading strategies than economic developments.
Gold prices fell in New York after rising overseas. Gold bullion for current delivery closed at $329.70 an ounce, down $1.40, on the New York Commodity Exchange. A late bid from the Republic National Bank in New York quoted gold at $329.20 an ounce, off $1.30. 
 The dollar moved within a fairly defined price range during the day as traders could find no remarkable economic news to bid it higher, George Lopez, a trader at the First Boston Corporation, said.
"It's really technical moves right now," Mr. Lopez said.
 
Response to Durable Goods Data
 Release of the January report on orders for durable goods, which showed a 1.7 percent decline for the month, actually helped push the dollar higher, said Karen Kluge, corporate adviser at Credit Suisse's New York office. Many analysts focused on the fact that despite the decline, when the volatile transportation orders were removed, the figure rose seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Ms. Kluge said the Japanese yen's strong rise abated during the session. The yen had made strong advances against the dollar in recent days, after comments by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen were interpreted as a call for a stronger Japanese currency.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 116.93 yen, up 0.15 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, it finished at 116.88 yen. By closing in New York, the dollar was quoted at 117.475 yen, up from 117.05 late Tuesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.4385, from $1.4585 late Tuesday. At closing in New York, the pound was quoted at $1.4305, less expensive than $1.4530 late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's late rates, included: 1.6265 German marks, up from 1.6230; 1.5065 Swiss francs, up from 1.4975; 5.5155 French francs, up from 5.5100; 1,595.375 Italian lire, up from 1,583.25, and 1.25915 Canadian dollars, up from 1.25325.

HEADLINE: Uncovered Short Sales Are Up 2.6% on Nasdaq

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The number of Nasdaq shares sold short and not yet covered rose slightly from mid-January to mid-February, the National Association of Securities Dealers said yesterday.
Short interest in all Nasdaq securities totaled 477.2 million shares in the period, up nearly 2.6 percent from the previous month's level of 465.2 million. 
 Reflecting the rising volatility among over-the-counter issues recently, the number of companies whose stock was sold short rose to 3,815, from 3,708 during the previous period.
The most recent figures reflect the continued record-breaking rise in short interest that began nearly a year ago. Nasdaq short interest is more than 25 percent higher than it was last April.
Figures on short interest are a widely watched gauge of investor sentiment because they reflect the activities of professionals who specialize in identifying companies they consider overvalued. These professionals borrow companies' shares and then sell the stock, essentially betting they will be able to buy the shares later for less money, repay the lender and pocket the difference.
 
Bull Market Has Stumbled
 Until recently, the short-selling business has been treacherous in the Nasdaq market, because short interest has risen even as over-the-counter market indexes kept posting new record highs.
But in late January and so far this month, the bull market in Nasdaq issues has stumbled, helping to ease short-sellers' pain.
"On average, short-sellers are up between 6 percent and 8 percent so far this year," said Harry Strunk, a Palm Beach, Fla., investment consultant who tracks short selling. "And February in particular has been a good month."
Worries about the implications of President Clinton's economic proposals, in addition to skyrocketing price/ earnings ratios for many high-flying Nasdaq issues, have contributed to the market's volatility and its recent downward price spiral.
Since the beginning of February, the Nasdaq composite index has fallen by 6 percent.
 
Recent Increase in Exposure
 Encouraged by the price action, Mr. Strunk said short-sellers have greatly increased their exposure to the market in the last few weeks.
"I would say these guys are much more exposed now than they were at the beginning of February," he said. "The average short is probably between 80 percent and 90 percent invested. In January, they were probably only 50 percent invested."
The short-interest figures are as of the 15th of the month, and include all short-interest positions reported as of Feb. 5 and settled as of Feb. 12.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields Are Slightly Lower On Money Market Funds

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Money market fund yields were off slightly last week, as investors, confused by monetary and fiscal policy in Washington, sought safety in money funds.
"The large inflow into money market funds is coming from the stock market and is just being parked temporarily," said Walter Frank, chief economist at The Money Fund Report, an Ashland, Mass., newsletter. 
 The assets of taxable money funds rose $16.4 billion, to $494.1 billion, in the week ended Monday. Institutions supplied $9.2 billion of the increase, swelling institutional money fund assets to $176.8 billion.
Yields edged down a bit. The seven-day simple yield for all taxable money funds declined 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 2.69 percent. The seven-day compounded yield also declined 2 basis points, to 2.73 percent. The 30-day simple yield fell 2 basis points, to 2.72 percent, and the 30-day compounded yield also dropped 2 basis points, to 2.76 percent. The average days to maturity of securities held in taxable portfolios remained unchanged at 61 days.
 
Top Funds
 The highest-yielding general purpose taxable money fund in the week was the Dreyfus Basic Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compounded yield of 3.56 percent. The fund is distributed by the Dreyfus Service Corporation of New York.
The highest-yielding government-only fund was United Services Government Securities Savings, with a seven-day compounded yield of 3.63 percent. The fund is distributed by United Services Advisers Inc. in San Antonio.
Tax-exempt yields also slipped a bit in the week, while total assets inched up only $42 million, to $102.6 billion.
The average seven-day simple tax-exempt yield declined by 4 basis points, to 1.88 percent, near a record low, and the seven-day compounded yield was 1.90, also down by 4 basis points.
The 30-day simple yield was 1.97 percent, down 3 basis points from the previous week, and the 30-day compound yield was 1.99 percent, also down 3 basis points. The average maturity was 51 days, down 2 days from the previous week.
In Connecticut, the top-yielding tax-exempt fund was the Fidelity Spartan Connecticut Municipal Money Market Portfolio, with a seven-day compounded yield of 2.21 percent. The top New Jersey fund was the Vanguard New Jersey Tax-Free/Money Market Portfolio, with a seven-day compounded yield of 2.35 percent. The top New York fund was the Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compounded yield of 2.19 percent.
The top tax-exempt fund with assets of more than $100 million was the Evergreen Tax Exempt Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compounded yield of 2.63 percent.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Clinton's plan pales before the 900-pound health-care gorilla.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
A MAJORITY of Americans polled thinks President Clinton's economic plan is just dandy. And why not? While both the Senate Finance Committee chairman, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, and the Republican leadership may hear the clatter of Mr. Clinton's no-middle-class-tax pledge being thrown out the window, the dominant sound is a collective sigh of relief that the President is asking for less than a dollar a day from the typical family.
The catch is that the dollar is only "a modest down payment," in the words of Henry Aaron, an economist at the Brookings Institution. Health care is the 900-pound gorilla of deficit finance. And unless Washington curbs the animal's appetite or sharply raises taxes to keep it supplied with bananas -- or both -- the deficit will break records by the end of the century. 
 For all the talk of sacrifice, the Clinton plan would not exact much from the average American. The proposed income tax increases are limited to the tiny fraction of families whose earnings exceed $140,000, even after they subtract mortgage interest, state and local taxes, charitable contributions and catastrophic medical bills.
The bite on Social Security pensions would be limited to couples with taxable incomes exceeding $32,000, with most paying only an extra $30 or $40 a month. And though the energy tax would touch everyone, the touch would be as light as a pickpocket's: Few families would ante up more than an extra $150 a year directly, along with perhaps an equal sum in higher prices for goods and services made with energy.
The only big losers would be the rich, who did very nicely thank you during the 1980's, along with a variety of interests -- everyone from bee keepers to timber harvesters on Federal land -- who depend heavily on Government largess.
One group more likely to elicit public sympathy, employees of military contractors, would certainly be hurt by the accelerated build-down in defense. But these generally affluent and skilled workers should have an easier time than the blue-collar workers in the Rust Belt who lost their jobs in the 1980's.
Still, the plan is sufficient to reduce the 1996 deficit projected by the Congressional Budget Office from $287 billion to $205 billion. And as Robert Gordon of Northwestern University points out, this level of deficit spending would be manageable indefinitely in the sense that the growth in the national debt would no longer be faster than the likely growth of national income.
Why, then, the gloom and doom? Because the package offers no way to hold the line past 1996. Unless programs are changed radically, the Budget Office expects health-care outlays to triple by 2003, to a whopping $672 billion.
"Even if we win the health inflation war," Robert Reischauer, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, believes "the fruits of victory" will not show up on the budget until the next century.
Medicare for the elderly currently covers only 90 percent of its cost to hospitals, while Medicaid for the poor covers just 80 percent. Hospitals make up the difference by overcharging private insurers by an average of 28 percent. And since any broad reform is likely to level the playing field, the portion of the national health bill underwritten by Government is bound to rise.
Second, 35 million Americans are now uninsured. Some will no doubt pay their own way under a system of universal coverage. But the great majority are working poor, and will have to be subsidized heavily by Uncle Sam.
Mr. Reischauer also points out that any package of minimum benefits offered under national health insurance will almost certainly be extended to the retired elderly as well. And since Medicare is currently a "bare bones" system that, for example, lacks provisions for long-term care, it is all but certain that Washington will expand subsidized services to the elderly.
Keeping the budget deficit in the $200 billion ballpark until cost containment pays off is thus likely to take hundreds rather than tens of billions of dollars in new revenue annually. And such sums could not be raised by clipping the rich or tacking a few more pennies onto the price of gasoline.
Jimmy Carter would like to collect a piece of it with a $2-a-pack tax on cigarettes. Many health economists favor the taxation of at least part of the insurance benefits provided by employers. Still others, among them Mr. Aaron, favor a dedicated "value added," or national sales, tax: a 5 percent V.A.T. on everything would yield a whopping $128 billion in 1998.
Hillary Rodham Clinton and company have yet to signal which way the Administration is heading. What is clear, though, is that the current recovery plan is an hors d'oeuvre. The main course -- and the bill -- has yet to be presented.

HEADLINE: A New Kind of Housing That Brings People Together

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

DATELINE: EMERYVILLE, Calif.

 BODY:
CRUISING along Interstate 80, Charles Durrett smirked at all the Legolike condominiums that clutter the hillsides from Oakland to Sacramento. "Nothing but big fat roads leading to big fat houses," he said. "I saw a sign once for this one development that said, 'Live and Shop.' And it showed a happy couple with a mall in the background."
Such anti-consumerism may sound strident, if not strange, especially from a developer like Mr. Durrett. But it's common among those who reside in co-housing complexes, increasingly popular communities that combine the privacy and amenities of 80's-style condo living with the togetherness and frugality of a 60's-style commune. 
 Mr. Durrett, who helped begin the co-housing movement in the United States five years ago, criticizes traditional multifamily developments as wastelands that separate people from each other, isolating them from any comfort but that of consumption. "Warehouses for people and their stuff," he called them.
By contrast, co-housing brings people together. Indeed, at the 12-unit complex here in Emeryville -- a town of about 5,000 wedged between Oakland and the San Francisco Bay Bridge -- 27 people, including Mr. Durrett and his wife, Kathryn McCamant, live in a renovated warehouse.
True, they own the apartment units in the building. But they also take part in committees that oversee everything from landscaping to laundry to pooper-scoopers. More radically, perhaps, they take turns cooking dinner in the common house. Plans vary among co-housing groups, but Emeryville's residents, in teams of two, cook meals for the group twice every six weeks; these community meals are offered about three times a week.
"There is also usually a spontaneous meal every week, potlucks or whatever," said Mr. Durrett, who, with his wife, wrote "Cohousing: A Contemporary Approach to Housing Ourselves" (Ten Speed Press, 1988; $21.95).
The book by Mr. Durrett, 37, and Ms. McCamant, 34, has become something of a bible for the co-housing movement; about 16,000 copies have been sold, and a second edition, with new material about the latest developments in the United States, is to be published in September.
Mr. Durrett, who with his beard, jeans and lanky laid-backness, has a faintly hippie demeanor, also operates the Cohousing Company in Berkeley, which serves as an information, referral and consulting service. "Co-housing is about making life more economical, more convenient and more fun, more practical, and to recreate the opportunity for a sense of community," he said.
Co-housing is not without its problems. Projects can take years to get off the ground. In particular, local planning and zoning departments can be very skeptical. And banks are wary because co-housing is unproven.
Then there is the sometimes awkward adjustment of not only getting to know the neighbors, but actually living with them. "I have noticed that people who don't have children have the hardest time getting used to it," said Monty Hunter, a motion-picture cameraman who lives with his wife, Hannah, and two children, Ben, 8, and Lizzie, 3, in a co-housing complex in Davis, Calif. "They feel overrun by children's needs."
Co-housing originated in 1976 in Denmark, where it is now common; there are about 150 co-housing communities there, and 150 more in Sweden and in the Netherlands. The concept stems from a belief that housing needs in the late 20th century are different from those developed in the middle of the century, when families were larger and women tended to stay at home, taking care of the house and raising the children.
"Mom is working," Mr. Durrett said. "She's not home all day managing the whale of a house and the larger family that goes with it. When I see a single mom or even a married couple trying to maintain a typical single-family home, I see them busy all weekend."
In the United States, the first co-housing community opened in 1991 in Davis, followed by communities in Bainbridge Island, Wash.; Emeryville, in May 1992, and Lafayette, Colo., in mid-February. About 300 people live in them. "The idea took hold first in the West probably because that's where we are," said Ellen Hertzman, project manager with the Cohousing Company.
Elsewhere in the nation, 12 co-housing groups are seeking land, and 150 more are trying to get their plans off the drawing board, Mr. Durrett said. The groups are scattered throughout the country. On the East Coast, there are co-housing groups in Amherst, Mass.; Westchester County; Ithaca, N.Y., and Manhattan.
"For an innovation to take off this fast is quite extraordinary," said Clare Cooper Marcus, a professor of architecture at the University of California at Berkeley. "It has met a need with people who really didn't know they had that need until the book came out. No one was aware of this type of housing."
Much of the activity in the West is along Interstate 80 in Northern California, where besides the Emeryville and Davis co-housing communities, projects are planned for Nevada City, Benicia, Sacramento and the Napa Valley. "This will be the co-housing belt by the turn of the century," Mr. Durrett said.
Co-housing differs from traditional housing in several ways, perhaps the most fundamental being that the residents decide in advance what the complex should look like and how it should function. Custom-made communities, they are often called.
In Emeryville, the co-housing complex was designed to fit in architecturally with the surrounding industrial neighborhood. For example, corrugated metal siding covers the upper floors, and culvert pipes have been turned into exterior columns.
In rural Davis, the co-housing complex is a series of brown stucco town houses surrounded by vegetable gardens and an orchard. A sign on the chalkboard in the common house says, "We Need Compost!!!"
"I didn't want a house; I wanted a community," said Jane McKennedy, 46, a research scientist who moved into the Davis complex when it opened two years ago.
People who want to live in co-housing often call Mr. Durrett first to find a group in their area that is trying to buy land and design a project. If they like the plans (and if the group likes them), they gradually put up money for land, an architect, a contractor and building expenses.
The process, which can take three years, can result in homes that cost about the same as comparable new housing. Co-housing apartments in Emeryville run from $135,000 for a one-bedroom, 940-square-foot unit to $260,000 for a three-bedroom, 1,600-square-foot unit.
"It is not a solution to the affordable-housing problem," Ms. Cooper Marcus said. "It will probably appeal to people who want to do something different, and they are probably well educated and reasonably well off."
But residents can save money by sharing, which is an important part of the co-housing spirit. "Individuals will have a litany of reasons for wanting to live in co-housing," Mr. Durrett said. "One of the reasons is often wanting to consume less. We have one lawn mower, one waffle iron, one guest fold-out bed, one wheelbarrow."
They also get a chance to own things as a group that they might be unable to afford on their own. Residents in Benicia, for example, have a communal sailboat; those in Emeryville have a woodworking shop and will soon have a hot tub.
The biggest luxury, though, may be the proximity to other people. "I used to drive 20 minutes to watch the Super Bowl with a friend," Mr. Durrett said. "Now, I go down to the common room."
The biggest appeal may be to empty-nesters and to retirees who are still in good health. "It seemed like a wonderful way of life for someone my age, to have your own place but be around people, too," said Margaret Hall, 67, who moved into the Emeryville complex after her husband died.
Younger families may choose co-housing because they want a neighbor for a baby sitter and playmates for their children. "I know of a mother who drives 15 miles so her child can play with another 7-year-old," said Mr. Durrett, who has an 18-month-old daughter, Jessie. "That's the kind of pathology the 20th century has brought us."
He added: "I have never known anyone in a co-housing development to hire a baby sitter."
Physically, the general design of co-housing complexes brings people together. See-through "full light" front doors are standard. Residences are also built close to each other and, if possible, face each other.
"They are laid out centripetally rather than centrifugally," Mr. Durrett said. "It allows people to commune with their neighbors, or not to."
Co-housing proponents emphasize that their philosophy is not for everyone. In Emeryville, residents often bemoan a neighbor's lack of social skills and self-centeredness. "It's a real good experience in getting along with people," Ms. Hall said. "You have to come into co-housing ready to compromise, or else it won't work."
Occasionally, residents rebel against the communal ethic. In Davis, one homeowner has decided not to take part in any joint chores and has put her unit up for sale. She has also been prohibited from taking part in any communal activities. (Residents in co-housing complexes cannot force an owner to sell. Nor do they have the right to reject any sale or rental, as do the boards in many New York cooperatives.)
The degree of conformity among co-housing residents may also match that in many traditional suburban subdivisions; few racial minorities or handicapped or poor people live in any of the four existing complexes in the United States.
Many residents maintain that they are a diverse bunch. "We don't only have pro-Clinton, pro-choice, read-Utne Reader-people here," said Joani Blank, 55, who founded a sexual aids company and recently moved into the Emeryville complex.
Ms. Blank thought for a second, then conceded that most of her neighbors were just that. "We do have two Republicans," she said.

HEADLINE: Mr. Mulroney Steps Down

 BODY:
Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada may be unpopular at home, but he has been a good friend to the U.S., a close ally on global issues and a strong partner in demolishing trade barriers.
Some Canadians say he is too friendly with Washington, but that's only one of his problems. He also faced an election this year, a long, deep recession and low standing in the polls. An astute politician, he decided it was time to get out. 
 His departure does not, by itself, portend a change in U.S.-Canadian relations. While opposition parties are less open on trade policy, the only critical issue right now is the North American Free Trade Agreement; it seems safe to assume Mr. Mulroney will have it ratified before he goes.
Regardless of who wins the next election, he has launched his nation in a promising new direction. Its free-trade links with the U.S., and later Mexico, will expand Canada's foreign trade, but these agreements also force the reduction of protectionist provincial barriers within Canada.
Mr. Mulroney's popularity began to plunge in the late 1980's, with imposition of an unpopular national sales tax, signs of corruption in high places and public discontent over the free-trade agreement. Then came the recession, which hit Canada much harder than the U.S., and another defeat in the struggle for a constitutional agreement between Quebec and the rest of Canada.
Canadians, like their U.S. neighbors, appear to be looking for change. That's been apparent since the upset election of a Socialist government in Ontario two and a half years ago, and the subsequent gains of the populist Reform Party in opinion polls, especially in western Canada.
Mr. Mulroney has had an exceptionally long run of eight and a half years as Prime Minister -- and as a good neighbor to the United States.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Balkan Strategy, Part I

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
This column will explain U.S. interests and policy options in Bosnia and what I think should be done. The next will show how to get other nations to join in stronger, though limited, action.
Why is Bosnia so important? 
 * The Serbs' "ethnic cleansing" is driving hundreds of thousands of Bosnian Muslims into Western Europe, igniting right-wing reactions, especially in Germany.
* If the West fails to counter the Serbs in Bosnia, Belgrade could be emboldened to start "cleansing" in Kosovo and Macedonia and thus cause a wider Balkan war -- engulfing Greece and Turkey.
* Bosnia is a major test case for whether the West and the U.N. can combat virulent nationalism and protect minorities.
* This war has unleashed a powerful evil inside people throughout ex-Yugoslavia -- just as surely as Hitler loosed an evil in Germany. Such evil can be highly contagious, empowering thugs and dispiriting decent citizens everywhere.
Few American or European leaders would dispute these stakes. Which makes Americans all the more dismayed that Europe, with the most to lose, acts so feebly.
The sad and undeniable truth is that European governments are too weak politically to take stronger action. The U.S. can curse the darkness and simply let the Europeans rot. Or it can help Europe, in America's own interest, as it has done throughout this century.
What can be done?
Option #1: Negotiated Settlement. Aid the stricken as much as possible without using force, sanction the Serbs economically and try to make a deal among the warring Serbian, Croatian and Muslim factions. This is the Vance-Owen course of fashioning largely autonomous ethnic enclaves policed by outside forces.
It is hard to see how all parties will accept such a plan. Because it is and must be based on present military realities, it rewards the Serbs and Croats and punishes the Muslims. The Muslims will not buy it. And if they get a better deal, the others will not go along. In any case, few will have faith in enforcement.
If the parties signed up under great external pressure, they would create a jigsaw puzzle requiring up to 100,000 outside troops -- indefinitely -- to keep the peace. These troops would be at great risk. To boot, Serbian crimes would be legitimized.
Option #2: Self-Exhaustion. Don't validate Serbia's ill-gotten gains in a treaty, just let the parties "exhaust themselves" in battle. This was the Bush Administration's approach and remains the unstated view of most West European leaders.
This attitude is grounded in the region's historical bloodletting. An observer wrote in 1917 that the inhabitants regarded their warring "partly as a sport and partly as a crusade."
But letting the parties slug it out with their current forces would mean a clear-cut Serb victory, countless Muslim deaths, the partition of Bosnia by Serbs and Croats and the flight of a million Muslim refugees into Europe.
Option #3: Limited Intervention/ Fair Fight. The idea here is that the stakes warrant stronger Western action, that the West should not become entangled in long-term, large-scale policing, that the Serbs must be punished and contained and that the Muslims deserve the chance to defend themselves.
First, launch air strikes against Serbian positions overlooking Sarajevo. While the attacks would not end the unlawful and barbaric siege, they would make life and aid delivery a lot easier.
Second, create safe havens where most Muslims now live and protect them with about 15,000 European and U.S. troops. This would prevent more Muslims from fleeing abroad and keep alive their hopes.
Third, offer heavy arms to the Muslims, and Croats if necessary. They, not the West, should provide the ground troops. Initially, fighting and casualties will be heavier, but it will be a fair fight. Eventually the factions will establish a new military balance and reach a modus vivendi.
The danger is that the Serbian government could escalate by sending troops into Bosnia. The West would have to respond with air strikes against those troops and against Serbia as well. No more, but no less.
This risky option -- or softer variants linking force to negotiations -- alone begins to satisfy U.S. interests. The problem will be persuading Russia, Britain, France and the U.N. to go along with it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Protectionism Doesn't Help Balance of Trade

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Protectionists will undoubtedly seize on the news that Japan's export surplus last year soared to some $130 billion (news article, Feb. 5) to justify "getting tough" -- threatening further to restrict our imports unless Japan opens its markets to us. 
 It's ironic: we consistently have an export surplus with Mexico, but that doesn't prevent the same protectionists from opposing the Free Trade Agreement with that country.
Businesses and their unions don't like competition and, as Peter Passell points out in his Feb. 4 Economic Scene column, are quick to invoke our antidumping laws against what we would consider salutary competition domestically. That is, selling below average full cost, in the presence of excess capacity -- regardless of whether our trade balance is positive or negative.
I'll rest easier when some responsible member of the Clinton Administration -- of which I am in all other respects an enthusiastic supporter -- shows a clear recognition that a country's balance of trade is simply the mirror image of the relation between its domestic savings and investments, and does not depend on the liberality or restrictionism of its trade policies or those of its trading partners. We will have a trade deficit so long as we save so little relative to Federal Government deficits and domestic investments; and Japan will always have a corresponding surplus for the opposite reason.
How that accounting identity works out in the real world is more complicated than that: Japan's export surplus has soared largely because Japan has been going into a recession -- not a very healthy way for a country to restrain its spending.
And our deficit is increasing because our economy has been moving modestly in the opposite direction and because the foreign exchange value of the dollar has strengthened slightly -- both of these developments that a sane country would be happy about, rather than use as an excuse to protect some of its citizens from competition at the expense of everyone else.
 
ALFRED E. KAHN
Ithaca, N.Y., Feb. 8, 1993
The writer is the Robert Julius Thorne Professor of Political Economy, Emeritus, at Cornell University.

HEADLINE: Protectionism Doesn't Help Balance of Trade;
We Must Manufacture

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Car Import Duty Can Only Hurt U.S. Economy"(letter, Feb. 7), Michael May seems to argue that America's economic position is improved if it imports automobiles without some form of control. The consumer will save $1 billion (no basis provided for that number), the trade deficit will help pay the Federal deficit and lower the interest rate. 
 If we accept that the American consumer will save $1 billion by purchasing automobiles at "a few hundred dollars less" than the domestic equivalent, does it necessarily follow that the American economy is improved? I am not sure it does.
The $1 billion saved is for those who buy automobiles. What would the impact be to the economy if the money spent for these foreign automobiles were spent for domestic products.
With the price of the average car in excess of $10,000, I doubt that the price elasticity of demand for new cars would cause a significant decrease in total units sold. Competition among G.M., Ford and Chrysler would work to control prices.
What would the impact be on the economy if we spread $20 billion additional automobile manufacturing across the economy. (The figure comes from an assumed 5 percent saving in Professor May's few hundred dollars a car.)
In introductory economics courses we are exposed to the multiplier effect of new spending. If we assume a modest multiplier of three we are talking about $60 billion of economic activity. This encompasses all segments of the economy: glass, tires, rubber, batteries, textiles, carpets, ferrous and nonferrous metals, machine tools, home building, retail trade, computers and controls.
We generate higher-paying jobs in these related industries without eliminating jobs in the service industries.
More jobs mean less paid out in unemployment and welfare benefits. At the same time we have an increase in taxes collected at every level of government. Increased taxes and reduced spending work to reduce government deficits. This reduces pressure on the capital markets by lowering one segment of demand. Funds available increase. With our modest savings rate of around 2 percent we could generate $1.2 billion of savings.
Domestic manufacture generates jobs, increases tax yields, reduces deficits and creates 20 percent more savings to help reduce interest rates. If we as a nation are going to consume products, we must manufacture products. When we do, we are all better off.
 
J. CARTER SHOOK
Ardmore, Pa., Feb. 11, 1993

HEADLINE: Subways Should Allow Newsstands Back In

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In a time of economic crisis for New York City's tabloid newspapers, the Transit Authority could give them an improved shot at survival by simply encouraging the return of news vendors to the city's subway platforms and stations. 
 The subways are a great place to read a paper, and many more New Yorkers would surely buy newspapers if they were more readily available for sale there.
But news vendors seem to have disappeared in many parts of the city. Many of those who are left do their work surreptitiously.
I have commuted daily on the IRT line from the Eastern Parkway, Franklin Street and Bergen Street stations and have been saddened to see well-meaning pseudovendors who stand in the rain outside a dry station, struggling to keep their papers dry under plastic wraps flapping in wind.
What kind of a society treats those who would uplift us with the news of the world in such a fashion?
While the use of the public's property to peddle papers should ordinarily give rise to taxes, fees, registration and the like, I would like to see the Transit Authority take some quick, effective action, without the normal governmental impediments.
Perhaps 2,000 jobs at three newspapers are at stake, with a total economic impact that has been put at $200 million annually for the city.
At the risk of added confusion on subway platforms, turf wars and litter, it would be great if the Transit Authority would open the gates of its stations to all comers, big and small. Beyond saving jobs, this could result in a more literate city. How about a try?
 
ROBERT C. APFEL
 New York, Feb. 17, 1993

HEADLINE: High-Level Grumbling Over Pace of Appointments

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Some Cabinet officers and others in the Clinton Administration are expressing frustration with the time-consuming efforts by the White House to add diversity and otherwise influence selections for top Government posts.
Some of the Cabinet members have told others that they blame fine-tuning by the White House for compounding a process that is already slower than that of President Clinton's comparable recent predecessors. 
 To fill 290 top Government jobs subject to Senate confirmation, Mr. Clinton has so far submitted just 30 formal nominations. That is only about half the pace of Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan in the first month of their Presidencies, and only slightly better than that of George Bush, who had many fewer vacancies to fill because he kept a large number of Reagan Administration officials in place.
At most Government departments, there is no backup person to step in if a top official is away or taken ill, as occurred this week when Defense Secretary Les Aspin was hospitalized with heart problems. Mr. Aspin's likely deputy, William Perry, has not yet been formally nominated for the post.
 
21 New Selections
 With a flurry of 21 announcements on Tuesday afternoon, the White House tried to blunt such criticism by identifying more officials the President will nominate to important jobs. But the announcements were not formal nominations, and officials said it could be weeks before background investigations were completed and the White House was actually ready to submit the names to the Senate.
To fill the void, the top officials at the State Department, the Pentagon, the Treasury and some other departments have quietly hired as temporary employees or consultants many of the officials expected to be named to top posts. At the Pentagon, for example, two policy aides, Walter Slocombe and Graham Allison, accompanied Mr. Aspin on a recent trip to Munich, Germany, even though neither has been nominated to a sub-Cabinet post.
But such shadow appointees lack full authority to take charge in departmental decisions, leaving much day-to-day management in the hands of civil servants and Bush Administration holdovers. That has left many Democrats uncomfortable. In some sensitive legal cases, it has even caused the White House to delegate its own overworked legal office to take charge rather than rely on an acting general counsel at a Government agency.
At the State Department, Strobe Talbott, the designated ambassador-at-large for Russian affairs, was permitted to join Secretary of State Warren Christopher on his current overseas tour only after a top Republican on the staff of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee granted him a special exception to a rule barring officials from such trips until their appointments are confirmed by the Senate.
 
Unease Among Democrats
 Such uneasy arrangements have made many Democrats uncomfortable. Representative Patricia Schroeder of Colorado, a member of the House Armed Services Committee, said she remained concerned that without Clinton appointees officially in place there would be "too few civilians" taking part in coming Pentagon debates over military spending.
The Clinton White House is not the first to claim a role in selecting those who will fill Government jobs below Cabinet rank. But it has been much more assertive than its recent predecessors in rejecting lists submitted by Cabinet officers and insisting upon its own choices, even at the assistant secretary rank.
For obvious reasons, Cabinet officers and other senior officials have not voiced their frustration in public. But Administration aides said that some had made plain their exasperation in conversations with top advisers and White House officials.
Among those said to be most clearly dissatisfied with the pace of appointments are Mr. Aspin, Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy and Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena. In an interview published this week in The Washington Post, Mr. Pena hinted at his discontent in recounting that while he had submitted "a whole page of names" to the White House, he had been reminded repeatedly that "they're Presidential appointments."
Mr. Pena was then quoted as saying that he and top aides were "working with the White House in trying to get some of these names out so we can start making some appointments."
A spokesman for Mr. Pena, Richard Mintz, said today that the Secretary was not inclined to be interviewed on the subject again. But other officials said that other Cabinet secretaries had encountered similar obstacles. They said Mr. Aspin had been advised that his first choices to top Pentagon jobs included too few women.
The officials also said that Henry G. Cisneros, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, had been told that his list of proposed nominees included the names of too many New Yorkers.
Without discussing those specific cases, Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, acknowledged that the scrutiny being imposed by Clinton aides had contributed to delays.
But she said White House aides remained determined to assure that appointments across the breadth of the Administration reflect Mr. Clinton's commitment "to casting the net wider than in the past and getting a diversity in terms of race and geography and background."
She also said that Mr. Clinton and his top advisers had been mainly concerned until last week with decisions about their economic program but had now begun to shift their attention to the unfilled Government jobs. George Stephanopoulos, the communications director, insisted: "We're beginning to break the logjam now."
Other Administration officials nevertheless said they feared that the process would remain cumbersome. For one thing, they said that the fact that public concerns about Government officials had widened to include such matters as child care had added to the officials' burdens in scrutinizing potential nominees.
In addition, they said, Hillary Rodham Clinton has joined with the White House personnel director, Bruce Lindsey, in asserting an extensive role in passing judgment on departmental recommendations.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 27, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article and a chart on Thursday about the pace of Clinton Administration appointments misstated the number of nominations formally submitted to the Senate for confirmation. By Thursday, the President had made 29 such nominations, not 30. One nomination, not two, was for a Justice Department post.

HEADLINE: Shoreham A-Plant Has Found a Taker For Its Spent Fuel

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The $5.5 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant lurched a step closer to oblivion yesterday as the Long Island Power Authority announced that it had found a home for the plant's partly spent nuclear fuel.
Instead of shipping the 100 tons of fuel to France at a cost of $80 million, as originally proposed, the authority will pay the Philadelphia Electric Company $45 million to take it. The fuel will be used over a 15-year period at two reactors near Pottstown, Pa., the company said. 
 The sale would help bring the long, troubled history of the plant to an end. After two decades of controversy over whether the $5.5 billion plant should go into operation, its owner, the Long Island Lighting Company, sold it to the power authority in early 1992 for $1. The plant closed without ever having opened.
If things go well, the fuel could be off the Shoreham site by the end of this year. It costs the power authority about $3 million a month to guard and maintain the fuel, and the savings could run into the tens of million dollars, said Richard Kessel, the authority's chairman.
"It's very good news, under the circumstances," Mr. Kessel said. The authority's board unanimously approved the deal yesterday afternoon.
Philadelphia Electric must still win the approval of the band in jail and told him of the fight.
"She visits him at Rikers and explains to him what happened," the chief said. "Subsequent to his release, he gets the cooperation of the other indivihoreham's fuel would save its customers an estimated $70 million.
Asked about possible opposition to the deal, Mr. Kessel said: "I'm hopeful there won't be. The bottom line is you've got to do something with it."
But opposition could come from New York City officials, who have balked in the past at shipments of radioactive materials through the city.
A spokesman for Mayor David N. Dinkins said last night that the city would study the transportation plans before deciding whether to try to block the shipments.
"Obviously this concerns us greatly," the spokesman, John Beckman, said. "We will of course insist on seeing the plans for the transportation of this material at the very least, and we will be insistent on safeguarding the health and safety of New Yorkers."
Mr. Kessel said the fuel will be shipped by rail in special casks that have already been approved by the Federal Department of Transportation. He said that no route had been determined, but he added it was unlikely that it would go through Manhattan. The fuel could, he said, travel over the Hell Gate bridge from Queens to the Bronx and continue north to cross the Hudson River upstate.
Mr. Kessel stressed yesterday that his agency had already shipped 1.8 million pounds of radioactive material from Shoreham by truck to a low-level waste dump near Aiken, S.C.
The shipments would be handled by General Electric for $20 million, which the power authority would pay. Shipments are to begin in June and be finished by next February. Two of the specials casks have been obtained; if General Electric can obtain a third, the work would be completed by the end of this year.
 
Radiation Hazard Discussed
 A spokesman for Philadelphia Electric said yesterday that the radiation hazard from the fuel shipments would be less than from shipments of low-level radioactive wastes that are routinely made around the country.
The Shoreham fuel is uranium metal in ceramic pellets about the size of pencil erasers. These are wrapped in long, thin metal tubes that are bound together in precisely spaced arrays called assemblies.
They will be handled by remote-controlled equipment and generally kept under water to shield people from radiation. The shipping containers, which are primarily for shielding, weigh 70 tons each.
The sale of the plant to The Long Island Power Authority, a public agency created by the state in large part to dispose of Shoreham, ended years of wrangling over its safety and economic viability. The authority has begun dismantling the plant, but disposing of the fuel has been a major problem.
The fuel was originally only slightly radioactive, but the Long Island Lighting Company, which built Shoreham, was desperate to demonstrate that the plant could be used and so ran it for an extended period at low power. When a nuclear reactor runs, it splits uranium atoms into cesium, strontium and other atoms that are substantially more radioactive.
 
Processing Plant in France
 The Long Island Power Authority, which owns Shoreham now, pursued a variety of options, including shipping the fuel to France, where used nuclear fuel is routinely broken down in a chemical processing plant at La Hague to retrieve unused uranium and the plutonium that is produced during reactor operation.
But the United States Department of Defense sought to block the shipment.
Disposal of the fuel has been difficult for several reasons. The United States has no permanent repository for spent fuel, a problem that is beginning to affect operating reactors.
In addition, different reactor designs use different fuels, and not many use fuel of precisely the type that Shoreham was supposed to use.
 
Enriching Fuel
 Uranium comes in two forms, one easy to split in a reactor and the other more difficult, and reactor fuel is "enriched" by raising the proportion of fissionable uranium from the natural level of .7 percent. Philadelphia Electric uses fuel enriched to 4 percent.
The Shoreham fuel was made to several different enrichment levels.
Hugh Diamond, the manager of nuclear fuel at Philadelphia Electric, said the 76 assemblies that are not enriched cannot be used. The remainder will be mixed with regular fuel and used in the Limerick reactors, he said.

HEADLINE: CLINTON ANNOUNCES AIRDROPS TO BOSNIA WILL BEGIN SHORTLY

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
President Clinton announced today that United States military planes would soon begin parachuting relief supplies to all three warring factions in remote areas of Bosnia as a good-will gesture aimed at inducing them to return to the negotiating table.
Pentagon officials said the operation would be short and could begin as early as Sunday. It will involve C-130 Hercules transports flying at night, and at around 10,000 feet -- lessening their chances of being hit by ground fire but also lessening the accuracy of the drops. 
 About 600,000 leaflets in Serbo-Croatian will be dropped ahead of time, telling Serbs, Bosnian Muslims and Croats when and where the food would be landing, and advising them not to interfere. The leaflets will also warn them to stay indoors when the one-ton bundles start parachuting to earth at a speed of 90 feet per second.
 
U.S. Acting Alone
 Although Mr. Clinton had said on Wednesday that he hoped other countries would take part, for now the Americans will conduct the operation alone. Some allies view the airdrops as an inefficient and dangerous way to deliver aid and believe they were adopted by the Clinton Administration to show it was doing something more than its predecessors, but without risking soldiers on the ground.
Even as the White House announced the airdrops, Serbian fighters allowed 12 trucks that it had held at a roadblock for two and a half days to proceed to Gorazde, an isolated Muslim town in eastern Bosnia. [Page A8.]
Administration officials acknowledged that the airlift was mostly a symbolic gesture, and that it would not be as accurate as they would like. But they insisted that it would save lives, and possibly prompt the Serbs to reopen the overland routes that they have kept mostly closed in recent weeks. Serbs control the key supply roads, especially in eastern Bosnia, and halt United Nations convoys at will.
United States officials hope that by making a gesture to all parties, they will demonstrate that Washington is ready to be an honest broker in the Balkan negotiations and that therefore the factions should resume their stalled peace talks in New York. As Mr. Clinton told reporters after the announcement, "We think if we do it we will be able to create a somewhat better climate for negotiations."
All week, as he inched toward this announcement, Mr. Clinton has tried to assure a public wary of getting entangled in the Balkans that the operation would not embroil Americans in conflict. He reinforced that today, telling reporters that the "the risk is quite limited and not appreciably more than training flights."
 
Carrier Standing By
 But given the history of this conflict and the number of military elements fighting in the Balkan war, no one can insure safety. Pentagon officials said that while the air transports would not have fighter-jet escorts, a Marine amphibious unit and the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy would be standing by in the Adriatic Sea.
Although it is a relief operation, the airdrops constitute the deepest American involvement yet in the Balkan conflict and the first major intervention abroad undertaken by the Clinton Administration.
Mr. Clinton, who spent the day selling his economic program, chose not to announce personally either the airdrop or the scheduling of a summit meeting with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia. Officials said this was deliberate, so voters would not think he was following his predecessor, George Bush, and getting overly absorbed in foreign affairs.
 
Emergency Need Cited
 In a statement released by the White House, Mr. Clinton said that "in view of the emergency humanitarian need," the United States would conduct relief airdrops over Bosnia in coordination with the United Nations and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, which now supervise the overland convoys. The exact timing and targets of the operations will also be worked out with the United Nations.
"The war that has raged in Bosnia-Herzegovina over the past year has taken a staggering toll," Mr. Clinton said, finally ending a week of speculation about the operation. "Thousands have been killed or imprisoned, thousands more are at risk due to hunger and exposure, and over two million people have been forced from their homes."
He said that the need for food and medicine was greatest in eastern Bosnia, and that "priority for air deliveries will be determined without regard to ethnic or religious affiliation." Most of the estimated 200,000 people living in the isolated areas are Muslims.
"These airdrops are being carried out strictly for humanitarian purposes," he added. "No combat aircraft will be used in this operation."
 
'A Temporary Measure'
 The President acknowledged that the convoys remain the best way to deliver aid, and said the airdrops were "a temporary measure, designed to address the immediate needs of isolated areas that cannot be reached at this time by ground."
Pentagon officials said each of the airdrops would include from three to five C-130 transports, preceded by MC-130 special operations planes, which carry electronic equipment for detecting antiaircraft fire. Each plane will carry 15 or 16 one-ton bundles of medical supplies, flour, cooking oil, coffee beans, rice and United States Army rations, and should be able to make the trip without refueling.
Mr. Clinton was asked if other countries would take part in the mission; all he would say was that there were "several volunteers." Britain and France, which have been delivering supplies by land, have shown no interest in airdrops, but they both endorsed the Clinton initiative.
Germany, Russia and Turkey, which have the ability to deliver aid by air, were apparently ruled out because of Germany's wartime links with Croatia, Russia's historical ties with Serbia and Turkey's sympathies with the Muslims. Their participation might have aroused suspicion among the factions that weapons, not food, would be dropped. Germany's tacit cooperation will be needed, though, since the flights will originate from the Rhein-Main base in Germany.
 
Dole Praises Operation
 Senator George J. Mitchell, the majority leader, and Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader, both issued statements praising the operation.
"It is a small step, but it is the right step," Senator Dole said. "There's no military edge to it. It's a humanitarian gesture."
Former Defense Secretary Dick Cheney expressed some doubts about it, saying it would be a "terrible mistake" for the United States to get drawn into the Balkan conflict. "It appears certainly to have symbolic significance," he said in an interview on the NBC News program "Today." "Whether or not it's an effective way to deliver humanitarian supplies remains to be seen."

HEADLINE: 'Strategic' Goats Gobble Up Trade Subsidy

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MENARD, Tex., Feb. 24

 BODY:
Here on a stony meadow in West Texas, at the end of 10 miles of unpaved road through mesquite-covered, coyote-infested scrub land, several hundred bearers of a strategic commodity of the United States of America are gathered.
They are goats. 
 "Woody, woody, woody, yip!" cries Bob Rieck, a rancher, as he calls the milling herd of angora goats to a feeding of high-protein cottonseed while his border collie, Traveler, chases after strays.
Of all the disputes that President Clinton faces with the end of the cold war, perhaps none is as strange as the plight of the nation's mohair ranchers.
 
'Strategic' Goods for Soviets
 At the end of the Korean War, the ranchers persuaded Congress to include them in a strategic commodity program for sheep wool. But because the military has had dwindling use for mohair, the ranchers ended up sending three-fifths of their subsidized annual production by 1990 to the Soviet Union through intermediaries who produced scarves, caps and overcoats.
The demise of the Soviet Union the next year has cut sales and led, in an odd reversal of the peace dividend, to increases in the Federal subsidies for owners of the greasy, inbred herds.
Payments to ranchers have soared to an estimated $3.60 for every $1 of mohair sold to manufacturers last year from 88.2 cents in 1987. The nation's 10,000 mohair ranchers collected $50 million in subsidies in 1991, and falling market prices last year have sent the subsidy cost even higher.
As part of the economic plan he announced on Feb. 17, President Clinton proposed to reduce their Federal wool and mohair subsidies to a maximum of $50,000 per producer, from $150,000 now. The Clinton Administration estimates that together with a similar cut in maximum payments for sheep wool, the changes could save $212 million over four years.
Some members of Congress want more. Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, said: "I've been trying to eliminate this program for three or four years. It's one of the most wasteful Government subsidies there is."
Decisions about the program do not just affect the nation's mohair ranchers. While most mohair is now exported to Taiwan, a fifth of the nation's production is consumed domestically as $150 mohair sweaters, $500 mohair suits and even a few $350 mohair teddy bears.
The decisions also affect the makers of skin-cream products that millions of Americans smear on their hands and faces. Body grease accounts for nearly a third of the weight of freshly cut mohair, and it is purified to make lanolin for these skin creams. Fresh mohair is so greasy that, at shearing time, affluent ranchers and mohair merchants sometimes wave their farmhands aside and stamp the mohair into burlap sacks themselves, to oil their finely carved boots.
Not surprisingly, national polls showing broad support for the Clinton economic plan do not seem to reflect opinions in the wind-swept hamlets here, where the few small oil wells no longer earn much money for their owners and where the grass is too sparse for cattle more demanding than goats.
"We want to do our part, do our best, but we don't want to get killed on something that people in Washington don't understand," said Armer F. Earwood, a rancher in Sonora who has a goat etched into the glass of his front door and has hung a huge painting of five goats over his fireplace.
 
'We're a Victim'
 Ranchers say the program is now needed for rural development. They contend that this year is a particularly bad time to cut subsidies because they are struggling to cope not only with the loss of the Soviet market but with sharply higher costs and a mohair import tariff increase by China in 1991 that virtually shut down American sales to another large foreign market.
"We're a victim, so what do you do with the U.S. mohair industry; do you let it go downhill or do you support it?" asked Mr. Rieck.
Rising labor costs have hit the industry especially hard, because of a Federal ban in 1986 on the employment of illegal aliens. Ranchers contend that their former farmhands are worse off now in Mexican border factories.
Ford Oglesby Jr., a second-generation rancher from El Dorado, said: "They pay them $5 a day. We used to pay them $10 or $15 and give them all their food and such." Mr. Oglesby, who wrote many of the nation's wool and mohair subsidy program regulations during a five-year stint at the Agriculture Department that started during the Korean War, added, "Of course, I know things are changing, and we need to change."
Ranchers say that subsidy cuts would force them to slaughter goats, leaving them unable to respond if demand for mohair bounces back or if output in South Africa, the only large foreign producer, continues to decline because of drought, political turbulence and new limits on government subsidies there.
If thinned because of shrinking Federal subsidies, the herds would be very hard to rebuild. All American angora goats descend from four imported from Turkey in 1845. As a result, they are so inbred that they are plagued by infertility and miscarriages.
Further bred for thick hair, the American goats are so shaggy that they have trouble running away from coyotes, and sometimes bump into trees when the hair grows over their eyes shortly before the semiannual shearings.
 
Uniforms and Blankets
 But once cleaned, the hair consists of strong, lustrous fibers that hold heat well and can absorb a third of their weight in water without becoming soggy. Mohair cloth holds a crisp crease, which made it popular for military dress uniforms for many years, while mohair blankets were sometimes issued because they were warm and lightweight.
But the subsidies continue even though the military use of mohair is now limited to some braids on dress uniforms and the embroidery on some officers' hats. In 1991, the most recent year for which figures are available, the Agriculture Department paid $50 million in subsidies for $20.9 million worth of mohair production. Mohair now sells for 75 cents a pound, down from $2.63 in 1987.
The cost of the subsidies have soared because market prices have collapsed, partly because mohair went out of fashion in the late 1980's as well as because of the Soviet Union's collapse. Yet the Agriculture Department continues to guarantee mohair producers a fixed price based on a complex formula of average farm costs in recent years and in the late 1950's. The formula, which is unique in American agriculture, locks in profits by virtually insuring that prices rise as fast as costs.
Less than 1 percent of the nation's wool and mohair ranchers received more than half of all payments for the two commodities in 1991, while a third of those ranchers received payments of $100 or less. Many of the small mohair payments went to Navajos in Utah, Arizona, New Mexico and Colorado, while almost all of the large payments came to West Texas, where five-sixths of the nation's mohair is produced.
Mr. Rieck, who receives about $30,000 a year in Federal payments, said President Clinton's reduction in payment caps to $50,000 would actually save the Federal Government very little money. He said large ranchers would break up their herds among their families to collect several payments, or would sell the goats to smaller ranchers who could continue to collect payments on them.

HEADLINE: U.S. Study of Drug Makers Criticizes 'Excess Profits'

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
A Congressional study of the costs of pharmaceutical development in the United States said today that even using the industry's own numbers and allowing for a substantial profit, drug companies still make "excess profits" totaling more than $2 billion a year.
The profits were excessive, the study said, in the sense that compared with other high-technology, high-risk industries that are also dependent on scientific research, like electronics, the returns in the drug business are higher by two to three percentage points a year. The study's data indicate that drug companies' average profits are in the range of 13 to 14 percent. 
 The study by the Office of Technology Assessment, a bipartisan Congressional agency, was commissioned by Representatives Henry Waxman, Democrat of California, and John Dingell, Democrat of Michigan. Mr. Waxman has been a primary critic of the drug industry.
The lead author of the study said that after four years of analysis by government, industry and consumer experts, the conclusion was that "the market for prescription drugs is broken." The authors of the study said the companies were free of constraints largely because doctors and patients had been unaware of the prices of drugs they prescribed and took.
The chief industry trade group, the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, responded principally with the argument that the price increases and high profits depicted in the report were more typical of past years.
Robert Allnutt, executive vice president of the association, said in a news conference today that prices in the last year rose only about 50 percent more than inflation, the lowest increase in 15 years, and that he expected future price increases to would be even less because of the President's health-care proposals.
"High financial returns are necessary to induce companies to invest in researching new chemical entities," Mr. Allnutt said. "The study comes to inaccurate conclusions that simply do not pertain to the marketplace or industry today."
 
'Where to Look for Cuts'
 Representative Waxman, chairman of the House Health and Environment subcommittee, said at a news conference today that the report was the most comprehensive on the subject, and "tells us why drug prices are so high."
"Competition simply does not work in the market for prescription drugs," he said. "That is why prescription drugs are no longer affordable in this country."
The report, Mr. Waxman said, "tells us where to look for cuts: the excess profits which appear to be as high as $2 billion per year; the $10 billion per year spent on wasteful and detrimental advertising and promotion; the billions of dollars spent on research and development for drugs that offer no therapeutic gain."
 
Drug Industry's Response
 Mr. Allnutt of the drug makers' association said he did not dispute the methods or the numbers in the report. But he took issue with the phrase "excess profits" used by the Office of Technology Assessment, which he said might soon be transformed into "excessive profits" by advocates of price controls.
He said the report's authors, in estimating profits, should not have considered the tax breaks the industry actually received in the past. Instead, he said, they should have looked at the lower tax breaks that might be expected in the future, in order to make more realistic estimates of present-day profits.
"We can expect ferocious price competition for our products from President Clinton's proposal," he said, "That's the future. It is the past that the O.T.A. looked at."
Mr. Allnutt said that basing new policies on data from the 1980's would be like building a Pentagon budget on the assumptions of a cold war world. He also noted that 10 large companies have now voluntarily agreed to keep their price increases to the level of the Consumer Price Index, which marks the level of general inflation.
"The price increases in the industry are the lowest in the last 15 years," he said. "In the last 12 months it was 5.1 percent. That is very different from what was going on in the 1970's and 1980's."
 
Data on Rate of Increase
 Senator David Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas, recently released figures on the increase in drug prices, which indicate that at the producer level prices went up 128 percent in the drug industry between 1980 and 1992, while producer prices increased only 22 percent for all products.
In 1992, the drug increases were smaller, but still four times the increase for other products. The Producer Price Index rose 1.5 percent last year, and for the drug industry alone it rose 6.4 percent.
The Office of Technology Assessment's report found little relationship between drug prices and the level of competition. One chart in the report, for example, shows that even after patent protection ends for drugs and they face competition from cheaper, generic versions, their prices do not fall. Instead, the report said, the prices continue to rise.
These are among the report's other conclusions:
*"Pharmaceutical research and development is a costly and risky business, but in recent years the financial rewards from R.& D. have more than offset its costs and risks."
*The full, after-tax cost of bringing a drug to market was $194 million, including the cost of capital. Although the industry had previously estimated the number at $259 million, Mr. Allnutt did not disagree with the new estimate.
*"In each year from 1976 through 1987, economic returns in R.& D.-intensive pharmaceutical companies were about two to three percentage points higher than those of firms in other industries" that have similar high-risk investments.
*On average, each new drug introduced to the United States market during a sample period, 1981 to 1983, will earn "at least $36 million more for its investors over its product life than is needed to pay off the R.& D. investment; this surplus return amounts to about 4.3 percent of the price of each drug over its entire product life."
*The report estimates that drug companies spend an average of about 22.5 percent of total sales on advertising and promotion. Mr. Alnutt did not dispute the number, or the estimate by Mr. Waxman that the industry spent more money on promotion than on research.
*Drug companies spent most of its efforts and money on new drugs that offer no therapeutic advantage over existing drugs; about 58 percent of new drugs may be referred to as "me too" drugs. But Mr. Allnutt said that even "me too" drugs competed in races to the marketplace, resulting in winners and losers.
