HEADLINE: G.O.P. Vows to Cut $100 Billion From Clinton's Spending Proposal

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Amid a flurry of political bickering, Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader, said today that Senate Republicans would develop an alternative economic package that would slash $100 billion from the spending increases proposed by President Clinton.
Mr. Dole bristled at accusations by the Clinton Administration that Republicans are being obstructionists in criticizing the Clinton program without proposing specific cuts of their own. "It certainly does not make Republicans want to jump up and support the President if we have somebody in the communications department saying we are doing nothing but whining or carping," Mr. Dole said on the Senate floor. 
 Reminding the White House that the election campaign is over, the Kansas Republican added, "They ought to calm down, go out for a weekend, have a Diet Coke, enjoy yourself."
George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, replied, "I don't know if I'd agree with that, but it's very thoughtful advice."
 
Need for Something to Sell
 While several Republican lawmakers have come up with lists of spending cuts and alternative budget plans, the party has been slow to coalesce behind any one plan. Some Republican strategists have argued against proposing a single list of cuts, fearing they could attract the rage of special interests away from the Clinton plan. But others say the party needs something to sell as it tells Americans that the President's program will merely tax them without tackling the deficit.
Senator Dole said the Republican Party would come up with a detailed alternative, but he first wanted to see the details of the President's budget. "For starters, there is $178 billion in new spending -- we can certainly cut that back by $100 billion or so," he said in an attempt to express the broad outlines of a Republican alternative.
Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, a leading Republican spokesman on economic affairs, announced a budget amendment he said he would introduce with Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, enforcing the discretionary spending caps of the 1990 budget agreement and slashing all new spending, income taxes, energy taxes and Social Security taxes in the Administration's program. "This is an amendment that would eliminate tax and spend," Mr. Gramm said.
 
The Democrats' Response
 Mr. Stephanopoulos dismissed the proposal, saying, "It's just simply the same old thing from the Republicans, and I don't think the American people elected Bill Clinton to pass the Bush 1990 economic plan."
For their part, House Democrats unleashed their own attack on an economic program offered recently by Mr. Gramm and Representative Richard Armey of Texas, chairman of the House Republican Conference, proposing an overall limit on automatic spending programs like Social Security and Medicare in an effort to reach a balanced budget by the year 2000.
Representative Mike Synar of Oklahoma, chairman of the House Democratic Study Group, said the plan was evidence that the Republican Party was being taken over by "radical libertarians" who want to destroy the modern Government.

HEADLINE: In Test of Serbia Embargo, U.S. Presses to Seize a Ship

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
In a test of the West's ability to enforce the embargo on trade with Serbia, the Clinton Administration has urged its allies to seize a Greek-owned ship that recently delivered goods to Yugoslavia.
American officials have alerted the NATO allies, North African countries and other nations in the Mediterranean to seize the Dimitrakis, a Greek-owned ship that is sailing under the Maltese flag, when it comes into port. 
 The seizure is necessary, the United States has told its allies, to demonstrate that the United Nations sanctions on Serbia "have teeth" and that violators will be punished.
 
Hard to Enforce
 The case of the Dimitrakis shows the difficulty Western nations have coordinating their efforts to enforce sanctions even as the Clinton Administration and key allies have stressed they are stepping up their efforts to police the trade embargo.
The hunt for the Dimitrakis comes as the United States is asking nations to impound another ship that has evaded the embargo. American officials said the Bana One, which is believed to be carrying Serbian weapons intended for Somalia, left the African coast and is headed for Singapore under a Honduran flag.
The story of the Dimitrakis began last month, when the ship steamed into the Adriatic, where NATO ships and ships from the Western European Union have been enforcing the trade sanctions against Yugoslavia.
The captain of the Dimitrakis said he was headed for Koper, Slovenia. But then the captain signaled that the vessel was in distress and needed to make an emergency stop at Bar in Montenegro. Clinton Administration officials say the ship delivered a supply of petroleum coke, which is used to refine oil, and took on a supply of lumber.
The United States wanted the vessel seized. And after the vessel left port, Italian warships seized it and towed it to Brindisi, Italy.
 
Denied Violating Sanctions
 The captain denied violating the sanctions, asserting that his cargo was confiscated and that the timber had come from Bosnia. But American officials say that is a cover story and that the timber came from Serbia.
The United States wanted the matter brought before the United Nations Sanctions Committee, established to monitor the sanctions. But the Italian Navy recently let the ship go.
American officials say Washington complained to Italy through diplomatic channels.
"We are seeking further clarification concerning the release," a senior State Department official said. "We do not like the fact that it was released."
Italian Government agencies have provided various explanations to Washington. The Italian Foreign Ministry said it was initially unaware that the vessel had left Brindisi until Washington raised the matter. The Italian Foreign Ministry said the decision was made by a local magistrate.
The head of the Italian fleet, however, said the Italian Navy let the ship go after Italian officials consulted with the United Nations and determined that there was no proof that the sanctions had been violated, an Administration official said.
 
No Official Protest
 Luca Giansanti, a spokesman for the Italian Embassy, said the Italian Defense Ministry takes the position that there was no reason to hold the ship since its papers were in order. Mr. Giansanti also said Washington has not lodged an official protest with Rome.
Washington has put out an all-points bulletin to nations in the region asking them to seize the Greek-owned vessel and impound its cargo when it comes into port, saying this is an important test of United Nations sanctions. It also has told Greece that it believes that those responsible for the violation should be prosecuted.
A Clinton Administration spokesman declined to say why the United States has not halted the ship or whether it might try to do so.
The Administration has also requested countries to detain the Bana One when it comes into port. The United States believes that the Belgrade Government is exporting the weapons in order to raise funds and purchase goods in violation of the economic sanctions.
Yugoslavia's Defense Ministry said today that Washington's assertions were part of a propaganda campaign to increase pressure on Serbia.
"Our country has for a long time exported significant amounts of modern, high-quality weapons and military equipment," Belgrade said in a statement. "Given this fact, one should not exclude the possibility of finding a certain amount of this weaponry even today planted in some cargo vessel so an inference can be drawn that we are exporting weaponry in spite of the United Nations embargo."

HEADLINE: New Boston Garden Plan Finally Gets Green Light

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
After being deluged by calls, letters and petitions from sports-minded Bostonians, the Massachusetts Legislature passed a bill tonight allowing construction of a new sports arena to replace the 65-year-old Boston Garden, home of the basketball Celtics and the hockey Bruins.
The agreement clears the way for construction to begin in June on a $160 million arena, which will offer fans air-conditioning and seats with better views. The project will employ 700 construction workers.
 
Earlier Plan Collapsed
 The Legislature's action came less than two weeks after plans to replace the Garden collapsed when the developer backed out of the deal, contending that politicians had made unfair last-minute changes in the contract. 
 A series of meetings this week between the new arena's developer, Jeremy M. Jacobs, and legislative leaders produced an agreement, which Mr. Jacobs also approved, Lawrence C. Moulter, president of New Boston Garden Corporation, said. The new arena will be adjacent to the Garden's current location and above North Station, which is also being rebuilt.
"This is great news for fans of the Bruins and Celtics, great news for people employed at the Garden, and great news for the Massachusetts economy," Gov. William F. Weld said in a written statement. He is expected to sign the bill Friday.
 
No 'Linkage Payments'
 The legislation does not include $3.5 million in so-called linkage payments to support public swimming pools and skating rinks, a requirement Mr. Jacobs had objected to. But it does require that the Garden be available at least three times a year for charity events to benefit the commission that oversees state recreation facilities, and it requires Mr. Jacobs's company, Delaware North, to contribute $10 million to help build the adjacent train station.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
With the prospect of a new energy tax, executives in many industries are beginning to contemplate how to adjust their business strategies, pricing policies and operating plans. Some industries where energy costs are significant could be severely affected. Others could be helped. Auto makers, for example, estimate that higher gasoline prices will spur sales of smaller cars. [D1.]
Some of Japan's biggest brokerage firms were accused of violating securities laws in the United States. Yamaichi, Daiwa, Nomura and Nikko were charged with reimbursing the losses of favored customers, hiding millions in foreign-exchange losses and fraudulently buying Treasury securities. [D1.] 
 Falling mortgage rates have shaken mortgage lenders out of their traditional winter doldrums, with February applications up 30 percent from January at major institutions. [D1.]
Mutual funds that invest in municipal bonds are taking in cash from Americans at the fastest pace in history. And so are funds that invest in common stocks. [D2.]
Most states are emerging from the recession and planning their first budgets in years without big tax increases or deep cuts in programs. But they are not reducing taxes. [A16.]
 
Companies
Drug companies are making excessive profits in comparison with other high-risk industries, partly because of lack of price constraints on prescription drugs, a Congressional study says. [D1.]
The $1.7 billion General Motors fund paying benefits to about 14,000 laid-off auto workers will run out of money on March 1. But a second fund will take over payments. [D3.]
First Chicago will sell a large chunk of its troubled commercial real estate portfolio to GE Capital for 50 cents on the dollar, or a total of $500 million. [D3.]
American Airlines will "reluctantly" comply with a Justice Department consent decree that prohibits carriers from giving advance notice to travel agencies of fare changes. [D3.]
American International reported a surprising 7 percent gain in 1992 earnings, and Equitable had a lower operating loss despite a year of huge property casualty insurance claims. [D3.]
Grubb & Ellis appointed a permanent president and chief executive, replacing a temporary executive. [D3.]
 
International
The head of a huge Italian construction group was placed under house arrest in a widening scandal involving payoffs to politicians. Earlier, two senior Fiat executives were arrested and jailed. [A5.]
 
Markets
A record amount of new corporate issues flooded the bond market as borrowers continued to scramble to take advantage of low interest rates. The Treasury bond's yield was unchanged. [D1.]
Computer stocks led the stock market, offsetting declines in medical and biotechnology issues. The Dow gained 8.64 points and the Nasdaq advanced 4.61. [D4.]
Heating oil and natural gas prices jumped amid frigid temperatures in much of the nation. [D14.]
The dollar was mixed in advance of a key economic report and the Group of Seven meeting. Gold prices rose. [D14.]
 
Today's Columns
Investors continued a selloff of biotech stocks, prompted by bad news from Amgen, which said its first-quarter sales and earnings would be well below Wall Street expectations. [D4.]
A prominent creative executive is returning to her roots, leaving a big New York agency to join Frankfurt Gips Balkind. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D15.]

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Draw a Rush Of Investors

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Mutual funds that invest in municipal bonds are taking in cash from Americans at the fastest pace in history. And so are funds that invest in common stocks.
"On the bond side, it's muni-mania," Bruce Speca, an executive with the TNE Fund Group, said yesterday. He said February would be the best month ever for his group, largely because of the surge in sales of municipal bond funds. 
 Those municipal fund sales have been stimulated by talk of much higher top tax rates. President Clinton's economic plan would increase the top marginal rate from 31 percent to 39.6 percent.
In January, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday, municipal bond funds had a net cash flow of $4.4 billion, topping the old record of $4.1 billion set in January 1987, shortly before the last big bull market in bonds came to a halt.
That same report by the trade group showed that cash flow into equity funds topped $10 billion in a month for the first time ever, at $10.2 billion. The previous record, of $9.9 billion, had been set in November.
Equity fund sales also seem to have picked up in February, notwithstanding the extraordinary jerkiness of the stock market this month. "Our equity fund sales were up 23 percent in February," said Donald Webber of State Street Research, a mutual fund company.
And there are indications it will continue. The University of Michigan survey of investors, conducted for Fidelity Investments, found that 57 percent of those who own mutual funds said they planned to buy shares in an equity fund within the next three months, while just 1 percent said they planned to sell. The purchase figure was the highest in the history of the survey, which began in 1990.
For much of the last few months, the big story in the stock market was the strong performance of small stocks, mostly traded on Nasdaq. As the cash flowed into aggressive growth mutual funds, the managers who ran the funds had trouble putting it all to work, and the cash positions of those funds grew steadily, from $7.8 billion at the end of September to $9.8 billion at the end of the year. But in January, those managers managed to invest some of that cash, and the amount fell to $9.5 billion.
That drop in available cash may have played a role in the weakness of small stocks over the last couple of weeks. But the signs are that mutual fund investors continue to like the sector. In January, $2.2 billion poured into aggressive growth funds, down slightly from $2.3 billion in December and less than the record of $2.8 billion set in November.
The two categories of less aggressive general equity funds set records. Cash flow into growth funds came to $3.4 billion, while the flow into growth and income funds hit $3 billion.

HEADLINE: Grumbling But Loyal To Clinton

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARREN, Mich., Feb. 24

 BODY:
The disenchanted Democrats here who abandoned their party in Presidential politics for more than a decade but returned last November to vote for Bill Clinton are still behind the new President, although cautiously.
A sounding of public opinion in shopping malls, coffee shops and on snow-swept sidewalks suggests that most voters are wavering between a wait-and-see attitude and strong support for Mr. Clinton and his economic program of tax increases, spending cuts and "shared sacrifice." 
 One important factor in their support is that most do not see the plan as a threat to them personally, usually because their incomes are too low.
 
'For the Working Man'
 "Clinton is more for the working man," said Kurt Hipchen, a 39-year-old sheet-metal worker who stopped with his wife to chat on the way to a movie. "He is the Democrat we have needed that we didn't have before. He offers more fair ideas and seemed more logical than the other candidates."
The Hipchens were among the Democrats here, and in similar industrial communities nationwide, who were lured to vote Republican by Ronald Reagan and had not returned to their party until last fall. These "Reagan Democrats" were the crucial component in the coalition that Mr. Clinton constructed to win. Their continuing support is now just as crucial to the new President's hopes of pushing his program through Congress.
Mr. Hipchen, and his wife, Ruthann, 35, said they did not know for sure how they would be affected by his plan, but they remained loyal. "I am very, very happy with Clinton," Ms. Hipchen said. "I hope he goes eight years."
 
Skepticism Easy to Find
 With the help of the Hipchens, Mr. Clinton carried this Detroit suburb of 145,000, as he did the State of Michigan, but he lost surrounding Macomb County. Some of the region's lingering skepticism emerged in more than two dozen interviews with Reagan Democrats.
Eddie Kincheloe, 57, said he was pleased that "people making a lot of money will get hit hardest," but he said raising taxes on anyone makes him nervous because, sooner or later, higher taxes "will be coming my way."
Mr. Kincheloe said that if he works hard this year he might make $15,000 selling family portraits in a Warren mall. "I exist, that's about all you can call it," he said.
But Dave Howard, the 40-year-old owner of a craft shop, is more typical. He said he does not make enough money to worry about paying more income taxes, but that if he must pay $150 to $200 more a year under a new energy tax, he is willing.
"Most people I've talked to have resigned themselves that raising taxes is necessary," he said. "Everybody needs to put in a little bit. I'd give Clinton an 'A' for effort and an incomplete for results."
 
Ready for 'Bitter Pill'
 Similarly, Emil Stewart, a 68-year-old bookkeeper, said he makes less than $30,000 a year, and therefore was not bothered by Mr. Clinton's program. Mr. Clinton has said his tax proposals would have their heaviest impact on families with incomes of $180,000 or more a year, and he has promised that families with incomes below $30,000 annually would feel virtually no effect.
As a nation, Mr. Stewart said, "We are going to have to swallow a bitter pill" to ease the deficit. Mr. Stewart also said Mr. Clinton's proposals seemed fairer than the programs of the Reagan and Bush Administrations.
Not all Reagan Democrats are blue-collar. Charles Leibel, 51, made as much as $60,000 a year in the 1980's as a supervisor at a company that made tractor-trailers, and he voted Republican in national elections. After Wall Street crashed in the late 1980's, he lost one job and then another and lived on unemployment for seven months.
"The supposed good times of the Reagan years really weren't very good for my family," said Mr. Leibel, who is finishing law school and earns about $22,000 working in a law firm. He voted for Mr. Clinton and called his program "a realistic approach to get us out of a mess it took 12 years to create."
"But I'd like to see more overall budget cuts before the taxes take place," he said. Mr. Leibel said he and his wife, Grace, a former teacher now working as a discount store clerk, make about $30,000 a year together and will not be seriously taxed.
 
Bracing for a Pinch
 Maryann Musial, a retired nurse, and her husband, Ted, a retired school administrator, are not wealthy but expect to feel the tax pinch. Their family income is $70,000.
Mrs. Musial said she has no regrets yet. "I have a lot of good friends who are worried about their incomes, but something has to be done," Mrs. Musial, 61, said. "I think his ideas are good."
Robert Lent, the 35-year-old manager of a printing company, said he was happy so far with most of Mr. Clinton's economic package, although he said he thought the President had become sidetracked too long on the issue of homosexuals in the military.
"It's important," said Mr. Lent, who is a veteran, "but he can help the gays, the straights, the blacks, the whites much more by getting this country moving again."
Although Mr. Lent praised the President, he added he had never believed during the campaign that Mr. Clinton would not raise taxes on the middle class. "It's not the first time we've heard a politician say they weren't going to raise taxes," Mr. Lent said. "But I don't mind one bit if he taxes the wealthy."
 
'Comrade Clinton'?
 Still, there are voters who are bitter. One termed the President "Comrade Clinton." Another man pulled his wife away by the hand, saying that after four years of Mr. Clinton the whole country would vote Republican.
As far as Catherine Gwizdala, a 79-year-old housewife living on a fixed income, is concerned, Mr. Clinton has failed the test. She said she and her husband, who watched as the Detroit automakers eliminated thousands of jobs, voted for Mr. Clinton because they wanted to see people back to work.
But when Mr. Clinton talked about more taxes, she became angry, even though she would not be greatly affected. "I think he has taken back all of his promises just to get where he is," she said. "I am very disappointed."
Her husband is in a nursing home and receives $600 a month from Social Security. She gets $200. "We can't afford to be taxed any more," she said.
 
Thinks She Made Mistake
 Helen Kaminsky, 72, said she was a loyal Democrat until Ronald Reagan, then she voted for Republicans in three elections. Last year, she liked what Mr. Clinton had to say about change and not taxing the middle class, so she returned to the Democratic Party.
"I think I made a mistake," she said. "He's hurting the little people. I was for change, but it seems like it's getting worse every day."
Mrs. Kaminsky and her husband of 53 years, Edward, said they receive no benefits from the tiny steel company they both retired from. Instead, they have to pay their own Blue Cross coverage of $310 a month. She said she cannot afford to pay a penny more in taxes or other costs.
Louis Gula, 72, retired from a job putting up billboards, said he remembered when there were manufacturing jobs for almost everyone in Detroit, but that his son had been out of work more than three years before the election. "Now, we have heard it all, and it sounds good," he said. "Let's get action. Actions speak louder than words."

HEADLINE: More Americans Can Buy the Dream

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
When Karen and Seth Starr learned that they were going to have twins, their Upper West Side one-bedroom co-op started to look a bit cramped. Unhappy with the kind of house they could afford last year, they delayed buying.
But when mortgage interest rates fell sharply in the last few weeks, the couple pounced, agreeing on Tuesday to buy a house in Manhasset, L.I. 
 Yesterday, the Starrs sat in the basement of a Citibank branch on 46th Street signing a mortgage application. They were able to get a mortgage with a rate of 7.5 percent, which allowed them to spend $40,000 to $50,000 more on a house while keeping monthly payments within their budget, Mr. Starr, who is a tax planner for Morgan Stanley & Company, said.
"The lower interest rates allowed us to get a much nicer house," Mrs. Starr said.
The Starrs are but two of thousands of people who have inundated mortgage lenders recently as long-term interest rates have fallen to their lowest levels in years. At banks all over the metropolitan area, the lower interest rates have shaken lenders out of their traditional winter doldrums, with February applications up 30 percent from January at major institutions.
"Housing is more affordable than it has been at any time since the 1970's," said Ephraim Feuer, the head of home mortgages for the Republic National Bank of New York. "That is causing a lot more people to look at buying a home." Republic has seen the volume of mortgage applications jump by one third in the last two weeks.
As it was a year ago, much of this business is existing homeowners trying to take advantage of the lower rates. More significant for the long term, however, the number of people like the Starrs seeking mortgages on new home purchases is up sharply over last year, bankers said.
"Thirty percent of what we are doing is home purchases," Kim Smith, the Citibank vice president in charge of the Manhattan mortgage sales office, said. "We haven't seen that kind of volume in a long time."
 
Drawing First-Time Buyers
 Rates are low and real estate prices have stabilized, she said, and this combination was drawing first-time home buyers into the market.
"Renters are starting to see that the economics makes sense to buy a co-op," Ms. Smith said. "And when the owners can sell their co-ops they will buy houses. The whole market seems to move with the lower rates because everyone has increased buying power."
Even though the Starrs expected to sell their co-op for far less than they paid for it, Mrs. Starr, who works in sales for a computer software company, said it did not trouble her. "Rates have come down so much, that's why I'm not crying as much over our loss," she said.
Outside the Citibank conference room, half a dozen bankers who specialize in home mortgages were working phones following up on the surge in inquiries that have poured in over the last few weeks. And those inquiries are turning into applications quickly. "In January, I sourced $1.5 million in business; so far in February I've done $4.7 million," James Towers, a mortgage salesman, said.
Many of those who are refinancing are those who did not do so last year, Donna J. Dieterle, Citibank's vice president for mortgage sales in the metropolitan region, said. "A lot of people who had been kicking themselves because they didn't refinance when rates were low last year have a second chance," she said.
But as rates fall further, even those that did take advantage of the lower rates last year could save money by refinancing again. "There are some refinance addicts who are refinancing for the second time in a year," Ms. Dieterle said.
Not only are the volumes higher, so are the sizes. The average mortgage application this month has been for $180,000, up from $150,000 in January. Ms. Dieterle speculated that one reason for the jump might be that more affluent people, worried about the proposed tax increases, were looking for the mortgage interest deductions.
Yet this boom is not without its problems for bankers who have to manage the level of staff in a business where volume is tied to the roller coaster of interest rates.
"A month ago at staff meetings we were trying to figure out what we could cut if volume stayed that low," said Patrick J. McEnerney, a regional vice president at the Bank of New York Mortgage Company. "Now the conversation is how many people do we need to add."

HEADLINE: Clinton Suggests 'Sin Tax' Increases May Be Used to Finance New Health-Care Plan

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
President Clinton strongly suggested for the first time today that he would propose higher taxes on tobacco to pay for his health-care program, and his advisers said they had long planned for such a tax.
Mr. Clinton addressed the idea of a tobacco tax increase as he continued his drive for support for his economic proposals. He appeared with two dozen business and labor leaders who endorsed the overall program that he presented to Congress last week. 
 Administration officials have floated the idea of a tax on tobacco, alcohol or some other "sin tax" for some time, but the President's comments today marked the first time he had spoken about the issue.
Asked by reporters whether he would rule out "sin taxes" because they were seen by some as an unfair burden on the middle class, Mr. Clinton replied: "I think health-related taxes are different. I think cigarette taxes, for example, are different.
"Why?" he continued. "Because I think that we are spending a ton of money in private insurance and in Government tax payments to deal with the health-care problems occasioned by bad health habits, and particularly smoking, which is costing us a lot of money."
 
No Decisions Yet
 George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said later that the President had made no decisions on which additional taxes he would propose. "I don't think I'm going to make a policy of commenting on any taxes that the President hasn't proposed," he said.
But Mr. Stephanopoulos made no effort to distance the White House from the idea of a tobacco tax, in contrast to strenuous efforts by officials last week to minimize Mr. Clinton's suggestion that a national sales tax might be needed soon.
And Leon E. Panetta, the White House budget director, said in an interview that officials who drafted the economic program specifically excluded new tobacco and alcohol taxes because they were saving those as a means of helping to pay for the health proposal. Mr. Panetta echoed the President in saying it made sense to put extra taxes on things that by their nature create health problems.
Though his advisers have discussed higher taxes on alcohol as well as cigarettes, Mr. Clinton later sought to emphasize that his comments were about cigarettes, not an alcohol tax. "We didn't say that," he said of an alcohol levy when asked about it during a picture-taking session. "I specifically passed up a chance to say that today."
Polls have shown that as far as taxes go, "sin taxes" are well received by the public. Administration officials have also considered a tax on workers' health benefits to help pay for Mr. Clinton's proposal to provide health care for uninsured Americans.
 
No Added Spending Cuts
 While Mr. Clinton said this week that he was considering more spending cuts, he was not willing today to respond to Republicans who were calling for him to propose such reductions immediately.
"Like what?" he asked a reporter. "Like what? I mean, unlike a lot of these other people, I worked for weeks and weeks and weeks on this budget."
The President went on to say: "I have a difficult time taking these people seriously who say we should have more spending cuts, who were here for the last 12 years. Where were they? Anyone can say whatever they want about more spending cuts, but why are you asking me? Why don't you ask them?"
Explaining that he was not ready now to lay out more cuts, Mr. Clinton said: "Some people think that we should abolish the Superconducting Supercollider, or the space station program. But I honestly don't agree with that."
Some of the many business and labor leaders who gathered at the Old Executive Office Building next to the White House to endorse Mr. Clinton's economic program had attended his conference on the economy in Little Rock, Ark., last December.
"We support the President's deficit reduction package as it now stands," said August A. Busch 3d, the president of the Anheuser-Busch Companies, who added that the President had a "bold approach."
While he said there was wide backing for the plan, Harold A. Poling, the chairman of the Ford Motor Company, said, "it is essential that spending cuts be approved at the same time as the tax program."
Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said the plan set the country "on the right course for the future," although he expressed concern about the one-year freeze on salaries of Federal employees.
In his address, Mr. Clinton repeated his promise that "I don't want new taxes unless we are going to have spending cuts."
There was a line missing, however, from the remarks he had made in recent appearances. He has cited the continued existence of the Bicentennial Commission, which was set up to coordinate activities for the 1976 Bicentennial, as an example of how the Government starts a program, then never stops it.
But after a report today in The Washington Post that the commission had been abolished last June and that $1.6 million in unspent money had been returned to the Treasury, the White House acknowledged that Mr. Clinton had been misinformed.
"He was ill-staffed," Mr. Stephanopoulos said.

HEADLINE: Clinton and Yeltsin to Hold Summit Meeting April 4

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Feb. 25

 BODY:
President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia will hold their first summit meeting on April 4, in a third country still undisclosed, the United States and Russia announced today.
The summit meeting, which is expected to be Mr. Clinton's first overseas trip as President, reflects what Administration officials said was his desire to bolster the standing of Mr. Yeltsin amid increasing challenges to his authority by Russians who oppose dramatic and sudden political changes. 
 The holding of a meeting is also described by officials as part of an evolving American approach that in the absence of major new economic aid, is intended to blend political, diplomatic and technical assistance and elevate Moscow to the level of a partner from that of a poor cousin of Washington.
Officials said that the summit meeting, which is likely to last only one day, is timed to provide crucial support for Mr. Yeltsin just one week before a Russian referendum on whether he or the Parliament that increasingly challenges him should wield more power and influence.
 
Little Said Since Election
 In the Presidential campaign last year, Mr. Clinton stated that "no national security issue is more urgent" than promoting reform in the former Soviet Union, but in his determination to remain focused on the domestic economy, has said nothing of substance on the subject since the election.
The announcement of the summit meeting was made here by Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev after three hours of meetings.
"It is of the utmost importance to the United States -- indeed to the world -- that President Yeltsin's reforms succeed," Mr. Christopher said at a joint news conference. "A strong and cooperative U.S.-Russian relationship of general partnership is of the highest priority for Mr. Clinton and his Administration."
Mr. Kozyrev described the summit meeting as "a major event that would make it possible" to broaden and speed up cooperation between the countries. He added that the American side suggested an even earlier date, but that the Russians felt they needed more time to prepare.
Mr. Christopher telephoned Mr. Clinton shortly after the meeting, and the President "stressed the importance of doing what we can to help reform succeed in the Soviet Union," a senior Administration said tonight.
 
No Pause in Policy
 To this end, Mr. Christopher assured his Russian counterpart that there would be no "pause" in American foreign policy the way there was when George Bush took office and his Administration began a review that froze policy for months.
One illustration of the American intention to elevate the Russians as negotiating partners came in another announcement today by the two officials. The United States and Russia, as co-sponsors of the Middle East peace negotiations, will invite the parties back to the negotiating table in April and will step up their role as "honest brokers" in the talks, the officials said.
Mr. Kozyrev also disclosed that the Russians would invite the Palestinians -- presumably a Palestine Liberation Organization delegation that could be led by Yasir Arafat -- to Moscow to persuade them to end their boycott of the talks.
Before Mr. Christopher left Jerusalem this morning, he gave reporters traveling with him no indication that the United States was ready to restart the talks by jointly issuing invitations with the Russians. In explaining why he did not do so today, he left the impression that it was a last-minute decision.
The United States had been "consulting closely with the Palestinians last night and again this morning, and all I can say at the present time is that we felt confident enough about the situation that we think the next round of negotiations should commence in April," he said, adding that the United States has been in contact with the Russians along the way.
Indeed, Mr. Christopher began working on the issue at 4 A.M., making phone calls to Israel and other countries and sending cablegrams to all the Middle Eastern leaders he visited to alert them to the expected announcement, a senior Administration official said.
 
Playing Down Deportee Issue
 Mr. Kozyrev today played down the significance of the 400 Palestinians deported by Israel to Lebanon in December. Their continued deportation has kept the Palestinians away from the talks.
Despite increasing pressure by nationalists to chart an independent course in Russia's foreign policy, Mr. Kozyrev, in another conciliatory gesture toward Washington, said Moscow approved of Mr. Clinton's plan to airdrop food into Bosnia and Herzegovina. It "goes in a positive direction," he said, adding that the world should "use all possible channels to deliver aid" through the United Nations.
But at the top of the Russian agenda today, and at the coming summit talks, will be what Russia says it needs to move along its reforms, including, among other things, its desire to reschedule its foreign debt of about $75 billion and to sell more of its conventional weapons to third countries. He argued that such arms sales, far from violating arms control agreements, would promote "overall stabilization" as long as the arms were sold to what he called "appropriate clients."
The United States is willing to help on the debt issue, senior Administration officials have said in recent weeks. The new Administration also intends to increase pressure on the the International Monetary Fund to treat Russia as a special case and loosen lending restrictions, and will move to strengthen the Group of Seven industrialized countries on Russian aid issues.
 
Arms Sales Opposed
 But the Administration has no intention of blessing Russian arms sales abroad, even though the United States continues to sell billions of dollars in conventional weapons to its allies. Mr. Christopher told Mr. Kozyrev that although the Administration has a strong commitment to keeping reform alive, it also has a strong commitment to non-proliferation, a senior Administration official said, adding, "There is a dilemma here and a potential conflict, but Secretary Christopher and Minister Kozyrev worked hard to at least establish where the two sides are."
Other arms control issues, particularly the arms treaty that was signed by President Bush and Mr. Yeltsin in Moscow in January, will also be discussed at the summit meeting.
Mr. Christopher also told Mr. Kozyrev that Mr. Clinton wants to discuss at the summit the human rights of the 25 million Russians living in the 14 other independent former Soviet republics, a senior Administration official said. The Secretary made no specific commitment on the amount of American aid the new Administration is prepared to give to Russia, adding that what really matters over the long run is to make Russia attractive to foreign investment.
Strobe Talbott, the Ambassador at Large for Russia and the other new nations, was in Geneva as a special consultant to Mr. Christopher, but did not attend any of the meetings because he has not been confirmed by the Senate.

Yeltsin will hold their first summit meeting in April. Mr. Christopher and Mr. Kozyrev talked to reporters yesterday after a meeting in Geneva. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Bracing for Shock of Energy Tax

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
The energy tax that President Clinton proposed last week would ripple through various industries in different ways. And from Maine to Washington State, executives are beginning to contemplate how to shift their strategies, pricing policies and operating plans to adjust to a tax on most energy consumption.
For some industries, energy represents a small fraction of costs. But for others, like aluminum manufacturing and airlines, it eats up a sizable share of revenues. Such a tax would also affect the cost of moving goods, and in some cases consumers' choices. Auto makers, for example, say a rise in gasoline prices of 8 cents a gallon or more by 1996 would spur sales of smaller cars. 
 The energy tax would be based on the energy content of nearly all fuels, as measured in British thermal units -- the heat required to raise the temperature of a pound of water by 1 degree Fahrenheit. The tax would be phased in starting next year and would take full effect in 1996.
Executives in some industries count on passing higher prices along to customers, but where that is not possible, they may have to pay for some of the tax out of their own earnings until they can cut costs. In industries like airlines and chemicals, market leaders say the extra tax will weigh heaviest on weaker rivals.
Here is a sampling of how executives in seven industries plan to cope if the energy tax becomes law:
 
Improving Mileage of Cars
Energy experts say Mr. Clinton's energy tax could add 8 to 12 cents to the price of a gallon of gasoline, and auto manufacturers and dealers expect that the tax will accelerate the shift by consumers toward smaller and more fuel-efficient cars. Some manufacturers, like the Ford Motor Company, were already beginning to look harder in that direction, and the tax could accelerate improvements in efficiency.
Ford, for example, said it was already gearing up to produce more of its smaller models, including the Ford Escort and Tempo and the Mercury Topaz, at the expense of bigger cars.
"The percentage of cars in the small end of the market will go up," said Dave Kulp, the company's manager of fuel-economy planning and compliance. He added, "We have available capacity to produce more."
Ford is also working on several design changes in aerodynamics, tires and transmissions to improve the fuel efficiency of all models, Mr. Kulp said.
 
Air Fares Likely to Rise
The nation's airlines have lost $6 billion in the last three years. Now they must calculate how much they can raise fares to recover increased jet-fuel taxes without losing too many passengers. In the short term, industry executives do not see much in the way of cost savings from more efficient engines or other improvements. The Air Transport Association estimates that the industry will pay $1.2 billion in higher costs when the tax reaches full force in 1997.
The tax would add "tens of millions of dollars" to costs at American Airlines, said Al Becker, a spokesman. Yet the nation's largest airline would not cancel flights or reduce service in other ways because of the tax alone, he said. "This energy tax is not going to persuade us to do something that we would not otherwise do," Mr. Becker said.
Southwest Airlines, the only profitable major airline in the last three years -- and the one with the lowest costs -- could possibly benefit if weaker carriers pull out of busy markets. "Obviously, when you are doing well and still growing, there is an advantage" when weaker carriers are forced to retreat, said Gary Kelly, chief financial officer of Southwest.

Utilities Plan to Pass Tax On
Utility executives, like those in other industries, are looking at a strategy of cutting costs and raising prices to cover the cost of a new energy tax.
In Michigan, which ranks No. 8 among the states in energy consumption, executives at the CMS Energy Corporation estimate that the proposed tax would push the company's costs up 5 percent. Including a higher corporate tax, costs would rise by a total of 7 percent. CMS provides electricity and natural gas to busineses and consumers in central Michigan.
William T. McCormick, the company's chairman, said CMS would pass the costs to customers through higher rates. Yet growth of demand will gradually slow or even decline because higher costs would make business customers less competitive. Then, he said, they "will not be able to afford as much energy."
Residential customers, though, normally do not cut back on heating, cooking, television viewing and other energy-consuming activities when prices rise, he said.
The Detroit Edison Company, which supplies electricity to 1.9 million customers in southeastern Michigan, said it would step up cost-cutting programs as one response to the Clinton energy tax.
Recent programs enabled the utility to pare electric bills by an average of 5 percent, starting last month. Still, Detroit Edison intends to charge customers for its rising costs from an energy tax, said Robert Dobkin, a spokesman. Most consumers will not cut consumption, he said, despite efforts by Detroit Edison to encourage conservation.
 
Truckers Plan to Cut Costs
The trucking industry anticipates a $3 billion increase in costs from the energy tax at a time when its yearly profits are about $5 billion.
William M. Clifford, president and chief excutive of the St. Johnsbury Trucking Company, in Holliston, Mass., estimated that the energy tax would add $90,000 a month to his company's costs. The privately held company, which ranks about 10th among the nation's trucking concerns, has yearly revenues of $300 million.
"It's a buyer's market, so we won't be able to pass on those costs to our customers," Mr. Clifford said. But he dreads trying to find ways to reduce the company's costs.
"We just went through a recapitalization of this company," he said. "We were not generating a profit. I had to cut costs, lay off people. It was very unpleasant. Certainly, our plans have to change."
 
Burden on Aluminum Makers
As big consumers of energy, the aluminum industry would find the energy tax a substantial burden. At the Intalco Aluminum plant in Ferndale, Wash., for example, the tax would increase electricity costs by perhaps $10 million a year, and add 11 percent to production costs. And Noel Shelton, power manager of the plant, said the higher costs could cause Intalco to lose sales to rivals across the border in Canada, whose prices would likely be harder to match or undercut.
Producers in Canada and elsewhere built large, modern plants in the late 1980's, and many pay less for power to make a pound of aluminum than do manufacturers in the United States, Mr. Shelton said.
Energy conservation programs at Intalco, a subsidiary of Alumax, "have gone about as far as we can go," he said. "If we make any further electricity cuts, we would have to reduce our plant output."
 
Refiners See Flat Demand
Petroleum refiners have had slack demand and slim profits for the last few years. For most refiners, a new tax of about $3.50 a barrel -- the level that would be reached in 1996 under the President's proposal -- would far exceed the current profit on each barrel, which has been less than $1 a barrel. But industry executives expressed doubts that the full cost of an energy tax could be passed to customers in all parts of the country.
"The markets aren't any good right now," said John R. Hall, chairman and chief executive of the Ashland Oil Company, the nation's largest independent oil refiner, based in Ashland, Ky.
On the West Coast, where refiners export a sizable portion of the gasoline, jet and diesel fuel, and other products they produce, executives are concerned that the extra cost of the tax would make their products less competitive abroad.
In periods of slack demand, such as January and February when gasoline demand falls, West Coast refiners export from 10 to 30 percent of their output of all fuels, mainly to East Asia, said Kenneth Riley, vice president of business management and new ventures for the ARCO Products Company. The refining and marketing unit of ARCO Inc. is based in Los Angeles.
"Every bit of common sense says that exports should be exempted from the tax," Mr. Riley said.
But Bruce Pasternack, senior vice president and managing partner of the energy group at Booz, Allen & Hamilton Inc., the accounting and consulting firm, said most other refiners -- whose products are sold largely within the United States -- would probably not lose customers by raising prices apace with taxes.
A price increase for gasoline of 7 or 8 cents a gallon will lower demand by less than 1 percent, or fewer than 100,000 barrels a day, he said. "If you think about gasoline prices, month to month and year to year, they fluctuate by at least that much," he said.
 
Chemical Exports May Fall
Chemical manufacturers consume 7 percent of the nation's total energy supplies. Half of that amount goes into feedstocks, mainly crude oil and natural-gas products, that are excluded from the Clinton energy tax. But the other half -- the power consumed by production equipment -- would be subject to the tax. And the Chemical Manufacturers Association estimates that the tax would increase the industry's annual fuel bill of $10 billion by about 12 percent.
Most chemical makers invested heavily in energy-conservation equipment during the last 20 years, and some companies said that continued improvements should cover some portion of the higher energy costs. Officials at Elf Atochem North America's plant in Tacoma, Wash., expect that over the next 10 years energy efficiency programs will cut more than $33,000 from monthly electric bills that currently average about $600,000.
The company, a unit of France's oil giant, Elf Aquitaine, is spending $5.8 million on programs that are projected to cut power consumption by 20 megawatts over 10 years.
"A tax could be a sizable figure," said Edward Lowe, operations manager. "But our competitors also are located within this country. If all energy ratios go up proportionately, we'd still be in the same competitive position. Our tax would be passed on to our customers."
But an energy tax could cause troubles for exporters. "As our costs go up in the U.S., that digs into our worldwide competitiveness," said Vince F. Villani, a vice president in the industrial chemicals division of the Union Carbide Corporation. Union Carbide, a low-cost producer, could gain sales and markets if higher costs from the energy tax cause uneconomical plants in the United States to close, he said.
The chemical industry is the nation's biggest export sector, larger than agriculture, producing a surplus of $16.3 billion last year, down from $18.8 billion in 1991. "We're forecasting further declines this year, without an energy tax," said Allen Lenz, chief economist for the industry trade group.

HEADLINE: Irate Soldiers Seize Zaire Parliament

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Hundreds of heavily armed soldiers have seized control of the Parliament building here and are holding hostage several hundred members of Zaire's Parliament, demanding that the lawmakers approve new bank notes as legal currency.
Officials inside the building, contacted by telephone, said the soldiers have told them that they would not be allowed to leave until the Parliament issues orders requiring local merchants to accept the new high-denomination bank notes. The bills, with which the soldiers are being paid their monthly salary, were issued by Zaire's central bank, which is under the direct control of President Mobutu Sese Seko. 
 The 5-million-zaire bills are supposedly worth $2 each, but in fact they are almost impossible to use because most merchants, heeding the advice of Mr. Mobutu's main political foe, Prime Minister Etienne Tshisekedi, have refused to honor them.
 
An Earlier Riot
 In a similar episode three weeks ago, soldiers rioted after being paid in the new notes, closing Kinshasa's airport and the port on the Congo River and looting stores and houses. As the pillaging and unrest spread, France and Belgium flew in hundreds of troops to evacuate their citizens from Zaire. At least 300 people are believed to have died in the melee.
The latest demands were issued when Zairean troops, some accompanied by their wives and children, blocked all entrances to the People's Palace conference hall, using large-caliber weapons and armored cars. As news of the encirclement spread, there reportedly was panic inside the conference center, where members of the Parliament were in session. But witnesses said there were no immediate signs of violence.
Today, hundreds of soldiers and their families were camped out inside the eight-foot-high fence surrounding the Parliament building. In the outside perimeter, street merchants gathered to sell food -- mostly bread and dried fish -- to those inside. But diplomats said there was no running water inside, and some of the hostages needed medical care.
 
America Backs Interim Rule
 Zaire's main Western donors -- the United States, France and Belgium, the former colonial power in Zaire -- have repeatedly expressed support for Mr. Tshisekedi and members of the interim government, known as the High Council of the Republic. The Western allies have already suspended aid to Zaire and are considering economic and political sanctions, to force Mr. Mobutu, who has ruled Zaire for 28 years, to accept democratic changes.
Under pressure, Mr. Mobutu agreed in 1991 to yield much of his administration's power to an interim government until multiparty elections could be held. But he has since resisted following through on his pledge and in a pointed rebuke to Western donors three weeks ago, Mr. Mobutu dismissed Mr. Tshisekedi as Prime Minister, blaming his longtime foe for the earlier violence over the bank notes.
The High Council was believed to be discussing whether to name a new Prime Minister when troops seized control of the building. Diplomats who have been in contact with the lawmakers inside the conference center said the soldiers have demanded that the Parliament leader, Joseph Ileo, read a statement on state radio approving the use of the new bank notes. The 72-year-old Mr. Ileo has insisted that he does not have the authority to make such a declaration.
Several African and Western diplomats voiced concern today that violence could easily erupt again unless the pay dispute was resolved soon. What has made the situation all the more explosive, the diplomats said, is that the country is seemingly leaderless. President Mobutu left Zaire last Friday for dental treatment in France. He is expected to remain at his villa on the Cote d'Azur near Monte Carlo at least until the weekend.
Meanwhile, Mr. Tshisekedi has cloistered himself in his residence near the outskirts of Kinshasa and has yet to make any public comments about the hostage seizure.

HEADLINE: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK;
In Japan, Dinkins's Lessons in Contrasts

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OSAKA, Japan, Feb. 25

 BODY:
In his travels through Japan, Mayor David N. Dinkins's deepest contact with the realities of urban life here -- and the contrasts with his own city -- probably came in Kazuko Mishimura's sixth-grade mathematics class at the Chuo Elementary School.
When Mr. Dinkins stepped into the public school in the heart of the city's most densely packed neighborhood, the students had just taken a break from some fairly complicated geometry lessons that were still perfectly sketched across the blackboard. Each of them was dressed in the school uniform: blue blazers for everyone, red bows and skirts for the girls, red bow ties and shorts for the boys. Their identical leather book bags were stored in neat rows against the back wall. This was no show for the Mayor: Walk into any Japanese school and the scene is the same.
 
Comparing Urban Living
 "I can see this is not a school with a discipline problem," Mr. Dinkins said later as he made his way down the corridors, which are lined with the shoes the students take off before they step into the classrooms. 
If there was a lesson in comparative urban living in Mr. Dinkins's travels, it hit home hardest here. While Japanese schools are hardly without their problems -- school bullying among them -- to Mr. Dinkins and his staff, Chuo Elementary seemed like heaven. Only hours before, Mr. Dinkins had been informed of the latest killing in a junior high school back home, the killing of an emotionally handicapped special education student during a dispute. Another student has been charged in the killing.
 
No Metal Detectors Here
 Mr. Dinkins was quick to condemn the slaying and to wonder aloud at "the depth of the anger or frustration or fear which leads one youngster to take another's life."
But he noted, "No matter how many metal detectors we put in the schools, no matter how much security, it cannot prevent youngsters from involving themselves in violent activity."
Needless to say, schools in Japan have no metal detectors, but schools here also play a very different role than they do in America. Record-setting mathematics scores aside, classrooms like Ms. Mishimura's are where the lessons of social control that make Japan one of the world's most crime-free industrial societies -- and also one of its most socially repressed -- begin. Children, and their parents, feel the weight of social opprobrium for the slightest step out of line: mothers have been known to be called in for a talking-to if their children arrive in unpressed uniforms, or without the right supplies.
Mr. Dinkins received a taste of the regimentation at lunch time, when he sat down for some soup and hamburger steak with a class of third graders.
"I drank all my milk," he announced proudly at the end. Unfortunately, he didn't take off his shoes.
 
Meeting One Next to Royalty
 During their sweep through Tokyo, Mr. Dinkins and his entourage met a parade of Japan's most instantly recognizable faces. There was Akio Morita, the white-haired founder of Sony and premier handler of foreign guests. There was Kiichi Miyazawa, the Prime Minister who, like the Mayor, is known first for his geniality.
Then there was Akebono, the 470-pound sumo star whose assistant wrestlers boosted the Mayor on their shoulders so that he could face off eye-to-eye with Akebono, the first foreigner ever named a sumo grand champion.
But the most memorable meeting for many in the entourage was with Hisashi Owada, the vice minister of foreign affairs. Until lately, Mr. Owada was not exactly a household name in Japan.
But these days Mr. Owada is known throughout the country as the father of the future empress: His 29-year-old daughter Masako, a Harvard graduate and diplomat in her own right, is engaged to Crown Prince Hiro, the son of Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko.
Speaking to Mayor Dinkins and his party of New York business executives, Mr. Owada, a former New Yorker not known for enthusiastic outbursts, declared, "I love New York." Immediately Lewis Rudin, the head of the Rudin Management Corporation and the longtime president of the Association for a Better New York, untied his "I <heart> New York" necktie and handed it to Mr. Owada as a gift.
"So Mr. Owada took off his own necktie and gave it to me," Mr. Rudin recalled. "Then he told me it had been given to him by his daughter."
That night, at a reception for Mr. Dinkins, Mr. Owada showed up with his new tie boldly in place. But Mr. Rudin had already put the future empress's selection in safe storage.
"I think I'm going to frame it," he said.
 
And How's He Doing?
 At one point during the Mayor's travels through Tokyo one of his aides asked how the event was being covered in the Japanese press. His hosts did not know quite how to say that the country's giant newspapers -- with circulations far larger than any dailies in the United States -- were not exactly splashing him over the front pages.
Searching for a diplomatic way to put things, one of them explained that Mr. Dinkins was getting about the same level of coverage that Shunichi Suzuki, the octogenarian governor of Tokyo, would expect in the American papers during his visits to New York. There was a long silence, and then everyone changed the topic.
 
Platitudes, Gifts and Gaffes
 There are two critical rituals of building relationships in Japan, and Mr. Dinkins was ready for both of them: Giving empty speeches and exchanging endless gifts.
Mr. Dinkins came armed with enough platitudes for his guests to enter the Japanese political world, where one rises by offending no one. At just the right moments he marveled at the efficiency of Tokyo's city services, the vastness of the landfill in Osaka harbor where a huge airport is under construction, and the skill of the parade of kimono-wearing young women who performed a tea ceremony in his honor. (By the time he was served tea today, the Mayor had even mastered one of the finer points: Always rotate the tea cup a half turn before you sip, so that the decorative side faces your hosts.)
He also knew what to avoid. Mr. Dinkins never engaged his hosts in Tokyo and Osaka in a discussion about why Japanese cities are virtually devoid of green space, with only a fraction of the park space per person that one finds in New York. He asked few questions about Japan's low crime rates.
When a young Japanese boy who founded the "Association to Stop Racism Against Blacks" came by to visit his hotel, he steered clear of any questions about discrimination in Japan -- against blacks, Koreans or the burakumin, a little-discussed but oppressed group that has traditionally performed much of the society's dirty work, from making leather to burying the dead. Rather, he concentrated on "arigato gozaimashita" -- thank you -- until he had it all down except the reflexive bow.
The gift-giving, an art form in Japan, was considerably more complicated. When Mr. Dinkins fills out his customs forms, he will be listing a lot of traditional Japanese dolls, traditional Japanese prints, and cards filled with Japanese calligraphy. He came well prepared: For the students at Chuo Elementary, there were New York Yankee baseball caps (in un-Yankee pink) and official David N. Dinkins note pads with etchings of City Hall on every page.
For officials, there were Tiffany's blue boxes containing a variety of gifts -- impressive, unless one stops to consider that Japanese interests own a good-sized chunk of Tiffany's. There were many bottles of New York wine.
And every once in a while there was the gaffe of unequal giving. The head of Takashimaya Department Store, which is about to open a $100 million outlet in New York, gave the Mayor a striking piece of modern statuary. In return, he received a paperback book about New York. But the executive, well trained in school, never stopped smiling.

HEADLINE: State Budgets Mending After Years of Surgery

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
Finally emerging from the recession, nearly all the states are planning their first budgets in years without big tax increases or deep cuts in programs.
But they are not celebrating their recovery by reducing taxes, as they usually do after a recession, according to a report being published today. Very few states are starting new programs, and most are still reducing spending to cope with the continuing sharp increases in health-care costs and prison populations. Nor are they certain that the gain in tax collections that most of them saw late last year will last. 
 "State budgets are on the gurney being wheeled out of the hospital," said Ronald K. Snell, fiscal program director of the National Conference of State Legislatures. "This is the first year of the recovery for state budgets, but they're not in full recovery and they're certainly not back to health."
Today the conference is making public a survey of the 50 states that provides the year's first comprehensive look at their economic condition and their outlook for the coming fiscal year, which begins July 1 for most states.
 
Paying Taxes Early
 The recession continues unabated in Maine and California, and some other states are struggling. Elsewhere, Mr. Snell, who directed the conference's survey, said there is not enough current information, particularly about unemployment rates, to assess the states' economic health.
"We found no regional patterns," he said, "but there is a clear national trend of recovery, and the national trend is the most important factor for any state's economy."
The strength of the states' recovery remains uncertain, Mr. Snell said. In particular, some state officials believe that tax collections surged in the last months of 1992 because many affluent taxpayers who have the ability to shift their income chose to pay their taxes early in anticipation of higher Federal taxes in 1993. State revenue, in the doldrums for the first nine months of the year, rose by nearly 6 percent in the fourth quarter, compared with that of 1991.
In New York State, for example, income tax payments rose 20 percent in the final quarter as businesses and individual taxpayers, expecting higher tax rates in 1993, took profits early but postponed tax-deductible expenses, said James W. Wetzler, State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance. "I call that the Clinton effect," he said, "and I think it's causing a lot of undue optimism in the wind."
 
States Like Clinton's Plan
 Other state officials are more positive. They are particularly pleased by President Clinton's economic plan, which would provide billions of dollars for public works and education and end a 12-year pattern of shifting responsibility for costly programs from Washington to the states. And even if the recovery is not explosive, they say, at least it is a recovery.
"This is the first year since the economic downturn began in 1987 that New York State will not have to borrow money to cover a year-end deficit," said Claudia S. Hutton, a spokeswoman for the state budget office. She was referring to New York's fiscal year 1993, which ends March 31.
David K. Coburn, director of Florida's Office of Planning and Budget, said, "This is the first time in three years that we have been in a position to actually fund some things, instead of telling people we're cutting, cutting, cutting."
Thirty states, including some of those hit hardest by the recession, have projected a revenue increase in the fiscal year 1994 by two or more times the rate of inflation, which is expected to be 2.85 percent. Ten states expect revenue to grow more slowly than the rate of inflation. Only three states expect no growth in revenue or an actual decline: they are Maine and Vermont, whose economies are still depressed, and Texas, which may lose $400 million a year when a special sales tax expires in June.
With such generally optimistic forecasts, few states are raising taxes by any significant amount. But many governors and legislatures are trying to hold onto surcharges or temporary taxes that are due to expire.
"Fiscal 1994 looks like a year where states are hunkering down, trying to hold the line and making very few initiatives," Mr. Snell said.
 
'Election-Year Budgets' Cited
 States are less well off than might be expected because 1992 was an election year, said Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States at Rockefeller Institute in Albany. "The election-year budgets were full of quick fixes and accounting gimmicks," he said. "So that means they're starting behind the eight ball in fiscal 1994."
California remains in the grip of a recession caused, in part, by the loss of 800,000 jobs, largely in the military industry. At the same time, sharp growth in the state's population, amounting to an influx of 1,700 new residents a day, continues to strain social service programs.
The 1994 fiscal year is shaping up to be a replay of last year's budget woes, with the state facing an accumulated deficit of $8.6 billion in a $70 billion budget, according to the survey by the conference of legislatures.
Gov. Pete Wilson opposes raising taxes or fees and has urged that the number of state employees, now 128,000, be cut by 15 percent.
 
Hard Times in Maine
 Proportionately, Maine is even worse off. The state faces a $1.2 billion shortage in its $3 billion combined budget for the fiscal years 1994 and 1995. The state's once-booming real estate industry is in depression and revenue has been shrinking since 1989, said Dale F. Doughty, deputy commissioner of the Maine Department of Administration and Finance.
"Every department in the state government is undergoing very, very careful scrutiny by the Legislature and the Governor's office," he said, "and every cut that can be tolerated is being made to bring about a balanced budget without any tax increases."
Even his own job will probably be eliminated when he retires this year, Mr. Doughty said.
 
Challenges in Colorado
 The new year also brings new problems. Colorado, for example, was struggling to cope with a $300 million shortfall in the fiscal year 1994 even before last November, when voters approved a ballot initiative requiring that all new taxes be approved by popular vote. Among other things, state officials may cut are considering reducing school aid by 6.9 percent, or $121 million, at a time when they had hoped to increase it. "You bet we're challenged," said Gov. Roy Romer.
Florida expects the nation's largest percentage growth in revenue, nearly 10 percent, largely as a result of sales taxes generated by rebuilding efforts after Hurricane Andrew struck South Florida last August. But even so, there is not nearly enough money, said Gov. Lawton Chiles.
"We've got a billion dollars more in our budget than last year, but all the money is eaten up by an 18 percent growth in health care costs, by 40,000 new welfare cases and by 70,000 new students in primary and secondary schools," the Governor said. "We're better off than in the last two years, but it's just like we're still going around on a wheel, not making progress."
Even with more revenue, the state needs to reduce spending by $200 million and raise $290 million in new sales taxes to balance the $13.5 billion general fund budget, Mr. Chiles said.
The effort to make government more efficient continues. In New Jersey, which has already eliminated 10,000 of its 70,000 state jobs since 1990, there are plans to eliminate 4,500 more jobs, mostly by attrition. At the same time, Gov. Jim Florio wants to put away $50 million in a new reserve fund and spend $400 million more on buildings and highways.
In Pennsylvania, Gov. Robert P. Casey has proposed a $637 million cut in medical assistance programs, but even so, health care costs will rise by 9 percent next year, to $2.3 billion, more than 15 percent of the state's $14.9 billion general fund. "Obviously, something had to be done to tame the health care monster," Mr. Casey said.
