SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1579 words

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
An Idealist's New Task: To Revamp Health Care

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
He made radical changes in the curriculum at Brown University. He led a band of young idealists working for social change in Brockton, Mass. He tried unsuccessfully to make his home state of Rhode Island into a laboratory for his theory of industrial policy.
And now he is trying to revamp the nation's health-care system. Ira C. Magaziner is President Clinton's senior adviser for policy development. But he works mostly for Hillary Rodham Clinton in her effort to devise a plan to control health costs and guarantee health care for all Americans. 
 Mr. Magaziner, who is 45, is variously described as a complex, intense man; a shy, eccentric genius; a harsh taskmaster who works harder than anyone on his staff.
"Ira is a nonlinear thinker," said Stephen H. Crolius, a 37-year-old consultant at Telesis, a company founded by Mr. Magaziner. "Most people are used to thinking in terms that proceed logically from A to B to C to D. Ira can go immediately from A and B to G."
 
'An Outsider in Washington'
 Following an edict he imposed on other officials, Mr. Magaziner refused to discuss the Administration's health-policy review. By his own account he is "an outsider in Washington," a novice in the capital's corridors of power. But he presides over a policy-making apparatus like nothing seen here in decades: more than 300 economists, health-policy experts, Government employees and consultants racing to assemble a major health-care proposal by May 1.
"He is worth several million dollars, but I think he owns one rumpled suit, which he doesn't press," said Mark Patinkin, who wrote a book with Mr. Magaziner in 1988. "He spends 90 percent of his mental energy thinking about policy. He lives to solve policy problems."
Mr. Magaziner's career as a business consultant illuminates his approach to health policy. He has immersed himself in vast quantities of detail and data, just as he did when he worked for clients like Volvo, General Electric, Corning, Wang Laboratories and the Governments of Israel and Sweden.
He has established more than two dozen committees to study aspects of health policy, including cost controls, long-term care and mental health. Each team must meet seven deadlines. Each deadline, in his jargon, is a tollgate. He spends his time talking with these committees, with members of Congress and with lobbyists from groups like the Health Insurance Association of America.
Mr. Magaziner was a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford University with Bill Clinton, and his intellectual imprint is evident in Mr. Clinton's campaign manifesto, "Putting People First."
In a 1990 study called "America's Choice: High Skills or Low Wages," Mr. Magaziner said the nation must train workers and reorganize the workplace to meet challenges of the 21st century. As candidate and as President, Mr. Clinton has often talked about the need for "an economy of high-wage, high-skill jobs."
 
Consultant and Agitator
 For nearly 20 years, Mr. Magaziner was a consultant to blue-chip companies, which he often charged more than $500 an hour, colleagues say. But he also advised Walter F. Mondale and Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic candidates for President in 1984 and 1988, and he has not abandoned his past as a political agitator.
Roger G. Ackerman, president of Corning, which makes glass and high-tech materials, described Mr. Magaziner as "a tremendous encyclopedia," the best consultant ever retained by the company. He said Mr. Magaziner helped Corning compare itself with foreign competitors.
"Ira constructed a model of what we were up against by visiting foreign countries and collecting huge amounts of information about our competitors' taxes and labor costs," Mr. Ackerman said in an interview. "Based on his advice, we decided to make a big commitment to the liquid-crystal display business in Japan, and it's been a success story for Corning."
On the other hand, in 1989, Mr. Magaziner told a Congressional committee that the Federal Government should invest in research on "cold fusion," lest the United States fall behind Japan and European countries in developing this technology. Congress, he said, must not "dawdle and wait until the science is proven." The science, however, has still not proved commercially valuable.
 
Led Curriculum Reform
 Mr. Magaziner grew up in New York City, the son of an accountant who worked at a tomato-packing company. As valedictorian of the class of 1969 at Brown, he led efforts to liberalize the curriculum. Through noisy rallies and quiet negotiations, he persuaded faculty members to move away from large lecture classes and toward individual instruction and independent study.
"The goal was to eliminate most of the requirements and let students have greater freedom to choose their courses," said Elmer E. Cornwell Jr., a professor of political science at Brown. "Ira and another student drafted a very comprehensive report, and most of their recommendations were adopted by the faculty. A great deal of Brown's popularity flows from the 1969 curriculum reform. We were viewed as an avant-garde kind of place."
After two years at Balliol College, one of the oldest colleges at Oxford University, Mr. Magaziner and several friends went to Brockton, an old shoe-manufacturing center 19 miles south of Boston, for a local experiment in social democracy that sought to reverse the city's economic decline.
In an effort to give more power to the residents of Brockton, Mr. Magaziner and his friends supported liberal candidates for local office and established a food cooperative, a weekly newspaper, a tenants' rights organization and a nonprofit corporation to repair dilapidated housing.
"We were very idealistic, committed and earnest," said Joshua C. Posner, who graduated from Brown in 1971. "After a couple of years, it became clear we were not going to change the world starting with Brockton. Ira realized there was a lot about the real world that he didn't know, and he wanted to learn. That's why he went to the Boston Consulting Group in 1973, to be a business strategy consultant."
 
Moving Toward the Center
 This was a turning point in Mr. Magaziner's career. At this time, his friends say, he moved toward the center of the political spectrum.
"Up till then, Ira had seen big business as an institution to be skeptical about," Mr. Patinkin said. "But a number of Brockton shoe factories shut down because of foreign competition. All his work to help the needy was overwhelmed by the closing of those factories. Ira realized that corporate and economic success was the truest path to save the world, to create prosperity for those who didn't have it."
In 1979 Mr. Magaziner formed his own consulting concern, Telesis, to develop his ideas on industrial policy and to advise corporate clients. In 1986 he sold it to Towers Perrin, a big consulting company, for a sum estimated by Rhode Island businessmen at $6 million. He formed another consulting concern, SJS Inc., in 1990.
Mr. Magaziner put his economic ideas to a test in 1984. He was the chief architect of a $248 million industrial development plan for the State of Rhode Island. The proposal was called the Greenhouse Compact, an allusion to the fact that Mr. Magaziner wanted to establish "greenhouses" to nurture promising industries like robotics. But the plan was overwhelmingly rejected by voters in a state referendum.
 
Economic Ideas Criticized
 Recalling the referendum, Prof. George H. Borts of Brown, who describes himself as a free-market economist, said, "Ira's economic ideas were primitive, just off the wall." He maintained that Mr. Magaziner seemed to assume that Rhode Island, the nation's smallest state, could develop its own economy and thrive on exports. That notion is absurd, Professor Borts said, because Rhode Island is economically dependent on its neighbors, Massachusetts and Connecticut.
In addition, Mr. Borts said: "There was great suspicion that the Greenhouse Compact would favor some firms at the expense of others. Businessmen feared their competitors would be subsidized by the state."
But many ideas from the Greenhouse Compact, like the proposal for government aid to high-tech industries, showed up in Mr. Clinton's economic proposals.
J. Joseph Garrahy, a Democrat who championed the Greenhouse Compact as Governor of Rhode Island in 1984, said, "Leading educators and businessmen saw it as a valid way of trying to help the state out of its economic difficulties."
Representative John F. Reed, a Rhode Island Democrat, said: "Ira's predictions about the state's economy have unfortunately been borne out. If we didn't do anything, he warned, the job base and the manufacturing base would decline. He was right."
In the national health-care industry, as in the Rhode Island economy, Mr. Magaziner wants to stimulate free-market competition, but he also welcomes the firm guiding hand of government. Thus, the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform is considering "interim cost controls" like limits on doctors' fees and hospital charges.
Edward J. Caron, a vice president of Providence College, who worked with Mr. Magaziner at Telesis and SJS Inc., said: "Ira thinks in very broad strokes. His health-care reform proposal will be well-supported and well-documented. But he will need nuts-and-bolts people to put his strategy into effect in the real world, at the level of the average person, because he thinks at a more global level."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ira C. Magaziner, President Clinton's senior adviser for policy development, is finding the health-care agenda of Donna E. Shalala, left, Secretary of Health and Human Services, and Hillary Rodham Clinton, the head of the President's task force, to be the major focus of his job. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)
 
Chronology: "Ira C. Magaziner"
 
Born: Nov. 8, 1947, New York City.
 
Hometown: Bristol, R.I.
 
Education: Public schools of Far Rockaway, Queens, and Lawrence, N.Y.; Brown University; Oxford University.
 
Career Highlights: 1971-73, neighborhood organizer, Brockton, Mass.; 1973-1979, Boston Consulting Group; 1979-1989, president of Telesis, a business consulting concern; 1990-92, president of SJS Inc., a consulting concern. 1988-91, chairman, Commission on the Skills of the American Work Force. Also involved in public policy studies like the Greenhouse Compact, for industrial development, and Aging 2000, for health care, in Rhode Island.
 
Family: Married to Suzanne McTigue; two sons and one daughter.
 
Hobbies: New York Giants football fan; New York Yankees baseball fan; travel with his children.

HEADLINE: At the Bar;
A judge's comments to co-workers conjure up memories of a disagreeable past.

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
Judge B. Joseph Fitzsimmons Jr. gave plenty of ammunition to his critics, including the Massachusetts Commission on Judicial Conduct. He sloughed off work and abused lawyers and litigants. He arrived in court late and left early, often for a nearby country club. Yet he chastised the unemployed, particularly women, when they came before him.
But Judge Fitzsimmons's real undoing were some wisecracks he made to some courthouse associates that brought down the wrath of Jewish groups, the legal establishment, the press and Gov. William F. Weld, among others. His remarks have left him unemployed, impoverished and under police protection. They have also conjured up memories, dimmed by time and the Second Vatican Council, of the tortured ties between Boston's Irish and Jews. 
 The judicial conduct panel laid out its charges against Judge Fitzsimmons with brutal exactitude a year ago. According to the panel's findings, the judge, in a conversation with a co-worker, referred to a Jewish lawyer as a "kike." Speaking in a kind of code -- so that "they won't know that we are talking about them," he told another associate -- he regularly called Jewish lawyers "Canadians," then took shots at them, again during unguarded moments off the bench. "Typical Canadian," he said of one. "All he thinks about is money."
Sometimes he dispensed with the metaphors. Informed that a Jewish lawyer was waiting to speak with him, the judicial panel noted, the judge responded "by remarking in substance, 'It's time to go warm up the ovens.' "
Anxious to end a three-year investigation, avoid a public hearing and save his job, Judge Fitzsimmons, who sat in the Boston suburb of Dedham, issued a mea culpa. He conceded that he had made certain comments regarding "attorneys of the Jewish faith" that could "reasonably be understood as being anti-Semitic," comments for which he said he was "profoundly sorry." But he insisted that he was not an anti-Semite and that three psychiatrists who had examined him -- all Jewish -- concurred.
He pledged to continue counseling, at his own expense, and sensitivity training. For its part, the judicial conduct panel meted out a six-month suspension without pay plus a $60,000 fine -- its most severe sanction ever, but one that allowed Judge Fitzsimmons to keep his pension and resume his judicial duties.
Everyone agrees that the Boston of years past -- in which, as native Jewish sons like Theodore H. White and Nat Hentoff have written, Irish toughs routinely set upon Jewish boys for deicide and other crimes -- has gone the way of Mayor James Michael Curley. The two groups now celebrate seders together, vote together and litigate together. Mutual affection runs deep. Irish litigants go to Jewish lawyers and Jewish litigants to Irish ones, according to local legal lore, because each thinks the other has a way with juries.
Perhaps because the episode conjures up such unhappy memories, however, the judicial conduct panel's resolution was not the end of the matter. Earlier this month, the normally polite Massachusetts Lawyers Weekly called on Judge Fitzsimmons to resign or be removed from office. So did The Boston Herald and The Jewish Advocate, a local newspaper. And so, too, did Governor Weld, who on Feb. 11 asked the State Legislature to begin impeachment proceedings.
The 51-year-old Judge Fitzsimmons, who lives in Weymouth, is not granting interviews. But his defense counsel, Earle Cooley of Boston, contended that with the Legislature now getting into the act, his client is being made to pay twice for the same offense. And the Governor, he added, is scoring cheap electoral points. "It's politically popular to croak this man while he's down," he said.
And, with breathtaking speed, the Fitzsimmons camp produced several Jewish lawyers who have only praise for the beleaguered judge. In separate interviews, Sumner Gillette of Quincy called him "a nice, decent guy who means well," Coleman Bornstein of Boston called him "extremely fair, pleasant, respectful and judicious," and Mark Hoffman of Walpole called him "a lovable guy, a big puppy dog."
In his admission, Judge Fitzsimmons said he had "never harbored anti-Semitic feelings" nor had even been charged with discriminating against Jews in his courtroom. Privately, Judge Fitzsimmons has denied making any comments about crematoriums or "kikes." As for calling Jews "Canadians," the judge, a passionate hockey fan, has said he really meant "Canadiens," as in the Montreal Canadiens. The suggestion is that by likening Jewish lawyers to such aggressive and highly successful skaters, he actually meant the term to be flattering.
Mr. Cooley said the judge would not resign and was, in fact, keeping up on his work. Come July 1, Mr. Cooley said, Judge Fitzsimmons fully expects to be back on the bench.

HEADLINE: Judge Devises Instructional Penalties

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEMPHIS, Feb. 25

 BODY:
A local judge who says jail is no longer a deterrent is trying to teach first-time nonviolent offenders a lesson by, among other things, sentencing them to write book reports and, in one case, to go to the zoo.
"I wanted him to get the idea that that could be him locked up and confined, and see how bad that was," said the judge, Joe B. Brown, referring to a drug offender whom he had ordered to stand in front of a gorilla cage for an hour. "It got to him." 
 Such maverick sentencing has brought much attention to the 45-year-old judge since he was elected to the county criminal court in January 1991. He has been the subject of newspaper articles as far away as Anchorage, was mentioned in Life magazine and appeared on Bill Cosby's "You Bet Your Life" television show in November. Indeed, because of the attention, some legal experts are questioning whether Judge Brown's approach to sentencing is aimed more at generating publicity than at reducing recidivism.
Under Tennessee law, Judge Brown has considerable leeway in sentencing; state law, in fact, tells judges to consider alternatives to jail for first-time nonviolent offenders. But most judges are content with probation and community service.
 
Effectiveness Questioned
 It is too soon to tell if Judge Brown's sentencing practices work, but there are plenty of doubters. "Some of these alternatives feel right and clever, but they really don't hold much promise of reducing crime," said Scott Wallace, a senior fellow with the Criminal Justice Policy Foundation, a Washington organization that evaluates alternative sentencing programs.
Judge Brown has his supporters, however. Having grown up in an inner-city neighborhood, they say, he is unusually street-smart and can empathize with the primarily young black male defendants who face him every day.
"I grew up in South-Central Los Angeles, and I went to a high school where, literally, when I came in there at 13 there was a dead man hanging from the flagpole," the judge said in an interview. "If you saw 'Boyz N the Hood,' that was the way I grew up."
After graduating from the University of California at Los Angeles in 1973, he moved to Nashville, then here to Memphis, where he worked as a defense lawyer and later a city prosecutor, the first black to hold such a position there.
 
'Village Chieftain'
 "I never wanted to be a judge until I found out the judge could be the village chieftain," said Judge Brown, who presides in robes made of African cloth. "The village chieftain protects his village, resolves disputes and problems and gets rid of the problems that cannot be corrected."
His methods of protecting his village are unusual. Paul Levine, director of public affairs with the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, said, "At any given time, you'll find judges who toy with creative sentencing, but at the moment I've only heard of one other judge who does it."
Judge Brown argues that locking up someone is not necessarily punishment. "For a lot of them, it is a very viable and good option to get sent to jail," he said. "They have food, shelter, a bed, recreation, a social structure and a concourse of friends."
 
Special Meanings
 The goal of his approach to sentencing, he says, is not to hand out easier punishments but to devise ones that have special meaning to lawbreakers. "You have to make the punishment fit the offender, more so than the offense," he said.
His unusual sentences for first-time nonviolent offenders are accompanied by probation and community work, like washing police cars or clearing weed-filled lots. As a condition of probation, Judge Brown also demands that offenders complete a job training course or return to school and receive a diploma if they do not already have one. He often makes offenders read "The Autobiography of Malcolm X" and turn in a 10-page essay on the book, hoping to build an awareness of their own culture.
Perhaps the most disputed of Judge Brown's sentences has been allowing burglary victims to visit the burglar's home and take something of equal value while the burglar watches. The victims, accompanied by a sheriff's deputy or bailiff, make these visits without warning so that the burglars cannot hide their most valuable possessions. The "raids" can take place any time during a burglar's probation, which normally lasts a year.
 
'Reverse Theft' Idea
 "This reverse theft thing was predicated on the theory that everybody has something of value, and the lower down on the economic scale you are, the more likely it is to be something material, even if small," said Judge Brown, who offered this option to more than 30 burglary victims in two years.
The victims often take back from burglars what was taken from them, like videocassette recorderse.
The sentence troubles Mr. Wallace of the Criminal Justice Policy Foundation. "I don't think it's a good idea to involve the victim in a face-to-face, intimidating confrontation," he said, noting that the burglar would know where the victim lives if he decided he wanted his belongings back. Mr. Levine also questioned the constitutionality of the practice.
Prosecutors and other judges declined to discuss Judge Brown's sentencing practices. But others applauded his approach.
"It's my firm belief that these sentences are not done just for the purpose of being different, but for the purpose of turning individual lives around," said Leslie Ballin, a defense lawyer in Memphis. "I like to see him give kids a chance, and sometimes that's all it takes to turn them around."
And Judge Brown does hand out severe sentences when necessary, Mr. Ballin said. "If someone has been down that same road too many times or has committed a heinous crime, he can be a real toughie, and that's not something that's too widely known," Mr. Ballin said of the judge.
But too often, Judge Brown says, society would rather jail offenders than rehabilitate them, adding that it spends more money on inmates than students. "In Memphis we spend $3,400 a year educating a school child from kindergarten through graduation from high school, yet we are quite willing to spend between $22,000 and $36,000 a year to lock that individual up," he said.
"What we're trying to do here is use the coercive power of the court to do a bit of social engineering. That's really what I'm trying to do."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Judge Joe B. Brown, whose maverick sentencing has legal experts arguing whether it is aimed at generating publicity or reducing recidivism. (Rollin A. Riggs for the The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Rise Slightly

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing initial claims for jobless benefits rose slightly in mid-February, the first advance in a month, the Government said today.
But the less volatile four-week moving average of new claims fell in the week, to 334,500 from 343,500, the third straight decline and a return to early January levels that were the lowest since the 327,250 average for the period that ended on Sept. 30, 1989. 
 The Labor Department said new applications for unemployment insurance totaled 325,000 during the week that ended on Feb. 13, up from 321,000 a week earlier. It was the first increase since claims rose 1,000, to 361,000, during the week that ended on Jan. 16.
The weekly total did not include first-time applications filed under a Federal emergency program. Those claims totaled 22,405, down from 30,118, during the week that ended on Feb. 6.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Cold Weather Brings Surge In Prices of Heating Fuels

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The prices of heating oil and natural gas jumped yesterday as much of the nation reported frigid temperatures.
The weather also influenced the livestock markets, where hog prices rose on reports of heavy snow in the Plains. 
 The cold weather, combined with a drop in domestic inventories of distillate fuels, helped create a rally in heating oil prices. March heating oil gained 1.39 cents, to 58.77 cents a gallon, on the Mercantile Exchange in New York.
"I think it's basically the weather," said Ted Eck, chief economist at the Amoco Corporation in Chicago.
March unleaded gasoline fell 0.54 cent, to 53.11 cents a gallon, as many traders closed their positions before the March contract expires today.
April crude oil rose 8 cents, to $20.61 a barrel, helped by reports that members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would act to curb production on March 1.
"People seem to believe that for the time being OPEC will abide by what they agreed," said Cyrus Tahmassebi, the chief economist at the Ashland Oil Company. "If that is the case, crude prices for the second quarter may be in the range of $20 to $22."
The Arctic cold blanketing much of the nation pushed up the price of natural gas, with the April contract climbing 4.6 cents, to $1.894 per million British thermal units.
In addition, new delays in restarting a Texas nuclear power plant diverted demand to natural gas.
Hog prices rose at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in reaction to the transportation problems posed by the winter storm, which left up to 18 inches of snow at Kansas City, Mo., and 12 inches at St. Louis. April hogs added 0.525 cent, to 45.625 cents a pound.
"I think the storm restricted marketings," said Daryl Dinkla, livestock analyst for Commodity Services Inc.
Cattle prices weakened despite the storm, with April dropping 0.45 cent, to 79.675 cents a pound.
Lumber prices fell sharply as traders took profits from the rally that began nearly three months ago. March lumber fell $8.70, to $436.50 per thousand board feet, and the contracts on the three succeeding months dropped the $10 limit.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A G.M. Jobless Fund Runs Out; the 2d Is Solvent

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 25

 BODY:
A $1.7 billion fund paying benefits to about 14,000 laid-off auto workers at the General Motors Corporation will run out of money on March 1, almost seven months before the automobile union's three-year contract with G.M. expires, the company said today.
But G.M. and the United Automobile Workers union said a second jobless benefits fund would take over payments, so no one would be left without checks. 
 The contract with the union, signed in 1990, agreed to pay up to $3.35 billion in benefits, divided among the two funds. But with slumping demand for their cars, General Motors and other auto makers have announced wide layoffs and plant closings, causing one of the G.M. funds to run out sooner than expected.
When it agreed to the contract in 1990, G.M. did not expect that business would be so bad, and layoffs so large, that $1.7 billion would have run out now. "We thought this money would be more than adequate," said Tom Pyden, a company spokesman.
The second fund, providing supplemental unemployment benefits, has about $725 million left out of $1.65 billion, G.M. said, adding that it should last until the present contract expires on Sept. 14.
The union's preparatory convention for bargaining on the next contract will be held in Detroit in April, and job-security benefits are certain to be one of the key issues in deciding the union's strategy with the Big Three auto makers this summer.
G.M. is expected to argue that given its losses, it cannot afford to maintain a financial safety net under all workers. Investors in G.M. and other automotive stocks had criticized Robert C. Stempel, the company's former chairman, for agreeing to the benefits, which were unprecedented. Under the agreements, those laid off receive about 95 percent of their pay plus health care.
The jobless provisions fell heaviest on G.M. because among the Big Three, it was the company with the greatest excess plant capacity and therefore the greatest risk of layoffs. The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation have operated leaner, and therefore had fewer layoffs and been forced to pay comparatively little in jobless benefits.
With no money in one of its funds, G.M. is expected to close its jobs banks, which had been intended to train workers who lost their positions because of productivity and technology improvements. In practice, workers assigned to the banks often performed community service or odd jobs for the union.
In the last 30 months, the company has paid $1.7 billion to workers assigned to jobs banks throughout the country. The union, without elaborating, said many members did receive some training. But some labor relations experts say the program provided little more than severance pay.
Harry Katz, a labor relations professor at Cornell, said the jobs banks fulfilled little of their promise because "G.M. didn't really know what to do" with them.
"The idea was to put people into training," he said, "thus giving G.M. the flexibility to bring more work into its plants and put people back on the job. But that has to happen as part of an overall manufacturing strategy. President Clinton talks about spending more on training, but here's a case of endless money being spent and very little happened."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mixed as Traders Await Meeting by Group of 7

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against major foreign currencies yesterday in advance of a key economic report and the meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations.
Gold prices rose. Gold bullion for current delivery closed at $329.90 an ounce, up 20 cents, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. A late bid from the Republic National Bank in New York quoted gold at $329.50 an ounce, up 30 cents. 
 Andrew Busch, a vice president in charge of foreign exchange at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, said the dollar had been fairly range-bound during the day before it moved upward on the German mark at the end of the day.
 
Some Short-Selling
 Traders, betting that the dollar would decline, indulged in some short-selling in anticipation of revised fourth-quarter gross domestic product numbers due today and the outcome of the Group of Seven meeting this weekend, Mr. Busch said.
In short-selling, traders borrow dollars, then sell them immediately, anticipating that the value will decline. If it does, the traders buy dollars at the lower price, then repay the loan and pocket the difference.
The Group of Seven leading industrial nations will discuss monetary policy and foreign exchange rates.
In New York, the dollar was quoted at 117.475 Japanese yen, unchanged from late Wednesday. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 117.53 yen, up 0.60 yen from Wednesday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 117.50 yen.
In New York, the British pound was quoted at $1.4315, more expensive than $1.4305 late Wednesday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.4297, from $1.4385 late Wednesday.
 
Other Late Rates
 Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's late rates, included: 1.6350 German marks, up from 1.6265; 1.5170 Swiss francs, up from 1.5065; 5.5500 French francs, up from 5.5155; 1,594.00 Italian lire, down from 1,595.375, and 1.25175 Canadian dollars, down from 1.25915.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.6345 German marks, up from 1.6200; 1.5175 Swiss francs, up from 1.4985; 5.5495 French francs, up from 5.4935; 1.8380 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8230; 1,591.00 Italian lire, down from 1,594.00, and 1.2535 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2617.

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

A Deal in Spain
At first, the deal was simply a rental. An option to buy didn't seem to be in the cards. But now it appears the Spanish Government will be able to acquire one of the world's greatest private art collections: more than 800 works belonging to the Swiss billionaire Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza and his family. The collection, whose works date from the 13th to the 20th century, has been valued by Sotheby's at nearly $2 billion. 
 In October, amid much fanfare, the artworks went on view to the public in the Villahermosa, a renovated early-19th-century palace about 100 yards from the Prado in Madrid. The Spanish Government paid about $45 million to renovate the palace specifically for this collection. It also agreed to pay Baron Thyssen and his heirs $5 million a year in rent until 2001.
Now, if everything goes as planned, Spain will pay a reported $500 million to buy the collection.
"I hope the negotiations will be finalized before July," said Rodrigo Uria, a managing partner in the Madrid law firm Uria & Menendez, who was retained by the Spanish Government six and a half years ago to advise it on negotiations with the Thyssens. "Everything has been agreed upon. Now it's up to the lawyers for the Thyssen trust to provide the necessary papers."
 
Official Fears Allayed
 The 71-year-old Baron and his fifth wife, Carmen (Tita) Cervera, have been involved in all aspects of the arrangements, including the negotiations to rent and then to sell the art to Spain. Word in Spanish art circles is that the Baroness persuaded the Baron and his heirs to agree to sell the collection to Spain because it is her native country. Last week, she told a reporter for El Pais, Spain's leading newspaper: "Within 45 days the Thyssen collection will be Spanish. The agreement among us all is about to become a reality. There are only mere bureaucratic procedures."
Tomas Llorens, the chief curator at the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum in the Villahermosa, declined to discuss the details of the negotiations but said Spain's fears that the art would eventually leave the country were now over. "The collection is perhaps the best introduction to the history of painting," he said.
The paintings include many types of art poorly represented in Spanish collections, with works by Old Masters, Impressionists, Post-Impressionists and Americans. Among works in the collection are fine examples from artists like van Gogh, Picasso, Gris, Chagall, Goya, Velazquez, Gauguin, Monet, Degas, Toulouse-Lautrec, Rembrandt, Rubens, Bonnard and Cezanne, as well as American artists including Charles Willson Peale, Thomas Cole, Winslow Homer and John Singleton Copley.
"Collections like this one can never stand still," Mr. Llorens said. "But what is sure is that this will no longer be a collection in formation. But that doesn't preclude the possibility of refinements and acquisitions." The collection, he added, will retain an international presence, participating in loan agreements with museums around the world.
 
Art and Taxes
 There is no question that the treatment of charitable gifts under President Clinton's tax proposal would greatly benefit museums, but how would the economic plan affect auction houses and galleries? And what about the President's plan to raise the taxes of those in high-income brackets, the prime art-buying public?
It all depends on whom you ask.
Part of the problem is that there are so many variables. The treatment of gifts of art to museums is one issue, but the potential of higher taxes is quite another. And a provision that affects auction houses one way may have quite a different effect on art galleries.
Referring to a measure in the 1986 Tax Reform Act that effectively made major gifts to nonprofit organizations deductible at the purchase price rather than at market value, Patricia G. Hambrecht, general counsel at Christie's, said: "We have long been advocates of a repeal of the provision. Three years ago, we went to Washington to lobby on Capitol Hill, even though we realize this may not have a favorable impact on our business." (The more artworks are donated to museums, the fewer the auction houses have to sell.)
President Clinton's proposal would allow the donor of a major gift to a nonprofit organization to deduct the property's current market value, rather than its original purchase price, as a charitable contribution. In most cases, the current market value is higher.
Donors were able to deduct the current market value for 18 months -- from Jan. 1, 1991, to June 30, 1992 -- when Congress suspended that provision of the 1986 tax law and allowed contributors to deduct the full fair market value of their gifts. Mrs. Hambrecht said Christie's appraisal business for donation purposes rose significantly in that period. "Any decline in the auction business during that period was unrelated to the tax window," she said.
Another aspect of Mr. Clinton's proposal would raise the tax rate on high incomes.
Diana D. Brooks, the president of Sotheby's in America, said she believed a tax increase could weaken the auction market's middle tier by leaving less discretionary income for acquiring art. "But it's hard to know," she said. "My guess is that the $130,000-to-$500,000 income range will be affected."
But Mrs. Hambrecht said, "At the very top level, people will always have money, so the increase probably won't have any effect on business at all."
Dealers see the President's tax plan differently. "If the economy will be pushed into the doldrums by Clinton's tax plan, we will be in deep trouble," said Andre Emmerich, the Manhattan gallery owner. "The bottom line is the creation of new wealth. If there's a sense of buoyancy, people will feel like spending money."
Mr. Emmerich added that if it became advantageous once again to donate artworks to museums, a scarcity of museum-quality works on the market could raise prices.
Richard Feigen, another Manhattan dealer, said he didn't believe prices would rise. "At least not right away," he said. "In most areas, from classic 20th-century to Old Masters and antiquities, people aren't affected by the vagaries of the economy, except psychologically."
Mr. Feigen added that he believed the market for contemporary art, which has always been subject to speculative buyers, would be the hardest hit. Looking to the future, he predicted, "The market will continue to rise because people will continue to think of art as a financial asset."
"I'm not pleased by this," he concluded, saying art should be bought for art's sake and not for investment purposes. "But it's a condition with which we seem to have to live."
 
A College's Loss
 The J. Paul Getty Museum's gain is an English college's loss, and the British are, understandably, sore losers.
Grave disapproval has been art experts' reaction to the news that Holloway College, a branch of London University in Egham, was forced to sell an important seascape by J. M. W. Turner, "Van Tromp Going About to Please His Masters," from 1844. The college said it planned to use the $16 million it received from the Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., to finance the upkeep of its magnificent Gothic building.
But museum curators in London say this precedent may deter potential benefactors from making collections available to academic institutions in the future. The painting is part of a private collection of 76 artworks bequeathed by Thomas Holloway, the Victorian industrialist who founded the college in the 1880's.
In September, the college obtained permission from the Charities Commission, a Government body, to sell the painting after British museums were offered the work but failed to raise the money. Prof. Norman Gowar, the principal of the college, said his institution had no other options because the British Government was also unable to help. "We are losing a painting to save a building," he said. "As a college, we are deeply sad to see the Turner go, but we are pleased it will be on public view at the Getty."
Nicholas Serota, the director of the Tate Gallery in London, whose Clore Gallery is devoted to Turners, issued a statement expressing his disappointment. "We are naturally sorry that the council of Royal Holloway College has broken the Founder's trust in deciding to sell works from the collection," he said. "The Turner is a magnificent painting and strong interest in acquiring it was expressed by one of the British national collections, though in the circumstances of a privately negotiated sale it was unable to match the sum being offered by the Getty Museum."
The Tate has a budget of about $2.4 million a year to buy artworks, less than one-sixth of the painting's price. It is a record for a Turner, but one that the Getty was happy to pay. "We don't have a Turner in our collection," said George Goldner, the Getty's curator of paintings and drawings. "It is a beautiful work in fine condition." He declined to comment on the uproar the painting's sale has caused in Britain, but said he believed the price was fair. Now the Getty must wait for an export license to be granted. "It will take several months," Mr. Goldner said. "But we're optimistic."

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
A Softer Side To a Knight Of Wicked Wit

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

 BODY:
IF you think you know Honore Daumier because you know the famous and beloved lithographic illustrations he did for the Paris journal Le Charivari in the mid-19th century, think again. A wonderful exhibition of Daumier's drawings, along with some related paintings and sculptures, which opens today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, will be a revelation.
For all the fluency and wicked humor of so many of his lithographs, Daumier reveals himself in these mostly private works to be an artist of wider technical range and vastly subtler emotions. Some of the drawings are heartbreaking in a quiet, almost surreptitious way that has nothing to do with the theatrics that Daumier was obliged to perform in his caricatures and that at one point landed him in jail. 
 Posterity has recorded little he said, but the show leaves no doubt about his ambition and the breadth of vision that allowed him to absorb with equal perspicacity Old Master paintings in the Louvre and impoverished itinerant musicians on the working-class streets of the Ile St.-Louis, where he lived for many years. Without taking too big a psychological leap, you can also feel, in the recurrent images of fugitives and displaced citizens, something of Daumier's attitude toward his own ambivalent status in Paris's artistic constellation, praised as he was by the likes of Baudelaire and Champfleury, but still regarded widely as a mere caricaturist.
When he depicts with evident affection a pair of connoisseurs in a painter's studio lovingly attending to a sheaf of works on paper, you can sense Daumier conjuring up ideal patrons. And when he depicts an aging pair of melancholic clowns lost in thought, you can see a reflection of Daumier himself, the comic artist. No wonder he also devoted a series of poignant and atmospheric drawings and paintings -- but not prints -- to the popular subject of Don Quixote, whose quest he might well have considered a metaphor for his own effort to establish himself as a serious artist.
It was left to succeeding generations to guarantee for Daumier, through their emulation of his work, the exalted status he deserved. A long and diverse list of artists built on his achievement: Cezanne, Degas, van Gogh, Toulouse-Lautrec, Picasso, Beckmann, perhaps Ensor, and Giacometti. Giacometti's characteristically obsessive style of drawing, in particular, recalls the way Daumier makes some of his most extraordinary images through swirls of angel's-hair lines, none of which on its own describes a form but all of which are together somehow precise. This is a long way from the "thick, strong, manly touch" that Henry James once noted about Daumier's prints.
Daumier was essentially self-taught, his remarkable gifts as a draftsman clearly innate. He was born in 1808 in Marseille, the son of a glazier, picture-framer and frustrated poet who moved his family to Paris in 1816, hoping to establish himself as a writer. It would be largely left to Daumier to support the family; his father died in 1851 in the Charenton insane asylum.
He studied briefly as a teen-ager with the artist Alexandre Lenoir and took drawing and painting classes at the Academie Suisse in Paris, where students worked without formal instruction. But by the late 1820's, he was already on his own, creating illustrations for the weekly La Silhouette. When, during the early 1830's, he produced a series of caricatures of King Louis-Philippe and his deputies, Daumier earned for himself a modest spell in Ste.-Pelagie prison. After 1835 and the Government's prohibition on political caricatures, he turned to the safer ground of illustrating everyday life.
His drawings, which are virtually all undated, seem to come principally from two periods: around the 1848 Revolution, which interrupted his press assignments and allowed him more time to devote to paintings, for which the drawings are often preparatory; and the 1860's, when Le Charivari temporarily laid him off, having incorrectly calculated that after three decades he had overstayed his welcome with the public.
The drawings are focused on a handful of eclectic subjects, including not only Don Quixote and carnival performers and connoisseurs and refugees, but also people on trains and in railway stations (displaced people of a sort), women and children (but, interestingly, rarely men and women), and lawyers. For Daumier, lawyers were as much performers in their dubious way as saltimbanques, and in a few cases, like "The Speech for the Defense" and "The Sideshow," he recycled the same basic composition to describe both groups.
Still, it is striking that so many of the works here depict people simply thinking, looking, sitting alone in silence or engaged in intimate conversation. It seems to have been mostly during the 1860's, when the unemployed Daumier was producing elaborate drawings and watercolors to satisfy collectors, who expected from him a certain brand of caricature, that he relied on the broader humor of his prints.
The Metropolitan's show is arranged more or less according to subject, with the addition of an early academic portrait, several gorgeous landscapes in watercolor and pen and ink, and a group of studies based on classical and religious themes, which make clear Daumier's debt to Old Masters like Rubens. There is, for example, the great "Drunkenness of Silenus," whose robust physicality he would also put to use in his sly depiction of a lawyer in "Grand Staircase." There is "The Kiss," whose emotional high pitch brings to mind Gericault, and "The Riot," whose tumult of figures pays homage to the Baroque. And there is "Five Studies for the Prodigal Son," a deeply moving group of sketches in which the tremulous lines with which Daumier describes the hunched figure of the son held by his father add immeasurably to the pathos.
Those same lines could also suggest movement, a tangle of them simulating the waving arms of a barker at a sideshow or the arc of a drumstick. Daumier was a master at this, as one after another drawing demonstrates. And it is the absence of this energetic, looser style in the works he did for collectors that can make them seem fussy and static by comparison.
He was also a master, as the exhibition makes clear, at the dramatic use of light and shadow, sometimes seeming to mimic Caravaggio and his followers, as when he silhouettes figures against a fire in "Hunters by the Fire," or when he gathers several men around a candlelit table in "A Good Vintage." His well-known watercolors of passengers in first-, second- and third-class railway carriages are as much studies in light as they are studies in character, and in fact it is the conspicuous softness of the light in the first-class carriage and the cavelike dimness in those of the other classes that most immediately put the message across.
Something of the same mastery of light and shadow applies to his sculptures, several of which are on view, including the bronze relief of "The Emigrants," a Michelangelesque procession of figures that is one of Daumier's finest achievements. As he does with drawings in which form is described by a jumble of lines that turn the whole page into a roiling plane, in sculptures like "The Emigrants" the undulated surface is a mass of scars, folds, wrinkles and facets that catch the light and give the sense of tremendous activity. Daumier's style of drawing varied, but it can often be most accurately described as sculptural.
Daumier never became a great painter, as he wished to be, and several of the projects commissioned by the state, with which he hoped to stake his claim as a serious artist, didn't pan out. But he produced some remarkable paintings nonetheless, and one of them is the oil sketch of Don Quixote on a white horse, which, fittingly, is the last work in the show. It is, unlike many of the other paintings, a loose swirl of strokes, reminiscent of Fragonard in its freewheeling virtuosity. It is also suggestive, in its strong color contrasts, of the encroaching blindness that left Daumier by his death in 1879 able to distinguish only lights and darks.
The show has been organized by Colta Ives of the Metropolitan and Margret Stuffmann of the Stadel in Frankfurt, where it was first seen. It includes about 125 of the roughly 800 drawings Daumier is known to have done (he produced thousands of lithographs). There are a few questionable selections; a study related to "The Emigrants" relief hardly seems, in its woodenness, to be by Daumier. But the exhibition is mostly full of terrific things, handsomely presented. At the entrance are a group of his best-known lithographs, which can make a very different impression after you have seen the show. You shouldn't miss it.
The exhibition of Daumier drawings remains at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, through May 2. It is sponsored by J. P. Morgan & Company, and will not travel.

HEADLINE: Hotel Dining Regains Glow Of Long Ago

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER

 BODY:
OVER the last decade, hotel restaurants have been the most fickle of suitors. Usually attractive, elegant and inviting, they can deliver a sublime experience one day and six months later turn out humdrum food that puts lobby coffee shops in a favorable light. The reasons for such instability vary: peripatetic chefs, the strain of running round-the-clock kitchens and cost-cutting dictated by far-off corporate headquarters.
Now the good news: hotel restaurants are on a roll, both around the nation and in New York City. Moreover, prices are more reasonable than they were in the high-rolling 1980's. 
 Many hotels that lost their quality restaurants to recessionary cutbacks in the late 80's are making a comeback, and noteworthy new restaurants have appeared. In Manhattan, they include those in the Essex House, the Mark, the Royalton, the Paramount, the Waldorf-Astoria and others. Around the country, to name just a few, there are the Mansion on Turtle Creek and Adolphus Hotel in Dallas; the Windsor Court in New Orleans; the Four Seasons hotels in Philadelphia, Chicago, Seattle and Boston, and the Ritz-Carltons in San Francisco, Chicago and Atlanta.
Hotel general managers say few hotel restaurants make a profit, largely because of higher labor costs and the lack of flexibility on hours because hotels are always open, but they say that a fine dining room can be effective public relations. Specifically, it brings in lucrative banquet business and lends a hotel the prestige that can attract hotel guests.
"Our restaurant is not profitable on its own," said Wolf Walther, general manager of the Essex House, whose year-old French restaurant, Les Celebrites, is booked weeks in advance.
He added that both the hotel's restaurants (the other is the more casual Cafe Botanica) were part of a financial strategy to generate banquet business. At the same time, Les Celebrites, while technically a hotel restaurant, has wide outside appeal: only 6 percent of its patrons are hotel guests, Mr. Walther said. The Essex House, which is owned by Nikko Hotels International, plans to open a Japanese restaurant later this year.
As good as hotel food might be, the industry is fighting a negative image created by the decades of stodgy hotel cooking that began after World War II. Before the war, travelers commonly checked into hotels for up to a week or more, and most ate in the hotel's dining room at least three or four times during their stay. Hotels took great competitive pride in their food. Some of the better hotel dining rooms at the time in Manhattan were in the Waldorf-Astoria, the Ritz-Carlton, the Pierre and the Astor.
But after the war, hotels became overnight lodging for many business travelers. Simultaneously, independent restaurants proliferated and improved, luring diners out of their hotels. The new chain hotels, bland but efficient, did not help the reputation of hotel food.
Several Manhattan hoteliers mentioned the stigma attached to hotel dining as a result of this long period of mediocrity. In fact, many hotel restaurants, including Les Celebrites, Lafayette in the Drake Swissotel and Le Regence in the Hotel Plaza-Athenee, have created separate entrances to minimize their connection with the hotel.
But others, like Mark's in the Mark, can be reached only by walking through the hotel lobby.
"There is definitely a stigma with this," Raymond Bickson, general manager of the five-year-old Mark, said of the situation at his hotel. "We just have to work harder to get around it."
Entrance aside, the Mark's luxury French restaurant characterizes the recent resurgence in hotel dining. "We see a good hotel dining room as a calling card to bring in people who live in the neighborhood," Mr. Bickson said. "You need the local residents; you can't survive on guests alone, especially when times are bad during a recession."
Here is a selective roundup of Manhattan's most ambitious hotel dining rooms. Several noteworthy restaurants that are in hotels but have no obvious connection to those establishments have been omitted, including Le Cirque, Bellini by Cipriani and Harry Cipriani.
 
Essex House
 160 Central Park South, (212) 247-0300.
In November 1991, after a two-year renovation, the Essex House unveiled LES CELEBRITES, its showcase dining room. The decorative motif and the name derive from several dozen paintings by celebrities of stage and screen: Gene Hackman, Phyllis Diller, Van Johnson, James Dean and others. Fortunately this amateur-hour conceit does not extend to the kitchen, where a seasoned professional, Christian Delouvrier, is in charge.
No expense was spared on the setting, which has only 14 tables. Gilded columns and ornate molding, thick rugs and crescent-shaped banquettes, dark mahogany walls, Limoges plates, Christofle silver and glittering crystal all contribute to the sumptuous tone.
In the mid-1980's Mr. Delouvrier was chef at the highly regarded restaurant Maurice in the Hotel Parker Meridien in Manhattan. In those heady days, the hotel flew in a consulting three-star French chef, Alain Senderens, to oversee the kitchen. Before opening Les Celebrites, Mr. Delouvrier traveled extensively in Asia, and his menus show it.
On the current menu are cross-cultural dishes like crab salad with lemongrass and olive oil, curried sea scallops in pastry with spinach, and salmon steak with crisped skin, Oriental spices and a leek compote. At the same time, there are earthy French winter specialties like roasted squab with cabbage, mashed potatoes and white truffle oil, and beef stew with a carrot tart and roasted cepes.
Desserts are appropriately lavish and delightful, including a cleansing tart of candied orange peel with bitter chocolate sorbet, chocolate souffle with praline ice cream, and charlotte of pears with raspberry puree.
The six-course tasting menu at Les Celebrites is $85, the a la carte menu is about $65 a person with a glass of wine before tax and tip.
A less formal cousin of Les Celebrites, CAFE BOTANICA, offers a light, colorful and herbaceous menu at lunch and dinner. The dining room, in the front of the hotel facing Central Park South, is bright and cheerful (featuring more celebrity art). The $19.93 lunch Mondays through Saturdays is a particular bargain.
In my experience, Cafe Botanica does not have as high a batting average as its more expensive counterpart down the hall. For example, a fish soup at lunch recently had a potent shellfish stock base but was underseasoned, and grilled swordfish nicoise style offered more flair than flavor. Yet many dishes are on target, including the grilled shrimp salad with red onions and endive at lunch, and the grilled salmon with a bright sorrel sauce and green lentils at dinner. The $29 three-course tasting menu available daily for dinner can be one of the best buys around.
 
Peninsula
 700 Fifth Avenue, at 55th Street, (212) 903-3918.
Like so many restaurants of its type, the stately ADRIENNE, the Peninsula's showcase dining room, has seen more changes than a hotel bed in recent years. New ownership, different management, revolving chefs: all have led to instability and confusion among diners. Now part of a prestigious international hotel chain, Adrienne may be finding its ballast.
The restaurant's comfortable and roomy Art Nouveau dining room offers deep armchairs and rose-tinted banquettes, floor-to-ceiling windows overlooking Fifth Avenue and an energetic, hospitable staff.
The chef, Adam Odegard, is anything but timid in his approach to cooking, and occasionally his enthusiasm results in clashing flavors. More often than not, though, his creations harmonize. Winners on the current menu include seared venison with truffle oil and a parsnip-almond tartlet, and steamed halibut with a ripe preserved tomato, grilled squash, couscous and a fennel emulsion.
Soups are a good way to start, especially the cinnamon-scented pumpkin puree, as are the little goat-cheese-filled won tons with salad, and marinated shrimp with horseradish-chili oil and mixed greens. Count on about $50 a person with a glass of wine before tax and tip. Adrienne offers a $32 pre-theater dinner Tuesdays through Saturdays and a $28 prix fixe lunch Mondays through Fridays.
 
Royalton
 44 West 44th Street, (212) 944-8844.
Renovated in 1988 with the help of the architect Philippe Starck, the Royalton may look like a tiresomely hip lair for people who wear all black and clomp around in orthopedic-looking shoes. But if you can ignore the eerie-blue lobby, carrot-shaped sconces and the funhouse-minus-the-fun restrooms, some of the most satisfying food in the theater district can be found.
The hotel's restaurant, called 44, is run by Brian McNally, who has been around the track more than a few times in Manhattan (Indochine, Canal Bar, 150 Wooster), and his chef, Geoffrey Zakarian. In the last year, this lobby restaurant has become a favorite lunch perch for publishing executives and the high-fashion crowd. Aside from gossip and intrigue, the 44 menu offers bright and appealing American fare with international accents. At a recent lunch, crispy fried calamari was clean and tasty, as was a dish called souffle of cod (sort of a brandade de morue on helium), with a Parmesan crust. Among main courses there is a nicely browned skate with sweet turnip puree, a three-story grilled tuna nicoise with mixed-green-and-olive puree, and a muddled, flat-tasting penne with chicken, tomato and parsley.
Some of the more appealing items at dinner are lamb stew with quince and homemade pasta, grilled Muscovy duck breast with spicy tempura of shallots and roasted pear, and spit-roasted squab with potatoes, apples and roasted squash. Waiters are knowledgeable and enthusiastic but sometimes lacking in the basic skills of getting dishes to the right customer and refilling wine.
Dinner runs about $45 with a glass of wine before tax and tip; lunch about $30. Pre-theater dinner, daily except Sundays, is $32.50.
 
The Mark
 25 East 77th Street, (212) 744-4300.
This dignified, intimate hotel on the Upper East Side has stressed quality food since it opened in 1988. MARK'S, the sumptuous dining room with faux skylights and dark walls adorned with classical prints and gold-framed mirrors, is as soothing as a favorite old sweater.
The chef, Philippe Boulot, has an eclectic style, borrowing ingredients from around the world to enliven his essentially French-based cuisine. When this works, the results can be splendid. A recent dinner began with a scintillating lobster roll made with Chinese rice paper and seasoned with tarragon, along with a carrot vinaigrette sharpened with a parsley essence. Also invigorating is the faintly peppery roast quail with a mache salad.
Among main courses, the crisp, air-dried duck is appealing with its minimally sweet plum wine sauce and sauteed bok choy. Braised sea bass is excellent over herbed mashed potatoes. One of the earthier items on the current menu is braised cheeks of beef, tender and gelatinous, in a rich beef-stock sauce with confit of carrots.
Desserts are excellent: banana tart with pineapple-coconut ice cream; a buttery, thin-crusted apple tart, and a rich, custardy bread pudding.
You will not find any bargain's on Mark's well-selected international wine list, but the sommelier is helpful in steering you toward wines that best complement various dishes. Dinner runs about $55 a person with a glass of wine before tax and tip. A prix fixe three-course dinner, available daily, is $45; the vintner's version, also daily, is $65. A $19.93 prix fixe lunch is offered Mondays through Saturdays.
 
Waldorf-Astoria
 301 Park Avenue, at 50th Street, (212) 355-3000.
This sprawling hotel on Park Avenue has a grand food tradition going back to the early 1930's, when the legendary Oscar Tschisky oversaw more than a half-dozen restaurants, including the musical Empire Room, the Sert Room (named for the Spanish artist who painted the murals there), the Starlight Roof, Peacock Alley, Cafe Lounge, Cafe Savarin and the Norse Grill.
In the 1970's and 80's, the Waldorf's dining rooms fell behind the pace of up-and-coming private restaurants. Last year, an ambitious young French chef, Laurent Manrique, took over PEACOCK ALLEY, and for the first time in many years, diners are talking about the Waldorf-Astoria.
After entering the front door, one has to wander around in the cavernous lobby of the hotel before finding Peacock Alley, a palatial Old World spot with burnished wood walls, large murals of peacocks and an army of tuxedoed waiters. There seems to be a tendency among young hotel chefs these days to gild the lily. Mr. Manrique is no exception. An example is his rabbit tartelette, which is moist, garlicky and fragrant with fresh thyme. It could easily do without a garnish of fresh figs. A rough-textured terrine of foie gras, leeks, duck confit and potatoes is delicious, though. So is a cassolette of artichoke hearts, snails and winter vegetables in a garlic-infused broth.
A gutsy winter dish is the wild boar stew. The caramelized meat is sinewy and mild in a thick reduced red wine sauce sweetened with dried prunes and pearl onions. A turgid lobster and shellfish stew lacks focus, but roasted salmon with savoy cabbage and brandade de morue (a garlicky puree of cod and potatoes) should not be missed.
Hotels can usually be counted on for an awesome array of desserts. Peacock Alley offers just that. Among the best sampled are a brittle prune and apple turnover with prune ice cream and Armagnac sauce, warm Valrhona chocolate cake with mocha cream, and a Grand Marnier napoleon with a semisweet tangerine sauce. Dinner runs about $50 a person with a glass of wine before tax and tip; lunch about $30. Three prix fixe dinners are offered daily: $45 (without wine), $60 (with wine) and $70 for six courses. A $22.50 prix fixe lunch is also offered daily.
 
Westbury
 840 Madison Avenue, at 69th Street, (212) 535-2000.
THE POLO, the patrician-looking restaurant with an equestrian decor, reached a gastronomic peak in the mid-1980's when Patrice Bouely, a native of Provence, was the chef. When the economy tumbled, so did the restaurant's ambitions. Mr. Bouely was dismissed and the Polo began a gradual downhill slide, broken briefly by the hiring of Terrance Brennan, who now is a partner in Prix Fixe and Steak Frites, both in Manhattan.
The current American chef, Neil Murphy, a student of Charles Palmer at Aureole in Manhattan, is trying to turn things around. Mr. Murphy has assembled a large contemporary American menu, perhaps too large. His strudel-wrapped shrimp with shaved fennel and a tomato compote is a lovely match of textures and flavors. Also good are little pan-braised dumplings in a Parmesan-laced broth. With successes like these, it is surprising that a simple field salad with pommes Maxime is oily and bland.
The chef has a deft touch with game, particularly a recent special of venison over sauteed potatoes with sweet carrots and turnips. Swordfish is inviting, too, served with asparagus, artichoke chips and a soothing vegetable broth. The best-sounding dish on the menu did not disappoint either: wood-grilled chicken breast with stuffed chicken leg, potato and onion cake, and a roasted garlic sauce.
Desserts are highly refined and visually arresting across the board, including the lemon parfait, a crisped banana fritter with hazelnut ice cream, and a whimsical chocolate ice cream sandwich. Dinner is about $50 a person with a glass of wine before tax and tip; lunch about $30.
 
Hotel Plaza Athenee
 37 East 64th Street, (212) 734-9100.
LE REGENCE, the sumptuous French restaurant, has been in the front ranks of fine dining in New York City since 1987, when the hotel hired the Rostang family in France (father and two sons) as consultants. That association ended last year, and Le Regence is in the process of redefining itself.
The ornate dining room is a sea of turquoise and white, with deep leather armchairs, benevolent lighting and comfortable banquettes. Service is highly professional. Based on two recent visits, the food ranges from adequate to very good. The kitchen seems to do best with a la minute preparation than with more elaborate fare. A good starter at lunch is fettuccine tossed with chunks of fresh lobster, basil and good olive oil. A goat cheese terrine was unexpectedly rich, even cloying, but house-smoked salmon with a warm potato pancake, creme fraiche and onions was well balanced.
Grilled red snapper with soybean butter under a stack of deep-fried scallions is hard to resist as a main course, as is medallion of venison in a pepper-spiked sauce with red cabbage, chestnuts and apples. Le Regence is more expensive than most hotel dining rooms, about $55 a person for dinner with a glass of wine before tax and tip, about $35 at lunch. There is a $33.50 prix fixe Sunday brunch; a prix fixe dinner served daily at $49, and a prix fixe lunch at $25.50.
 
Drake Swissotel
 65 East 56th Street, (212) 832-1565.
LAFAYETTE, the French restaurant in this most European of hotels, had the dubious distinction of being one of the most talked about restaurants in the country several years ago. The chef was Jean-Georges Vongerichten, whose distinctive cooking elevated Lafayette to a four-star rating. Then in 1991, Mr. Vongerichten left to open his own Manhattan establishment, Jo Jo. Thus began a long slide for Lafayette as a series of chefs tried to fill Mr. Vongerichten's oversized shoes.
The restaurant closed in July 1992, perhaps in an effort to exorcise the four-star ghost, and reopened in November with a bright young chef, John DiLeo, who made his mark at the breezy American grill in SoHo called Zoe.
Except for some colorful murals of the Hudson River Valley, Lafayette looks the same. It still has a sparkling kitchen behind glass, well-separated tables, soft beige-and-cream tones and a low noise level. Mr. DiLeo has a wide-reaching, somewhat sassy style, as evidenced by an excellent appetizer featuring seared tenderloins of lamb encrusted with fennel seeds and mustard seeds along with a cooling fennel salad: a nice one-two punch. Also well conceived is his seared smoked salmon set over rice cake flecked with truffles. Only a tomato and lemongrass broth with assorted shellfish was oddly flat tasting.
Duck is one of the best main courses, crisp skinned, juicy and paired with a well-seasoned potato pancake and pear chutney. Spit-roasted cod is savory over a puree of potatoes and olives. For dessert, there is a picture-perfect creme brulee and superb fruit sorbets.
Dinner is about $50 a person with a glass of wine before tax and tip; lunch is about $35. A pre-theater dinner, from 6 to 7 P.M. Mondays through Saturdays, is $38; lunch prix fixe at $28 is served Mondays through Saturdays.
 
St. Regis
 2 East 55th Street, (212) 339-6719.
Since 1991, with the arrival of Gray Kunz, the enterprising chef who artfully fuses the cuisines of East and West, LESPINASSE has been a ground-breaking New York City restaurant, in or out of hotels.
The grand Old World setting may seem incongruous with Mr. Kunz's cutting-edge cooking, but it is certainly comfortable. Giant murals, a gilded ceiling, thick rugs, oversize chairs, widely spaced tables; such comforts are rare outside a hotel dining room.
Typical of Mr. Kunz's style is his restorative bouillon of capon with winter savory and lotus seeds, sort of chicken soup with a cosmopolitan education. Also on the winter menu is an earthy fricasee of mushrooms with risotto flavored with rosemary and shallots.
Main courses to watch for are the roast duck seasoned with an exotic orange-based spice blend, all over a bed of endive, and the gutsy marinated beef short ribs and a potato mousseline with a peppy horseradish-mustard sauce.
The superb desserts range from the exotic (sauteed bananas with a star anise parfait) to the soothing (honey-apple strudel with vanilla creme fraiche). Dinner averages $60 a person with a glass of wine before tax and tip. A tasting menu is prix fixe at $64; the vegetarian version is $48. The prix fixe lunch is $38.
 
Paramount
 243 West 46th Street, (212) 719-5588.
This sleek, stylish hotel in the theater district opted for something different when it opened its main restaurant last year. Rather than go with a formal, cozy institutional approach, it flung the door open and created a snappy French brasserie called BRASSERIE DES THEATRES, which caters to the theater crowd at all hours.
The job was turned over to masters of the genre, Max Bernard, Jean-Michel Diot and Philippe Lajaunie, the owners of Park Bistro and Les Halles on Park Avenue. Not only is Brasserie des Theatres the most authentic-looking brasserie in New York City, it also serves some of the most authentic food: sturdy fish soup with aioli, rabbit terrine, boeuf en gelee, saucisson en brioche, pistou, brandade de morue, choucroute garnie, cassoulet. Within two months it became one of the most popular dining spots in midtown.
Brasserie des Theatres serves until 1 A.M. daily for the late-night crowd. Dinner runs about $40 a person with a glass of wine before tax and tip; lunch about $25.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
An Emergency That Need Not Be

BYLINE: By RICHARD E. MOONEY

 BODY:
Congress thought it had solved the problem of expiring unemployment benefits when it passed an "emergency" law last July. The law was designed to prevent future emergencies by giving states the power to enact extra benefits when they were needed. But the states did nothing and now Congress finds itself forced to do it all over again. It's an example of how Washington politicians can get caught up in problem-solving that solves nothing.
The new bill is clearly needed. It provides up to 26 extra weeks of support for jobless workers who exhaust their current benefits and still can't find work. It is first on President Clinton's action list for boosting the economy, and not a moment too soon. 
 The current program of extra benefits expires in two weeks and the rate of unemployment remains distressingly high. At 7.1 percent, it is higher than it was at the official trough of the recession almost two years ago. Close to 1.8 million of the long-term unemployed will see their benefits cut off in early March if the emergency program isn't extended, and it's estimated that a similar number will exhaust their benefits within the next six months.
But wait. Didn't Congress fix the jobless insurance system just last summer, so that emergency legislation wouldn't be needed again? Yes, and for a change, President Bush didn't veto it. Yet barely seven months later that "permanent" solution stands exposed as an inside-the-Beltway fix that didn't fly.
Probably in all sincerity, the Democrats who designed last summer's repair thought it was forever. From then on, under the new law, states with high unemployment could extend benefits for their long-term jobless without waiting for Washington to pass another special law.
As of now, it appears that more than 20 states would qualify for an extension when current benefits run out next month, if their governors and legislatures had done as the new law assumed they would. But none did. Not even one. Because the Congressional engineers of the new option misread one consideration that should have been obvious: Who pays?
If a state triggers extra benefits, it bears half the cost -- and all the onus among businesses that will eventually have to cover that cost. But smart governors and state legislators know that if they just wait long enough, Washington will ride to the rescue, and maybe with full Federal funding. Congress paid the last round of added benefits out of the Government's general revenues, breaking the once-firm rule that the unemployment insurance system is financed by the unemployment insurance tax. And the same is about to happen again.
Granted, no one foresaw last summer that unemployment would continue so high for so long, and that still another extension of benefits would be needed in the current recession cycle. But the new Federal law was enacted in early July. There has been plenty of time for states to act. There's also been time for Washington to prod them, but there's no sign anyone did.
The pending bill, already approved by the House, has one worthwhile new feature. Patterned on an experiment in New Jersey, it's a $23 million program to identify and help workers whose jobs are gone forever, distinct from those who are temporarily laid off. The rest of the bill -- all $5.7 billion of it -- is obviously necessary, because current emergency benefits are about to cease. But let it also be a reminder that when Congress fixes a problem, it isn't necessarily fixed.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Maiden Voyage, Smooth Sailing

 BODY:
Warren Christopher isn't known for dramatic gestures, but he does have a reputation for competently managing complex and dangerous crises. He used his first overseas voyage as Secretary of State to tackle two big challenges on the foreign policy agenda -- reviving the stalled Middle East peace talks and reaching out to Russia and its embattled President, Boris Yeltsin.
The results, jointly announced yesterday in Geneva by Mr. Christopher and his Russian counterpart, Andrei Kozyrev, were encouraging, not least because they indicate that President Clinton has decided not to stiff-arm foreign policy. On April 4, Presidents Clinton and Yeltsin will meet at a site not yet disclosed. Delegates to the Mideast peace talks have been invited to reconvene in Washington the same month. 
 The Secretary was warmly received at each stop, but he rightly warned his entourage against "travel euphoria." Careful preparation will be required for both meetings. It's not even certain that all the invited Middle East parties will show up.
Nevertheless, Mr. Christopher's initial foray has helped swing the Administration's focus to the two foreign policy issues that most urgently require Presidential attention: rejuvenating the Middle East peace process and solidifying America's most important strategic relationship.
Mr. Christopher appears to have found face-saving common ground between Israelis and Palestinians on the angry dispute over the mass deportation of 400 alleged terrorists from the Israeli-ruled Gaza Strip and West Bank. Palestinians have called for the repatriation of the 400, and as a precondition for rejoining peace talks have sought a pledge that it won't happen again.
The deportations aided fundamentalists bent on wrecking the talks. Israel now says it will speed the return of the deportees, still languishing in southern Lebanon, and that it is not Israeli policy to engage in future deportations. What would help is for Israelis to spell out to Palestinians more forthcoming proposals on self-rule for the West Bank and Gaza, the main agenda item.
In short, Palestinians who seek peace and American good will can reasonably declare victory and resume negotiations. As Mr. Christopher learned, many hope they will -- not only Arab moderates in Egypt and Saudi Arabia but also Syria, for decades Israel's most rejectionist neighbor. What has turned Damascus around is the collapse of Soviet power and Israel's willingness to discuss swapping land for peace on the Golan Heights.
Thus the process nurtured by President Bush has a good chance of surviving in a new Administration. If this is to happen, however, Mr. Christopher will need timely backing from Mr. Clinton, whose ear and favor all governments in the Mideast covet.
The Government in Moscow also wants Mr. Clinton's ear. The April summit meeting will come not a moment too soon for Mr. Yeltsin, who is in the midst of a tough fight at home with conservative leaders of the Russian congress over his presidential powers and constitutional reform. If the conservatives get their way, cooperation between Washington and Moscow in the Middle East, the Balkans and Iraq could become next to impossible.
It's not Washington's place to become the arbiter of Russian domestic politics, particularly at a time when Russia is trying, really for the first time in its history, to develop a democratic political culture. But the U.S. has a strong interest in the survival of democracy, reform and foreign policy cooperation. Protecting that interest requires a credible package of economic support.
The responsibility for selling that package to the American public will fall to Mr. Clinton. Many Americans resist the idea of spending money abroad when they are being asked to sacrifice; Mr. Clinton's task is to persuade them that they are getting a bargain compared with the likely costs of a larger military establishment should reform and democratization fail.
Mr. Christopher has proved himself a good listener and a careful interlocutor. His boss is still mainly occupied with matters domestic. With the April meetings now on the agenda, the Secretary must soon claim a larger share of Mr. Clinton's attention.
