HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Lessons of Yugoslavia

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
President Clinton's planned airdrops of food and medicine to besieged villages in eastern Bosnia have been called little more than symbolic. That is true. Planes flying at 10,000 feet to avoid ground fire will not be able to get many relief packages near their intended recipients.
But symbols matter, and this one may matter a good deal. For the airdrops send a message to the Serbian forces besieging those villages that the United States cares -- that it does not like the idea of aggressors trying to starve and shell people out of their homes. 
 The Serbian gangsters who have been waging war on the other peoples of Bosnia for the last year have not had to worry about the disapproval of any outside power. The leaders of Western Europe have clucked -- and made clear they would do nothing. Britain and France have been true to the tradition of Munich. President Bush hemmed and hawed.
The leaders who did nothing to stop the slaughter told us that the situation in the former Yugoslavia was very complicated. Yes it was, and is. But the basic facts of the horror are really quite simple.
First, the Serbs are the aggressors. None of the ethnic groups in the conflict is above reproach. But it is the Serbs who have grabbed pieces of territory in Croatia and Bosnia. It is the Serbs who are shelling Sarajevo and Gorazde and other small towns in eastern Bosnia -- and throttling relief supplies to them.
There was a typical scene this week when U.N. relief trucks headed for Gorazde were stopped at a Serbian checkpoint. Serbian soldiers insisted on checking the contents of each truck carton by carton. The result was a two-day delay in getting food to the 70,000 desperate residents of Gorazde, mostly Muslims.
The purpose of such Serbian tactics is to make the civilians in Gorazde and other towns so hungry, or so frightened by shelling and sniper fire, that they will leave. Then more territory will have been ethnically cleansed, and Serbs can move in.
Second, the Serbian aggression poses dangers far wider than the human disaster in Yugoslavia. The reason is well stated in the current Foreign Affairs in an article by Stephen John Stedman entitled "The New Interventionists." Mr. Stedman is critical of too-easy calls for U.S. intervention abroad on moral grounds. But he puts the Yugoslav situation in a different category, warning of the burden of refugees on Europe and of widening instability.
"Left unchecked," he writes, "Serbian aggression could advance to Kosovo and Macedonia, raising the specter of broader interstate conflagration. The war in the Balkans is a greater danger to international security than civil wars in Somalia, Liberia or Sudan because it may overwhelm Europe's political stability and economic productivity."
Third, the only thing likely to turn the Serbian leaders from their murderous course is outside force or a realistic fear of it. Empty moral disapproval -- the clucking of Prime Minister John Major, President Francois Mitterrand and the rest -- does not impress Slobodan Milosevic.
It would have been easy to stop the Serbs, by a meaningful threat of force, at the beginning of their aggression. When they began shelling the ancient Croatian city of Dubrovnik 16 months ago, the leaders of Western Europe could so easily have said: Stop or we shall intervene. But they lack the courage, and the Serbs got the message. They went on to destroy Vukovar on the other side of Croatia, and then to savage Bosnia.
Now it is much harder. The Serbs indicate that if any outside power tries to keep them from killing and starving Muslim civilians in Bosnia, they will attack the U.N. forces protecting relief efforts.
Even the modest Clinton plan to drop food to the besieged was denounced by the Serbs. A Yugoslav Army statement said: "American interference is becoming increasingly drastic and unbearable."
That is the brute fact of where we are. While Serbian leaders talk of negotiating peace, they wage undiminished war on civilians. And I see no reason to believe they will stop short of their territorial goals unless they think they will be hurt.
President Clinton may well have adopted the airdrop plan as a minimal gesture, hoping to avoid any more serious responsibility. But he will have to be serious, sooner or later, if he hopes to stop Serbian aggression -- and the widening danger to European security.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Struggle For India

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: NEW DELHI

 BODY:
The struggle for India goes on as it has almost without pause for 4,000 years.
Time and again the struggle has changed the history of the world, causing great empires to rise and fall in Asia and Europe. 
 And over the millennia it has touched the lives of billions of people everywhere -- particularly their minds and most deep beliefs.
India is where Hinduism and Buddhism were born and the Sikh religion came to be, where Islam flourished, where Christianity established an Eastern outpost that became part of the growth of the West.
Muslim emperors, and then British generals, came to seize the real crown jewels of India -- trade, labor, markets, control of the passages between East and West. Without India neither Islam nor the British Empire might have grown to great wealth and command.
Then came a new kind of struggle for India. Mahatma Gandhi and Nehru and the Indian freedom movement won independence almost without a shot -- armed with idealism and a talent for hard bargaining.
That began the great adventure. In 1947 India became the only large newly freed nation to reach for economic decency by building a democratic, secular, pluralistic state.
Now that part of the struggle for India is rising in intensity. Its outcome will be felt in the world as surely as were other great events in the struggle for India.
Hindu nationalists are growing in strength. They want to establish Hinduism as the only heritage and destiny of India and bring under a Hindu nationalist umbrella the 110 million Muslims who live among India's 730 million Hindus.
The Hindus' destruction of a Muslim mosque touched off riots around the country and a month later the anti-Muslim pogrom in Bombay.
Yesterday Prime Minister Rao stuffed New Delhi with troops to block a monster rally by a collection of nationalist parties and street gangs.
India knows that although Muslims are victims, this is a struggle between nationalist Hindus and those Hindus who believe that religious nationalism is the opposite of the vision of the 1947 independence movement -- a democratic society in which all religions would flourish but none would dominate.
Mr. Rao's wise decision to enforce a ban on the rally showed Muslims at last that the Government would protect them. But he seems totally unable to arouse the passionate idealism of the independence movement, and does not much try.
In some important part the great adventure endures -- a democracy, flawed but real, is fighting the religious fundamentalism that other nations have embraced.
But the ruling Congress Party, once India's independence movement, is now a back room where politicians haggle for jobs and candidacies.
People also blame corruption for loss of faith -- bribery to get a seat on the train or a seat in Parliament. A good American district attorney would probably arrest the whole Government.
Violence is an everyday political weapon. No self-respecting politician travels without backup cars filled with bodyguards. Often it is hard to find the moral difference between political and police terrorism.
But no, this is not the end of India, as proclaimed by foreigners and bewept by Indian intellectuals every few years. Democracy's strength here is that it is the only practical way for Hindus and Muslims to live together instead of killing each other off.
But the future will be decided by what the Hindu and Muslim democrats in India do to save the democracy they inherited.
In this capital, my home and journalistic post for four years in the Nehru era, the friends of religious and political liberty have not pulled themselves out of the shock of nationalism's rise.
Mostly, they clutch their heads. That is not known to have stopped bigoted nationalism ever. I am told that in other cities, particularly Bombay, the enemies of fanaticism are out working in the streets and I will go see.
The other day, at the home of the Sikh writer Kushwant Singh, I saw something nailed to the door -- a mezuza. And in an Indian Muslim diplomat's home I saw a statue of the Hindu elephant-headed god Ganesh, and a large painting of the Last Supper.
For a country like that, the great adventure can't be all over, it can't be.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Albany Hurts Health Insurance Consumers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You report that health insurers, despite dire predictions, have adjusted to New York State's new rate plan (news article, Feb. 6). However, you soft-pedal the detrimental economic effects of increased regulation. 
 During last year's State Legislature session, elected officials again threw a monkey wrench into the workings of the marketplace by imposing "community rates" on commercial health insurers. Community rate rules essentially require insurers to charge the same for all customers carrying a particular policy -- no matter the risk levels -- adjusting for cost differentials around the state.
Community rate regulation forces lower-risk customers to pay higher premiums to subsidize high-risk customers. Naturally, this distorts the price system and creates the potential for additional losses as more high-risk customers seek to purchase insurance and some low-risk customers can no longer afford to do so.
Increased losses, or their potential, will ultimately hurt all insurance consumers. As many warned last year, various insurers will drop individual and smaller group coverage as the law goes into effect.
Although you note that this development has begun -- with at least nine major insurers eliminating traditional coverage for small-group customers -- you play down the effect. The competitive forces that exert downward pressure on prices and foster incentives to improve services will be curtailed as companies drop out of particular markets.
Under this community rates scenario, higher rates could be a reality for everyone in the long run, but most assuredly for those in low-risk categories. State legislators should undo this competition-limiting initiative before it actually goes into effect on April 1.
 
RAYMOND J. KEATING
Director, New York Citizens
for a Sound Economy
Manorville, L.I., Feb. 10, 1993

An explosion apparently caused by a car bomb in an underground garage shook the World Trade Center in lower Manhattan with the force of a small earthquake, collapsing walls and floors, igniting fires and plunging the city's largest building complex into a maelstrom of smoke, darkness and fearful chaos. TRAPPED INSIDE THE TOWER
Minutes after the explosion, thousands of people in the World Trade Center knew they were in the grip of one of the most dreaded urban nightmares: they were in the city's tallest building and something was very wrong. 1
 
TRAFFIC SNARLS AND SMOKE

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES MORE RUSSIAN AID

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26

 BODY:
President Clinton declared today that having spent trillions of dollars to win the cold war, the United States must summon the will to spend much more than planned in Russia and the other former Soviet republics "to support democracy's success where Communism failed."
Documents sent to Capitol Hill with the President's economic message last week, but little noticed at the time, indicated the President will ask for $700 million in aid next year for the former Soviet republics, nearly doubling the $417 million allotted for this year. Mr. Clinton, who plans to meet with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia on April 4, said "the world will suffer" if Russia's tottering economic reforms collapse. [Excerpts, page 6.]
 
Wants America to Compete
 In a speech at American University consciously evocative of one delivered there 30 years ago by John F. Kennedy, the President endorsed the broad thrust of former President George Bush's trade policies. But at the same time, he sent two signals of change with his call for greater support for Russia and a suggestion that he would demand progress on human rights as the price for continued growth in trade with China. 
 The speech was devoted to international economics and trade and was not a comprehensive presentation of President Clinton's foreign policy views.
He warned that the United States "must compete, not retreat" if its economy is to flourish in an era of burgeoning international trade, but he demanded that American trading partners eliminate barriers to the sale of American products abroad.
Mr. Clinton identified himself neither as a protectionist who "wants to build walls to protect firms from competition," nor as a pure free trader who thinks "government should do nothing in the face of foreign competition, no matter what the dimension and shape of that competition is, no matter what the consequences are in terms of job losses, trade dislocations or crushed incomes." Neither view, he said, "takes on the hard work of creating a trading system that enables us and our trading partners to prosper."
 
'Devilishly Difficult'
 For the industrialized world, Mr. Clinton said, the central, devilishly difficult economic problem is how "to maintain a high-wage, high-growth economy" when "production is mobile and can quickly fly to a place with low wages.""
Mr. Clinton acknowledged that the United States has been slow to reform its own economy, describing his new economic stimulus and deficit-reduction plan as only a first step toward maintaining world economic leadership. A healthier domestic economy "must be the steel of our competitive edge," he said.
"Too many of the chains that have hobbled us in world trade have been made in America," the President told 4,200 students and others in the basketball arena of the 100-year-old university in northwest Washington. His first speech on international economics came on the eve of a meeting in London this weekend of the finance ministers and central bankers of the world's seven largest industrial democracies.
 
July Meeting is a Target
 By the annual Group of Seven summit meeting in Tokyo in July, Mr. Clinton said, he hopes to have his economic program well on the way to Congressional approval. If so, he said, he would be in a much better position to press European and Japanese leaders hard to lower their trade barriers.
Only a few months before his death, President Kennedy went to American University on June 10, 1963, to deliver what became his second-best-known speech, after his Inaugural Address. In the university speech, he appealed for reconciliation with the Soviet Union, or at least its people, arguing that "no government or social system is so evil that its people must be considered as lacking in virtue."
"While defending our own vital interests," he said, in a sentence that became a doctrine, "nuclear powers must avert those confrontations which bring an adversary to a choice of either a humiliating retreat or a nuclear war."
Mr. Clinton was in boyish form at the university today, halting the formal academic procession to shake students' hands and concluding a tribute to the United States with these comments: "We were all born for the information age. This is a jazzy nation -- thank goodness, for my sake -- that created bebop and hip-hop and all those other things."
His visit prompted him to reflect on his own salad days. As a law student at Yale University, Mr. Clinton volunteered as an aide in the unsuccessful 1970 Senatorial campaign of Joseph D. Duffey, who is now American University's president."
Wearing a blue academic gown and the hood of a doctor of laws, bestowed upon him just before he spoke, Mr. Clinton said the world stood now at the third great turning point of the century. After World War I, he said, the wrong path was taken, with the democracies turning inward, but after World War II, that mistake was avoided with the creation of international institutions.
"Overarching everything else" in the post-cold-war world, the President argued, is trade: an "amorphous but profound challenge in the way humankind conducts its commerce."
On China, the President made no direct mention of that country's most- favored-nation status, which many critics of the Beijing Government consider unjustified in light of China's human rights record. But he issued an only slightly veiled warning.
"We are now making a major contribution to the astonishing revitalization of the Chinese economy, now growing at 10 percent a year, with the United States buying a huge percentage of those imports," he said. "And I say that I want to continue that partnership, but I also think we have a right to expect progress in human rights and democracy as we support that progress."

HEADLINE: Robert Triffin, 81, an Economist Who Backed Monetary Stability

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Robert Triffin, the Belgian-born Yale economist who championed European unity for much of his life and correctly foresaw the demise of the Bretton Woods international monetary system, died on Tuesday in Ostend, Belgium. He was 81.
He suffered from emphysema, his son Nicholas said. 
 For several decades, Professor Triffin was at the center of the debate over the international monetary system.
An ardent internationalist, he stepped into the limelight when he warned in the late 1950's that the Bretton Woods system was inherently unstable and would eventually unravel. Under the system, any country could present the United States Treasury with dollars and receive gold at $35 an ounce. When the United States ran balance-of-payments deficits, other countries would pile up more and more dollars, United States gold reserves would dwindle and a liquidity crisis would ensue.
 
Professor Proved Right
 History proved Professor Triffin right, but he mourned the demise of the system of fixed exchange rates of which he was a lifelong champion.
"He was unhappy with the way the international monetary system evolved when he saw instability of floating exchange rates and the rise of inflation," said Michael Mussa, chief economist at the International Monetary Fund.
Professor Triffin wrote a large number of books and articles. His dissertation, Monopolistic Competition and General Equilibrium Theory, proved to be a surprisingly modern approach to international trade that has recently generated interest among the current generation of international economists.
"He was also an activist," said James Tobin, his colleague at Yale and a Nobel laureate.
Professor Triffin was, for example, the architect of European currency convertibility after World War II and helped end the wartime system of bilateral trade and exchange controls, paving the way for expanded trade. He was also assisted in the formation of the Common Market. More recently, he was a strong supporter of a European central bank.
"He believed that movements of goods, money and capital were the road to peace and prosperity," Professor Tobin said.
When the King of Belgium made him a baron in 1989, Professor Triffin chose as his motto a paraphrase of Belgium's national motto, transposing "Unity makes strength" into "Unity makes peace."
 
Retired From Yale in 1977
 Professor Triffin won several high honors in economics including the San Paolo Prize for Economics in 1987 and the Frank E. Seidman Distinguished Award in Political Economy in 1989.
Professor Triffin, who was born in Flobecq, Belgium, in 1911, studied economics at the Catholic University at Louvain, where he had been a guest lecturer since his retirement from Yale in 1977, and at Harvard University. He decided to stay in the United States after he completed his graduate studies and became an American citizen in 1942.
A memorial service is scheduled for March 23 in Louvain-La-Neuve, Belgium. In addition to his son Nicholas, he is survived by his wife, Lois, and two other sons, Kerry and Eric.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert Triffin (NYT, 1968)

HEADLINE: President's Speech: Prosperity Aids Freedom

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's speech today at American University:
When I was growing up, business was mostly a local affair. Most farms and firms were owned locally, they borrowed locally, they hired locally, they shipped most of their products to neighboring communities or states within the United States. It was the same for the country as a whole. By and large, we had a domestic economy. 
 But now we are woven inextricably into the fabric of a global economy.

 	 	 		. . .	 	What all this means is that the best investment we can make today is in the one resource firmly rooted in our own borders, that is in the education, the skills, the reasoning capacity and the creativity of our own people.
For all the adventure and opportunity in this global economy, an American cannot approach it without mixed feelings. We still sometimes wish wistfully that everything we really want, particularly those things that produce good wages, could be made in America.
We recall simpler times when one product line would be made to endure and last for years. We're angry when we see jobs and factories moving overseas or across the borders or depressing wages here at home when we think there is nothing we can do about it. We worry about our own prosperity being so dependent on events and forces beyond our shores.
Could it be that the world's most powerful nation has also given up a significant measure of its sovereignty in the quest to lift the fortunes of people throughout the world? It is ironic and even painful that the global village we have worked so hard to create has done so much to be the source of higher unemployment and lower wages for some of our people.
 
A Failure to Act
 But that is no wonder. For years our leaders have failed to take the steps that would harness the global economy to the benefit of all of our people: steps such as investing in our people and their skills, enforcing our trade laws, helping communities hurt by change. In short, putting the American people first, without withdrawing from the world and people beyond our borders.
The truth of our age is this, and must be this: Open and competitive commerce will enrich us as a nation. It spurs us to innovate. It forces us to compete. It connects us with new customers. It promotes global growth without which no rich country can hope to grow wealthier.
It enables our producers, who are themselves consumers of services and raw materials, to prosper. And so, I say to you, in the face of all the pressures to do the reverse, we must compete, not retreat.
Our exports are especially important to us. As bad as the recent recession was, it would have gone on for twice as long had it not been for what we were able to sell to other nations.
Every billion dollars of our exports creates nearly 20,000 jobs here, and we now have over 7 million export-related jobs in America. They tend to involve better work and better pay. Most are in manufacturing. And, on average, they pay almost $3,500 more per year than the average American job. They are exactly the kind of jobs we need for a new generation of Americans.
American jobs and prosperity are reason enough for us to be working at mastering the essentials of the global economy, but far more is at stake. For this new fabric of commerce will also shape global prosperity or the lack of it, and with it, the prospects of people around the world for democracy, freedom, and peace.
We must remember that even with all our problems today, the United States is still the world's strongest engine of growth and progress. We remain the world's largest producer and its largest and most open market.
Other nations such as Germany and Japan are moving rapidly. They have done better than we have in certain areas. We should respect them for it and, where appropriate, we should learn from that. But we must also say to them you too must act as engines of global prosperity.
 
Five Steps
 I believe there are five steps we can and must take to set a new direction at home and to help create a new direction for the world.
First, we simply have to get our own economic house in order. I have outlined a new national economic strategy that will give America the new direction we require to meet our challenges. It seeks to do what no generation of Americans has ever been called upon to do before: to increase investment in our productive future and to reduce our deficit at the same time.
We must do both. A plan that only plays down the deficit without investing in those things that make us more productive will not make us stronger. A plan that only invests more money without bringing down the deficit will weaken the fabric of our overall economy, such that even educated and productive people cannot succeed in it.
Second, it is time for us to make trade a priority element of American security. . . . We will continue to welcome foreign products and services into our markets, but insist that our products and services be able to enter theirs on equal terms.
We will welcome foreign investment in our businesses knowing that with it come new ideas as well as capital, new technologies, new management techniques, and new opportunities for us to learn from one another and grow. But as we welcome that investment, we insist that our investors should be equally welcome in other countries.
We welcome the subsidiaries of foreign companies on our soil. We appreciate the jobs they create and the products and services they bring, but we do insist simply that they pay the same taxes on the same income that our companies do for doing the same business.
 
A Leadership Mandate
 Third, it is time for us to do our best to exercise leadership among the major financial powers to improve our coordination on behalf of global economic growth.
At a time when capital is mobile and highly fungible, we simply cannot afford to work at cross purposes with the other major industrial democracies. Our major partners must work harder and more closely with us to reduce interest rates, stimulate investment, reduce structural barriers to trade, and to restore robust global growth.
And we must look anew at institutions we use to chart our way in the global economy and ask whether they are serving our interests in this new world or whether we need to modify them or create others.
 
Growing Market
 Fourthly, we need to promote the steady expansion of growth in the developing world, not only because it's in our interests, but because it will help them as well.
These nations are a rapidly expanding market for our products. Some 3 million American jobs flow from exports to the developing world.
Indeed, because of unilateral actions taken by Mexico over the last few years, the volume of our trade has increased dramatically and our trade deficit has disappeared.
Our ability to protect the global environment and our ability to combat the flow of illegal narcotics also rests in large measure on the relationships we develop commercially with the developing world.
There is a great deal that we can do to open the flow of goods and services. Our aid policies must do more to address population pressures, to support environmentally responsible sustainable development, to promote more accountable governance, and to foster a fair distribution of the fruits of growth among an increasingly restive world population, where over 1 billion people still exist on barely a dollar a day. These efforts will reap us dividends of trade, of friendship and peace.
 
Acute Perils
 The final step we must take, my fellow Americans, is toward the success of democracy in Russia and in the world's other new democracies. The perils facing Russia and other former Soviet republics are especially acute, and especially important to our future, for the reductions in our defense spending that are an important part of our economic program over the long run here at home are only tenable as long as Russia and the other nuclear republics pose a diminishing threat to our security and to the security of our allies and the democracies throughout the world. . . .
If we are willing to spend trillions of dollars to insure communism's defeat in the cold war, surely we should be willing to invest a tiny fraction of that to support democracy's success where communism failed.
To be sure, the former Soviet republics and especially Russia must be willing to assume most of the hard work and high cost of the reconstruction process. . . .
These five steps constitute an agenda for American action in a global economy. As such, they constitute an agenda for our own prosperity as well.
Some may wish we could pursue our own domestic effort, strictly through domestic policies, as we have understood them in the past. But in this global economy there is no such thing as a purely domestic policy.

HEADLINE: Fed Chief Sways to Clinton's New Economic Tune

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26

 BODY:
After two staid decades among the gray suits of Washington and Wall Street, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, is suddenly popping up in the oddest places.
First, there he was grinning next to Bill Clinton at an Oval Office "photo op" shortly after the new President took office. Then there was the night recently when he found himself wedged uneasily between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Tipper Gore as President Clinton introduced his economic package before a joint session of Congress. 
 And finally, in three marathon appearances before Congress, while almost all of his fellow conservatives were heaping scorn on Mr. Clinton's plan, Mr. Greenspan lavished praise upon it, something he had declined to do for President George Bush's economic policies.
 It is obvious why the Clintons want to court Mr. Greenspan. The Clinton plan will, of course, face easier going in Congress if a respected conservative like Mr. Greenspan gives it a thumbs-up. In addition, his immense influence over short-term interest rates could help make or break the President's proposals.
But why, everyone in Washington seems to be asking, has this Republican stalwart suddenly joined hands with Bill and Hillary Clinton? Why, enraged Republicans demand, is Mr. Greenspan acting nicer to Mr. Clinton than he did to Mr. Bush, who reappointed him a year ago to a second four-year term as chairman?
Certainly, Mr. Greenspan can afford to be more accommodating to politicians than he could have been a year or two ago, because inflation has fallen and there are no signs that it will come back soon. In addition, Mr. Greenspan has a zealot's interest in reducing the budget deficit, and that is Mr. Clinton's goal as well.
But that does not entirely explain why Mr. Greenspan seems to be going along with the new President so enthusiastically. And some Fed watchers say the answer can be found in politics.
 They say it may have much to do with Mr. Greenspan's fears about losing some of the central bank's treasured independence -- that by staying visibly close to the new President, Mr. Greenspan could thwart an attempt by some Senators, led by Paul S. Sarbanes, the Maryland Democrat who is his primary Congressional tormentor, to take away some of the Fed's independence.
Whatever the reason, former Bush Administration officials and other Republicans hardly bother to disguise their resentment toward Mr. Greenspan, who held numerous posts during the Nixon, Ford, Reagan and Bush Administrations. Bush Administration alumni bitterly contrast his warm words for the Clinton plan with the way he spurned their pleas to cut interest rates faster to lift the economy out of recession. The main reason for Mr. Bush's defeat, some Bush aides say, was the Fed's foot-dragging on rate cuts.
Mr. Greenspan "has certainly created the appearance of a warm embrace of President Clinton," said John E. Robson, who was Deputy Treasury Secretary under President Bush. "Obviously one would like to feel, as the Administration that reappointed him, that we were warmly embraced, too. But we had our disagreements with him."
 Mr. Greenspan has told his associates that the reason he sat next to the First Lady in Congress was simple: she invited him. He felt it would have been churlish not to accept. "Hillary made him an offer he couldn't refuse," one Fed official said.
The arrangement was a public relations coup. Although Mr. Greenspan appeared about as comfortable as, say, a mouse caught between two cats, his appearance in the seat of honor seemed to signal that this guardian of America's fiscal rectitude had signed onto Mr. Clinton's deficit-reduction package.
Some of Mr. Greenspan's conservative friends were dismayed that he did not give Hillary an excuse, such as that he had to go bowling that Wednesday night. And they were shocked two days later when he voiced support for Mr. Clinton's economic package in an appearance before the Senate Banking Committee.
 
 
A Warm Response, Relatively

The Fed chairman called the plan "serious" and "credible" and hailed it for suggesting specific, line-by-line deficit-cutting measures, rather than the lofty, vague -- and empty -- deficit-cutting oratory of past proposals. From a man who normally shows all the exuberance of Uriah Heep, that sounded like a ringing endorsement. "The President is to be commended for placing on the table a serious proposal that is activating debate" on the deficit, Mr. Greenspan intoned. "Unless addressed, the deficit will increasingly threaten the stability of our economic system."
Many conservatives wondered aloud why Mr. Greenspan -- whose association with Ayn Rand, the hard-line free-market philosopher gave him an aversion to taxes and regulation -- would praise a deficit-cutting plan that relied more on tax increases than on spending cuts. All week, conservatives reminded him of their almost religious belief that increasing taxes would not cut the deficit because Congressional pork-barrelers will merely use the new revenues as an excuse to spend more.
"If what he means was that this package is going to reduce the deficit, then he has definitely flipped out," said Paul Craig Roberts, a Treasury official in the Reagan Administration.
In his 10 hours of Congressional testimony in the last week, two clear explanations emerged of why Mr. Greenspan went to bat for the President's plan -- even though he did not endorse every detail.
 
 
The Only Game in Town
 First, Mr. Greenspan, a devotee of deficit reduction, believes the new President stuck his neck out in presenting a plan to cut the deficit, and the least he could do was provide some support.
Second, although Mr. Greenspan would undoubtedly have written a vastly different deficit-cutting plan himself, focusing more on spending cuts, he felt compelled to praise the Clinton plan because there is no other vehicle in sight to cut the deficit.
Never before, his testimony makes clear, has he felt such urgency about the Federal deficit. The common view is that the deficit will dip for a few years and then explode to more than $600 billion at the end of the decade if nothing is done.
After testifying repeatedly in public this past week, Mr. Greenspan declined to sit down for an interview.
But anyone who talks to him at length knows that he sees himself -- at least in part -- as shepherd of the nation's bond markets, in which corporations and governments raise money by selling interest-paying bonds. In his view, the budget deficit is the biggest threat to his flock because it can fuel inflation, which erodes the value of bonds.
 But in Washington, where every action brings 100 skeptical reactions, many Fed watchers thought the decision to jump to Mr. Clinton's aid might have been motivated more by politics than economics.
"There is one reason why he praised the President's plan, and it is spelled S-A-R-B-A-N-E-S," said Prof. Allan H. Meltzer, an economist at Carnegie Mellon University.
By that, Mr. Meltzer meant Senator Sarbanes, the vice chairman of the Joint Economic Committee and a powerful voice on the Banking Committee. Convinced that the Greenspan Fed has done too little to promote growth, Mr. Sarbanes is pushing legislation that would reduce what Mr. Greenspan most cherishes: the independence of the Federal Reserve. Mr. Greenspan would not want to be remembered as someone who presided over the central bank when Congress clipped its wings.
Mr. Greenspan has told some Fed colleagues that he fears that the Sarbanes bill would have a better chance of passing under Mr. Clinton than under President Bush. Inside the Fed, one view is that Mr. Greenspan praised the Clinton plan because he feared that if he wasn't nice to the President, then Mr. Clinton would back the Sarbanes proposal.
"He ought to be nice to the Clinton plan because it is the first serious effort to address a lot of these problems since he became chairman," Mr. Sarbanes said in an interview.
 Some people who have spoken to Mr. Greenspan say that in private he is skeptical that Mr. Clinton's plan will cut the deficit by $140 billion in 1997, as promised.
Another view inside the Fed is that Mr. Greenspan has bent over backward to praise the Clinton plan to buy some peace. After taking a beating during the Bush Administration, Mr. Greenspan knows there will be battles ahead with Mr. Clinton, and his recent actions are undoubtedly helping him to build good will.
"He is not looking to pick a fight with the new Administration," said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist with Bear, Stearns and an economist in the Reagan Administration. "He knows that the nanosecond the Fed raises interest rates, he's going to have a major fight on his hands."

They were flanked by John Sculley, left, of Apple Computer, and Albert Gore 3d. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Last Quarter's Growth Revised to Robust 4.8%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26

 BODY:
The economy expanded at a robust pace of 4.8 percent in the final three months of 1992, the best quarterly performance in five years, the Commerce Department reported today.
The revised estimate of gross domestic product -- the total output of goods and services within American borders -- was a full percentage point higher than the initial estimate published a month ago. 
 The growth rate for the full year was 2.1 percent, compared with a 1.2 percent contraction in 1991, which included the final three months of a seven-month recession that began in July 1990.
The strong fourth-quarter showing was seen by economists as conclusive evidence of an economic surge during the second half of 1992, when the economy grew at a 4.1 percent annual rate, up from 2.2 percent for the first half.
But because the jump in output was mainly a result of greater efficiency, which implied little employment growth, it was scant help to the re-election campaigns of President George Bush and fellow Republicans, who were unable to persuade voters that the economy was sufficiently on the mend.
Even now, analysts said, it is unlikely that President Clinton will be dissuaded from pursuing his plan for modest stimulus. They note that Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has been cautioning for the last week or so against complacency.
Figures issued today showed that consumer confidence fell back a bit in February while the industrial sector of the economy, as represented by the behavior of Chicago-area purchasing managers, remained buoyant.
The upward revision in G.D.P., which was in line with what economists had come to expect, was powered by improved gains in consumer spending and exports, and a smaller shrinkage in business inventories.
The holiday spending spree pushed consumer spending up at a 4.8 percent pace, instead of the 4.3 percent estimated last month, while exports climbed at a 9.8 percent rate instead of 3.7 percent. Inventories fell by $2.7 billion less than first reported by the department.
Still, economists say the robust economic pace of late 1992 is probably already on the wane.
"It looks to me that consumer spending has gotten ahead of personal income," said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities. He allowed that the current high rate of home-mortgage refinancing would help sustain consumer spending, but said this would not be enough to fully offset sluggish jobs and earnings growth and some ebbing of consumer confidence.
Indeed, data from the University of Michigan today showed that the address by President Clinton on Feb. 17 outlining his economic plan apparently fanned consumer anxiety about the economy's prospects.
The university's index of consumer sentiment, which measures optimism and pessimism about the economy, fell to 86.6 in February from 89.3 last month, with virtually all the decline recorded after the speech. A preliminary calculation of the index based on responses during the first half of the month had showed that confidence had simply leveled off after sharp gains.
Another poll, a weekly survey published Thursday by ABC and Money magazine, showed that consumers gave the President's performance high marks but turned fearful about their own financial situations. Still another survey, one conducted by the Conference Board before the Clinton speech, showed a sharp drop in confidence.
Yet another survey, by Sindlinger & Company, found that consumer confidence rose 1.5 percent in the week after the Clinton speech but that there was a sharp divergence between those who owned stock and those who did not.
For stockholders, confidence tumbled to the lowest level in the 39 years of the firm's daily polling but this was more than offset by a smaller rise among the more numerous group of nonstockholders.
At Dillard Department Stores Inc., a regional chain based in Little Rock, Ark., a spokesman said business had fallen off since last week's speech. "We are not sure whether it was the speech or the weather," she said.
The Michigan results showed that consumers remained fairly upbeat about current conditions -- the reading of 96 was practically unchanged -- but dubious about conditions six months from now. The expectations component of the index, part of the Government's principal gauge for forecasting the economy, slipped to 80.6, from 83.4 in January.
 
Throttling-Down Seen
 David C. Munro, chief economist for High Frequency Economics, a New York adviser, was one of numerous economists who thought the economy had already begun to throttle down from its rapid fourth-quarter pace.
"I think we're probably doing 3 percent now," he said, referring to current G.D.P. growth. He added that the output pace could dip to 2 percent during the spring before edging up again.
"It is almost wholly a productivity advance," Mr. Munro said, a development that bodes well for the nation's standard of living in the long run but that suggests limited consumer buying power in the short run.
At a fourth-quarter pace of $3.36 trillion, personal spending accounted for 67.3 percent of G.D.P., which totaled $4.99 trillion expressed in constant 1987 dollars.
Today's G.D.P. also showed that current-dollar G.D.P., unadjusted for inflation, rose at a 7.1 percent pace in the fourth quarter, compared with a 5.7 percent estimate a month ago. The fixed-weighted price index for gross domestic purchases remained at 2.8 percent.
The savings rate -- personal savings as a percentage of disposable personal income -- was calculated at 4.5 percent, the same as in January.
The 4.8 percent rate of advance in G.D.P. was the fastest since a 5.9 percent burst in the fourth quarter of 1987. The 3.8 percent gain reported a month ago had been the fastest since the fourth quarter of 1988, the last full quarter of the Reagan Administration.
Following are data included in the gross domestic product for the fourth quarter of 1992. All dollar amounts are in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates.

HEADLINE: EXPLOSION AT THE TWIN TOWERS: Car Bombs;
A Tool of Foreign Terror, Little Known in U.S.

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26

 BODY:
The phenomenon is well known in Belfast, Lima, Bogota and Beirut, but if the explosion that rocked the World Trade Center today was indeed caused by a car bombing, as the F.B.I. believes, it would be the largest such attack in American history, experts said.
Not since 1975, when 11 people were killed at La Guardia Airport, has anyone used a bomb, delivered in any fashion, to kill so many civilians in the United States. It is unknown whether a terrorist group was responsible for the explosion today. 
 "This is the largest-scale bombing on U.S. soil in modern history" in terms of fatalities and material damage, said Brian Jenkins, a security consultant with Kroll & Associates who is one of the nation's leading private experts on terrorism.
If the American setting is novel, however, the apparent use of a vehicle as a platform for the bomb represents only the latest use of what for more than four decades has been a favorite tool for terrorists.
 
How to Pack a Big Punch
 Ever since the Irish Republican Army first used the car bomb in 1971, Mr. Jenkins and other experts said, terrorist groups have found no better way to bring so much explosive power so close to a target.
In the last several weeks alone, car bombs have exploded repeatedly on the streets of cities in Colombia and on the streets of London. If the tactic until now has been barely known in the United States, experts said, it is a reflection only of what has until now been Americans' relative immunity from terrorism on their own shores.
"Think of how simple it is," said Bruce Hoffman, a terrorism specialist with the Rand Corporation. "Think how many people pull into a garage or park on a street, lock their car and then walk away."
Assassins in the United States have frequently planted bombs in a target's vehicle, including that of the former Foreign Minister Orlando Letelier of Chile who, along with an aide, was killed in a 1976 attack. But Mr. Hoffman and others said the only previous known use of a car bomb in an indiscriminate attack on civilians in the United States occurred in 1973, as part of an attack by Puerto Rican nationalists on five New York banks.
What until now were the two largest terrorist bombings in American history were staged without the help of a car. The most deadly, an explosion in a La Guardia airport terminal, left 11 people dead in 1975. No one claimed responsibility in the attack.
The same year, four people were killed and 65 wounded in the bombing by Puerto Rican separatists of the historic Fraunces Tavern in Lower Manhattan. Even the most recent close call, the arrest in 1988 of a suspected Japanese Red Army member carrying explosives on the New Jersey Turnpike, was believed to have thwarted, not a car bombing, but a more conventional attack.
But as the 1983 assault on a United States Marine barracks in Beirut that killed 241 suggests, the addition of a vehicle to any bombing plot can multiply its destructive power.
Experts say terrorists were initially attracted to car bombs because they could haul heavy loads. Without access to sophisticated explosives, Irish Republican Army terrorists found that an car could carry enough nitrate fertilizer mixed with diesel fuel to create a blast that no hand-delivered explosive could match.
But the experts say the development of potent plastic explosives has added to the threat posed by terrorists, permitting them to pack far more destructive power into a much smaller space. While rarely known to have been used in a car bomb, so-called plastique explosives can explode at a velocity of 23,000 feet per second, many times the rate of ordinary dynamine.
At the same time, terrorists have learned that the seemingly benign shell of a vehicle can allow them to conceal explosives in particularly effective settings. If the aim of whoever planned today's bombing was to create maximum impact, the experts say, the apparent use of the World Trade Center parking garage for a platform is a reminder of the deadly access a vehicle can bring.
For one thing, they said, the enclosed structure of a garage would multiply any explosive's impact, preventing its energy from escaping except at the weakest point, either the walls or the ceiling. Mr. Jenkins of Kroll & Associates said the underground structure would guarantee perhaps more than any other setting that "the explosive force would be more greatly exaggerated."
Perhaps more important, the vehicular access provided to the World Trade Center complex may have provided an opportunity for what other experts said they believed was an attack staged for its impact upon a highly visible American target.
"A car bomb in a street in New York doubtlessly would have killed more people," said Mr. Hoffman of the Rand Corporation, who is the author of several surveys of terrorism in the United States. "But the World Trade Center is a symbol of Wall Street and the Manhattan skyline and the United States itself, and I think that is very important.
"Putting a bomb in a car is not sophisticated," he said. "What's sophisticated about this operation, I would argue, is the planning and calculations that went into it to extract the maximum publicity possible."
After the blast, Federal and local authorities in Washington tightened security around Government buildings and other possible targets in what they described as a precaution against a further attacks. Among Federal officials specializing in explosives, the explosion elicited a sense of awe.
"This is a tremendous blast doing huge amounts of structural damage to steel and concrete," said Jack Killorin, a spokesman in Washington for the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. "I can't overstate this: What went down there was big."
 
 
 
AT A GLANCE -- New York as Victim: Other Bombings
Previous terrorist bomb explosions in New York City
 
Jan. 24, 1974: Four people were killed and 55 injured in a bombing at Fraunces Tavern. In lower Manhattan, the site where George Washington bid farewell to his officers. A Puerto Rican independence group, knows as the Armed Forces of National Liberation or F.A.L.N. claimed responsibility.
 
Dec. 29, 1975: Eleven people were killed and 75 hurt when a bomb that had been placed in a coin-operated locker exploded at the TWA terminal at LaGuardia Airport
 
Aug. 3, 1977: One person was killed in a bombing at the Mobil Oil building, 150 East 42nd Street. The F.A.L.N. claimed responsibility.
 
PUB-DATE: May 16, 1981:
 
Dec. 31, 1982: Three police officers were gravely injured in bombings in Manhattan and Brooklyn. The F.A.L.N. took responsibility.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The economy expanded at the robust pace of 4.8 percent in the final three months of 1992, the best quarterly performance in five years. Economists saw the strong fourth-quarter showing for gross domestic product as evidence of an economic surge. But the Administration still appears to be planning a stimulus. [Page 35.] 
 Alan Greenspan is suddenly popping up in the oddest places after two staid decades among the gray suits of Washington and Wall Street. Some think the Federal Reserve chairman is courting Presidential alliances to preserve the Fed's independence from intrusion by the Senate. [35.]
 
International
President Clinton, in a speech devoted to international economics and trade, said the United States must spend more than planned to bolster the economies of Russia and the other former Soviet republics. He endorsed George Bush's trade policies and demanded that foreign markets be opened further to American products. [1.]
The President's strong endorsement of free trade is an attempt to reconcile the need for open international markets with his commitment to help industries at home. News Analysis. [6.]
 
Companies
General Electric will cut its aircraft-engine work force by more than 10 percent because of slow aircraft orders. Most of the cuts will come at the units headquarters near Cincinnati. [35.]
A meeting of personal-computer executives reveals that the leaders of the $70 billion-a-year industry are a close-knit tribe of 30- to 40-year-old Californians who grew up together. [35.]
Leslie Fay announced preliminary results of an audit of accounting irregularities. The dress company lost $13.7 million in 1992 and revised 1991 earnings to $17 million from $29 million. [37.]
First Union agreed to buy the largest remaining subsidiary of First American Bankshares, the company embroiled in the Bank of Credit and Commerce International scandal. [37.]
Salomon's Phibro unit said the White Nights petroleum joint venture in Siberia it operates faces bankruptcy unless it settles a dispute with Russia over oil export taxes. [37.]
The Baltimore-area home of Eli S. Jacobs, the financially troubled businessman and owner of the Baltimore Orioles baseball team, was sold at a court-ordered auction. [37.]
 
Markets
Stocks completed a week of recovery with modest gains but some continuing queasiness. The Dow rose 5.67 points, to 3,370.81, ending the week with a gain of 48.63 points. [36.]
Bond prices were mostly lower in light trading after an explosion at the World Trade Center curtailed activity. The 30-year Treasury bond yield rose to 6.90 percent. [44.]
Grains and soybeans rose and energy futures declined in trading shortened by an explosion at the World Trade Center. [46.]
The dollar firmed against most major currencies, especially the Japanese yen. Gold prices eased. [46.]
 
Your Money
The President's proposed energy tax will have a varied impact on the budgets of three types of families: Manhattan apartment dwellers, suburban householders and rural residents. [33.]
Fine-tuning an investment portfolio to minimize the bite of new taxes is advised, but moving money around can be costly and can often offset the tax-savings of new investments. [33.]
Commemorative medals have so little bullion content that they can never recoup their high sales prices. [33.]
Local bar associations are expanding their activities to provide referral services to find lawyers. [34.]
A Long Island saleswoman made a hefty profit by self-publishing her book on massage. [34.]

HEADLINE: Dow Up 5.67, to 3,370.81; Gain for Week Is 48.63

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Stocks completed a week of recovery yesterday with modest gains but some continuing queasiness. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 5.67 points, to 3,370.81, ending the week with a gain of 48.63 points, or almost 1.5 percent.
This left the Dow only about 20 points below where it stood two weeks ago, just before the market's worst one-day plunge in 15 months as details of the Clinton budget proposals emerged.
 
Helped by Bond Rally
 The week's rally in the bond market helped stocks, as did a calmer look at the Clinton plan. "People are beginning to analyze the total package in a somewhat less emotional manner," said Stefan D. Abrams, a portfolio manager at the Trust Company of the West. "They realize that this nation is not going to commit economic suicide." 
 Big Board gainers have consistently outnumbered losers recently, he pointed out, as they did yesterday by 1,151 to 757. Trading volume was relatively light, as some investment firms were forced to curtail their operations after the explosion at the World Trade Center in lower Manhattan.
A look at the Nasdaq market and many individual stocks continued to give some analysts pause. The Nasdaq Composite index rose 3.70, to 670.77 yesterday, up 7.16 points, or slightly more than 1 percent for the week. Despite shooting up so rapidly last fall, the Nasdaq index still has a net loss this year.
 
'There Were Disasters'
 Investors' reaction to disappointments last week was especially severe -- most of all for such biotechnology stocks as Amgen and Synergen, but also for issues that are usually less volatile. "Despite the advance today and weekly, there were disasters," said Harrison Roth, a senior options strategist at Cowen & Company. "Every day a different stock or stock group gets taken out and shot."
Yesterday, the makers of disk drives, or memory devices for personal computers, were on the firing line after Conner Peripherals predicted lower first-quarter earnings, citing increased competition. Conner fell 1 1/2, or 8.7 percent, to 16 3/4, in very heavy trading. Among other disk drive makers, Seagate Technology dropped a point, to 15 5/8; Maxtor 3/8, to 7 3/4; Quantum 1 5/8, to 15, and Western Digital 5/8, to 8 1/8.
The selloff appeared to harm the personal computer makers as well, as Compaq Computer fell 1 5/8, to 45 1/4.
One of the Big Board's biggest losers was Rollins Environmental Services, off a full point, or 11.2 percent, to 7 7/8, also on a dark earnings forecast.
Stocks proved about as capable of responding to good news, however. LDDS Communications, which provides long- distance telephone service, jumped 3 1/4, to 35 1/4, on news of a three-way merger.
The markets showed little apparent response yesterday to a full percentage point upward revision in the fourth-quarter economic growth. Railroads and airlines, among the stocks most sensitive to the economy, in fact fell steeply. With a 3 3/8-point drop in CSX to 70 1/8, the Dow Jones transportation average fell 14.10, nearly 1 percent, to 1,518.10.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Hard-Pressed Orioles Owner Sells His Home at a Loss

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
The 11-room Baltimore-area home of Eli S. Jacobs, the financially troubled businessman and owner of the Baltimore Orioles baseball team, was sold at a court-ordered auction yesterday.
The 4,000-square-foot home, on six acres in Owings Mills, Md., fetched $1.44 million from an unidentified buyer as the press covered the sale. 
 Mr. Jacobs, who heads E. S. Jacobs & Company, an investment concern, had no comment, a spokesman said.
The sale of the house, for $800,000 less than Mr. Jacobs paid for it in 1990, is tangible evidence of the venture capitalist's tumble into debt in a variety of his enterprises.
 
Team Likely to Be Sold
 The sale is also a likely precursor to his sale of the Orioles to a group led by William DeWitt Jr., a Cincinnati businessman, for an estimated $140 million.
Mr. Jacobs is a secretive businessman who jumped into the leveraged-buyout binge of the mid-1980's, taking stakes in the Memorex Corporation and merging it with Telex as the Memorex Telex Corporation, and leading a leveraged buyout of Triangle Pacific, among other deals.
But with some of his deals going sour, Mr. Jacobs has been accused of defaulting on more than $40 million in loans and other commitments.
As his diverse and private business empire has fallen, Mr. Jacobs's most valuable asset has been the Orioles. Its value has soared since the opening last season of Oriole Park at Camden Yards, which drew 3.6 million fans.
 
An Asset, Not a Passion
 Mr. Jacobs may be able to erase most or all of his debts with the sale of the Orioles, which some baseball executives say he treated more like an asset to appreciate in value and sell than as an object of his sporting or civic passion.
"The lesson of Eli Jacobs is, wasn't he damned lucky to buy a baseball franchise," said Jack Sands, a player agent and author of the new book "Coming Apart at the Seams."
When the Orioles were sold in 1988 for $70 million by the estate of Edward Bennett Williams, the legendary defense lawyer, Mr. Jacobs took an 87 percent stake. His minority partners are the lawyer R. Sargent Shriver and Lawrence Lucchino, a former Williams protege who is the president of the profitable team.
If the DeWitt group buys the Orioles for $140 million, it may be a bargain. If Mr. Jacobs were not financially pressed the team could fetch probably $200 million, thanks to the cash generated at Camden Yards.
 
No Longer Hot Properties
 "His profits are probably $35 million to $40 million, so it being worth $200 million isn't out of whack," said Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College and the author of "Baseball and Billions."
Baseball teams are no longer red-hot properties because of skyrocketing salaries, uncertainty over future costs, the absence of a commissioner, and an expected fall in television rights fees after this season. Mr. Zimbalist said Mr. DeWitt might be looking for a bargain in a troubled market.
Baseball has monitored Mr. Jacobs's financial problems, but top officials like Deputy Commissioner Steven Greenberg declined comment.

HEADLINE: With Clinton Visit Due, Program at Rutgers Is Spotlighted

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 26

 BODY:
When Luis Guardardo heard President Clinton's idea to make money available for students who serve their communities after graduation, he was immediately sold.
The 20-year-old sociology major at Rutgers University already makes community service part of his life. He tutors elementary-school students in an after-school program, takes courses in civic education and lives in the Community Service House, a residence for 40 students committed to doing volunteer work. 
 After graduation, Mr. Guardardo said, he hopes to return to his hometown, Union City, N.J., and teach for a few years before going to law school. "I think a lot of people have a genuine urge to give," he said, "but don't have the resources."
 
President Schedules a Visit
 Mr. Guardardo is one of close to 200 students enrolled in Rutgers University's Civic Education and Community Service Program, the most extensive undergraduate program in the country that combines volunteer work in the curriculum as an education in citizenship. He plans to to be there on Monday, when Mr. Clinton is scheduled to give a major policy address on national service at Rutgers' Lewis Brown Athletic Center in Piscataway.
Rutgers officials say they haven't been told exactly why the President decided to come here, but they presume their program's success is probably the reason.
Practical politics may also have played a role. "I dare say the fact that we have a Democratic Governor who is up for re-election may have something to do with it," said Dr. Benjamin R. Barber, director of the Walt Whitman Center for the Culture and Politics of Democracy, which coordinates the program.
No one at Rutgers, he added, has been told what the President is planning to say.
"All we know," Dr. Barber said, "is that he is calling it his most important address on the subject of national service. We're thrilled to be the backdrop for that."
The President has suggested that his national-service program would allow students to borrow money from the government to attend college. They could repay the loan in cash or by serving the community in such jobs as teachers, police officers or health-care and social workers.
The Civic Education and Community Service Program, in its fourth year, was the brainchild of the university's late president, Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, who saw it as a way to respond to what he saw as growing racism, sexism and alienation on campus, Dr. Barber said. Since it was started, 800 students have contributed 60,000 hours tutoring youths, teaching adults to read and working in AIDS programs.
Students in the program usually volunteer four to five hours a week of their time, working in teams with other students. They earn regular course credit, plus an extra academic credit for volunteer service. Class seminars discuss civic responsibility and the greater ramifications of what they see in their volunteer work.
Dr. Richard Battistoni, the program's director, said its purpose is to teach students that community service is not simply altruism, but a part of democracy.
"We have to be honest," he said. "A lot of the students have the spirit of community service instilled in them when they sign up. The payoff, we hope, is that students learn as well as help."
Community service, Dr. Barber said, is straightforward. "The problem has been that for the past 20 or so years, we've had a government telling students to do for themselves."
 
They Keep Serving
 Graduates of the program have usually continued some type of community-service involvement, Dr. Battistoni said.
The program is voluntary for most students, although Rutgers honors students are required to take one of the dozen or so courses that include a community-service component. The courses, taught at the Camden, New Brunswick and Newark campuses, include "The Civic Community, H.I.V. and Public Policy," "Urban Literacy Practicum" and "Citizenship, Democracy and the Role of Performing Artists."
Stacey Bader, a 21-year-old senior in the program who has been volunteering in various campus projects since she was a freshman, said she is noticing more and more students are also volunteering.
"We pretty much feel that you just can't keep taking from society," said Ms. Bader, a political science and history major now working in an elementary-school after-school program. "I really feel that students are starting to realize that in order to solve the economic problems, you really have to have social responsibility."
"That's why the President's coming is such an exciting thing," she added. "Just the entire initiation of this idea reminds me of F.D.R."
While saying he was excited by President Clinton's commitment, Dr. Barber expressed some concern that the President's plan would attract students motivated only by getting their tuition paid.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Off in Disrupted Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Bond prices were mostly lower in light trading yesterday after an explosion and fire beneath the World Trade Center curtailed activity at many New York brokerage firms and distracted traders.
The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond was down 35/16 point, while its yield rose to 6.90 percent. 
 On Thursday, the bond's yield closed at 6.88 percent. Bond prices and yields move in opposite directions.
"The big story is the fire," Gib Clark, chief trader at Daiwa Securities Inc., said at midafternoon. "I don't think anybody's paying any attention to the market."
 
Operations Curtailed
 Trading continued but was extremely quiet after the midday fire forced several major firms in the trade center's twin towers -- Salomon Brothers, Dean Witter and Cantor Fitzgerald -- to shut or sharply curtail operations.
The quieter day followed a hectic week that saw a 2 9/32 -point price gain Monday and Tuesday in the 30-year bond and sent the bond's yield to an all-time low of 6.82 percent. Analysts said trading was slow yesterday even before the explosion.
"The market was out of gas," said John Slosberg, senior fixed-income analyst at the Technical Data Global Markets Group in Boston. "It was a tough week; people got battered and bruised."
Mr. Slosberg attributed yesterday's moderate gains in short- and medium-term maturities to positioning ahead of the weekend and some profit taking.
Gary Schlossberg, senior economist at Wells Fargo & Company in San Francisco, said the market shrugged off an upward revision of Government figures for fourth-quarter economic growth.
Signs of a buoyant economy tend to depress bond prices because faster growth is usually associated with higher inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-income investments.
 
Data Set Next Week
 Next week, the release of a number of important economic indicators, including February unemployment and factory orders, could bring renewed volatility to the market, traders said.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, short-term maturities advanced between 3/32 point and 3/16 point, while intermediate maturities gained 3/16 point to 5/16 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all Treasury issues outstanding with maturities of a year or longer, rose 1.12, to 1,294.93.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills were unchanged at 2.99 percent with the discount at 2.94 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 3.13 percent as the discount rose one basis point, to 3.05 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 3.28 percent as the discount fell two basis points, to 3.17 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was 3 1/4 percent, up from 3 1/8 percent late Thursday.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Firmer as Group of 7 Gathers for London Talks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar firmed against most major currencies yesterday, especially the yen, as traders tried to anticipate the outcome of this weekend's Group of Seven ministers meeting.
Gold prices eased. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery closed at $329.00 an ounce, off $1.60. A late bid at the Republic National Bank in New York quoted it at $328.10 an ounce, off $1.40. 
 The weekend meeting in London of the Group of Seven -- the cabinet finance members from the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy -- was the focus of attention for many market participants.
Earl Johnson, a vice president at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, said he did not expect the meeting to produce agreement on the yen's value. The yen, which has rallied recently, slipped against the dollar as a result, he said.
 
Dollar Up in Tokyo
 In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 117.85 yen, up 0.32 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London it rose to 118.05 yen. At closing in New York, the dollar closed at 118.25 yen, up from 117.475 late Thursday.
Traders said expectations were high that Germany's Bundesbank would have to cut interest rates, perhaps next week, after a wage settlement with German workers and renewed pressures in the European Exchange Rate Mechanism on the French franc.
In Europe, the dollar closed at 1.6422 German marks, up from 1.6345 late Thursday. In New York, it closed at 1.6455 marks, up from 1.6350 marks late Thursday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.4230, from $1.4297 late Thursday, while in New York, sterling's closing quote was $1.4240, less expensive than $1.4315 late Thursday.

HEADLINE: One Man's Arrival in Town Exposes a Racial Fault Line

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VIDOR, Tex., Feb. 23

 BODY:
As he dropped off a box full of his belongings at 530 National Drive here a few days ago, John DecQuir Sr. told one of his future neighbors, who looked on curiously: "I don't understand why this is such a big deal. I'm just renting an apartment."
But his move into the federally financed housing project in Vidor has become a very big deal in this small city in the piney woods of East Texas, one that has forced the police to set up a 24-hour-a-day patrol outside his home. Mr. DecQuir, local officials say, is the first black adult to live in Vidor since the 1920's. 
 The 58-year-old Mr. DecQuir (pronounced DEK-weer) is a one-man pilot program in a sweeping order last fall by a Federal judge to desegregate 170 housing projects, some all white and some all black, in 36 counties across east Texas. The order was unusual in its breadth, but in all-white Vidor, where a Ku Klux Klan branch once operated a book and supply store on Main Street, the order is all the more unusual for what it has produced: a black man willing to move in.
Although 1,300 blacks are on the waiting list for public housing in a three-county area here, and 45,000 blacks live in the nearby city of Beaumont, Mr. DecQuir was the only one who volunteered to come to Vidor.
 
Sharp Dividing Line
 The desegregation order has led to Klan rallies in Vidor, and the rallies in turn have prompted an anti-Klan vigil by several Vidor churches. More broadly, in a town of 10,800 people where some celebrate and others bemoan its past image as a Klan stronghold, Mr. DecQuir's move has revealed a stark fault line between whites who have rushed to welcome him and those who have warned him to stay away.
The divide was evident today even in the immediate vicinity of his apartment, one of the 74 vinyl-and-brick units set in a swampy pine grove on the south side of town.
Roxcie Setzer, a member of the women's guild at Central Baptist Church, drove up and wedged a note in the door, inviting Mr. DecQuir to a soup-and-sandwich meal at the church and concluding, "Jesus loves you and we love you, too!"
One new neighbor, Joyce Dennis, said she was eager to have Mr. DecQuir over for coffee. "This is the 1990's," she said. "It's time for Vidor to get the past behind and get on with it."
 
Hostility Easy to Find
 But it was just as easy to find people who were adamantly opposed to having Mr. DecQuir live anywhere near them and who wanted nothing to do with him. Among them was Marie Johnson, an unemployed waitress, 46, whose home is across a grassy courtyard from Mr. DecQuir's. "He best not come over here to meet me or he's liable to meet a baseball bat," she said.
Her 27-year-old daughter, Joyce, who was asked what she would do if Mr. DecQuir simply came over to borrow an egg, shook her head. "No, no, no," she said, dismissing the thought with a racial epithet. "I might be holding an egg right there in my hand but I'd sure say, sorry, I've got no eggs."
While plenty of people in Vidor readily allow that they do not like black people, period, others argue that they have nothing personal against Mr. DecQuir, a former concrete finisher who now lives on a disability check he receives because of a diabetic condition. It's just that they fear what will happen next, they say.
"Long as he doesn't bother me I'm not going to bother him," said a 68-year-old woman who gave only her first name, Frances. She watched from her kitchen window the other day as Mr. DecQuir unloaded his pickup truck.
 
Fear of Young Blacks
 "It's not really him I'm worried about," she said. "I'm worried about the younger blacks. They're the rough ones. We've already got some rough white ones living in here, and if blacks come in, there's no telling what will happen."
The gray-haired Mr. DecQuir has gone to great lengths to play down his arrival. "They say that faith can move mountains," he said during a break from his unpacking. "This ain't nothing but a molehill."
Nevertheless, almost everything about the desegregation of the Vidor housing project seems mired in controversy, beginning with Mr. DecQuir himself. For one thing, many of his new neighbors say they are angry that he has a criminal record. He was imprisoned for five months last year for violating a parole agreement stemming from a 1989 conviction for assaulting his estranged wife.
Vidor's Mayor, Ruth Woods, who has argued strenuously in favor of peaceful integration of the Vidor complex, complained to officials of the Department of Housing and Urban Development that Vidor had been put in a precarious position because many people in the complex were seizing on the record as a pretext for kicking him out, even though several white people living there also have criminal records.
The executive director of the Orange County Housing Authority, Richard Stanfield, said Federal law prohibited his agency from using a criminal record to bar a qualified applicant like Mr. DecQuir from public housing.
Vidor, on Interstate 10 a few miles west of the Louisiana border, was founded by the father of the movie director King Vidor. Its economy is largely dependent on jobs from the much bigger refinery towns Port Arthur and Beaumont. But until the early 1970's it was known for being something else: a hotbed of Klan activity.
At least six competing branches of the Klan had bases here, including one that set up its headquarters and store on Main Street. A hand-lettered sign stood untouched near the entrance to the town for several years in the 1960's: "Nigger, Don't Let the Sun Set on You in Vidor."
While there are still Klan sympathizers here, the official Klan apparatus has drifted away, people here say. The city canceled a 1982 Christmas parade after an outside Klan group said it would enter a float. But now Mr. DecQuir's move has brought back the specter of Klan rallies, even as most of the participants came from out of town.
For instance, the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, based in Waco, rallied in Vidor on Feb. 20, protesting the integration of the housing project as well as a recent subpoena served by the Texas Department of Human Rights that sought the Klan group's membership records.
The desegregation order affecting Vidor's and dozens of other projects was handed down in September by Judge William Wayne Justice of Federal District Court in a case that began 12 years before. Although it does not mandate that every all-white or all-black project bring in residents of a different color, the order requires that open applications are encouraged.
And in some cases, specific apartments are to be reserved for people of specific races. This is the case in Vidor, where 8 of the project's 74 units are being kept vacant, ready for black tenants, though there is a long list of whites who want to move in.
Mr. Stanfield, the county housing director, sent questionnaires to 1,300 black people in the area who are waiting for public housing, informing them about the opening in Vidor, where the rents are based on income and range from $26 a month to $250.
But only four people have so far expressed interest, he said. One dropped out after finding housing elsewhere, and two others, both single mothers, are hesitating. Mr. Stanfield, who helped Mr. DecQuir move a couch and a television set into the apartment last week, is hoping that Mr. DecQuir's presence will encourage other blacks to join him.
Mr. Stanfield is predicting a smooth transition, though there are plans to keep the 24-hour police detail for at least a month. The $8,182-a-week overtime is being paid by the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
Mrs. Dennis and her husband, Ross, the former president of the tenants' council, say they have told Mr. DecQuir that he is welcome to visit them anytime. They think that once people get to know their new neighbor, things are likely to be just fine.
"I told him, the coffee pot's always boiling," Mr. Dennis said.
But others in the project, including those who say they bear the new tenant no ill will, say they do not think desegregation in Vidor will work. "The whole thing is a sad joke," said Philip Freeman, 28, who gave his occupation as "housewife" as he watched after his two young sons. "Someone's going to get hurt. Probably not today, probably not this month as long as the police are around. But after it calms down, somebody's going to get hurt."
And some say they are unsure how it will all turn out. "I don't know," said Paula Strong, a 37-year-old mother of three. "I haven't met the guy."
