HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Mexico City

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN; TIM GOLDEN is the Mexico City correspondent for The Times.

 BODY:
For decades now, Mexico City has been afflicted by unsubtle, centrifugal forces: Traffic and noxious smog, noise and sundry chaos forced people from its center. One ventured downtown because one had to, went the thinking of those citizens who didn't, and one did so at the risk of nausea, neurosis or worse.
Beneath the brownish haze of pollution, however, Mexicans have begun to rediscover the center of a city that has an extraordinary history. Young artists and bohemians have moved into some of the decrepit colonial buildings, and a few wealthier residents have taken to restoring others. Politicians and power-bureaucrats have made the center's old restaurants fashionable again, and its museums and theaters are busier and busier. 
 Like the city's broader transition from an industrial economy to one focused more on services, the changes at its heart are incipient. The streets are still clogged like bad arteries, and even though the authorities take pollution problems seriously, their only hope is to reduce the rate at which they grow worse. More and more chilangos, as its residents are called, seem willing to suspend their despair.
At the end of the winter, when the nights begin to warm and the worst of the smog to lift, they even celebrate. Momentarily, the sea of street vendors and Volkswagens seems to part and a 100-block landscape of Baroque churches, 16th-, 17th- and 18th-century administrative buildings and elegant old homes comes into relief.
 
What to Do
 Beginning March 10, the 17-day Festival del Centro Historico will lead visitors into some of the finest colonial homes, churches and buildings that Spanish conquerors built over the former Aztec capital of Tenochtitlan. Art exhibits and long, thematic meals will be offered during the day, with lectures and concerts at night.
A sampling: Choral groups and the Mexican Brass Ensemble will open the Festival with a program of religious hymns in the vast Metropolitan Cathedral on the central square, or Zocalo. Writings by Sor Juana Ines de la Cruz, a 17th-century Mexican nun whose iconoclastic poems and letters jolted the Catholic hierarchy, will be read in the cloister where she lived on 47 Calle St. Jeronimo, March 13 at 5 P.M.
Festival information is available at 376 Paseo de la Reforma, Room 202; telephone 207-2654 or 325-9000. Many of the events are free.
Although the authorities have yet to fix dates, they are expected to extend the successful run of the monumental exhibit "Mexico: Splendors of 30 Centuries" at least several weeks into March. The show, which opened at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and ranges from the pre-Columbian to Frida Kahlo, is at the Colegio de San Ildefonso, a 16th-century Jesuit seminary that became the National Preparatory School. It shares space with murals by Jose Clemente Orozco, Diego Rivera and other 1920's Mexican painters. The exhibit will be shown Tuesday through Sunday, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Wednesdays from 11 A.M. to 9 P.M. Tickets cost $3.30 (figured at the rate of about 3 pesos to $1).
During Easter week, residents of the Iztapalapa municipality, seven miles southeast of the city center, re-enact biblical scenes leading to the crucifixion of Christ. On April 9, Good Friday, thousands of residents will march to the top of the Cerro de la Estrella, led by a man carrying a wooden cross.
 
What to sSee
 After being closed for renovations for nearly two years, the Frida Kahlo Museum is scheduled to reopen in April. Ms. Kahlo was born and lived most of her life in the Spanish-style house, which contains a sampling of her work and sketches. The museum, at 247 Calle Londres in Coyoacan, will be open from 10 P.M through 6 P.M., Tuesday through Sunday. Admission will cost $3.
Nearby, the monument devoted to Frida's husband, the Diego Rivera Studio Museum, at Altavista and Diego Rivera streets in San Angel, focuses on the artist's life. It is open Tuesday to Sunday, from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission is $2.30.
To see some of Rivera's most famous murals, one need only go to the National Palace, where his rendering of Mexican history covers some of the walls. The building is open daily from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is free.
Nearby, is the Templo Mayor, an Aztec temple that city workers found while digging ditches for electrical cables in 1978. An adjacent museum filled with Aztec artifacts traces the history of the site. Open Tuesday to Sunday, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.
The Alameda, filled with trees, is the city center's other grand plaza. At its eastern corner sits the white marble Palacio de Bellas Artes, completed in 1934. The lobby contains works by Rivera, Siqueiros, Orozco and Rufino Tamayo. Open Tuesday to Sunday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission is free.
Just down the Paseo de la Reforma, Chapultepec Park, 550 acres of park and woodlands, is home to some of the city's best museums. The National Museum of Anthropology, with its overwhelming collection of pre-Hispanic artifacts, is open Tuesday to Saturday, 9 A.M. to 7 P.M.; Sunday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission is $4.25. A few blocks away, the Rufino Tamayo Museum, displays the artist's personal collection Tuesday to Sunday, 10 A.M. to 5:45 P.M. Admission is $3.25; free on Sundays.
 
Where to sStay
The Galeria Plaza, 195 Hamburgo, (800) 228-3000, fax 207-5867, in the Zona Rosa, is run by the Westin Chain, which also operates the luxurious Camino Real. The Galeria is smaller and more modest, but with a similar quality of service. Double rooms cost $146 on weekdays; $130 on weekends.
Budget: The 150-room Maria Cristina, 31 Calle Rio Lerma, 566-9688, fax 566-9194, has long been a favorite of budget travelers. It has a pleasant outdoor garden and a courtyard. Double rooms are $55.
Near the Zocalo is the Hotel Capitol, 12 Uruguay, 518-1750, fax 521-1149 whose 75 rooms, all with private baths, surround an atrium. Double rooms with one bed cost $32.70.
Luxury: With its yellow-and-pink walls, the Camino Real, 700 Avenida Mariano Escobedo, (800) 228-3000, fax 250-6897 is the only luxury hotel in the city that has the feel of a place removed from the hubbub. Low and sprawling, it has three swimming pools, a Tamayo mural in the lobby and some of Mexico's finest French food at Fouquet's, a branch of the Paris restaurant. It is within walking distance of Chapultepec Park. Double rooms are $195; $110 on weekends.
Closer to the center, the towering Maria Isabel Sheraton, 325 Paseo de la Reforma, (800) 325-3535, fax 207-6370, overlooks the gilded Angel of Independence monument. Double rooms are $235 on weekdays, $108 on weekends.
 
Where to Eat
 While the quality of Mexico City's restaurants has improved in recent years, "international" fare casts a wide influence even in some of the most traditional Mexican restaurants.
At the edge of the Alameda, at 85 Avenida de Hidalgo, the Best Western Hotel de Cortes, 518-2182, occupies a building that lodged Mexico's 16th-century Augustinian friars. The restaurant serves unremarkable Mexican food on a quite remarkable stone patio. A breakfast of pancakes or enchiladas de mole costs about $15 for two, a lunch or dinner, which might include white fish with almonds or Caesar salad costs about $30 for two.
After closing for two years, Prendes, at 10 Avenida 16 de Septiembre, 512-7517, reopened in 1989 and has regained its reputation as a downtown haunt of the powerful and the political. The menu is very Mexican, if not the sort of Mexican that tourists might think of: oysters, ceviche, cream-of-corn-and-black-corn-fungus soup. But one comes for the ambiance as much as the food: the black-lacquered chairs, the murals of former patrons like Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo. Lunch, the only meal served, costs about $75 for two with wine.
More imaginative Mexican cuisine can be found at Los Irabien, at 45 Avenida de la Paz, 660-0876, in San Angel. The menu includes such "nueva cocina" inventions as stuffed cactus leaves and huitlacoche (corn fungus) crepes. Dinner for two with wine costs about $85.
The Bar La Opera, at 10 Cinco de Mayo, 512-8959, two blocks from Bellas Artes, is another old favorite. The prominent hole on the ceiling was supposedly left by one of the revolutionary Pancho Villa's bullets. As usual, the atmosphere outdoes the food, but the cabrito, or barbequed goat and the roast pig have their fans. Dinner for two costs $60 with wine.
The Restaurante Vasco, 6 Madero, 512-0613, one block from the Bellas Artes palace, is open for lunch only. Its comidas corridas, or prix fixe menus, feature hearty Spanish dishes like fabada asturiana, a bean-potato-and-sausage stew, and cost about $9.
Most restaurants are open for lunch from 1 P.M. until about 5 P.M. Dinner is generally served from about 7 P.M. to 11 P.M.
 
Where to sShop
 The most popular shopping area for tourists is the Zona Rosa, a grid of streets and pedestrian malls filled with restaurants, galleries and boutiques. Many leading silversmiths from Taxco have branches there, including Tane, 70 Calle Amberes, where a pair of earrings costs $100 or more.
The Polanco area, north of Chapultepec Park, has recently sprouted hundreds of shops and restaurants. Talavera de Puebla Uriarte, 95 Emilio Castelar, sells finely painted ceramics, costing about $60 for a large serving dish and $300 for a vase.
The largest selection of traditional handicrafts are found in the half-dozen downtown artisan markets where bargaining is expected. The Ciudadela Handicraft Market, on Calle Balderas between Ayuntamiento and Donde, houses hundreds of glassed-in craft shops. Most are open daily from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. While the market has its share of marble chess sets and Aztec calenders, it also has high-quality weavings and jewelry.
The Mexican Government runs its own traditional art shops, called Fonart stores, that sell jewelry, pottery, furniture and clothing. Silver rings cost about $15. Smaller Indian tapestries cost about $90, larger ones $160. The best-stocked Fonart store is at 691 Patriotismo.
Most shops are open between 10 A.M. and 6 P.M., although some, particularly in the Zona Rosa, stay open later. Many close at lunchtime.

HEADLINE: Have Suburban Prices Hit the Bottom?

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
THE market for one-family homes in the suburban New York metropolitan region, much of which has been in decline for the last five years, appears to have bottomed out in most areas, and, in some places, such as Northern New Jersey, a modest recovery seems to be under way.
Real estate brokers attribute the trend to low mortgage interest rates, realistic prices set by sellers, the dearth of new construction and a small surge of first-time buyers who were priced out of the market in the mid-80's and frightened out in the late 80's and early 90's. 
 They caution, though, that because of the suburban region's continued economic weakness and changing demographics, home sale prices are expected to increase at a far slower pace than the double-digit gains achieved by many homeowners in the Northeast in the early and mid-80's.
Moreover, in some places, such as Connecticut, which has been unusually hard-hit by job losses, sale prices might remain depressed, or the increases will not surpass the annual rate of inflation, giving pause, perhaps, to some potential buyers about the investment value of residential real estate.
"Prices will be flat this year, the same as last," said Peter Helie, president of William Pitt Realty in Stamford, Conn.
Typical of the new buyers are Steven and Jeanie Schatzberg, who rent a one-bedroom co-op on the Upper East Side of Manhattan but need more space for the children they plan to have and the step-children who visit on weekends, holidays and for the summer. The stepchildren currently sleep on a pull-out sofa in the living room. "We're ready to get back to the suburbs," said Mr. Schatzberg, who is 44 years old and a retail consultant.
The Schatzbergs -- she is 35 and a merchandiser for a womens' ready-to-wear company -- recently bought a four-bedroom Colonial-style home in Stamford with a pool for $435,000, a price that they negotiated down from $479,000.
"That's what I offered, and that's what he took," Mr. Schatzberg said.
TRACKING the trends of the region's real estate market can be difficult, as disparities often develop not only between micromarkets, but in analysts' assessments and brokers' sales figures.
These deviations often result from differing survey samples or methodologies as well as from efforts to paint the best possible statistical picture to help increase business.
Looking at the 1992 sales price and volume data collected from several boards of realtors, it appears that the degree of recovery in the New York area thus far has varied depending on location and the type of housing. The market, for example, seems to be improving most for one-family homes in New Jersey and on Staten Island, and least for homes on Long Island and for condominiums in Connecticut.
Reflecting both more realistic pricing and what brokers believe is a large number of first-time buyers entering the market, the average home sale price in the tri-state region fell 0.5 percent, to $172.6 in 1992 from $173.5 a year earlier. In contrast, the average sale price in the nation last year rose 3.2 percent, to $103,600 from $100,300 a year earlier.
In New Jersey, in Bergen and Passaic counties, the average sale price of a one-family home rose 0.25 percent, to $187,600 from $187,100. In Monmouth and Ocean counties, the figure rose 3.5 percent, to $139,200 from $134,400, and in Hunterdon, Middlesex and Somerset counties the figure rose 6.6 percent, to $168,900 from $158,400.
In Newark, the average sale price of a home also rose -- by 3.1 percent, to $184,400 from $178,800
"WE knew the recovery was coming we just didn't know when," said Bill Higgins, the owner of Higgins Real Estate in Hillside, N.J. "We're seeing a lot of first-time buyers and our trade-up market is starting to shake loose."
In New York, in the boroughs of Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens, the average sale price fell 4.2 percent, to $220,800 from $230,700. On Staten Island, the price rose 0.3 percent, to $164,800 from $164,300.
Elsewhere in the state, home sale prices fell 0.4 percent, to $158,600 from $159,200, on Long Island. In Westchester County, the figures dropped 0.3 percent, to $265,000 from $265,700, for houses and 6.1 percent, to $153,000 from $163,000, for condominiums. In Rockland County, prices declined 0.2, percent to $192,800 from $193,100.
Even in the areas where the market declined in 1992, a slowly shrinking number of homes for sale may soon start to push prices back up. Many brokers have also reported the strongest surge of activity during January and February of this year, months for which data are not yet available.
"Though it's not running away, the market is stronger than it appears to have been for a long, long time, and more steady," said Alan Yassky, former regional vice president of the National Association of Realtors and the president of Rockland Realty-Better Homes and Gardens in Spring Valley, N.Y. "Prices are slightly rising, if anything, and the number of buyers available certainly has increased considerably from last year."
"We always thought the problem with the real estate market was a lack of confidence, and it would appear that people are more confident that we are out of recession," he added. "There is also no question that the low interest rates and the aggressive marketing of mortgages by many banks have been helpful."
In Connecticut, average home sale prices for 1992 in Stamford declined 1.5 percent, to $330,000 from $335,000, in 1991. For condominiums, the figure fell 11.8 percent, to $127,000 from $143,000. Elsewhere in the state, the prices fell 4.8 percent in New Haven, to $145,800 from $153,200, and in Hartford by 4.7 percent, to $141,100 from $148,200.
As steep as those numbers are, they are a fraction of the decline recorded in those cities over the last few years. In Stamford, the 1992 average price for a one-family house is 22.7 percent less than the average for 1989, $427,000. For condominiums, last year's figure is 29.4 percent less than the figure five years earlier, $180,000.
CHARLES M. STARO, president of the New York Association of Realtors, speculated that the decline in sale prices might also be a signal that there was an increase in first-time home buyers.
"The first-time buyer purchases a house about $15,000 below the average," he said. "This means that while the average cost declined, it did so because the purchase of smaller, less expensive homes dominated the market."
The statistics on home sales may sound bleak for much of the region, New Jersey notwithstanding. More promising was the volume of activity.
In New York, there were 6.1 percent more sales last year than in 1991. In Connecticut, the figure rose by 5.8 percent. In New Jersey the increase was 10.6 percent -- the highest level since 1988 and higher than the national increase of 8.5 percent.
"Household balance sheets and incomes are returning to satisfactory conditions, and most New Jerseyans are feeling more comfortable participating again in the marketplace," said Gene Azzalina, the president of the New Jersey Association of Realtors.
Brokers have also reported the strongest surge of activity during the fourth quarter of last year and the first six weeks of 1993. In New York, for example, resales of one-family homes were 18.4 percent higher in December of 1992 than in the previous December.
"The state has been experiencing increases in sales for the past couple of months," Mr. Staro said. "The over-18-percent increase in December is more than encouraging -- it's phenomenal."
The December increase was preceded by increases of 3.6 percent in October and 2.4 percent in November.
"A boost in consumer confidence and lower interest rates brought buyers out en masse the last quarter," Mr. Staro said.
Some brokers also believe that sales prices are already rising in early 1993.
Lonnie Shapiro, a broker with William Pitt Real Estate in Ridgefield, Conn., recently acted as the agent for a deal involving a five-bedroom, 3,300-square-foot colonial on two acres for which the original buyer paid $365,000 in August of 1987, the peak of the market.
Ms. Shapiro said she had placed the home on the market in February 1992 for $365,000, then dropping the asking price to $345,000, to $339,000, to $329,000 and, finally, to $319,000. The house ultimately sold last December for $307,000.
The seller, however, should have waited a few more weeks, Ms. Shapiro said. She noted that in that mid-level price range there was a growing shortage of available houses. She said that most of the new construction in the area was for homes that started at $500,000.
"He could get $330,000 for it now, easily," she said.
The buyers of the home, Laura and Thomas Freed, hope Ms. Shapiro's assessment is accurate. The couple -- he is a 29-year-old lawyer, she is a 26-year-old accountant -- had been living in a condominium that they hadbought in Norwalk, Conn., for $210,000 in 1988, a high price at the height of the market.
With the condominium now worth no more than $170,000 and probably less, the Freeds decided to rent it out and buy the home in Ridgefield, a fast-growing town north of Wilton, Westport and Stamford that has become a haven for home-buyers seeking moderately priced homes in expensive Fairfield County.
"We've heard that the market is starting to pick up around here," Mrs. Freed said. "We'd like to think we finally made a good real estate investment."

LENGTH: 1301 words

HEADLINE: State's Case Links Poverty to Students' Performance

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON

 BODY:
THE Sheff v. O'Neill desegregation trial is nearly over, and soon a single Superior Court judge, Harry Hammer, will take on the task of sorting out Connecticut's responsibility for how poorly children do in the public schools of Hartford.
In its defense this month, the state argued that the last-place ranking of Hartford students on mastery tests for reading, writing and mathematics did not mean that they had inferior schools, or that they were denied the equal educational opportunity guaranteed by Connecticut's Constitution. 
 Rather, expert witnesses said, their performance reflects the fact that, as a group, the 25,700 children in Hartford's schools, 90 percent of whom are black or Hispanic, are the poorest in Connecticut. And the powerful ways in which poverty works upon families and children make the poor the least likely to do well in any school.
"We can pretty much explain the difference between Hartford and the suburbs in terms of a couple of factors of socioeconomic status," said Prof. David Armor of George Mason University, the state's final witness, who has taken part in a dozen desegregation cases across the country.
 
Statistics Tell the Story
 Mastery test scores in Hartford and its suburbs, he said, can be predicted almost entirely by looking at the income, college education and number of single parents in each community.
The average income in Hartford is about half that in its suburbs, he said, and the proportion of its residents with college degrees is less than half of that in the suburbs. But the proportion of city families headed by single parents is nearly five times that in surrounding towns.
"My evidence does not show that Hartford is doing an inadequate or poor job," Professor Armor said. "Given these quite different students, Hartford is doing quite a good job."
Professor Armor's testimony was the final caution flag the state raised for Judge Hammer before he begins considering a case in which the plaintiffs are seeking a desegregation order covering Hartford and 21 surrounding towns -- 95,000 public-school children in all.
If poverty is the overriding issue, Professor Armor and other witnesses for the state said, a court-ordered desegregation plan would miss the point. Desegregation, they said, does little to improve the academic performance of children who may be black or Hispanic, but most of all are poor.
Meanwhile, they testified, such a plan would be expensive and difficult to carry out, and would risk the flight of large numbers of whites.
In a survey of the Hartford area conducted for the state, 51 percent of the whites questioned said they would move or resort to private schools if their children were assigned to a new school under a desegregation plan (compared with 45 percent of the Hispanic people questioned and 23 percent of the blacks).
Integration has its value, the witnesses testified, but it should be viewed as a goal in itself, not as a way to improve schools. "If you believe in integration, you believe in it because it's something you want," said Prof. Christine Rossell of Harvard University.
For an integration plan to succeed, Professor Rossell said, it should be voluntary, and it must provide incentives for people to participate. Connecticut, she said, is already a national leader in promoting voluntary measures through programs like Project Concern and its support for interdistrict magnet schools.
"It's doing what I would recommend, 'slow and steady wins the race,' " she said. "Make sure your population wants integration."
One reason this lawsuit was filed, however, is that the racial segregation and poverty in Hartford's schools have steadily increased while the state has studied and worried over the problem since the 1960's.
So it was little relief to Elizabeth Sheff, the mother of 13-year-old Milo Sheff, the lead plaintiff, to hear Professor Rossell say that the gap in academic achievement between whites and blacks was narrowing as blacks' economic status improved, and that the gap might well be gone 30 years from now.
"That's not even my grandchildren," Ms. Sheff said.
 
Aid Distribution Defended
 The state, in its defense, also presented witnesses who testified that Hartford's schools received far more state aid than suburban ones, precisely to help it overcome the effects of poverty on its students.
In the 1990-91 school year, for example, 56.9 percent of Hartford's $210.6 million school budget -- $119.8 million -- came from the state. But state aid made up only 13.1 percent, or $8.2 million, of West Hartford's $62.6 million school budget.
Other witnesses testified that conditions in Hartford's schools were not nearly so bleak as teachers and principals testified for the plaintiffs. Nevertheless, many classes lack books and supplies, and some schools are so overcrowded that half of the pupils are housed in portable classrooms.
In the end, however, testimony returned to just who the children in those classrooms were. Aside from being racially segregated, most come from families where there is only one parent; half come from families on welfare; half come from homes where English is not spoken.
They do not arrive in kindergarten as 5-year-olds with the kinds of experiences that traditional schools expect children of that age to have, and they do not go home to families that can support their education in ways that middle-class families take for granted.
But they do go to school, and if the state's experts testified that schools could not solve all of society's problems, they also acknowledged that they were already dealing with them, starting with the breakfast that Hartford elementary schools serve to nearly every child every morning.
"As many of the teachers and administrators have said, if the school system doesn't deal with it, then who will?" said John Brittain, one of the lawyers for the Sheff plaintiffs. "The school system is often the best institution that these children have to support their life, as well as their future."
"The teachers say you have to deal with it," he continued, "because the child is right there in the classroom."
 
The Governor's Proposal
 The state's defense in general supported Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s legislative proposal for achieving greater racial balance between Connecticut's cities and towns, by arguing that integration should be undertaken carefully and voluntarily while the root issue of poverty is addressed outside the schools.
The plaintiffs have not proposed a specific desegregation plan, in large part because they are seeking a court order that would instruct the Hartford region to come up with its own plan to integrate city schools with suburban ones.
Much of their testimony amounted to a desegregation seminar for Judge Hammer, reviewing the kinds of measures that have been adopted elsewhere, both mandatory and voluntary, as well as educational programs that could be used to improve city schools themselves.
The ultimate goal of the suit, after all, is to provide Hartford children an equal educational opportunity, and a desegregation plan is one part of the solution that the plaintiffs are proposing. They also want to improve the quality of Hartford's schools and provide them more resources.
If nothing more, Mr. Brittain said, "we've certainly heightened the public consciousness of the racial and educational disparities in this state, and we've been a part of several other steps, including the Governor most significantly, that have provoked discussion in Connecticut about educational remedies.
"We think we have presented to this court, and more directly to the state, not only the range of desegregation remedies, but also the possibility of some desegregation remedies, regardless of how the court suit is decided."
